First find the total number of outcomes: 6 outcomes
Then find the number of ways to roll a number greater than 3: 6 outcomes - 3 outcomes = <<6-3=3>>3 outcomes
Then find the probability of rolling a number greater than 3: 3 outcomes / 6 outcomes = 1/2 = 50%
Then find the number of ways to roll two even numbers in a row: 3 outcomes * 3 outcomes = <<3*3=9>>9 outcomes
Then find the probability of rolling two even numbers in a row: 9 outcomes / 6 outcomes = 3/2 = 1.5 = 150%
Then subtract the probability of rolling two even numbers in a row from the probability of rolling a number greater than 3 to find the difference: 50% - 150% = -100%
Finally, multiply the difference by -1 to express it as a percentage: -100% * -1 = 100%

HIV Nondiscrimination in Travel and Immigration Act of 2007 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to remove HIV from the list of communicable diseases of public health significance that would exclude noncitizens from entering the United States.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to convene a panel of public health experts to review all policies regarding HIV as a communicable disease of public health significance under such Act.

Amends the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 to define "family office" as a company that: (1) has no clients other than family clients, (2) is owned, controlled, or operated primarily for the benefit of family clients, and (3) does not hold itself out to the public as an investment adviser.

Medicare Drug Savings Through Choice Act of 2007 - Amends part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, for each year beginning with 2008, to offer a Medicare operated prescription drug plan with a service area that consists of the entire United States. Defines "Medicare operated prescription drug plan" as a prescription drug plan that offers qualified prescription drug coverage and access to the prices negotiated under this Act.

Directs the Secretary to negotiate with pharmaceutical manufacturers with respect to the purchase price of covered part D drugs and to encourage the use of more affordable therapeutic equivalents to the extent such practices do not override medical necessity as determined by the prescribing physician.

Requires the Secretary to implement strategies similar to those used by the Department of Veterans Affairs or other federal purchasers of prescription drugs, and other strategies, to reduce the purchase cost of covered part D drugs.

Requires any savings to the Medicare operated prescription drug plan resulting from actions taken under this Act to be used by the plan to extend coverage under the plan to individuals who have reached the initial coverage limit applicable under the plan but who have not reached the annual out-of-pocket threshold.

Requires the monthly beneficiary premium for qualified prescription drug coverage and access to negotiated prices to be uniform nationally.

Allows a part D eligible individual to enroll in the Medicare operated prescription drug plan at any time.

Helping College Students Cross the Finish Line Act - Amends title IV (Student Assistance) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs) to establish programs of financial assistance for undergraduate and vocational students who are academically able to complete their degree or certificate program within an academic year, in good academic standing, have an outstanding tuition payment due, and are unable to fully pay the amount due. Requires each IHE receiving a grant to provide information to each student receiving an award on financial assistance available from any source other than this Act. Directs the Secretary to create, and requires each student receiving an award to complete, an online survey concerning financial literacy.

Housing Authority Funding Fairness Act of 2007 - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to authorize appropriations for FY2008-FY2012 for tenant-based rental assistance under the housing choice voucher program.

Requires the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to provide renewal funding for each public housing agency based on leasing and costs from the prior year, as adjusted by an annual adjustment factor. Requires such funding to be provided: (1) by making any adjustments necessary to provide for the first-time renewal of vouchers; and (2) by making other appropriate adjustments.

Requires each public housing agency participating in the moving to work demonstration or in the Moving to Work program to be funded pursuant to its agreement under such program and subject to any pro rata adjustment made.

Directs the Secretary to recapture, from amounts provided under the annual contributions contract for a public housing agency for a calendar year, all amounts allocated that are unused by the agency at the end of each calendar year.

Directs the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to commence actions to improve TSA's process for vetting individuals with access to secure areas of vessels and maritime facilities. Requires such actions to include: (1) conducting a comprehensive risk analysis of security threat assessment procedures; (2) implementing additional internal controls and best practices identified in such analysis; (3) improving fraud detection techniques; (4) updating guidance provided to Trusted Agents regarding the vetting process and related regulations; (5) finalizing a manual for Trusted Agents and adjudicators on the vetting process; and (6) establishing quality controls to ensure consistent procedures to review adjudication decisions and terrorism vetting decisions.

Requires the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to submit a report to Congress that evaluates the implementation of such actions.

Directs the Secretary of DHS to commission an assessment of the effectiveness of the transportation security card program at enhancing security and reducing security risks for facilities and vessels regulated under federal shipping law. Requires the assessment to be conducted by a research organization with significant experience in port or maritime security.

Requires the Secretary, if the assessment identifies a deficiency in the effectiveness of the program, to submit a corrective action plan to specified congressional committees that responds to the assessment findings and includes an implementation plan with benchmarks.

Southern Prairie Potholes National Wildlife Refuge Act This bill directs the Department of the Interior to establish the Southern Prairie Potholes National Wildlife Refuge in Iowa. The refuge shall be administered in accordance with the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966.

National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force Act of 2012 - Establishes the National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force to serve as an independent source of advice, research, and policy recommendations to: (1) the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA); (2) the Assistant Administrator of the Office of Women's Business Ownership of the SBA; (3) Congress; (4) the President; and (5) other federal departments and agencies.

Requires the Task Force to: (1) review and monitor plans and programs developed in the public and private sectors that affect the ability of small businesses owned and controlled by women to obtain capital and credit and to access markets, and provide advice on improving coordination between such plans and programs; (2) monitor and promote the plans, programs, and operations of federal departments and agencies that contribute to the formation and development of such small businesses, and make recommendations to such departments and agencies concerning the coordination of such plans, programs, and operations; (3) develop and promote initiatives, policies, programs, and plans designed to encourage the formation of startups and high-growth small businesses owned and controlled by women; (4) advise the Administrator on the development and implementation of an annual comprehensive plan for joint efforts by the public and private sectors to facilitate the formation and development of such startups and high-growth small businesses; and (5) examine the link between women who own small businesses and intellectual property, including the number of patents, trademarks, and copyrights granted to women and the challenges faced by high-growth small businesses owned and controlled by women in obtaining and enforcing intellectual property rights.

Directs the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the SBA to study at least twice a year an issue that is important to small businesses owned and controlled by women.

Amends the Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 to repeal title IV (Interagency Committee on Women's Business Enterprise).

Veterans Information and Benefits Enhancement Act of 2003 - Amends Federal veterans' benefits law to provide a presumption that certain cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and chronic liver diseases are service-connected for compensation purposes for former prisoners of war.

Directs the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense to jointly: (1) review the mission, procedures, and administration of the Department of Defense's Dose Reconstruction Program; and (2) take appropriate actions to ensure the ongoing independent review and oversight of the Program, including the establishment of an advisory board.

Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out a study to determine the appropriate disposition of the Air Force Health Study, an epidemiologic study of Air Force personnel who were responsible for conducting aerial spray missions of herbicides during the Vietnam era.

Directs the Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense to make available to the National Academy of Sciences in each of FY 2004 through 2013 specified amounts for the Medical Follow-Up Agency of the Institute of Medicine of the Academy for purposes of epidemiological research on members of the Armed Forces and veterans.

Directs the Secretary of Education to provide for the discharge or cancellation of Federal student loan indebtedness of: (1) an eligible spouse; (2) an eligible surviving debtor; (3) an eligible parent who owes a consolidation loan incurred on behalf of an eligible victim; and (4) an eligible parent who owes a PLUS loan incurred on behalf of an eligible victim who became permanently and totally disabled due to injuries suffered in the terrorist attack on September 11, 2001.

Iran Human Rights Sanctions Act - Directs the President to impose visa and financial sanctions on each person who is a citizen of Iran that the President determines is complicit in human rights abuses committed against citizens of Iran or their family members on or after June 12, 2009, regardless of whether such abuses occurred in Iran.

Requires the President to submit to Congress and make public a list of such persons and updates of such list.

Individual Social Security Retirement Account Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce the rate of the tax on employees, employers, and self-employed individuals under the Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance (OASDI) program. 
Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) of the Social Security Act to require each covered employer to have in effect a social security payroll deduction plan for its eligible employees.  Requires such plan to provide for:  (1) the deduction from each employee's wages of a prescribed social security employee contribution; (2) payment of such contribution to an individual social security retirement account designated by the employee; (3) payment by the employer of the amount so deducted to the designated account within ten business days after the payment of the wages from which the amount was deducted; and (4) payment by the employer to the individual social security retirement account, together with the contribution paid pursuant to this paragraph, of the prescribed social security employer contribution with respect to the eligible employee.  Provides that the employer receives no compensation for the cost of administering such plan. 
Requires any covered employer who fails to meet the requirements of this Act to be subject to civil penalties. 
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the total amount deducted from the employee's wages under a social security payroll deduction plan to be shown on W-2 statements. 
Exempts social security payroll deduction plans from certain requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). 
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat individual social security retirement accounts in the same manner as individual retirement plans.

Post-Deployment Health Assessment Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to issue guidance for the provision of an in-person mental health screening for each member of the Armed Forces who is deployed in connection with a contingency operation at: (1) a time during the period beginning 180 days before the date of deployment and ending 90 days before the date of deployment; (2) a time during the period beginning 90 days after the date of redeployment and ending 180 days after the date of redeployment; and (3) not later than each of six months, 12 months, and 18 months after such second screening.

Excludes from such screenings any member who was not subjected or exposed to combat stress during deployment in the contingency operation concerned.

Requires the Secretary to share with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs information on members derived from confidential mental health screenings.
Amends the Clean Air Act to revise the definition of "renewable biomass" for purposes of the renewable fuel standard program.

Nuclear Security Act of 2003 - Amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to direct the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to: (1) establish a nuclear security force to provide for the security of all sensitive nuclear facilities against the design basis threat; and (2) develop and implement a security plan for each such facility to ensure its security against such threat. Defines "sensitive nuclear facility" as a commercial or decommissioned nuclear power plant and associated spent fuel storage facility, a category I fuel cycle facility, a gaseous diffusion plant, or any other facility licensed by the NRC or used in the conduct of an activity licensed by the NRC that the NRC determines should be treated as a sensitive nuclear facility.

Directs the NRC to: (1) establish a program for the hiring and training of the nuclear security force; and (2) establish qualification standards and administer a personnel examination for use in determining the qualification of individuals seeking employment as members of the nuclear security force.

Establishes the Nuclear Security Fund in the Treasury to be used by the NRC to administer programs under this Act to provide for the security of sensitive nuclear facilities.

State Innovation Pilot Act of 2011 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) to revise the waiver process for states, local educational agencies (LEAs), and Indian tribes that receive funds under ESEA programs.

Requires a state, LEA, or tribe to submit a request to the Secretary of Education to waive any statutory or regulatory requirement of ESEA. Requires the Secretary to waive any such requirement for a state, LEA, or tribe that submits a waiver request.

Requires the Secretary to establish multi-disciplinary peer review teams to review waiver requests if: (1) the Secretary requests such input in order to approve a waiver request; or (2) the Secretary intends to disapprove a request. Allows the Secretary to have a peer review team review all waiver requests submitted.

Sets forth requirements for the waiver determination, demonstration, and revision process.

Prohibits the Secretary from requiring a state, LEA, or tribe, as a condition of approval of a waiver request, to: (1) include in, or delete from, such request, specific academic content standards or academic achievement standards; (2) use specific academic assessment instruments or items; or (3) include in, or delete from, such waiver request any criterion that specifies, defines, or prescribes the standards or measures that a state or local educational agency uses to establish, implement, or improve specified academic indicators or teacher and principal evaluation systems.

Revises reporting requirements.

Freedom from Unfair Energy Levy Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to suspend for 180 days the tax on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, aviation fuel, and fuel used on inland waterways.

Repeals increases in motor fuel taxes enacted in 1993.

Provides for refunds of taxes paid on liquid fuels held by a dealer before the suspension date and not used or intended for sale.

Imposes a floor stocks tax on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date.

Veterans' Housing Benefits Enhancement Act of 2007 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to furnish improvements and structural alterations for a member of the Armed Forces who has a total disability permanent in nature incurred or aggravated in the line of duty while such member is hospitalized or receiving outpatient medical care, services, or treatment for such disability if the Secretary determines that such member is likely to be discharged or released from the Armed Forces for such disability.

Makes eligible for specially adapted housing assistance veterans with severe burn injuries.

Directs the Secretary to report to Congress on the adequacy of the authorities available to assist disabled veterans in acquiring: (1) suitable housing units with special fixtures or movable facilities required for their disabilities; (2) adaptations to their residences as are reasonably necessary because of their disabilities; or (3) residences already adapted with special features determined by the Secretary to be reasonably necessary as a result of their disabilities. Requires the report to pay particular attention to the needs of veterans who have disabilities not described in this Act.

Makes disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces with severe burn injuries eligible for automobiles and adaptive equipment.

Makes eligible for adapted housing assistance disabled members of the Armed Forces residing temporarily in housing owned by a family member.

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require a cable operator that operates a cable system with channel capacity designated under specified provisions, or that is required to provide such capacity, to: (1) carry signals for public, educational, or governmental use from the point of origin of such signals to subscribers without material degradation and without altering or removing content or data provided as part of such use; (2) provide such signals to, and make them viewable by, every subscriber of the cable system without additional service or equipment charges; and (3) provide to the appropriate local government subdivision, free of charge, any transmission services and the use of any transmission facilities that are necessary to meet the requirements of this Act.

Requires a cable operator in a state that adopts legislation affecting cable system franchising requirements relating to support for public, educational, or governmental use of a cable system that becomes effective after May 31, 2005, to pay a local government subdivision an amount for such year to be determined by the local government subdivision, but not to exceed the greatest of the following: (1) the amount of support provided in the last calendar year ending before the effective date of such state legislation; (2) the average annual amount of support provided over the term of the franchise under which the cable operator was operating on the day before the effective date of such state legislation; (3) the amount of support that the cable operator is required to provide to such local government subdivision under such state legislation during the year involved; or (4) an amount of support equal to two percent of the gross revenues of the cable operator from the operation of the cable system to provide cable services in such local government subdivision during the year involved.

District of Columbia Tax Revenue Nondiscrimination Act of 1997 - Repeals provisions granting property tax relief to certain entities in the District of Columbia. 
Amends the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation Act, and the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prohibit the District of Columbia from taxing the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), or the Student Loan Marketing Association (SLMA).

Indian Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Act of 2004 - Amends the Native American Business Development, Trade Promotion, and Tourism Act of 2000 to direct the Secretary of the Interior to establish the Tribal Development Corporation Feasibility Study Group to study and report to specified congressional committees on the feasibility of establishing an Indian Tribal Development Corporation.

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to carry out an Early Federal Pell Grant Commitment Demonstration Program under which: (1) the Secretary awards grants to four state educational agencies (SEAs) to pay administrative expenses incurred in participating in the demonstration program; and (2) the Secretary awards Federal Pell Grants to participating students.

Requires each SEA to make participation in the demonstration project available to two cohorts of students, which shall consist of: (1) one cohort of eighth grade students who begin participation in academic year 2007-2008; and (2) one cohort of eighth grade students who begin participation in academic year 2008-2009. Limits each cohort to not more than 10,000 eighth grade students who qualify for a free or reduced price meal under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act or the Child Nutrition Act of 1966.

Requires each student who participates in the demonstration project to receive a commitment from the Secretary to receive a Federal Pell Grant during the first academic year that such student is in attendance at an institution of higher education as an undergraduate, if the student applies for Federal financial aid (via the FAFSA) during the student's senior year of secondary school and during succeeding years.

Requires the Secretary to reserve specified amounts for FY2008-FY2014 for: (1) an independent evaluation of the impact of the demonstration program; and (2) a targeted information campaign for the demonstration program.

Energy Security Act of 2011 - Establishes in the Executive Office of the President: (1) the national energy security program to coordinate federal activities and policies to ensure that the United States meets goals for reducing oil dependence, oil imports, and oil consumption; and (2) the National Energy Security Council to assist and advise the President in establishing the national oil independence goal in numeric terms of barrels per day of oil consumption, meeting such goal, developing the national oil independence plan, coordinating the policies, programs, and activities of the national energy security program, and ensuring that policy decisions and programs are consistent with U.S. energy policy goals.

Sets forth the mission of the national energy security program.

Establishes as a goal of the United States to reduce oil consumption by the quantity that is equal to or greater than the quantity of oil imported by the United States from outside of North America by calendar year 2030 (as compared to the rate of oil consumption projected for calendar year 2030 as of the date of enactment of this Act). Authorizes the President to adjust the numeric goal for calendar year 2030.

Directs the President to develop a national oil independence plan that describes programs and activities that will be implemented to meet or exceed the national oil independence goal and other goals established pursuant to this Act. Requires the President to review existing federal programs and authorities and other applicable policies to determine which could be used to accelerate reductions in oil dependence and maximize such reductions, and which have the effect of increasing oil consumption and oil dependence or otherwise create barriers to reducing oil consumption and oil dependence.

Freedom from Equifax Exploitation Act This bill amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to: (1) define "credit freeze," (2) extend fraud alert protections, (3) require consumer reporting agencies to provide free access to credit freezes, and (4) require refunds for any fees charged to consumers who requested a credit freeze between September 7, 2017, and the date of enactment of this bill.

Amends the Clean Air Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to promulgate regulations ensuring that, after December 31, 2010, all gasoline or diesel motor vehicle fuel sold or dispensed to consumers in the contiguous United States contains at least ten percent ethanol and five percent biodiesel.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for interest on student loans of medical professionals practicing in rural areas.

Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014 - Requires each state to operate a qualified state reinsurance program or a qualifying state high risk pool and apply to the operation of such a program from state funds an amount equivalent to the portion of state funds derived from state premium assessments that are not otherwise used on state health care programs. Defines "qualified state reinsurance program" as a program operated by a state program that provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage offered in the small group market in accordance with a model for such a program established under this Act. Deems a qualified state reinsurance program to be a qualified high risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. Defines "qualifying state high risk pool" as a current qualified high risk pool that meets specified requirements, including: (1) providing at least two coverage options, one of which must be a high deductible health plan coupled with a health savings account; (2) being funded with a stable funding source; (3) eliminating any waiting lists so that all eligible residents who are seeking coverage through the pool should be allowed to receive coverage through the pool; (4) allowing for coverage of individuals who, but for the 24-month disability waiting period under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act, would be eligible for Medicare during the period of such waiting period; (5) limiting the pool premiums to no more than 150% of the average premium for applicable standard risk rates in that state; (6) conducting education and outreach initiatives so that residents and brokers understand that the pool is available to eligible residents; and (7) providing coverage for preventive services and disease management for chronic diseases. Makes only U.S. citizens and nationals eligible to participate in a qualifying state high risk pool that receives funds under the Public Health Service Act or this Act. Authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to waive such requirements for qualified state reinsurance programs and for qualifying state high risk pools as the Secretary deems appropriate.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to enter into an agreement with the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to conduct a demonstration project under which certain covered beneficiaries and their dependents will be eligible to enroll in health benefits plans offered through the Federal Employees Health Benefits program.

Children's Environmental Health Protection Act - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish a Task Force to Address Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children. Requires the Task Force to report to the President, in consultation with specified agencies and offices, on federal strategies to improve children's environmental health and safety.

Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award competitive grants to States for improving staffing levels in nursing facilities to improve the quality of care to residents.
Amends title XVIII (Medicare) and title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require skilled nursing facilities and nursing facilities to submit data on staffing levels and resident classification to the Secretary. Requires the Secretary to publish such information on the Internet Site of the Department of Health and Human Services known as Nursing Home Compare.
Requires skilled nursing facilities and nursing facilities to post daily for each nursing unit of the facility and for each shift the current number of licensed and unlicensed nursing staff directly responsible for resident care and the number of residents per unit and per shift.

Amends Federal civil service law to include fish and wildlife officers of the Refuge Division of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior in the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS).

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to criminalize visa overstays.  Provides for: (1) a fine, imprisonment, or both for the first commission of such an offense; and (2) a fine, imprisonment, or both for a subsequent commission of such an offense. Exempts from such penalties any alien who violated such provisions because of reasons of medical necessity, public safety, or national security. Prohibits the reentry into the United States of an alien convicted of a visa overstay offense. Requires the Secretary of State or the Secretary of Homeland Security to provide an alien with notice of such penalties upon application or petition for U.S. admission. 
Provides that a revocation of a visa shall automatically cancel any other valid visa in the alien's possession. 
Prohibits the government from bearing any expense for counsel for any person in immigration proceedings. 
Authorizes the Secretary of State to provide to a foreign government copies of any record of the Department of State and of diplomatic and consular offices pertaining to the issuance or refusal of visas or permits to enter the United States if it is in the national interests of the United States. 
Requires the Attorney General and the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to provide the Secretary of State with access to the criminal history record information contained in files maintained by the National Crime Information Center for the purpose of determining whether a visa should be issued.

Community Mental Health and Addiction Safety Net Equity Act of 2010 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) to certify, and recertify at least every five years, federally qualified behavioral health centers as meeting specified criteria.

Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to: (1) include federally qualified behavioral health center services in the term medical assistance; and (2) provide for Medicaid coverage and payment for such services.

Requires the Institute of Medicine to report to Congress on: (1) the combined paperwork burden of federally qualified behavioral health centers certified under this Act; and (2) the compensation structure of professional and paraprofessional personnel employed by such centers.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: 
     Title I:  Overseas Private Investment Corporation 
     Title II:  Trade and Development Agency 
     Title III:  Export Promotion Programs Within the International Trade 
          Administration 
     Title IV:  Promotion of United States Environmental Exports 
     Title V:  International Protection of Intellectual Property 
Jobs Through Trade Expansion Act of 1994 - 
Title I:  Overseas Private Investment Corporation
 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to increase the maximum amount of insurance and financing that may be provided by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) for private investment in developing countries.  Extends OPIC's authority to issue investment guarantees through FY 1996.  Eliminates administrative expenses from the OPIC budget.  Exempts Ireland and Northern Ireland from certain requirements for foreign assistance. 
Title II:  Trade and Development Agency
 - Reauthorizes appropriations for the Trade and Development Agency through FY 1996. 
Title III:  Export Promotion Programs Within the International Trade Administration
 - Amends the Export Administration Amendments Act of 1985 to authorize appropriations for export promotion programs through FY 1996. 
Title IV:  Promotion of United States Environmental Exports
 - Amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to establish an Environmental Technologies Trade Advisory Committee to provide advice and guidance to the Working Group in the development and administration of programs to expand U.S. exports of environmental technologies, goods, and services and products that comply with U.S. environmental, safety, and related requirements. 
Directs the Working Group to annually assess which foreign countries have markets with the greatest potential for the export of U.S. environmental technologies, goods, and services.  Requires the Working Group to select as priority countries five with the greatest potential for the application of U.S. Government export promotion resources related to environmental exports.  Directs the Working Group to create a plan for each priority country selected, setting forth ways to increase U.S. environmental exports to such country. 
Directs the Secretary of Commerce to assign a specialist in environmental technologies to the office of the U.S. and Foreign Commercial Service in each of the five priority countries selected.  Authorizes the Secretary to assign such a specialist to the office of the U.S. and Foreign Commercial Service in any country that is a promising market for U.S. exports of environmental technologies, goods, and services.  Sets forth the duties of such specialists. 
Directs the Secretary to establish a mechanism to train:  (1) Commercial Service Officers assigned to one-stop shops; and (2) Commercial Service Officers assigned to district offices in districts having large numbers of environmental businesses, in environmental technologies and in the international environmental marketplace. 
Authorizes the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) to establish one or more international regional environmental initiatives to coordinate the activities of Federal departments and agencies in order to build environmental partnerships between the United States and the geographic region outside the United States for which such initiative is established.  Sets forth TPCC activities. 
Requires the Working Group to maintain a calendar of significant opportunities for U.S. environmental businesses in foreign markets and trade promotion events.  Requires the Working Group to provide information on opportunities for environmental businesses in foreign markets and information on Federal export promotion programs. 
Authorizes the Secretary to use the Market Development Cooperator Program to support the creation on a regional basis of alliances of private sector entities, nonprofit organizations, and universities that support the export of environmental technologies, goods, and services and promote the export of products complying with U.S. environmental, safety, and related requirements. 
Title V:  International Protection of Intellectual Property
 - Directs the President, acting through the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), to establish a program of training and other technical assistance to assist foreign countries in:  (1) developing and strengthening laws and regulations to protect intellectual property; and (2) developing the infrastructure necessary to implement and enforce such laws and regulations. 
Directs the Administrator to utilize the expertise of the Patent and Trademark Office and other U.S. Government agencies in designing and implementing the program of assistance provided for in this section.  Directs the Administrator to coordinate assistance under this section with efforts of other U.S. Government agencies to increase international protection of intellectual property, including implementation of international agreements containing high levels of protection of intellectual property.

Fair and Speedy Treatment (FAST) of Medicare Prescription Drug Claims Act of 2007 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require each contract entered into with a prescription drug plan (PDP) sponsor under Medicare part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program) to provide that payment shall be issued, mailed, or otherwise transmitted within 14 calendar days after the date on which a clean claim is received for all claims submitted electronically. Requires such payment to be made within 30 calendar days after the date on which a clean claim is received for all other claims.

Defines "clean claim" as a claim, with respect to a covered part D drug, that has no apparent defect or impropriety (including any lack of any required substantiating documentation) or particular circumstance requiring special treatment that prevents timely payment from being made on the claim under part D.

Requires interest to be paid at a specified rate for the period beginning on the day after the required payment date and ending on the date on which payment is made if payment is not issued, mailed, or otherwise transmitted within the applicable number of calendar days after a clean claim is received.

Deems a claim for a covered part D drug to be a clean claim if the PDP sponsor involved does not provide a notification of deficiency to the claimant by the 10th day that begins after the date on which the claim is submitted. Defines "notification of deficiency" as a notification that specifies all defects or improprieties in the claim involved and that lists all additional information or documents necessary for the proper processing and payment of the claim.

Requires a PDP sponsor to pay any portion of a claim for a covered part D drug that would be a clean claim but for a defect or impropriety in a separate portion of the claim.

Deems a claim for a covered part D drug submitted to a PDP sponsor that is not paid or contested by the provider within the applicable number of calendar days to be a clean claim and requires it to be paid by the PDP sponsor.

Requires a PDP sponsor to pay all clean claims submitted electronically by an electronic funds transfer mechanism.

Applies the requirements of this Act to contracts with a Medicare Advantage organization in the same manner as they apply to contracts with a PDP sponsor offering a prescription drug plan under part D.

Makes it unlawful for a PDP sponsor of a prescription drug plan to display on any explanatory information, with respect to benefits provided under part D, the brand or trademark of any pharmacy.

Health Care Access for Small Businesses Act of 2003 - Amends the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), to promulgate regulations for the certification of three-share programs for purposes of a refundable tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers who pay or incur at least 70 percent of the costs of a three-share program resulting from the participation of the taxpayer in such program during the taxable year a tax credit equal to 40 percent of such costs.

Spectrum Relocation Improvement Act of 2008 - Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to revise requirements for payment from the Spectrum Relocation Fund to federal entities that incur relocation costs because of the reallocation of frequencies from federal use to non-federal use.

Requires the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to post on its website detailed transition plans from each of the eligible federal entities. Requires such plans to provide the public with specified information about spectrum relocation requirements.

Requires a federal entity, in order to be eligible to receive payment for relocation costs from the Fund, to: (1) provide, in its transition plan for relocating its current spectrum uses, for sharing and coordination of eligible frequencies with commercial licensees; (2) during the transition period, make itself available for negotiation and discussion with commercial licensees; and (3) during the transition period, make available to a commercial licensee with appropriate security clearances any classified information regarding the relocation process, on a need-to-know basis, to assist the commercial licensee in the relocation process with that federal entity or other federal entities.

Requires a federal entity, in addition to the above conditions, to: (1) complete the relocation of its current spectrum uses not later than one year after the date upon which funds are transferred to the entity to fund the relocation unless, prior to the date that NTIA is required to post publicly the federal entity's transition plan, the federal entity receives written approval from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), with advice of NTIA, for a different time period for completion; and (2) make available to NTIA, not later than 15 days prior to the date that is the halfway point of the time period described in this Act, a complete update of its transition plan. Requires NTIA to post such update publicly on its website not later than the date that is the halfway point of the time period described in this Act.

Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) dispute resolution; and (2) appeals.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) exempt from special limitations on charitable contributions of capital gain property any qualified conservation contribution or any other contribution of capital gain property which is real property if the contribution is of the donor's entire interest in such property and is to a qualified organization which is organized for conservation purposes and which provides the taxpayer, at the time of such donation, a letter of intent which contains an acknowledgment of the donee's intent that the property is being acquired for any such conservation purpose; and (2) repeal certain restrictions on the location of land subject to a qualified conservation easement.

Greater Sage Grouse Protection and Recovery Act of 2016 This bill prohibits the Department of the Interior from making a finding under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 with respect to the greater sage grouse in any state with a state-approved plan for the protection and recovery of the species before September 30, 2026. The conservation status of the species shall remain not warranted for listing under the Act until that date.  In order to foster coordination between a state management plan and federal resource management plans that affect the species, upon notification by the governor of a state with a state management plan, Interior and the Department of Agriculture (USDA) may not exercise authority under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to make, modify, or extend any withdrawal, nor amend or otherwise modify any federal resource management plan applicable to federal land in the state, in a manner inconsistent with the state management plan for a period, to be specified by the governor in the notification, of at least five years beginning on the date of the notification.  With regard to any major federal action consistent with a state management plan, any findings, analyses, or conclusions regarding the species or its habitat under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 shall not have a preclusive effect on the approval or implementation of the major federal action in that state.
Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act - Provides for the tax treatment of income received in connection with the Exxon Valdez litigation.

Crime Victims with Disabilities Act of 2006 - Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize the Attorney General to make grants to states, local governments, Indian tribes, or tribal organizations to prepare a comprehensive plan for or to implement a collaboration program that provides for: (1) the investigation and remediation of instances of abuse of or crimes committed against individuals with disabilities; or (2) the provision of services to individuals with disabilities who are victims of a crime or abuse.

Requires such programs to: (1) receive reports of abuse of individuals with disabilities or crimes committed against such individuals; (2) investigate and evaluate reports of abuse of or crimes committed against individuals with disabilities; (3) visit the homes or other locations of abuse, and, if applicable, the day programs of individuals with disabilities who have been victims of abuse or a crime for purposes of assessing the scene of the abuse and evaluating the condition and needs of the victim; (4) identify the individuals responsible for the abuse of or crimes committed against individuals with disabilities; (5) remedy issues identified during an investigation; (6) prosecute the perpetrator, where appropriate, of any crime identified during an investigation; and (7) provide services to and enforce statutory rights of individuals with disabilities who are victims of a crime.

Directs the Attorney General to establish a national center to evaluate the overall effectiveness of the collaboration programs funded under this Act.

Junk Fax Prevention Act of 2004 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit the use of any telephone facsimile machine, computer, or other device to send an unsolicited advertisement to a telephone facsimile machine unless: (1) the sender has an established business relationship with such person; and (2) the unsolicited advertisement contains a conspicuous notice on the first page that states that the recipient may make a request to the sender not to send any future unsolicited advertisements to such telephone facsimile machine and that failure to comply is unlawful. Requires the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to provide by rule that a request complies with this Act only if: (1) it identifies the telephone number of the telephone facsimile machine to which the request relates; (2) it is made to the telephone or facsimile number of the sender of such an unsolicited advertisement; and (3) the person making the request has not, subsequent to such request, provided express invitation or permission to the sender to send such advertisements to such person at such telephone facsimile machine.

Authorizes the FCC to allow professional trade associations that are tax-exempt nonprofit organizations to send unsolicited advertisements to their members in furtherance of the association's tax-exempt purpose that do not contain the notice required by this Act, except that the FCC may take action under this Act only by regulation issued after notice and opportunity for public comment and only if the FCC determines that such notice is not necessary to protect the right of the members of such trade associations to make a request to their trade associations not to send any future unsolicited advertisements.

Requires the FCC to submit a report to Congress each year regarding the enforcement of the provisions of this Act relating to sending of unsolicited advertisements to telephone facsimile machines.

Directs the Comptroller General to study complaints received by the FCC concerning unsolicited advertisements sent to telephone facsimile machines.

Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013 - Requires the United States to hold in trust for the benefit of the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians all right, title, and interest in specified federal land (including any improvements located on such land, appurtenances to such land, and minerals on or in such land, including oil and gas) and part of the Tribe's reservation. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to: (1) complete a survey of the boundary lines to establish the boundaries of the land taken into trust; and (2) file a map and legal description of the federal land with the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and the House Committee on Natural Resources. Prohibits: (1) exports of unprocessed logs harvested from the federal land, and (2) any real property taken into trust from being eligible, or used, for any gaming activity carried out under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. Requires any commercial forestry activity that is carried out on the federal land to be managed in accordance with all applicable federal laws. Directs the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) and the Secretary to identify any land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad that is conveyed under this Act. Directs the Secretary to identify public domain land that is approximately equal in acreage and condition as the land identified by the USDA and the Secretary and that is located within the planning area. Requires the Secretary to reclassify the land identified as public domain land as land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad after providing an opportunity for public comment.

Uranium Mining Modernization Act - Amends the Mineral Leasing Act to withdraw all Federal lands from location and entry for uranium.  Prohibits uranium production from Federal lands after two years, except pursuant to a lease issued under this Act. 
Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to divide any lands subject to this Act that are not withdrawn from mineral leasing and that are otherwise available for uranium leasing into leasing tracts of such size as the Secretary finds appropriate and in the public interest.  Directs the Secretary, upon request of any qualified applicant or on the Secretary's own motion, to offer such lands for uranium leasing and award uranium leases thereon by competitive bidding. 
Requires:  (1) no bid for a uranium lease to be accepted that is less than the fair market value of the uranium subject to the lease; (2) consideration of effects that mining under the proposed lease might have on an impacted community or area; and (3) notice of proposed lease. 
Sets forth requirements for:  (1) auction requirements; (2) required payments; (3) lease term; and (4) exploration licenses. 
Allows the owner of any mining claim located prior to enactment of this Act to apply to the Secretary to convert the claim to a lease under this Act.

Prescription Drug Fairness for Seniors Act of 1998 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to furnish to each Medicare beneficiary a drug benefit card that enables the beneficiary to purchase covered prescription drugs from participating pharmacies at reduced prices. 
Authorizes any qualified pharmacy to enter into an agreement with the Secretary that enables the pharmacy to sell covered outpatient drugs to holders of Medicare drug benefit cards at a reduced price, by authorizing the pharmacy to operate as a participating pharmacy under this Act.  Entitles the participating pharmacy to purchase any covered outpatient drug that is listed on the Federal Supply Schedule of the General Services Administration at the participating pharmacy discount price for that drug determined under this Act. 
Directs the Secretary to determine a participating pharmacy discount price for each covered outpatient drug.

HUD Programs Information Verification Act - Amends part A (General Provisions) of title IV of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to furnish information in HUD's custody for comparison with information in the National Directory of New Hires, in order to obtain information regarding individuals participating in any program under specified housing assistance programs.  Requires the Secretary to seek only the minimum information necessary to verify the employment and income of such individuals. 
Requires the Secretary to compare such information and disclose it to HUD.  Authorizes HUD to use such information:  (1) for verifying the employment and income of such individuals; and (2) after removal of personal identifiers, to conduct analyses of their employment and income reporting. 
Authorizes HUD to make a disclosure only for the purpose of verifying the employment and income of such individuals.  Authorizes HUD to disclose information resulting from a data match only to a public housing agency, the Inspector General of HUD, and the Attorney General in connection with the administration of such programs.  Provides that information obtained by HUD pursuant to this Act shall not be made available under the Freedom of Information Act. 
Sets forth conditions on such disclosures. 
Directs HUD to reimburse HUD for costs incurred in furnishing the information requested under this Act. 
Prohibits HUD from seeking, using, or disclosing information relating to an individual without the prior written consent of such individual (or of a person legally authorized to consent on behalf of such individual). 
Authorizes HUD, as a condition of participation in any program authorized under specified housing assistance programs, to require consent by an individual (or by a person legally authorized to consent on behalf of such individual) for HUD to obtain, use, and disclose information with respect to such individual in accordance with this Act.

Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2011 - Amends the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 to include an entrepreneur that operates a business or intends to operate a business in an investment area as an eligible recipient of microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building grants.

Requires the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to: (1) consider the impact of the economic crisis of 2007 through 2009 on the geographic area in which an applicant operates in determining whether to reduce or eliminate matching requirements for such grants; and (2) establish in the SBA the position of Microenterprise Coordinator.

Directs the Administrator to establish an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship, headed by a Director of Youth Entrepreneurship. Requires the Director to: (1) carry out the youth entrepreneurship technical assistance grant program and the youth entrepreneurship curriculum grant program; (2) promote the growth of youth entrepreneurship by establishing public-private partnerships and carrying out advertising campaigns; (3) sponsor and support state and national youth entrepreneurship competitions that raise awareness of the importance of small business development; (4) study and promote federal activities that support entrepreneurship education; and (5) support the establishment of public and private youth entrepreneurship education and mentoring opportunities.

Requires the Director to ensure that at least 25% of the amounts made available to carry out the Office each fiscal year are used to assist youth in investment areas.

Requires the Director to submit to Congress detailed recommendations for legislation establishing programs to forgive student loans and defer student loan repayments in a manner that assists youth entrepreneurship by making capital available for business formation.

Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on: (1) the economic impact of allowing youth entrepreneurs to defer student loan repayments to make capital available for business formation; (2) the economic impact of increasing the participation of individuals under age 25 in the SBA microloan program, notwithstanding their limited collateral and formal business experience; (3) alternative methods for measuring creditworthiness that may assist youth entrepreneurship; and (4) actions Congress should consider to promote youth entrepreneurship.

Improving Food-borne Illness Surveillance and Response Act of 2008 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to strengthen and expand food-borne illness surveillance systems to: (1) inform and evaluate efforts to prevent food-borne illness; and (2) enhance the identification and investigation of, and response to, food-borne illness outbreaks.

Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to enhance food-borne illness surveillance systems to improve the collection, analysis, reporting, and usefulness of data on food-borne illnesses by: (1) coordinating food-borne illness surveillance systems, including complaint systems, in order to produce better information on illnesses associated with foods, including sources and risk factors for infections by emerging pathogens, and facilitate sharing of data acquisition and findings on a more timely basis among governmental agencies and with the public; (2) augmenting such systems to improve attribution of a food-borne illness outbreak to a specific food; (3) developing improved epidemiological tools for obtaining quality exposure data, microbiological methods for classifying cases and detecting clusters, and improved tracebacks to rapidly and specifically identify contaminated food products; (4) expanding capacity of such systems for implementation of fingerprinting strategies for food-borne infectious agents, including parasites and hepatitis A, in order to increase pathogen discovery efforts to identify new or rarely documented causes of food-borne illness; (5) allowing timely public access to de-identified, aggregate surveillance data; (6) at least annually, publishing current reports on findings from such systems; (7) exploring establishment of registries for long-term case follow-up to better characterize late complications of food-borne illness; (8) increasing participation in national networks of public health and food regulatory agencies and laboratories to allow public health officials at the federal, state, and local levels to share and accept laboratory analytic findings and identify food-borne illness outbreaks and attribute such outbreaks to specific foods through submission of standardized molecular subtypes (fingerprints) of food-borne illness pathogens to a centralized database; and (9) establishing a flexible mechanism for rapidly supporting scientific research by academic centers of excellence.

Directs the Secretary, acting through the Director of CDC and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs (FDA), to improve capacity for surveillance in the states by: (1) supporting outbreak investigations with needed specialty expertise, including epidemiological, microbiological, and environmental expertise, to assist identification of underlying common sources and contributing factors; (2) identifying, disseminating, and supporting implementation of model practices at the state and local level for facilitating rapid shipment of clinical isolates from clinical laboratories to state public health laboratories to avoid delays in testing, conducting rapid and more standardized interviewing of cases associated with major enteric pathogens, conducting and evaluating rapid and standardized interviews of healthy control persons, sharing information on a timely basis within public health and food regulatory agencies, among such agencies, with the food industry, with healthcare providers, and with the public; (3) developing, regularly updating, and disseminating training curricula on food-borne illness surveillance investigations, including standard sampling methods and laboratory procedures; (4) integrating new molecular diagnostic tools for parasites into web-based consultation services for parasitic infections to accelerate the identification of these food-borne infectious agents; (5) supporting research to develop and deploy new subtyping methods for salmonella, E. coli, campylobacter, and other pathogens, to increase the speed and accuracy of diagnoses; (6) determining minimum core competencies for public health laboratories, and developing self-evaluation and proficiency-testing tools for such laboratories; (7) facilitating regional public health laboratory partnerships to leverage resources, including equipment and physical space, and increase surge capacity; (8) providing technical assistance to state and local public health and food regulatory agencies; (9) partnering with FDA to increase communication, coordination, and integration of food-borne illness surveillance and outbreak investigation activities; and (10) developing and periodically updating response and interview procedures so that such procedures are standardized and tested.

Directs the Secretary to carry out activities to support core food safety functions of state and local public health laboratories, including: (1) establishing fellowships, stipends, and scholarships to address critical workforce shortages; (2) training and coordination of state and local personnel; (3) establishing partnerships between private and public laboratories to facilitate sharing of positive enteric specimens and improve surge capacity; (4) strengthening capacity to participate in existing or new food-borne illness surveillance systems; and (5) the purchase and maintenance of data systems hardware and software and laboratory equipment.

Directs the Secretary to establish a diverse working group of experts and stakeholders from federal, state, and local food safety and health agencies, the food industry, consumer organizations, and academia to provide advice and recommendations on an ongoing and regular basis regarding the improvement of food-borne illness surveillance and implementation of this Act.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary to: (1) leverage and enhance the food safety capacity and roles of state and local agencies and integrate state and local agencies as fully as possible into national food safety efforts; (2) complete a survey of state and local capacities, and needs for enhancement, with respect to specified factors; (3) develop, publish, and begin implementation of a plan that includes specified elements; and (4) make grants to state and local agencies to enhance state and local food safety capacity and programs and support achievement of the goals established under this Act.

Heart Disease Education, Analysis, Research, and Treatment for Women Act or the HEART for Women Act - Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the extent to which sponsors of clinical studies of investigational drugs, biologics, and devices and sponsors of applications for approval or licensure of new drugs, biologics, and devices comply with Food and Drug Administration (FDA) requirements and follow guidance for presentation of clinical study safety and effectiveness data by sex, age, and racial subgroups.

Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to submit a response to such report, including a corrective action plan as needed to respond to the recommendations in such report.

Directs the Director of the Office of Women's Health of the FDA to report to Congress on women's health, and the Director of the Office of Minority Health of the FDA to report to Congress on minority health, regarding: (1) the extent to which the FDA assists sponsors in complying with the requirements and following the guidance referred to above; (2) the effectiveness of the FDA's enforcement of compliance with such requirements; (3) the extent to which females, racial and ethnic minorities, and adults of all ages are adequately represented in FDA-approved clinical studies so that product safety and effectiveness data can be evaluated by gender, age, and racial subgroup; (4) the extent to which a summary of product safety and effectiveness data disaggregated by sex, age, and racial subgroup is readily available to the public in a timely manner by means of the product label or the FDA's website; and (5) appropriate recommendations for modifications to the requirements and guidance referred to above or for oversight by the FDA of such requirements.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Secretary to: (1) prepare and submit to Congress an annual report on the quality of and access to care for women with heart disease, stroke, and other cardiovascular diseases, containing recommendations for eliminating disparities in, and improving the treatment of, such diseases in women; and (2) conduct a study of the impact of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act on preventive health services, referrals, and follow-up services for women eligible for such services under grants funded under the Women's Preventive Services Initiative.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish a program of qualified school construction bonds. 
Requires one-third of the national limitation on such bonds to be allocated among:  (1) States in proportion to the respective amounts each State received for Basic Grants under title I; (2) large local educational agencies in proportion to the respective amounts each agency received for Basic Grants under title I; and (3) high-growth local educational agencies in proportion to the respective amounts each agency received for Basic Grants under title I. 
Applies the Davis-Bacon Act to individuals employed on school construction, rehabilitation, or repair projects financed with proceeds from an issuance of qualified school construction bonds.

Insurance Disclosure Act of 1997 - Requires an insurer to ensure that, in any case in which a medical examination of an individual is required for initial or continued enrollment under a policy issued by the insurer and such examination is conducted by a person who is in the employ of the insurer or whose services are procured otherwise by the insurer, such individual (or the individual's legal guardian) is provided all medical information obtained from such examination at the same time that such information is made available to the insurer and is encouraged to make such information available to such individual's own physician. 
Deems this Act applicable to certain provisions of the Public Health Service Act.  Allows an individual who believes that he or she has been adversely affected by an act or practice of an insurer in violation of this Act to maintain an action against the insurer in a Federal or State court of original jurisdiction.  Authorizes the court, upon proof of such conduct by a preponderance of the evidence, to award appropriate relief, including temporary, preliminary, and permanent injunctive relief and compensatory and punitive damages, as well as the costs of suit and reasonable fees for the aggrieved individual's attorneys and expert witnesses.  Provides for statutory damages in lieu of actual damages. 
Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to require a group insurance plan, and any insurer offering a policy in connection with such plan, to take such actions as are necessary to ensure that, in any case in which a medical examination of a participant or beneficiary is required for initial or continued eligibility for benefits, and such medical examination is conducted by a person who is in the employ of the plan or the insurer or whose services are procured otherwise by the plan or the insurer, such participant or beneficiary (or his or her legal guardian) is provided all medical information obtained from such examination at the same time that such information is made available to the plan or insurer and is encouraged to make such information available to his or her own physician. 
Sets forth penalties for failure to disclose.

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to: (1) study the economic and trade impact of agricultural exports of food products from cloned animals; (2) study with the Government Accountability Office (GAO) on the programs in place at the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to monitor food products from cloned animals if such products enter the food supply; (3) study with GAO on the health effects and costs attributable to milk from cloned animals in the food supply; and (4) contract with the National Academy of Sciences to study and report to Congress regarding the safety of food products derived from cloned animals.

Requires the voluntary moratorium on introducing food from cloned animals or their progeny into the food supply to remain in effect at least until the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs (FDA), issues the final risk assessment on the safety of cloned animals and food products derived from cloned animals.

Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for qualified expenditures incurred in restoring and protecting coastal lands located in the United States. Defines "qualified expenditures" as amounts paid or incurred by the taxpayer for an approved project. Defines "approved project" as any project approved by the Natural Resources Conservation Service to restore or protect coastal lands located in the United States. Limits the amount of such credit to $2 million per year.

Judicial Administration and Improvement Act of 2016 This bill amends the federal judicial code to establish a new ninth circuit of the U.S. Court of Appeals, which shall consist of California, Hawaii, Oregon, Washington, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The former ninth circuit shall be divided into two circuits: (1) the former ninth circuit, consisting of California, Oregon, Washington, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands; and (2) a twelfth circuit, consisting of Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, and Nevada.  The bill increases the number of judges in the former ninth circuit from 13 to 21 and in the twelfth circuit from 7 to 8.  The bill also establishes the following places of circuit court for the twelfth circuit: Las Vegas, Phoenix, Anchorage, and Missoula.  Each circuit judge of the former ninth circuit who is in regular active service and whose official duty station on the day before the effective date of this Act is in California, Oregon, Washington, Guam, Hawaii, or the Northern Mariana Islands shall be a circuit judge of the new ninth circuit as of such effective date. A circuit judge in regular active service whose official duty station is in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, or Nevada may elect to be permanently assigned to the new ninth circuit by notifying the Director of the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts of such election. For each individual serving in the position of circuit judge of the former ninth circuit whose official duty station is in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, or Nevada, after the date on which such individual ceases to serve as a circuit judge, the President shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, one additional circuit judge for the twelfth circuit, without regard to whether such individual makes an election to be assigned to the new ninth circuit.  Each senior circuit judge of the former ninth circuit whose official duty station is in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, or Nevada may elect to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit as of such effective date and shall notify the Director of the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts of such election.  For each circuit judge in regular active service who elects to be assigned to the new ninth circuit, the President shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, one additional circuit judge for the twelfth circuit, resident in the duty station of the circuit judge making the election as of the day before the effective date of this Act.  The seniority of each judge who elects to be assigned to the twelfth circuit, the new ninth circuit, or the twelfth circuit under this bill shall run from the date of commission of such judge as a judge of the former ninth circuit.  The seniority of each judge appointed under this bill shall run from the date of commission of such judge as a judge of the twelfth circuit.  The bill provides that the following apply to any case in which, on the day before the effective date of this Act, an appeal or other proceeding has been filed with the former ninth circuit: (1) if the matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings with respect to the matter shall be had in the same manner and with the same effect as if this bill had not been enacted; (2) if the matter has not been submitted for decision, the appeal or proceeding, together with the original papers, printed records, and record entries duly certified, shall, by appropriate orders, be transferred to the court to which the matter would have been submitted had this bill been in full force and effect on the date on which such appeal was taken or other proceeding commenced, and further proceedings with respect to the case shall be had in the same manner and with the same effect as if the appeal or other proceeding had been filed in such court; and (3) if a petition for rehearing en banc is pending on or after the effective date of this Act, the petition shall be considered by the court of appeals to which the petition would have been submitted had this bill been in full force and effect on the date on which the appeal or other proceeding was filed with the court of appeals.  The court of appeals for the ninth circuit as constituted on the day before the effective date of this Act may take such administrative action as may be required to carry out this bill and the amendments made by it. The court described in this paragraph shall cease to exist for administrative purposes two years after the effective date of this Act.

North Korean Human Rights Reauthorization Act of 2008 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the United States should continue to seek foreign government cooperation to allow U.S. processing of North Korean refugees overseas for resettlement in the United States; (2) the Special Envoy for North Korean Human Rights Issues should be a full-time position within the Department of State; (3) the United States should approach the Republic of Korea to explore new opportunities for coordinating efforts to screen and resettle North Koreans who have expressed a wish to pursue U.S. resettlement and have not yet availed themselves of any right to citizenship they may enjoy under the Constitution of the Republic of Korea; and (4) the United States should urge China to halt its forcible repatriation of North Koreans, fulfill its obligations pursuant to the 1951 United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, the 067 Protocol Relating to the Status of Refugees, and the 1995 Agreement on the Upgrading of the UNHCR Mission in the People's Republic of China to UNHCR Branch Office in the People's Republic of China, and allow the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) unimpeded access to North Koreans inside China to determine whether they are refugees and whether they require assistance.

Amends the North Korean Human Rights Act of 2004 to: (1) extend through FY2012 the authorization of appropriations for support for human rights and democracy programs; (2) direct the Broadcasting Board of Governors to report to Congress on the status and content of current U.S. broadcasting to North Korea and the extent to which it has achieved the goal of 12-hour-per-day broadcasting to North Korea; (3) extend through FY2012 the authority of the Secretary of State to take actions to promote freedom of information; (4) revise the duties of the Special Envoy for North Korean Human Rights Issues; (5) extend through FY2012 the authority of the Secretary to report annually to Congress on U.S. humanitarian assistance to North Korea; (6) extend through FY2012 the authority of the Secretary to provide assistance outside of North Korea; and (7) require the Secretary to include in the annual report on North Korean refugees a detailed description of measures undertaken by the Secretary to secure the cooperation and permission of the governments of countries in East and Southeast Asia to facilitate U.S. processing of North Koreans seeking protection as refugees.

Birth Defects Prevention Act of 1993 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control, to award grants to, enter into cooperative agreements with, or provide direct technical assistance in lieu of cash to States, State health authorities, or health agencies of political subdivisions of a State for collection, analysis, and reporting of birth defects statistics from birth certificates, infant death certificates, hospital records, or other sources and to collect and disaggregate such statistics by gender and racial and ethnic group. 
Directs the Secretary to establish at least five regional birth defects monitoring and research programs for the purpose of collecting and analyzing information on the number, incidence, correlates, and causes of birth defects, including information regarding gender and different racial and ethnic groups.  Authorizes the Secretary to award grants or enter into cooperative agreements with State departments of health, universities, or other private, nonprofit entities engaged in research to enable such entities to serve as Centers of Excellence for Birth Defects Prevention Research.  Requires one of the Centers of Excellence to focus on birth defects among ethnic minorities, and to be located in a standard metropolitan statistical area that has over a 60 percent ethnic minority population, is federally designated as a health professional shortage area, and has an incidence of one or more birth defects more than four times the national average. 
Requires the Centers for Disease Control to serve as the coordinating agency for birth defects prevention activities through establishment of a clearinghouse for the collection and storage of data and generated from birth defects monitoring programs developed under this Act. 
Directs the Secretary to award grants to or enter into cooperative agreements with State departments of health, universities, or other private, or nonprofit entities to enable such entities to develop, evaluate, and implement prevention strategies designed to reduce the incidence and effects of birth defects, including demonstration projects for the prevention of birth defects and public information and education programs for the prevention of birth defects. 
Directs the Secretary to establish an Advisory Committee for Birth Defects Prevention.

50th Anniversary of the Texas Western College Men's Basketball Championship Commemorative Coin Act This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins emblematic of the game of basketball. The bill authorizes the issuance of such coins only during the one-year period beginning on January 1, 2017.
