All sales of such coins shall include a surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin, $10 per coin for the $1 coin, and $5 per coin for the half-dollar coin. All surcharges received from the sale of such coins shall be paid to the National Collegiate Basketball Hall of Fame to help finance renovations of existing facilities.

Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act - Amends the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 to: (1) reduce from 50 to 25 the number of employees in a covered employer's workforce required for an employee to be eligible for leave under such Act; (2) provide additional leave for parental involvement; and (3) extend such parental leave entitlement to Federal civil servants.

Millennium Challenge Compact Improvement Act (MCIA) - Amends the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 to: (1) limit the duration of a Millennium Challenge Compact to five years, with an exception for projects that cannot be completed in five years or less; and (2) allow eligible countries to enter into more than one Compact at any given time.

Authorizes regional assistance through a Compact with two or more countries in the same geographic region collectively.

Michelle's Law - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit a group health plan from terminating coverage of a dependent child due to a medically necessary leave of absence before the earlier of: (1) one year after the first day of such leave; or (2) the date on which such coverage would otherwise terminate under the terms of the plan. Defines "medically necessary leave of absence" as a leave of absence from a postsecondary educational institution that is due to a severe illness or injury, as certified by the attending physician of the dependent child involved, and that causes the dependent child involved to lose full-time student status.

Directs the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to assess and collect charges for utilization of radio and television communications sites located on Federal lands administered by the Forest Service or the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) at such rates as the Forest Service and BLM shall establish, or at modified rates established pursuant to this Act. 
Requires the Schedule of Charges to be reviewed annually by the Forest Service and BLM to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index.  Requires increases or decreases in charges to apply to all categories of charges, but any increase or decrease shall not total less than three percent or more than five percent of the charge assessed to the user in the preceding year.  Directs the BLM and the Forest Service to transmit to the Congress notification of any such adjustment not later than 60 days before the effective date of such adjustment. 
Provides for:  (1) a transition period during which site users are charged an amount equal to the amount they paid to the BLM or the Forest Service as of January 1, 1993, plus $1,000; and (2) continued payment of the higher amount until the charge to the site user in the Schedule of Charges equals or exceeds that amount. 
Requires a site user who is permitted under the terms of its site use authorization from the BLM or the Forest Service to grant access to the site to additional users to pay annually to the BLM or the Forest Service an amount equal to 25 percent of the gross income it receives from each such additional user during that year.  Requires site users to provide the BLM or the Forest Service with a certified list which identifies all additional users of such sites and all gross revenues received from such additional users.  Prohibits the BLM and the Forest Service from requiring any additional user of a radio or television communications site to obtain a separate authorization to use such a site. 
Directs the Secretaries to establish a broad-based advisory group, including representatives from the radio and television broadcast industry, to review the Schedule of Charges and other acceptable criteria for determining fair market value for radio and television communications site uses. 
Directs the Secretaries to jointly establish a broad-based advisory group comprised of representatives from the nonbroadcast communications industry (users of both private and public communication sites) and the two agencies to review recommendations on acceptable criteria for determining fair market values and next best alternative use.

Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to extend the Medicare prescription drug initial enrollment periods for 2006 and 2007.

Suspends the late enrollment penalty through December 31, 2007.

Allows open enrollment and disenrollment in prescription drug plans during the first 12 months of enrollment.

Prohibits a prescription drug plan sponsor from removing a covered part D drug from the plan formulary or imposing a restriction or limitation on the coverage of such a drug other than at the beginning of each plan year except as the Secretary of Health and Human Services may permit to take into account new therapeutic uses and newly covered part D drugs.

School Desegregation Litigation Reform Act of 1996 - Amends the Equal Educational Opportunities Act of 1974 to prohibit a Federal court from having jurisdiction to award prospective relief in any civil action with respect to the operation of public schools that extends further than necessary to remedy the violation of a Federal right of a plaintiff. 
Prohibits a Federal court from having jurisdiction to grant or approve any prospective relief unless the court finds that such relief is narrowly drawn, extends no further than necessary to remedy the violation of the Federal right, and is the least intrusive means necessary to remedy the violation of the Federal right. 
Prohibits a Federal court from having jurisdiction to order any prospective relief that requires or permits a government official to exceed authority under State or local law or otherwise violates State or local law, unless:  (1) Federal law requires such relief to be ordered in violation of State or local law; (2) the relief is necessary to remedy a violation of a Federal right; and (3) no other relief will remedy the violation of a Federal right. 
Prohibits a Federal court from having jurisdiction to enter a student assignment order unless:  (1) a Federal court has previously entered an order for less intrusive relief that has failed to remedy the violation of the Federal right sought to be remedied through the student assignment order; and (2) the defendant has had a reasonable time to comply with the previous court order. 
Requires a student assignment order to be entered only by a three-judge court. 
Sets forth provisions regarding termination of relief, settlements, procedure for motions affecting prospective relief, special masters, and intervention. 
Prohibits a State from denying equal educational opportunity to an individual on account of race, color, or national origin by:  (1) the intentional segregation by an educational agency of students on the basis of race, color, or national origin among or within schools; (2) the assignment or transfer of a student to a school other than the one closest to the place of residence within the school district in which the student resides if the assignment was made on the basis of race, color, or national origin of students among schools in the school district, including assignments made for the purpose of attaining a balance on the basis of race, color, or national origin, unless such assignment is necessary to remedy the violation of a Federal right and there are no other means for remedying the violation of the Federal right; or (3) the modification of the lines drawn by the State, subdividing its territory into separate school districts, if the modification was made for the purpose of attaining a balance, on the basis of race, color, or national origin, of students among public schools, unless such assignment is necessary to remedy the violation of a Federal right and there are no other means for remedying the violation of the Federal right.

Continuity of Electric Capacity Resources Act - Amends the Federal Power Act to require the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to notify each transmission organization with a tariff on file that includes provisions addressing the procurement of electric capacity resources that such organization is required to file a report with FERC. Requires such report to: (1) identify electric capacity resources available to the organization and describe their fuel sources and operational characteristics; (2) evaluate the financial health, viability, and projected remaining years of service of such resources; (3) identify announced and projected retirements of such resources over the short- and long-term periods in the organization's planning cycle, the organization's projected future needs for such resources, and the availability of transmission facilities and transmission support services necessary to provide reasonable assurances of essential reliability services; (4) assess the current and projected status of the reliability of the elements of the bulk-power system under the organization's control; and (5) have been made available to members of the organization and to the public for comment.

Requires the organization to file with FERC one or more tariff amendments that would achieve specified objectives, including: (1) a diverse generation portfolio and the availability of transmission facilities and transmission support services necessary to provide reasonable assurances of a continuous supply of electricity for customers at the proper voltage and frequency; (2) an enhanced opportunity for self-supply of electric capacity resources by electric cooperatives, federal power marketing agencies, and state utilities with a service obligation; (3) a reasonable assurance of short- and long-term reliability; and (4) a reasonable likelihood of prudent investment in, and adequate fuel supply for, existing and future electric capacity resources over the short- and long-term periods in the planning cycle identified in the applicable report.

Provides that any person subject to an order issued under the Federal Power Act shall not be liable for actions carried out in compliance with the order.

Strengthening Homeland Security, Intelligence, and Essential Law Enforcement Departments Act of 2011 or the SHIELD Act of 2011 - Provides for priority payments to members of the Armed Forces and critical federal law enforcement officers if the total public debt reaches the public debt limit.

Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to make available to the Secretary of Defense (and the Secretary of Homeland Security in the case of the Coast Guard) such amounts as the Secretary of Defense (and the Secretary of Homeland Security in the case of the Coast Guard) determines to be necessary to continue to provide pay and allowances to members of the Armed Forces during a period of lapsed appropriations.

Child Care Access and Refundability Expansion Act or the Child CARE Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make the tax credit for dependent care expenses refundable, (2) increase the dollar limitation of such credit, (3) allow a 50% credit for qualified dependent care expenses, and (4) impose an income limitation on such credit. Allows a business-related tax credit for 50% of child care educational expenses paid or incurred by a taxpayer with respect to the operation of a qualified child care center during the taxable year.

Lord's Resistance Army Disarmament and Northern Uganda Recovery Act - Directs the President to develop and submit to Congress a regional strategy to guide U.S. support for multilateral efforts to: (1) protect civilians from attacks by the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA); (2) eliminate the threat to civilians and regional stability posed by the LRA; and (3) enforce the rule of law and ensure full humanitarian access in LRA-affected areas.

Authorizes the President to provide assistance to respond to the humanitarian needs of populations in northeastern Congo, southern Sudan, and Central African Republic affected by the activity of the LRA.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should support efforts by the people of northern Uganda and the government of Uganda to: (1) assist internally displaced people in transition and returnees to secure durable solutions by spurring economic revitalization, supporting livelihoods, helping to alleviate poverty, and advancing access to basic services at return sites; (2) enhance the accountability and administrative competency of local governance institutions and public agencies in northern Uganda with regard to budget management, provision of public goods and services, and related oversight functions; (3) strengthen the operational capacity of the civilian police in northern Uganda to enhance public safety, prevent crime, and deal sensitively with gender-based violence, while strengthening accountability measures to prevent corruption and abuses; (4) rebuild and improve the capacity of the justice system in northern Uganda, including the courts and penal systems, with particular sensitivity to the needs and rights of women and children; (5) establish mechanisms for the disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration of former combatants, including vocational education and employment opportunities; and (6) promote programs to address psychosocial trauma, particularly post-traumatic stress disorder.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of State and Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) should work with Congress to increase assistance in future fiscal years to support such activities if the government of Uganda demonstrates a commitment to transparent and accountable reconstruction in war-affected areas of northern and eastern Uganda.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the President should support efforts by the people of northern Uganda and the government of Uganda to advance efforts to promote transitional justice and reconciliation on both local and national levels, including to implement specified mechanisms outlined in the Annexure to the Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation between the government of Uganda and the LRA/Movement, signed at Juba February 19, 2008.

Directs the President to report to Congress on: (1) actions taken by the executive branch to fulfill the sense of the House of Representatives expressed in House Resolution 185, passed on April 1, 2008; (2) actions taken to ensure that any statements that include a reference to the required resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue by the Quartet on the Middle East must also include a similarly explicit reference to the resolution of the issue of Jewish refugees from Arab countries; (3) assistance provided to Israel to help it accomplish its goal that the interests of Jews displaced from Arab countries are considered in any final settlement of the Middle East refugee question that is part of any comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace; and (4) recommended actions that would ensure that the interests of all refugees displaced from Arab countries are considered in any final settlement of the Middle East refugee question that is part of any comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace.

National Care Corps Act of 2014 - Establishes in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) a program to be known as the National Care Corps through which Corps members provide approved services to individuals in need via participation in local Care Corps programs. Requires the Director of the Corps to: (1) select eligible individuals for membership in the Corps, (2) provide for members to receive allowances, health insurance, and post-service educational awards, (3) assign each Corps member to participate in a local Care Corps program, and (4) develop a training program that provides Corps members with instruction in the skills necessary to carry out an assignment in a local Care Corps program.  Defines "individual in need" as an individual who is at least 65 years of age or has a disability, has difficulty with self-care, and meets other criteria determined by the Director.  Authorizes the Director to award grants to qualified entities for the operation of local Care Corps programs.

End Excessive Oil Speculation Now Act of 2011 - Directs the Chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to unilaterally: (1) establish speculative position limits in any registered entity on or through which crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, or heating oil futures or swaps are traded that are equal to the position accountability levels or position limits established by the New York Mercantile Exchange; (2) establish speculative position limits that are equal to the position accountability levels or position limits established by the New York Mercantile Exchange on the aggregate number or amount of positions in contracts based upon the same underlying commodity that may be held by any person for each month across contracts listed by designated contract markets, contracts traded on a foreign board of trade that provides members or other participants located in the United States with direct access to the electronic trading and order matching system of the foreign board of trade, and swap contracts that perform or affect a significant price discovery function with respect to regulated entities; (3) establish margin requirements of 12% for speculative swaps and futures trading in crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and heating oil; (4) require that each bank holding company, investment bank, hedge fund, or swaps dealer engaged in the trading of energy futures or swaps for the benefit of the bank holding company, investment bank, hedge fund, or swaps dealer or on the behalf of, or as counterparty to, an index fund, exchange traded fund, or other noncommercial participant register with the CFTC as a noncommercial participant and be subject to each position limit and margin requirement under this Act for each position in a manner by which the position is considered to be a speculative, proprietary position of the bank holding company, investment bank, hedge fund, or swaps dealer; (5) take any other action that the Chairman determines to be necessary to eliminate excessive speculation in the aggregate to ensure that the price of crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and heating oil accurately reflects the fundamentals of supply and demand; and (6) ensure that each bank holding company, hedge fund, investment bank, and swaps dealer that is engaged in the trading of energy futures or swaps for the benefit of the bank holding company, hedge fund, investment bank, and swaps dealer, or on the behalf of, or as counterparty to, one or more noncommercial participants abides by each position limit and margin requirement under this Act.

Exempts bona-fide hedge trading from such position limits and margin requirements.

Authorizes the Chairman to adjust any position limit to the extent that the position of all noncommercial participants or speculators shall not equal an amount greater than 35% of the annual, aggregate position of all traders in such futures and swaps market or markets for crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and heating oil trading.

Terminates this Act on the date on which the CFTC imposes position limits to diminish, eliminate, or prevent excessive speculation as required by, and increased margin requirements as authorized in, title VII of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.

Expresses the sense of Congress that, if finalized, the proposed position limits for derivatives that the CFTC included in the notice of proposed rulemaking entitled "Position Limits for Derivatives" are not sufficient to fulfill the statutory requirements of title VII of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act to diminish, eliminate, or prevent excessive speculation.

Fair Justice Act of 2001 - Establishes the Fair Justice Agency, an independent agency in the executive branch, to investigate and prosecute any alleged misconduct, criminal activity, corruption, or fraud by an officer or employee of the Department of Justice.

Justice for Sergei Magnitsky Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of State to publish a list of individuals believed to be responsible for the detention, abuse, or death of Sergei Magnitsky, who was a Russian tax consultant and whistleblower who died in custody after being arrested by the Russian Ministry of the Interior.

Makes an alien ineligible to receive a visa to enter the United States and ineligible to be admitted to the United States if the alien: (1) is on such list; or (2) is the spouse, son, daughter, or parent of an individual on that list. Directs the Secretary of State to revoke the visa or other documentation of any alien who would be ineligible to receive such a visa or documentation under this Act.

Authorizes the Secretary of State to waive the application of this Act in the case of an alien if the Secretary determines that such a waiver is in the national interests of the United States.

Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to instruct domestic financial institutions and domestic financial agencies to take special measures to freeze and prohibit all transactions in all property and interests in property of an individual that are in the United States, that come within the United States, or that are or come within the possession or control of a U.S. person if the individual: (1) is on such list; or (2) acts as an agent of or on behalf of an individual on the list in a matter relating to an act described in this Act. Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to waive the application of this Act in the case of an alien if the Secretary determines that such a waiver is in the national interests of the United States.

Subjects a person that violates, attempts to violate, conspires to violate, or causes a violation of this Act or any regulation, license, or order issued to carry out it to the penalties set forth in the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to the same extent as a person that commits an unlawful act described in such Act.

Terminates this Act when the Secretary of State and the Secretary of the Treasury certify to Congress that: (1) the government of the Russian Federation has conducted a thorough and impartial investigation into the detention, abuse, and resulting death in custody of Sergei Magnitsky and the conspiracy to defraud the Russian Federation of taxes on corporate profits and to misappropriate entities owned or controlled by Hermitage; (2) the investigation was properly conducted, transparent, and free of political influence; (3) the individuals responsible for the detention, abuse, or resulting death of Sergei Magnitsky or for the conspiracy have been brought to justice according to the laws of the Russian Federation and pursuant to its international legal obligations; and (4) the government of the Russian Federation has taken significant steps to bring the criminal justice system and penal system of the Russian Federation into compliance with applicable international legal standards, has substantially strengthened statutory protections for individuals who disclose evidence of illegal government activities, and has recognized the contribution of Sergei Magnitsky to the fight against corruption and for the rule of law.

Small Business Hardship Relief Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt small businesses from the employer health insurance mandate for five years if they experience a hardship. Defines "hardship" as: (1) missing two or more consecutive loan payments; (2) being a debtor in a bankruptcy case; (3) receiving a notice from a utility that it is preparing to stop providing services due to nonpayment of amounts owed; (4) receiving a notice of eviction of foreclosure; (5) experiencing a fire, flood, other natural or human-caused disaster that resulted in substantial damage to business property; or (6) experiencing such other hardship as the Secretary of the Treasury may determine.

Directs the Secretary to study and report to Congress on additional hardships which would be appropriate to add to the list of hardships.

Preventing Waste, Fraud, and Abuse Act of 2010 - Requires the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Social Security, the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Secretary of Labor, and the Secretary of the Treasury to: (1) identify existing federal laws and regulations that may impede the ability to decrease waste, fraud, and abuse of funds appropriated to their respective agencies; and (2) develop appropriate performance metrics to measure their agency's success in decreasing waste, fraud, and abuse.

Requires each agency head to make appropriate accommodations for innovation and development to address such program integrity efforts.

Requires each agency head to submit to Congress: (1) an interim report that includes a description of what the performance metrics developed will be measuring and how such metrics will measure and provide an accurate analysis of the performance of the applicable programs and activities; and (2) a final report that sets forth the performance metrics developed.

Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to submit to Congress an annual report measuring the success of each agency head's agency in decreasing waste, fraud, and abuse of funds appropriated to such agency.

Fort Sumner Project Title Conveyance Act - Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to convey to the Fort Sumner Irrigation District, located in De Baca County, New Mexico, all right and title of the United States in and to all works, land, and facilities of the Fort Sumner reclamation project, in accordance with the terms and conditions established in a specified agreement between the United States and the District that identifies the specific terms and conditions of the title transfer.

Requires the Secretary to assure compliance with all applicable requirements under: (1) the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969; (2) the Endangered Species Act of 1973; and (3) any other law applicable to the property conveyed.

Terminates the repayment contract between the United States and the District dated November 5, 1948, effective beginning on the date of the conveyance.

Welfare Improvement Act of 1997 - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act to prohibit a State from using any part of a TANF grant to provide cash benefits for a minor child who is born to:  (1) a recipient of assistance under the program; or (2) a person who received such assistance at any time during the ten-month period ending with the birth of the child. 
Makes exceptions for:  (1) children born into families with no other children; (2) vouchers which are provided in lieu of cash benefits and which may be used only to pay for particular goods and services specified by the State as suitable for the care of the child involved; (3) children who are born as a result of rape or incest; and (4) States that specifically exempt their TANF program from the application of this prohibition. 
Provides for substitution of family caps in effect under waivers. 
Prohibits recruitment activities under title XVI (Supplemental Security Income) (SSI). 
Revises requirements for mandatory termination of assistance if an individual in a family receiving assistance under the TANF program refuses to engage in work required in accordance with the program. 
Increases the work participation rate requirement for FY 2002 or thereafter. 
Prohibits payment of funds to a State unless it:  (1) establishes and maintains a reasonable program for randomly testing an individual in a family receiving assistance under the TANF program for the use of controlled substances; and (2) terminates assistance under the TANF program for any individual who tests positive for the use of controlled substances.

Deficit Reduction Check-Off Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow every individual, regardless of income tax liability for the taxable year, to designate that an amount (not less than $1 and not more than $10) shall be paid over for the purpose of reducing the deficit of the United States. In the case of a joint return of husband and wife, each spouse may so designate an amount.

Amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to require a sequestration to eliminate the deficit equivalent to ten times the amount designated under this Act.

True Cost of War Act of 2011 - Directs the President to report to Congress an estimate of the long-term costs of Operation New Dawn (the successor contingency operation to Operation Iraqi Freedom) and Operation Enduring Freedom for each of three scenarios: (1) a reduction in the number of members of the Armed Forces deployed in support of such operations; (2) an increase in the number of members of the Armed Forces deployed in support of such operations; and (3) an alternative scenario determined by the President based on current contingency operation and withdrawal plans.

Overseas Citizens Voting Rights Act of 1996 - Amends the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act to:  (1) permit absentee ballots to be received at least until the close of polls on election day; (2) extend Federal write-in absentee ballot provisions to special, primary, and runoff elections; (3) require each State, in cooperation with the Presidential designee, to consider means for providing for expeditious methods for the return of absentee ballots, including return by electronic transmittal, with maximum regard for ballot secrecy, audit procedures, and other considerations relating to the integrity of the election process; (4) prohibit any electronic transmittal or related procedure that is paid for, in whole or in part, with Federal funds from being carried out in any manner that permits any person other than the voter to view a completed ballot or otherwise compromises ballot secrecy; (5) require each State, in cooperation with the Presidential designee, to establish a system for electronic transmittal of balloting materials for overseas voters; and (6) require the Presidential designee to report to the Congress on any method of electronic transmittal before approval.

Computer Crime Enforcement Act - Directs the Office of Justice Programs to make grants to States for use in conjunction with local governments, courts, other States, or combinations thereof to: (1) assist State and local law enforcement in enforcing criminal laws relating to computer crime; (2) assist State and local law enforcement in educating the public to prevent and identify computer crime; (3) assist in educating and training State and local law enforcement officers and prosecutors to conduct investigations and forensic analyses of evidence and prosecutions of computer crime; (4) assist State and local law enforcement officers and prosecutors in acquiring computer and other equipment to conduct investigations and forensic analysis of evidence of computer crimes; and (5) facilitate and promote the sharing of Federal law enforcement expertise and information about the investigation, analysis, and prosecution of computer crimes with State and local law enforcement officers and prosecutors, including the use of multijurisdictional task forces. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Secure Online Communication Enforcement Act of 2000 - Amends the Federal criminal code to authorize a governmental entity to require a provider of remote computing service to disclose the contents of any electronic communication pursuant to: (1) a warrant issued under the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure or equivalent State warrant, a copy of which warrant shall be served on the subscriber or customer of such remote computing service before or at the same time the warrant is served on the provider; or (2) a Federal or State grand jury or trial subpoena, a copy of which subpoena shall be served on the subscriber or customer of such remote computing service under circumstances allowing the subscriber or customer a meaningful opportunity to challenge the subpoena. 
Applies limitations on disclosure of communication records to an operator of an Internet Web site (including an agent of such operator) or other third party. 
Prohibits a provider of electronic communication service or remote computing service or operator of an Internet Web site from terminating the provision of such service or access to or use of such Internet Web site to an individual who refuses to consent to the disclosure of records or other information as a result of such refusal.

Fair Pay Act of 1997 - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to prohibit discrimination in compensation for equal work on the basis of sex, race, or national origin. 
Prohibits employers from reducing the wage rate of any employee in order to comply with such prohibition. 
Prohibits labor organizations or their agents representing employees of an employer having employees subject to such provisions from causing or attempting to cause such an employer to discriminate against an employee in violation of such prohibition. 
Deems any amounts owing to any employee which have been withheld in violation of such prohibition to be unpaid minimum wages or unpaid overtime compensation under such Act. 
Prohibits:  (1) employers from discriminating against any individual because such individual has opposed any act or practice made unlawful by this Act or because such individual made a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in any manner in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under this Act; and (2) employers from discharging or in any other manner discriminating against, coercing, intimidating, threatening, or interfering with any employee or any other person because the employee inquired about, disclosed, compared, or otherwise discussed the employee's wages or the wages of any other employee, or because the employee exercised, enjoyed, aided, or encouraged any other person to exercise or enjoy any right granted or protected by this Act. 
Requires courts, in any action brought under this Act for violation of such prohibition, to allow expert fees as part of the costs.  Allows any such action to be maintained as a class action. 
Requires every employer subject to such prohibition to preserve records which document and support the method, system, calculations, and other bases used by the employer in establishing, adjusting, and determining the wages paid to the employees of the employer.  Requires every employer subject to such prohibition to preserve such records for such periods of time and to make such reports therefrom to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) as shall be prescribed by the EEOC by regulation or order as necessary or appropriate for the enforcement of the provisions of this Act or any regulations promulgated thereunder. 
Requires every employer subject to such prohibition to file annually with the EEOC a report signed by its president, treasurer, or corresponding principal officer containing information in such detail as may be necessary accurately to disclose the wage or salary rates paid to each classification, position, job title, or other wage or salary group of employees employed by the employer, as well as the sex, race, and national origin of employees at each wage or salary level in each classification, position, job title, or other wage or salary group.  Prohibits the report from containing the name of any individual employee. 
Makes the contents of the reports filed with the EEOC public information.  Authorizes the EEOC to publish any information and data it obtains pursuant to the provisions of this Act.  Authorizes the EEOC to use the information and data for statistical and research purposes, and compile and publish studies, analyses, reports, and surveys based thereon as it may deem appropriate. 
Directs the EEOC to undertake studies and provide information and technical assistance to employers, labor organizations, and the general public concerning effective means available to implement the provisions of this Act prohibiting wage discrimination between employees performing work in equivalent jobs on the basis of sex, race, or national origin.

Safe and Secure Border Infrastructure Act - Directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish a grant program to construct transportation and supporting infrastructure improvements at existing and new international border crossings to facilitate the safe, secure, and efficient cross-border movement of motor vehicles, non-motor vehicles, cargo, and individuals, including pedestrians.

Requires the Secretary to give priority to projects that accomplish one or more of the following objectives: (1) improve the safety and security at facilities in the United States, including ports of entry; (2) facilitate safe, secure, and legal trade crossings of motor vehicles, non-motor vehicles, cargo, and individuals, including pedestrians, to alleviate border congestion and reduce the economic effect of border wait times and delays; (3) implement innovative technologies that enhance safety, security, or efficiency at the border; (4) coordinate a system of projects that improve security and systems efficiencies at ports of entry; (5) facilitate economic development strategies with respect to safety and security; and (6) implement congestion relief and air quality management strategies to improve the environment.

Women's Business Procurement Assistance Act of 1993 - Amends the Small Business Act to require Federal agencies to set goals for participation by small business concerns owned and controlled by women in Federal procurement contracts. 
Requires Federal agencies to report annually on their progress toward meeting such goals. 
Directs the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA) to include in the contract clause of a contract with a prime contractor for the performance of a contract or subcontract for which the SBA has a small business program, a requirement that the prime contractor use specified percentages of the contract amount for small businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals and women. 
Requires the Director of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization in a Federal agency to designate an employee of such office to be a women-in-business specialist responsible for the implementation and execution of programs designed to assist small business concerns owned and controlled by women. 
Requires each Federal agency having procurement powers to engage in affirmative efforts to identify and solicit offers from small business concerns owned and controlled by women and the small business concerns owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. 
Establishes in the SBA the Office of Women's Business Ownership. 
Directs the Comptroller General to submit to the Congress a report comparing the number of small business concerns owned and controlled by women procuring Federal contracts during the year preceding the date of enactment of this Act with the number of such businesses during each of the three years occurring after such date.

Answer Africa's Call Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an additional individual income tax surcharge of 0.8 percent on adjusted gross incomes exceeding $500,000 ($1 million for joint returns) through 2010.

Establishes in the Treasury the United States International Finance Facility Trust Fund to receive such surtax revenues and make expenditures in connection with U.S. commitments to the International Finance Facility.

Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to remove the agriculture tariff-rate quota limitation from duty-free treatment of agricultural products from beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries.

Amends the African Growth and Opportunity Act to revise the short supply provisions for articles that are both cut (or knit-to-shape) and sewn or otherwise assembled in one or more beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries.

Revises the user developed beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries provision to: (1) extend the 2.9285 percent rate for the 1-year period beginning October 2, 2005, and for each 1-year period thereafter through September 30, 2015; and (2) apply a five percent rate to Mauritius.

Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee Act - Establishes the Great Lakes Protection and Restoration Committee to study and report on programs established and carried out to achieve restoration goals for the Great Lakes prepared by the Governors of Great Lakes States (Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin) and to make recommendations for prioritization of such goals, legislation and funding to achieve such goals, and improvement of coordination among programs and governments with respect to such goals.
Amends the Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act of 1988 to revise provisions regarding the sale of net operating losses by a Native Corporation.

Government Travel Cost Reduction Act - Requires the General Services Administration (GSA) or any agency entering into a contract with an air carrier for travel on official business to include as a term of such contract that such air carrier shall: (1) establish a separate air travel business account for any employee, designated by the head of the agency employing such employee, for travel on official business by such employee on such air carrier; (2) deposit any award or bonus by such air carrier awarded to such employee for travel on official business into the employee's air travel business account; and (3) apply any such award or bonus from such employee's air travel business account to any travel on official business by such employee on such air carrier, except that such awards or bonuses shall not be used for seating upgrades. Authorizes the GSA to include as a term of such contract that such air carrier shall: (1) establish an air travel business account for any office or administrative unit of an agency, as designated by the head of such agency, for travel on official business by employees of such office or administrative unit on such air carrier; (2) deposit any award or bonus by such air carrier awarded to any employee of such office or administrative unit for travel on official business into the air travel business account of such office or administrative unit; and (3) apply any such award or bonus from the air travel business account of such office or administrative unit to any travel on official business by any employee of such office or administrative unit, except that such awards or bonuses shall not be used for seating upgrades. Requires all air travel business accounts established under this Act to be separate from any personal account of an employee.  Directs the GSA to promulgate regulations to carry out this Act, including a requirement that, to the greatest extent practicable to maximize travel costs savings, employees shall: (1) travel on official business with air carriers awarding awards and bonuses for official business travel, regardless of whether such travel is on an air carrier under a contract described in this Act; and (2) participate in any program of such air carrier awarding awards and bonuses and use such awards and bonuses for only official business travel, except that such awards shall not be used for seating upgrades.  Requires the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration and the House Committee on Administration to promulgate regulations relating to Members of Congress and any employee whose pay is disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate or the Clerk of the House of Representatives that require any Member of the Senate, officer of the Senate, Member of the House of Representatives, or officer of the House of Representatives who enters into a contract with an air carrier for travel on official business by a Member or employee to include as a term of such contract that such air carrier shall: (1) establish a separate air travel business account for any Member or employee, designated by the applicable Member or employing committee or office of such employee, for travel on official business by such Member or employee on such air carrier; (2) deposit any award or bonus by such air carrier awarded to such Member or employee for travel on official business into the Member's or employee's air travel business account; and (3) apply any such award or bonus from such Member's or employee's air travel business account to any travel on official business by such Member or employee on such air carrier, except that such awards or bonuses shall not be used for seating upgrades. Authorizes the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration and the House Committee on Administration to include as a term of such contract that such air carrier shall: (1) establish an air travel business account for any committee or office as designated by the applicable Member, committee, or office, for travel on official business by Members or employees of such committee or office on such air carrier; (2) deposit any award or bonus by such air carrier awarded to any Member or employee of such committee or office for travel on official business into the air travel business account of such committee or office; and (3) apply any such award or bonus from the air travel business account of such committee or office to any travel on official business by any Member or employee of such committee or office, except that such awards or bonuses shall not be used for seating upgrades. Requires all air travel business accounts established under this Act to be separate from any personal account of a Member or employee.  Requires any Member of Congress or officer of the Congress entering into a contract as provided under this Act to include the term described above to maximize costs savings.

HOPE VI Program Reauthorization and Small Community Mainstreet Rejuvenation and Housing Act of 2003 - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to revise the selection criteria for awarding grants under the HOPE VI program. Authorizes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to make such grants to smaller communities to provide assistance to carry out eligible affordable housing activities in connection with an eligible project that: (1) is a main street project; (2) is carried out within the jurisdiction of the smaller community receiving the grant; and (3) involves the development of affordable housing located in the commercial area that is the subject of the project.

Weekends Without Hunger Act - Amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to establish a program under which the Secretary shall provide commodities, on a competitive basis, to eligible institutions to provide nutritious food to at-risk children on weekends and during extended school holidays during the school year.

Defines "eligible institution" as a public or private nonprofit institution that is determined by the Secretary to be able to meet safe food storage, handling, and delivery standards established by the Secretary. Includes an elementary or secondary school or school food service authority, a food bank or food pantry, a homeless shelter, and other emergency feeding agencies approved by the Secretary.

Requires the Secretary to give priority to eligible institutions that: (1) have ongoing programs and experience serving populations with significant proportions of at-risk school children; (2) have a good record of experience in food delivery and food safety systems; (3) maintain high quality control, accountability, and recordkeeping standards; (4) provide children with readily consumable food of high nutrient content and quality; (5) demonstrate cost efficiencies and the potential for obtaining supplemental funding from non-federal sources to carry out projects; and (6) demonstrate the ability to continue projects for the full approved term of the pilot project period.

Directs the Secretary to issue guidelines containing the criteria for projects to receive commodities under this Act. Requires such guidelines to take into account: (1) geographical variations in project locations to include qualifying projects in rural, urban, and suburban areas with high proportions of families with at-risk school children; (2) different types of projects that offer nutritious foods on weekends and during school holidays to at-risk school children; and (3) institutional capacity to collect, maintain, and provide statistically valid information necessary for the Secretary to analyze and evaluate the results of the pilot project and make recommendations to Congress.

Requires the Secretary to complete an interim evaluation of the pilot program carried out under this Act by November 30, 2013, and submit to Congress a final report that contains an evaluation of the pilot program and any recommendations for legislative action by December 31, 2015.

Assessing Progress in Haiti Act of 2014 - Expresses the sense of Congress that transparency, accountability, democracy, and good governance are integral factors in any congressional decision regarding U.S. assistance, including assistance to Haiti. Directs the Secretary of State to report annually through December 31, 2017, on the status of post-earthquake recovery and development efforts in Haiti. Requires the Secretary, acting through the Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs, to coordinate and transmit to specified congressional committees a three-year Haiti strategy based on rigorous assessments that: (1) identifies and addresses constraints to sustainable, broad-based economic growth and to the consolidation of responsive, democratic government institutions; (2) includes an action plan that outlines policy tools, technical assistance, and anticipated resources for addressing the highest-priority constraints to economic growth and the consolidation of democracy, as well as a specific description of mechanisms for monitoring and evaluating progress; and (3) identifies specific steps and verifiable benchmarks appropriate to provide direct bilateral assistance to the government of Haiti.

Community Services Block Grant Amendments of 1994 - Amends the Community Services Block Grant Act to revise provisions regarding the community initiative program. 
Repeals the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to local, private, nonprofit community development corporations for economic development activities in economically distressed communities. 
Repeals the requirement that each community development corporation receiving funds under such program be governed by a board that shall consist of residents of the community and business and civic leaders. 
Repeals the requirement that the Secretary annually publish a statement of the types of projects or activities for which funding under such program will be a priority. 
Repeals the requirement that the Secretary take into consideration the geographic distribution of funds among States and the relative proportion of funding among rural and urban areas. 
Repeals the authority of the Secretary to reserve up to one percent of amounts made available to carry out such program for each fiscal year to make grants to private nonprofit organizations or to enter into contracts with private nonprofit or for profit organizations to provide technical assistance to aid community development corporations in developing or implementing projects funded under such program and to evaluate projects funded under such program. 
Repeals the Community Food and Nutrition Program. 
Repeals the Demonstration Partnership Agreements. 
Requires the Secretary to make allotments of funds for FY 1995 through 1998. 
Repeals the requirement that the Secretary reserve $35 million for each fiscal year for carrying out the community initiative program. 
Repeals the authority of the Secretary to reserve not more than one-half of one percent of the amount remaining after the application of such requirement for each of the fiscal years 1995 and 1996, and up to one percent of such amount for fiscal year 1997 and each fiscal year thereafter, for training, technical assistance, planning, and evaluation activities related to programs or projects carried out under the Community Services Block Grant Act. 
Repeals the authority of the Secretary to reserve not more than two and one-half percent of the amount remaining after the application of such requirement for fiscal year 1995, up to four percent of such amount for fiscal year 1996, up to five percent of such amount for fiscal year 1997, and up to six percent of such amount for fiscal year 1998, for grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to address needs or problems of the poor which are identified by the Secretary as priorities in the effort to alleviate the causes of poverty. 
Revises requirements for applications and requirements for community services block grant programs.

Medicare Telemedicine and Medical Informatics Demonstration Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, to make a grant to an eligible grantee to provide for a four-year demonstration project to apply high-capacity computing and advanced networks to the provision of health care to residents of medically underserved rural and inner-city areas. 
Requires the project to focus on:  (1) improvements in primary care and prevention of complications for those residents with diabetes mellitus; and (2) those residents who are Medicare beneficiaries. 
Sets forth project objectives, including improving patient access to and compliance with appropriate care guidelines for chronic diseases through direct telecommunications link with information networks, developing a curriculum to train and provide standards for credentialing and licensure of health professionals in the use of medical informatics and telecommunications, demonstrating the application of advanced technologies to assist primary care providers in assisting patients with chronic illnesses in a home setting, applying medical informatics to residents with limited English language skills, developing standards in the application of telemedicine and medical informatics, and developing a model for the cost-effective delivery of primary and related care both in a managed care environment and in a fee-for-service environment. 
Sets forth requirements for eligible grantees, including that they be located in an area with a high concentration of medical schools and tertiary care facilities and have appropriate arrangements with such schools and facilities, universities, and telecommunications providers. 
Sets forth provisions regarding the use of funds, including that Federal payments made available to an eligible grantee under this Act shall be used for the development and operation of telemedicine and medical informatics systems and related activities under the project.

Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to conduct and support research that utilizes human embryonic stem cells (regardless of the date on which the stem cells were derived from a human embryo).

Requires human embryonic stem cells to be eligible for use in any research conducted or supported by the Secretary if the cells meet each of the following: (1) the stem cells were derived from human embryos that have been donated from in vitro fertilization clinics, were created for the purposes of fertility treatment, and were in excess of the clinical need of the individuals seeking such treatment; (2) prior to the consideration of embryo donation and through consultation with the individuals seeking fertility treatment, it was determined that the embryos would never be implanted in a woman and would otherwise be discarded; and (3) the individuals seeking fertility treatment donated the embryos with written informed consent and without receiving any financial or other inducements to make the donation.

Directs the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to issue guidelines on research involving human embryonic stem cells and may issue guidelines on research involving other human stem cells as determined to be scientifically warranted. Requires the Director to review and update such guidelines when scientifically warranted.

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) in developing, updating, and implementing such guidelines, the Director should consult with the Commissioner of Food and Drugs; (2) any research using human stem cells should comply with such guidelines; and (3) the Commissioner should keep the Director informed of the types of human stem cell and related research that would facilitate the evaluation of the safety or effectiveness of drugs, devices, and biological products.

Enhancing Educational Opportunities for all Students Act - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to allow a state educational agency (SEA) to allocate grant funds under title I (Improving the Academic Achievement of the Disadvantaged) among local educational agencies (LEAs) based on the number of eligible children enrolled in public schools served by each LEA and the state-accredited private schools within each LEA's geographic jurisdiction. Defines "eligible child" as a child aged 5 through 17 from a family with an income below the poverty level. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) allow home school expenses as qualified education expenses for purposes of a Coverdell Education Savings Account, (2) eliminate the Coverdell Education Savings Account contribution limitation, and (3) expand the definition of "qualified education expenses" for purposes of a tax-exempt education savings plan to include qualified pre-kindergarten, elementary, and secondary education expenses.

National Forest Good Neighbor Act of 2017 This bill amends the Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978 to authorize the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to enter into a good neighbor agreement with a governor to carry out authorized restoration services. The bill defines "authorized restoration services" as similar and complementary forest, rangeland, and watershed restoration services carried out: (1) on National Forest System land, except a component of the National Wilderness Preservation System, federal land on which the removal of vegetation is prohibited or restricted by a law of Congress or a presidential proclamation, or a wilderness study area; and (2) by USDA or a governor pursuant to a good neighbor agreement.  The bill defines "good neighbor agreement" as a cooperative agreement or contract entered into between USDA and a governor to carry out authorized restoration services.  The bill states that the National Forest Management Act of 1976 does not apply to authorized restoration services.
Dairy Farmer Viability Act - Establishes the Dairy Farmer Viability Commission to study and report to the President and Congress on matters relating to improving the viability of dairy farming.

Hunt Unrestricted on National Treasures Act or the HUNT Act - Requires each head of a federal public land management agency (National Park Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, or Bureau of Land Management) to make available to the public on its website: (1) a list of the location and acreage of land more than 640 acres in size under the jurisdiction of such agency on which the public is allowed to hunt, fish, or use the land for other recreational purposes to which there is no public access or egress or to which public access or egress to the legal boundaries of the land is significantly restricted; (2) with respect to such land, a list of the locations and acreage that the head of the agency determines have significant potential for use for hunting, fishing, and other recreational purposes; and (3) with respect to such land, a plan developed by the agency that identifies how public access and egress could reasonably be provided to the legal boundaries of the land in a manner that minimizes the impact on wildlife habitat and water quality, specifies the actions recommended to secure the access and egress, including acquiring an easement, right-of-way, or fee title from a willing owner of any land that abuts the land or the need to coordinate with state land management agencies or other federal or state governmental entities to allow for such access and egress, and is consistent with the travel management plan in effect on the land.

Requires each head of a federal public land management agency to make available to the public on its website, and thereafter revise as appropriate, a list of roads or trails that provide the primary public access and egress to the legal boundaries of contiguous parcels of land equal to more than 640 acres in size under the jurisdiction of such agency on which the public is allowed to hunt, fish, or use the land for other recreational purposes.

Amends the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 to require that at least 1.5% of the funds appropriated for the Land and Water Conservation Fund be used for projects that secure public access to federal land for hunting, fishing, and other recreational purposes through easements, rights-of-way, or fee title acquisitions from willing sellers.

Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from the payroll tax for employers and employees wages paid by a qualified employer (any employer other than the United States, any state, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing) to a qualified individual (any individual who begins employment with a qualified employer after February 3, 2010, and before January 1, 2011, and who certifies by signed affidavit that such individual has not been employed for more than 40 hours during the 60-day period ending on the date such individual begins such employment) for services performed in a trade or business of such qualified employer or in furtherance of the activities related to the purpose or function constituting the basis of the employer's tax-exempt status.

Allows a qualified employer to elect to have this exemption not apply.

Increases the current year business credit for increasing employment by $1,000 for each retained worker. Defines "retained worker" as any qualified individual who was employed by the taxpayer on any date during the taxable year, who was so employed by the taxpayer for a period of at least 52 consecutive weeks, and whose wages for such employment during the last 26 weeks of such period equaled at least 80% of such wages for the first 26 weeks of such period.

NOAA Corps Disestablishment Act - Provides for the conversion of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Corps to the civilian service. 
Provides a conversion benefit to each conversion-eligible officer converted to the civilian service.  Requires any officer leaving NOAA within 180 days after such conversion to refund to the Treasury an amount equal to five percent of the product of:  (1) the member's years of active service; and (2) 12 times the monthly basic pay to which the member is entitled on the date of the disestablishment of the NOAA Corps. 
Makes each conversion-eligible officer converted to the civilian service eligible immediately to make an election to contribute to the Thrift Savings Fund. 
Provides for credit for unused leave. 
Authorizes appropriations to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for the Federal Employee Retirement System supplemental liability created by granting service credit under this Act. 
Directs the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere to establish additional civilian positions in NOAA as necessary for fulfilling essential mission functions. 
Disestablishes the NOAA Corps as of October 1, 1997. 
Provides for noncompetitive appointment eligibility for any competitive service position within the Department of Commerce for which the officer meets the minimum qualification requirements. 
Requires each conversion-eligible officer who has not signed a conversion agreement to be involuntarily separated from the NOAA Corps not later than September 30, 1997. 
Amends the Coast and Geodetic Survey Commissioned Officers Act of 1948 to repeal certain provisions regarding the Coast and Geodetic Survey Commissioned Officers Corps.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: 
     Title I:  Trade Remedy Actions 
     Title II:  Extension and Modification of Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act 
Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 - 
Title I:  Trade Remedy Actions
 - Provides that any act, policy, or practice of a deficit foreign country that adversely affects the access to such country's market of motor vehicle parts produced by U.S. motor vehicle parts manufacturers shall be considered as an act, policy, or practice of a foreign country that is unjustifiable and burdens or restricts U.S. commerce.  Directs the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to proceed to determine what action to take under the Trade Act of 1974 to obtain the elimination of such act, policy, or practice. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) negotiation agenda; and (2) additional estimates and consequential effect. 
Directs the Secretary of Commerce to commence an investigation to determine if imports of motor vehicle parts into the United States that are products of any deficit foreign country, or sales (or the likelihood of sales) of such parts for importation into the United States, constitute grounds for the imposition of antidumping duties. 
Title II:  Extension and Modification of Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act
 - Amends the Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act of 1988 to extend through December 31, 1998, the authority of the Secretary of Commerce to investigate and report to the President on alleged unfair trade practices with respect to auto parts and accessories. 
Requires the Secretary to coordinate:  (1) U.S. policy regarding auto parts and the market for auto parts; and (2) the sharing of data and market information among the relevant departments and agencies of the U.S. Government, including the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Justice, the Department of Commerce, and the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative.

Preventing Iran's Access to United States Dollars Act of 2016 This bill prohibits the President from issuing any license under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act that permits a person to: (1) conduct an offshore U.S. dollar clearing system for transactions involving the government of Iran or an Iranian person, or (2) provide U.S. dollars for any offshore U.S. dollar clearing system conducted or overseen by a foreign government or a foreign financial institution for such transactions. The Department of the Treasury shall report to Congress and publish in the Federal Register on a regular basis a list of any financial institutions identified as operating an offshore U.S. dollar clearing system that conducts transactions involving the government of Iran or an Iranian person. The President shall block and prohibit all transactions in all property and interests in property of any financial institution specified in the most recent list submitted if such property and interests are in the United States, come within the United States, or are or come within the possession or control of a U.S. person. The President may impose additional sanctions with respect to a financial institution that is subject to such sanctions. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 is amended to clarify that freezing of assets of Iranian financial institutions includes assets in possession or control of a U.S. person pursuant to a U-turn transaction.

Consumer Affordable Transaction Account Act of 2001 - Requires each insured depository institution to make available to consumers an affordable transaction account with specified features, including: (1) a minimum number of free withdrawals; and (2) a maximum monthly service charge.

Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017 or the LOVE Act of 2017 This bill directs the Director General of the Foreign Service and the Department of State's Director of Human Resources to review all employee terminations that occurred after January 1, 1950, to determine who was wrongfully terminated owing to their sexual orientation. The Director General shall compile the information in a publicly available report. The State Department shall: (1) establish an independent Reconciliation Board to review the reports released by the Director General and the Director of Human Resources; (2) work with the current public-private partnership associated with the Department's new United States Diplomacy Center to establish a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" in the museum; and (3) submit to Congress a report on countries not issuing visas to the spouses of all Foreign Service personnel posted overseas due to their sexual orientation. The State Department shall establish, within the Office of the Director General, a board comprised of senior-level officials to address the issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families.

Alcohol Tax Equalization Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase excise taxes on wine and beer to the alcoholic equivalent of taxes on distilled spirits. 
Establishes in the Treasury the Mental Health and Substance Abuse Benefits Trust Fund, consisting of amounts equivalent to additional taxes received under this Act.  Makes such amounts available for purposes of providing mental health and substance abuse benefits under health care reform legislation enacted hereafter.

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to carry out in FY2010: (1) construction for the realignment of services and closure projects at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Livermore, California; (2) construction of a Multi-Specialty Care Facility in Walla Walla, Washington; (3) construction for a new medical facility at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Louisville, Kentucky; (4) replacement of the existing Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Denver, Colorado; and (5) construction of Outpatient and Inpatient Improvements in Bay Pines, Florida.

Authorizes the Secretary to carry out in FY2010 major medical facility leases at specified locations.

Authorizes appropriations.

Mexican Agricultural Trade Compliance Act - Declares that the rights of the United States under the Uruguay Round Agreements are being denied by Mexico in connection with the imposition by Mexico of a 20 percent tax on soft drinks containing high fructose corn syrup, an extension by other means of Mexico's unjustified antidumping order on high fructose corn syrup from the United States.

Secondary Payer Advancement, Rationalization, and Clarification Act or the SPARC Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to revise Medicare prescription drug secondary claims responsibility.

White House Inspector General Act of 1996 - Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to establish an Office of Inspector General for the Executive Office of the President. 
Requires the Inspector General of the Executive Office of the President to be under the authority, direction, and control of the President with respect to audits or investigations, or the issuance of subpoenas, which require access to information concerning:  (1) ongoing criminal investigations or proceedings; (2) undercover operations; (3) the identity of confidential sources, including protected witnesses; (4) deliberations and decisions on policy matters, including documented information used as a basis for making policy decisions; (5) intelligence or counterintelligence matters; or (6) other matters the disclosure of which would constitute a serious threat to the national security, or would cause significant impairment to the national interests (including interests in foreign trade negotiations), of the United States. 
Authorizes the President to prohibit the Inspector General from carrying out or completing any audit or investigation, or issuing any subpoena, after the Inspector General has decided to initiate, carry out, or complete such audit or investigation or to issue such subpoena, if the President determines that:  (1) the disclosure of that information would interfere with the core functions of the constitutional responsibilities of the President; and (2) the prohibition is necessary to prevent the disclosure of that information. 
Requires the Inspector General to include in each semiannual report to the President:  (1) a list of the title or subject of each inspection, investigation, or audit conducted during the reporting period; (2) a statement of whether corrective action has been completed on each significant recommendation described in previous semiannual reports, and, in a case where corrective action has been completed, a description of such corrective action; (3) a certification that the Inspector General has had full and direct access to all information relevant to the performance of functions of the Inspector General; (4) a description of all cases occurring during the reporting period in which the Inspector General could not obtain documentary evidence relevant to any inspection, audit, or investigation due to a determination of the President; and (5) recommendations concerning legislation to promote economy and efficiency in the administration of programs and operations undertaken by the Executive Office of the President, and to detect and eliminate fraud, waste, and abuse in such programs and operations.

Consumer Protection and Choice Act This bill amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit deferred presentment transactions, except as authorized by this bill. A deferred presentment transaction is a transaction in which currency or other payment instrument is provided to a consumer in exchange for a consumer's check or other payment instrument and an agreement that such consumer's check or other payment instrument shall be held for a deferment period prior to presentment, deposit, or redemption.  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) may not promulgate or enforce any regulation related to deferred presentment providers with respect to deferred presentment transactions during the 24-month period beginning on the date of enactment of this bill. The CFPB may not impose any additional requirements related to deferred presentment providers with respect to deferred presentment transactions in a state if such state has enacted a covered deferred presentment law by the effective date of this bill. The CFPB may not regulate payday loans during the 24-month period beginning on the date of enactment of this bill. The CFPB may regulate payday loans in a state after such period only if such state has not enacted a covered deferred presentment law.

Stop Iran From Smuggling Weapons to Terrorists Act This bill authorizes the Department of Defense (DOD), with the concurrence of the Department of State, to provide training to the national military or other security forces of Israel, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Kuwait, and Qatar that have among their functional responsibilities maritime security missions. The provision of assistance and training may be referred to as the Counter Iran Maritime Initiative.  Training provided shall include elements that promote: (1) observance of and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms; and (2) respect for legitimate civilian authority within the country to which the assistance is provided.  DOD shall negotiate a cost-sharing agreement with a recipient country regarding the cost of any training provided. The agreement shall set forth the terms of cost sharing that DOD determines are necessary and appropriate, but such terms shall not be less than 50% of the overall cost of the training.  Assistance and training may not be provided after September 30, 2021.

World Trade Center Zone Tax Incentive Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide that, if there is a qualified headquarters relocation of an eligible foreign corporation, any qualified headquarters activities of the corporation conducted in the New York Liberty Zone shall be treated as conducted outside the United States for purposes of determining: (1) the amount of any tax imposed on the corporation or the amount of withholding tax on the corporation; and (2) whether the corporation has a permanent establishment within the United States for purposes of any applicable income tax treaty between the United States and any foreign country.

Defines "qualified headquarters relocation" as any relocation of an eligible foreign corporation's qualified headquarters activities to the New York Liberty Zone but only if the corporation with respect to such relocation: (1) before September 11, 2007, enters into a contract under which the corporation agrees to acquire, lease, sublease, or otherwise occupy office space located in the New York Liberty Zone for use in the conduct of the activities to be relocated, and which requires a substantial financial commitment or provides a substantial cancellation penalty; and (2) before September 11, 2009, transfers to the New York Liberty Zone qualified headquarters activities meeting specified requirements and locates employees in the New York Liberty Zone in accordance with specified requirements.

So No Innocent Person Ever Repeats the Sniper Tragedy Act of 2003 or the SNIPER Act of 2003 - Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to require the Attorney General to inspect or examine the inventory and records of a licensed importer, manufacturer, dealer, or collector who is found in violation of such Act at least four times during any 12-month period. Requires the Attorney General to inspect or examine the inventory and records of such a violator at least once each year during the three years following such violation.

Requires the Attorney General to issue a warning letter to a licensee who has violated any provision of this Act, and maintain a copy of such letter, along with any written report prepared by the inspector: (1) in the files of the appropriate Director of Industry Operations; and (2) at the headquarters of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF).

Requires the Attorney General to require the Director of Industry Operations of ATF to issue a final decision within 120 days from the date on which a notice of revocation, suspension, or imposition of a civil fine is mailed to a licensee.

Prohibits the effective date of a final decision from being postponed unless so ordered by a U.S. district court judge or magistrate who has jurisdiction over the matter.

Makes enforcement action not dependent upon criminal conviction.

Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to prohibit the sale of a firearm to an individual who is not a resident of the State in which the firearm is sold.
