Requires the Secretary, in awarding national emergency grants to address the effects of Hurricane Katrina by providing disaster relief employment, to give priority to: (1) States in which areas that have suffered major disasters are located; and (2) the remaining States that have been most heavily impacted by the demand for services by workers affected by Hurricane Katrina.

Prohibits an entity from denying disaster relief employment to a worker affected by Hurricane Katrina because of the worker's inability, due to the effects of Hurricane Katrina, to provide appropriate documentation of eligibility.

Authorizes the use of such funds to provide needs-related payments to individuals who do not qualify for (or have ceased to qualify for) unemployment compensation, and who are not employed on a project described under WIA, for the purpose of enabling such individuals to participate in activities related to job search, training, and placement.

Authorizes any State to use funds that remain available for expenditure under any grants awarded to the State under WIA or under this Act to provide any assistance authorized under such Act, or personal protective equipment not otherwise available through public funds or private contributions, to assist workers affected by Hurricane Katrina, including workers who have relocated from areas for which an emergency or major disaster was declared, due to the effects of Hurricane Katrina.

Authorizes the Secretary, in awarding national emergency grants to address the effects of Hurricane Katrina, to award such a grant to an entity to provide employment and training assistance to workers affected by Hurricane Katrina, including workers who have relocated from areas for which an emergency or major disaster was declared, due to the effects of Hurricane Katrina.

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) States that operate mobile one-stop centers should make such centers available for use in the areas affected by Hurricane Katrina, and areas where large numbers of workers affected by Hurricane Katrina have been relocated; and (2) one-stop operators should increase access for workers affected by Hurricane Katrina to the one-stop delivery systems authorized under WIA.

Authorizes the Court of Veterans Appeals to provide funds (in advance or by way of reimbursement) to nonprofit organizations, under such terms and conditions consistent with this Act as the Court considers appropriate, in order to permit such organizations to provide financial assistance by grant or contract to legal assistance entities for purposes of permitting such entities to carry out programs to ensure that financially needy veterans receive, without charge, legal assistance in connection with decisions to which certain provisions of this Act may apply or with other proceedings before the Court.

Critical Infrastructure Protection Act or the CIPA (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to: (1) include in national planning frameworks the threat of electromagnetic pulse (EMP) events, and (2) conduct outreach to educate owners and operators of critical infrastructure, emergency planners, and emergency response providers at all levels of government of the threat of EMP events. DHS shall conduct research and development to mitigate the consequences of EMP events. The bill requires DHS to submit to Congress a recommended strategy to protect and prepare the critical infrastructure of the American homeland against EMP events, including from acts of terrorism. (Sec. 3) Nothing in this Act shall be construed to grant any regulatory authority. (Sec. 4) This Act may be carried out only by using funds appropriated under the authority of other laws.

Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2017 This bill amends the federal criminal code to prohibit a person from operating a gun show unless: (1) the person is at least 21 years old, (2) the person has not willfully violated any provision of the code or regulation issued under it, and (3) the person has registered with the Department of Justice (DOJ) as a gun show operator. A person who operates a gun show must: (1) notify DOJ within 30 days before the commencement of the gun show of the date, time, duration, location of the gun show, and the identity of each vendor; (2) verify the identity of each vendor by examining a valid identification document containing a photograph of the individual; (3) require each vendor to sign a ledger identifying information concerning the individual and a notice setting forth the obligations of a gun show vendor; and (4) notify each person who attends the gun show of the requirements of this bill. A person who is not licensed under the code may not transfer possession of, or title to, a firearm at, or on the curtilage of, a gun show, to another person who is not so licensed, or for a person who is not so licensed to receive possession of, or title to, a firearm at, or on the curtilage of, a gun show from another person who is not so licensed, unless a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer: (1) has entered into a separate bound record the make, model, and serial number of the firearm and other information about the transaction, and (2) has notified the prospective transferor and transferee that the national instant criminal background check system has provided the licensee with a unique identification number indicating that receipt of the firearm by the prospective transferee would not violate the code or state law. A licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer who provides such notice shall: (1) submit to DOJ a report of the transfer within 10 days after the date of the transfer, which report shall specify the make, model, and serial number of the firearm and contain other information required by DOJ, except that the report shall not include the name of or other identifying information relating to any person involved in the transfer who is not licensed under the code; and (2) retain a record of the transfer, including the same information as would be required if the transfer were from the inventory of the licensee, as part of the permanent business records of the licensee. DOJ may enter during business hours any place where a gun show operator operates a gun show or is required to maintain records for purposes of examining the records and the inventory of licensees conducting business at the gun show. The entry and examination shall be conducted for the purposes of determining compliance with the code by gun show operators and licensees conducting business at the gun show, and shall not require a showing of reasonable cause or a warrant.  The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives may hire at least 40 additional Industry Operations Investigators for the purpose of carrying out inspections of gun shows.

Curecanti National Recreation Area Boundary Establishment Act of 2010 - Establishes the Curecanti National Recreation Area in Colorado as a unit of the National Park System.

Establishes a conservation opportunity area within the boundaries of the national recreation area.

Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into management agreements with the National Park Service, the Bureau of Reclamation, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), or the Forest Service to manage federal lands within the boundary of the national recreation area. Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative management agreements for any lands administered by Colorado that are within or adjacent to the national recreation area.

Requires the Secretary to allow boating, boating-related activities, hunting, and fishing within the national recreation area in accordance with applicable federal and state laws. Authorizes the Secretary to designate zones where, and establish periods when, no boating, hunting, or fishing shall be permitted for reasons of public safety.

Authorizes the Secretary to acquire lands, or interests in lands, within the boundaries of the conservation opportunity area and provide technical assistance to landowners in order to conserve resources and values identified as important to the national recreation area on lands that are outside but adjacent to the national recreation area.

Withdraws all federal lands within the national recreation area from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws; from location, entry, and patent under the mining laws; and from disposition under all laws relating to mineral and geothermal leasing.

Authorizes the Secretary to allow the continuation of grazing on: (1) state or private lands acquired for the national recreation area on which authorized grazing is occurring on the date of enactment of this Act, subject to applicable law; and (2) federal land within the boundary of the national recreation area, unless the Secretary determines that grazing would harm the resources or values of the national recreation area.

Authorizes the Secretary to acquire from willing sellers lands, or interests in lands, within the boundary of the national recreation area or the conservation opportunity area necessary for effective management of the national recreation area. Requires lands acquired within the conservation opportunity area to be added to the national recreation area and the boundary of the national recreation area to be adjusted accordingly.

Authorizes the Secretary to conduct land exchanges with the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) and between the National Park Service and the BLM.

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture and the BLM to transfer, without consideration, administrative jurisdiction for lands to be added to the national recreation area to the National Park Service. Requires the boundary of the Gunnison National Forest to be modified to reflect the transfer of administrative jurisdiction from the Secretary of Agriculture.

Directs the National Park Service to prepare a general management plan for the national recreation area.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small manufacturer (an unincorporated business, partnership, or for-profit corporation that employed an average of 50 or fewer employees on business days during the preceding calendar year) a tax credit for 50% of the amount paid or incurred for qualified computer hardware and software property, up to $35,000. Terminates such credit after 2011.

Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to arrange for the evaluation of a wide variety of promising programs designed in whole or part to prevent pregnancy in teenagers, including programs that do not receive Federal grants. 
Directs the Secretary to establish the National Clearinghouse on Teenage Pregnancy Prevention Programs. 
Authorizes the Secretary to make one-time incentive grants to entities operating effective prevention programs.

Working Waterfront Preservation Act of 2005 - Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to authorize the Secretary of Commerce to award grants to eligible entities (the government of a coastal state, a unit of local government within a coastal state, or a nonprofit organization or a fishing cooperative) for projects to: (1) acquire real property located in a coastal state for the purpose of providing access to persons engaged in the commercial fishing industry or the aquaculture industry to coastal waters in working waterfront areas; or (2) make improvements to real property located in a coastal state and owned by an eligible entity, including the construction or repair of wharfs or related facilities, to provide such access.

Requires the Secretary to consider specified factors in awarding such grants. Requires the appropriate state fisheries official to prepare an assessment of the need for the proposed project before it may be considered by the Secretary.

Limits the amount of a grant to 75 percent of the total cost of the eligible project. Requires the eligible entity to provide assurances that the share of the cost of each eligible project that is not funded by the grant has been secured.

Authorizes the use of grant funds to purchase privately-owned real property or interests in such property, including easements, only from willing sellers at fair market value. Allows the use of grant funds to acquire privately-owned real property or an interest in such property at less than fair market value only if the owner certifies to the Secretary that the sale is being entered into willingly and without coercion. Prohibits any federal, state, or local agency from exercising the power of eminent domain to secure title to any real property or facilities in connection with a project carried out under this Act.

Requires the Secretary to enter into an agreement with an eligible entity that receives a grant that requires the eligible entity to provide assurances that the eligible project is not converted to a use that is inconsistent with the purposes for which the grant was awarded. Provides for reversionary interest if the Governor of a coastal state makes a determination that: (1) the unit of local government or nonprofit organization is unable or unwilling to enforce the terms of the easement; or (2) the easement has been modified in a manner that is inconsistent with the purposes for which the grant was awarded. Authorizes the State to convey or authorize the unit of local government or nonprofit organization to convey the easement to another unit of local government or nonprofit organization.

Authorizes appropriations.

International Tuberculosis Control Act of 2002 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to direct the agency primarily responsible for administering assistance for tuberculosis (TB) prevention, treatment, control, and elimination to: (1) coordinate with the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control, the National Institutes of Health, and other organizations with respect to the development and implementation of a comprehensive TB control program; and (2) set as a goal the detection of at least 70 percent of the cases of infectious TB, and the cure of at least 85 percent of the cases detected, by December 31, 2005, in those countries classified by WHO as among the highest TB burden, and by December 31, 2010, in all countries in which the agency has established development programs.

National Women's Rights History Project Act of 2005 - Amends the Women's Rights National Historical Park Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service (NPS), to designate a vehicular tour route, to be known as the Votes for Women History Trail Route, to link properties in New York that are historically and thematically associated with the struggle for women's suffrage in the United States.

Directs the Secretary to: (1) produce and disseminate appropriate educational materials regarding the Trail Route; (2) coordinate the management, planning, and standards of the auto route in partnership with participating properties, other federal agencies, and state and local governments; (3) create and adopt an official, uniform symbol or device to mark the Trail Route; and (4) issue guidelines for the use of such symbol or device.

Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative agreements and memorandums of understanding with, and provide technical and financial assistance to, other federal agencies, the State of New York, localities, regional governmental bodies, and private entities to facilitate the establishment of the Trail Route and to ensure effective coordination of the federal and non-federal properties designated as stops along the Trail Route.

Authorizes the Secretary to make annual grants to state historic preservation offices for up to five years to assist those offices in surveying, evaluating, and nominating women's rights history properties to the National Register of Historic Places. Directs the Secretary to ensure that the National Register travel itinerary website, "Places Where Women Made History," is updated to contain the results of the inventory and links to websites related to places on the inventory when such links are available.

Authorizes the Secretary to make matching grants and technical assistance for development of a network of governmental and nongovernmental entities whose purpose is to provide interpretive and educational program development of national women's rights history, including historic preservation.

Authorizes the Secretary to convey, by sale or exchange, specified parcels of National Forest System land in Texas.
Authorizes the Secretary to convey to the New Waverly Gulf Coast Trades Center a parcel of real property within the Sam Houston National Forest, Walker County, Texas. Requires the Center to pay the fair market value of the property and the cost of the appraisal of the property. Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) payment; (2) release; (3) right of reentry; and (4) alternative property disposal authority.
Directs the Secretary to deposit the proceeds of a sale or exchange under this Act in the Sisk Act Fund. Makes such funds available for: (1) the acquisition, construction, or improvement of administrative facilities for units of the National Forest System in Texas; or (2) the acquisition of lands or interests in lands in Texas.

Chesapeake Bay Program Reauthorization and Environmental Accountability Act of 2005 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to complete a plan for achieving the nutrient and sediment reduction goals described in the agreement entered into by the Chesapeake Executive Council entitled "Chesapeake 2000" dated June 28, 2000.

Requires the Administrator to publish and widely circulate an annual tributary health report card to evaluate progress made during the preceding year and overall progress made in achieving and maintaining nutrient and sediment reduction goals for each major tributary of the Chesapeake Bay and each separable segment of such a tributary. Requires the baseline for the report card to be the tributary cap load allocation agreement numbered EPA 903-R-03-007, dated December 2003, and entitled "Setting and Allocating the Chesapeake Bay Basin Nutrient and Sediment Loads: The Collaborative Process, Technical Tools and Innovative Approaches."

Requires Delaware, Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, West Virginia, and the District of Columbia to submit annually to the Administrator information describing, for each jurisdictional tributary strategy basin of the Chesapeake Bay located in the State or District, for the preceding year: (1) the nutrient and sediment cap load allocation of the jurisdictional tributary strategy basin; (2) the principal sources of nutrients and sediment in the jurisdictional tributary strategy basin, by category; (3) for each category of pollutant source, the technologies or practices used to achieve reductions, including levels of best management practices implementation and sewage treatment plant upgrades; and (4) any Federal, State, or non-Federal funding used to implement a technology or practice described in this Act.

Prohibits the Administrator from making a grant to a State if the State fails to submit any information in accordance with this Act.

Requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to report to Congress on: (1) the feasibility and advisability of combining into a single fund certain or all funds made available to each Federal agency to carry out restoration activities relating to the Chesapeake Bay and distributing amounts from that fund in accordance with the priority of water quality improvement activities identified under the Chesapeake Bay Program; and (2) an interagency crosscut budget that displays the proposed budget for use by each Federal agency in carrying out restoration activities relating to the Chesapeake Bay for the following fiscal year and a detailed accounting of all funds received and obligated by Federal and State governments to achieve the objectives of the Chesapeake Bay Program during the preceding fiscal year.

Requires the Administrator to report to Congress on: (1) an estimate of the reduction in levels of nutrients and sediments in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries and a comparison of each estimated reduction and the appropriate annual goal described in the implementation plan; (2) based on review by the Administrator of the budget and implementation plans of each Federal agency and any tributary strategy of an appropriate State agency, an estimate of the reductions in pollutants likely to occur as a result of each program of an agency under this Act during the subsequent one-year and five-year periods, including an analysis of the success or failure of each program in achieving nutrient and sediment reduction and an estimated timeline during which a reduction in nutrient and sediment pollution will occur; and (3) accounting for other trend data, an estimate of the actual reduction in the quantities of nutrients and sediments in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries from all sources that has occurred over the preceding one-year and five-year periods.

Authorizes appropriations for FY2006 through 2010.

Directs the Civil Air Patrol, in its capacity as a federally chartered corporation and a volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, to be administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force, under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. 
Requires the Secretary to appoint a National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol.  Requires the chairman of the National Board of Directors to be the senior active duty Air Force officer. 
Requires the National Board of Directors to appoint:  (1) a National Commander; (2) an Executive Director; (3) a Safety Officer; and (4) an Inspector General.  Requires the Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General to report directly to the Secretary through the National Board of Directors. 
Authorizes the Chief of Staff of the Air Force to assign officers and enlisted members of the Air Force on active duty and civilian employees of the Department of the Air Force to serve on the staff of the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. 
States that the appointment or assignment of members of the armed forces or civilian employees is not precluded by any law or regulation prohibiting active duty members of the armed forces or civilian employees from participating in the management of non-Federal entities.  Prohibits an officer or enlisted member of the Air Force appointed to or assigned to duty in a Civil Air Patrol management position from receiving any compensation, other than the regular military compensation to which the officer or member is otherwise entitled, as a result of the appointment or assignment. 
Authorizes the Executive Director and National Board of Directors to use Civil Air Patrol employees and volunteer Civil Air Patrol members as necessary to administer the Civil Air Patrol and to ensure that it is capable of assisting the Department of the Air Force in the performance of its noncombat mission.  States that a member of the Civil Air Patrol or an employee of the Civil Air Patrol is not a Federal employee and is not subject to the provisions of law relating to Federal employment, including those relating to hours of work, rates of compensation, leave, unemployment compensation, Federal employee benefits, ethics, conflicts of interest, and other similar criminal or civil statutes and regulations governing the conduct of Federal employees.  Authorizes the Secretary to prescribe standards of conduct and behavior for Civil Air Patrol members and employees. 
Subjects all funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol to the requirements of the Federal Grant and Cooperative Agreement Act and the Federal regulations governing the provision of appropriated funds to private, nonprofit organizations. 
Subjects the powers granted to the Civil Air Patrol to the approval of the Secretary under this Act and to any policies, regulations, or instructions issued by the Secretary under that authority.

Healthy Schools Partnerships Act of 2010 - Amends the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a demonstration project under which grants are made to school food authorities that demonstrate collaboration with local partner organizations to test and evaluate innovative models to improve nutrition education, student decisionmaking, and healthy school environments.

Requires such grants to be used to: (1) assess the problem of childhood obesity and poor nutrition in the school environment; (2) develop an innovative plan or intervention to address specific causes of the problem in coordination with outside partners; (3) implement the plan or intervention in partnership with outside partners; (4) measure and evaluate effectiveness of the intervention; and (5) assess the sustainability and replicability of this model.

Amends the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act to direct the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy to establish and promote a Governmentwide program to encourage and recognize contractor innovation and excellence in facilitating the defense of the United States against, or recovery from, terrorism or nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack. Requires the Administrator to: (1) issue agency announcements seeking unique and innovative solutions to advance such defense; (2) convene a multiagency technical assistance team to assist in screening proposals submitted to provide such solutions; and (3) provide monetary awards in recognition of unique and innovative solutions with the potential to significantly advance such defense.

Directs the Administrator to establish a pilot program under which the Secretaries of Defense, Energy, Commerce, Transportation, and the Treasury may test the innovative use of streamlined acquisition authorities and procedures authorized by law, with emphasis on provisions authorizing the rapid acquisition of goods and services, and test the feasibility of rapidly entering into contracts with private entities to carry out immediate solutions to key homeland security needs using commercial, off-the-shelf items and commercially available services.

Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011 - Reduces the annual rate of pay for a Member of Congress (including a Delegate or Resident Commissioner to the Congress) based on the federal deficit. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report annually to Congress on the gross domestic product and whether a federal deficit existed in the most recent fiscal year.

Increases the contributions payable by Members of Congress under the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and the Federal Employees' Retirement System (FERS).

Amends the Commodity Exchange Act and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to prohibit any person from buying or selling commodities or securities while such person is in possession of material nonpublic information relating to pending or prospective legislative action if: (1) such information was obtained by reason of being a Member or employee of Congress, or (2) such information was obtained from a Member or employee of Congress and such person knows that the information was so obtained.

Expresses the sense of Congress that any law enacted by Congress should apply to Members of Congress in the same manner and to the same extent as the law applies to other individuals.

Sport Fish Restoration and Recreational Boating Safety Act of 2015 This bill amends the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act to increase the percentage of funds allocated for sport fish restoration grants. The bill also increases the amount available for boating infrastructure improvement projects.  The bill revises the formula for determining the amount of funds that may be used by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for Coast Guard administration.  The bill repeals the authority of the Secretary of the Interior to use funds from the Boat Safety Account for recreational boating safety programs. Instead, the bill authorizes the Secretary to use amounts made available each fiscal year under the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act for payment of expenses of the Coast Guard for investigations, personnel, and activities directly related to: (1) administering state recreational boating safety programs; or (2) coordinating or carrying out the national recreational boating safety program.  The bill requires the Director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to submit an assessment of the administrative services provided by the Service under the Dingell-Johnson Sport Fish Restoration Act to the states and the sportfishing community.

Community-Based Mental Health Infrastructure Improvements Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to states that are recipients of Community Mental Health Services Block Grants and Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Block Grants, or Indian tribes or tribal organizations, for the construction or modernization of facilities used to provide mental health and behavioral health services to individuals.

Authorizes a state that receives such a grant to award a subgrant to a qualified community program for activities such as: (1) the construction, expansion, and modernization of facilities used to provide mental and behavioral health services to individuals; (2) acquiring and leasing facilities and equipment to support or further the operation of the subgrantee; and (3) the construction and structural modification of facilities to permit the integrated delivery of behavioral health and primary care of specialty medical services to individuals with co-occurring mental illnesses and chronic medical or surgical diseases at a single service site.

Requires an eligible entity that receives a grant under this Act to agree, as a condition of receipt of such grant, that it will make available non-federal contributions in an amount equal to not less than $1 for every $1 of federal funds provided under the grant.

Service for Schools Act of 2015 This bill amends the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to establish a national service program for schools. The Corporation for National and Community Service must establish a Service Opportunity Registry that lists eligible service opportunities and the organizations offering them. A qualified student is an individual who is not younger than age 12 or older than age 30 and who completed 2000 qualifying hours of service when the individual was a qualified student. A participant in a professional corps program may receive compensation without regard to the maximum compensation limit if the opportunity meets human, educational, environmental, or public safety needs in a high-need community with an inadequate number of such professionals. An eligible student shall receive an award of $10,000 from the National Service for Schools Account to repay student loans or pay all or part of the cost of attendance or other educational expenses at an institution of higher education.

Improving Corporate Governance Through Diversity Act of 2017 This bill requires executive agencies to require certain contractors to submit data on the racial, ethnic, and gender composition of their board of directors and C-level executives (senior executive officers, information officers, technology officers, financial officers, compliance officers, or security officers). The Securities and Exchange Commission must revise its regulations to require that when the description of a nominee's qualifications is presented in a proxy or information statement relating to the election of directors, the nominee's gender, race, ethnicity, and affiliation with a historically underrepresented group should be presented in a chart or matrix form.

Government Shutdown Prevention Act - Provides for continuing appropriations if any regular appropriation bill for a fiscal year does not become law before the beginning of such fiscal year or a joint resolution making continuing appropriations is not in effect.

Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2013 - Amends the Department of Energy Organization Act to establish a Biennial Commission on Energy Policy to make recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to create an integrated and comprehensive energy policy for the United States.

Syria Humanitarian Support and Democratic Transition Assistance Act of 2012 - Directs the President to appoint a Special Envoy for Syria to coordinate U.S. engagement with the country and to ensure that the U.S. government supports efforts to bring about a democratic transition in Syria.

Directs the President to: (1) provide enhanced support for humanitarian activities taking place in and outside Syria, including the provision of food, water, and medical supplies; (2) support efforts for a peaceful resolution of the conflict in Syria as well as the establishment of an inclusive representative form of government in Syria; (3) continue to encourage the participation of all groups, including women, business leaders, civil society organizations, traditional and religious leaders, and minority groups in efforts for a peaceful resolution of the conflict and political transition in Syria; (4) encourage the Arab League and other international bodies to insist that transitional and future governments are committed to multiparty democracy, open and transparent governance, respect for human rights and religious freedom, ending the violence throughout the country, promoting peace and stability with Syria's neighbors, enhancing the rule of law and combating corruption, and rehabilitating and reintegrating former combatants; (5) contribute to future capacity building for governing institutions after a political transition takes place in Syria; and (6) support post-transition efforts, including programs for demobilizing and reintegrating former combatants.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Department of State should submit a budget request for FY2014 that contains an appropriate increase in bilateral and multilateral assistance for Syria based on progress by the government of Syria toward accomplishing the policy objectives described in this Act.

Directs the President to instruct the U.S. permanent representative or executive director to the United Nations voluntary agencies, including the World Food Program, the United Nations Development Program, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and other appropriate international organizations to use the voice and vote of the United States to support additional humanitarian and development assistance for the people of Syria in order to accomplish the policy objectives described in this Act.

Directs the President to increase bilateral funding to countries, including Iraq, Jordan, Turkey, and Lebanon, that have experienced an influx of refugees from Syria.

Directs the President to instruct the Secretary of State to work with the appropriate United Nations agencies, regional organizations, nongovernmental organizations, and the broader international community to establish an international donors group to maximize resources and efficiently provide humanitarian assistance to the people of Syria.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Department of State should submit a budget request for FY2014 that contains an increase in bilateral nonproliferation, demining, and anti-terrorism assistance for Syria toward accomplishing the policy objectives described in this Act.

Directs the President to report annually to Congress on the implementation of this Act.

Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior (acting through the Director of the National Park Service) to provide a grant to the City of Philadelphia to undertake the restoration of Washington Square, as depicted on a specified map.  Conditions such grant upon:  (1) conduct of such restoration in accordance with standards established by the Secretary to facilitate the inclusion of the square in Independence National Historical Park; and (2) the city's entrance into a memorandum of understanding with the Secretary regarding the long-term lease and administration of the square. 
Requires any Federal funds appropriated for the purpose of restoring Washington Square to be used to offset any funds made available to the National Park Service pursuant to this Act. 
Authorizes appropriations. 
Authorizes the Secretary, upon completion of the restoration, to enter into a lease agreement with the city of Philadelphia for the lease of such area to the National Park Service for an amount not to exceed $1 per year, and to acquire such area or an interest in the area by donation.  Authorizes the Secretary to modify the boundaries of Independence National Historical Park to include such area within such boundaries, and to provide for the administration of such area as part of such Park. 
Requires the city of Philadelphia, as a condition of receiving the grant, to provide services for Washington Square with respect to electricity, natural gas, water and sewer, curbside garbage collection of bagged trash or receipt of hauled trash at a city collection point, and police services comparable to those provided in the surrounding community.

Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008 - (Sec. 3) Amends the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 to revise the definition of "hydrographic data" to include information acquired through: (1) hydrographic, bathymetric, photogrammetric, lidar, radar, remote sensing, or shoreline and other ocean- and coastal-related surveying; (2) geodetic, geospatial, or geomagnetic measurements; and (3) tide, water level, and current observations.

Revises the definition of "hydrographic services" to include the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of bathymetric, hydrographic, shoreline, geodetic, geospatial, geomagnetic, and tide, water level, and current information, including the production of nautical charts, nautical information databases, and other products derived from hydrographic data.

Authorizes the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to create, support, and maintain a Joint Hydrographic Institute.

Authorizes the Administrator to acquire hydrographic data and provide hydrographic services to: (1) support the conservation and management of coastal and ocean resources; (2) save and protect life and property; (3) support the resumption of commerce in response to emergencies, natural disasters, and man-made disasters; and (4) meet homeland security and maritime domain awareness needs, including carrying out mission assignments.

(Sec. 4) Revises the composition of the Hydrographic Services Review Panel to include two Co-directors.

Requires voting members of the panel to be reimbursed for actual and reasonable expenses, including travel and per diem, incurred in the performance of duties for the panel.

(Sec. 5) Authorizes appropriations for FY2009-FY2012 for: (1) nautical mapping and charting functions; (2) contracting for hydrographic surveys, including the leasing or time chartering of vessels; (3) operating U.S.-owned hydrographic survey vessels operated by the Administration; (4) geodetic functions; (5) tide and current measurement functions; and (6) acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel capable of staying at sea continuously for at least 30 days.

(Sec. 6) Amends the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act to add a short title.

Veterans Equal Treatment Act - Discontinues the Veterans Equitable Resource Allocation (VERA) formula for the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) medical care system. Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to develop a new formula for the allocation of funds appropriated to the VA for medical care to the national service regions, known as Veterans Integrated Service Networks (VISNs), of the VA. Requires the new formula to: (1) provide funding levels that are not less than those provided under the VERA formula for any fiscal year in which appropriations for medical care increase from the preceding year; and (2) take into account additional costs incurred by a VISN due to specified factors at that VISN being in excess of the median for all VISNs.Authorizes appropriations for FY 2004 for: (1) development and implementation of a replacement funding allocation formula; and (2) medical care.

International Clean Development Technology Fund Act of 2008 - Establishes in the Treasury the International Clean Development Technology Fund.

Directs the President to establish an International Clean Development Technology Board to administer the Fund and ensure that: (1) funds are deployed in a manner that best promotes the participation of, and investments by, the private sector; (2) funds are allocated in a manner consistent with commitments by the United States under international climate change agreements; (3) funds achieve the greatest greenhouse gas emissions mitigations with the lowest possible cost; and (4) assistance is targeted at reducing or eliminating the increased costs associated with deploying clean technologies in place of traditional technologies.

Authorizes the Board, acting through the Secretary of State, to use the Fund to provide assistance to qualified entities to support this Act. Defines "qualified entity" as the national government of an eligible country, a regional or local governmental unit of an eligible country, or a nongovernmental organization or a private entity located or operating in an eligible country.

Requires the Board to determine whether a country is eligible for technology program assistance based on specified criteria.

Authorizes the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to seek review of a panel's determination in the Appellate Body of the World Trade Organization (WTO). 
Requires the USTR, if the United States Trade Representative seeks to enforce U.S. rights under a multilateral trade agreement or to defend a challenged action or determination of the U.S. Government before a dispute settlement panel or the Appellate Body, to permit a private U.S. person that is supportive of the U.S. Government's position and that has a direct economic interest in the panel's or Appellate Body's resolution of the matters in dispute to participate in consultations and panel proceedings.

Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1998 - Establishes the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site in South Dakota as a unit of the National Park System. 
Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to acquire lands and interests within the boundaries of the Site by donation, purchase with donated or appropriated funds, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency.  Provides that lands or interests owned by the State of South Dakota may only be acquired by donation or exchange.  Prohibits the Secretary from acquiring any lands pursuant to this Act if the Secretary determines that such lands, or any portion thereof, are contaminated with hazardous substances unless all remedial action necessary to protect human health and the environment has been taken pursuant to the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act. 
Directs the Secretary to prepare a general management plan for the Site which shall include an evaluation of an appropriate location for a visitor facility and administrative site within the areas depicted as "Support Facility Study Area-Alternative A" or "Support Facility Study Area-Alternative B" on the map referred to in this Act.  Requires modification of the boundaries of the Site to include the selected site upon a determination by the Secretary of the appropriate location for such facilities.  Directs the Secretary, in developing the plan, to consider coordinating or consolidating appropriate administrative, management, and personnel functions with Badlands National Park. 
Authorizes appropriations. 
Requires the Secretary of the Air Force to transfer to the Secretary any funds specifically appropriated to the Air Force for the maintenance, protection, or preservation of the facilities described in this Act.  Requires such funds to be used by the Secretary for establishing, operating, and maintaining the Site.

Veterans Accountability Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to submit semiannual reports to Congress on the cost of certain travel made by VA employees, including those stationed in a foreign country, on official business. Requires such reports to include: (1) the purpose of the travel, destination, name and title of each employee included on such travel, duration of such travel, total cost to the VA, and identity of the person or entity that paid or reimbursed for such travel; and (2) final costs to the VA with respect to all covered travel made during the period covered by the report, including transportation, expenses or reimbursements relating to operating and maintaining a car, passport and visa fees, lodging, per diem payments, baggage charges, computer rental fees, rental of halls, auditoriums, or other spaces, entertainment, contractors, registration fees, and promotional items. Defines "covered travel" as travel made by an employee of the VA, including an employee who is stationed in a foreign country, on official business to any location outside of the United States if the Department or other element of the federal government pays for such travel, or to any location regardless of whether it is inside or outside of the United States if any person or entity other than the federal government pays (or reimburses) for such travel. Directs the Secretary to report to the appropriate entity each case of a notifiable infectious disease or condition that is diagnosed at a VA medical facility in accordance with the laws of the state in which the facility is located. Requires the Secretary to report each such case that is classified as a health-care-associated infection sentinel event to the accrediting organization of such facility. Sets forth penalties for failure to report a case of a notifiable infectious disease or condition at a VA medical facility in accordance with state law. Requires the Inspector General of the VA to investigate any suspicion that a director of a Veterans Integrated Service Network has failed to comply with this Act. Directs the Secretary to suspend such director for such period as the Secretary considers appropriate under specified provisions. Authorizes the Secretary to impose other administrative disciplinary action on the director as the Secretary considers appropriate and for which the Secretary is otherwise authorized. Directs the Secretary to maintain records of each notifiable infectious disease or condition reported and to submit to the congressional veterans committees a notification of each such notifiable infectious disease or condition. Directs the Secretary to prescribe regulations establishing procedures to ensure that any visual recording made by the Secretary of a patient during the course of furnishing care is carried out only with the full and informed consent of the patient or, in appropriate cases, a representative thereof. Authorizes the Secretary to waive the requirement for informed consent with respect to the visual recording of a patient if such recording is made: (1) pursuant to a determination by a physician or psychologist that such recording is medically necessary or necessary for the safety of the patient; (2) pursuant to a warrant or order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or (3) in a public setting where a person would not have a reasonable expectation to privacy, such as a waiting room or hallway, and such recording is for general security purposes not particularized to the patient.

Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services to delay the effectiveness of a termination of a Medicare+Choice organization's contract with the Secretary if the Secretary determines that:  (1) the termination would cause an imminent and serious risk to the health of individuals enrolled under the plan; (2) the termination would result in a significant reduction in the Medicare+Choice plans available in the area affected by the termination; or (3) the organization terminating coverage is offering Medicare+Choice plans in contract areas that are in close proximity to the area affected by the termination without suffering considerable financial losses. 
Authorizes the Secretary to end such a delay if the Secretary determines that an adequate provider network has been established which will provide at least an equal level of insurance coverage as existed in the area affected by the termination on the date the Medicare+Choice organization informed the Secretary of its intention to terminate the contract. 
Allows the Secretary and the Medicare+Choice organization terminating coverage to negotiate during such period for a new contract which will enable such organization to continue such coverage. 
Extends from one year to three years the initial Medicare+Choice contract period. 
Requires each contract to require the organization to provide (and pay for) written notice at least 120 days prior to the contract's termination, as well as a description of alternatives for obtaining benefits under Medicare, to each individual enrolled with the organization.

Investment Tax Incentive Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for an accelerated depreciation deduction for certain property placed in service after December 31, 1992. 
Repeals special depreciation rules applicable under the adjusted current earnings provisions of the minimum tax.

Fair Accountability and Innovative Research Drug Pricing Act of 2016 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require a drug manufacturer to submit a report to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) for each price increase of a qualifying drug that will result in an increase in the average manufacturer price of that drug that is equal to 10% or more over a 12-month period. A "qualifying drug" is any drug that is approved under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act or licensed under the Public Health Service Act that: (1) is subject to prescription drug program requirements or commonly administered by hospitals, (2) is not designated as a drug for a rare disease or condition, (3) is not designated by HHS as a vaccine, and (4) for which, during the previous calendar year, at least $1 of the total amount of sales were for individuals enrolled under Medicare or Medicaid or under a waiver of such plan. The bill sets forth the contents of the report, including information on the drug's history of price increases, research and development expenditures, and marketing costs. Any manufacturer of a qualifying drug that fails to submit a report shall be subject to a civil penalty of $100,000 for each day on which the violation continues. HHS shall annually review and consider the average manufacturer price information submitted under regulations governing the reporting of average manufacturer prices of certain drugs and biologicals. HHS shall post the reports on its website. HHS shall use civil penalties collected under this bill to improve consumer and provider information about drug value and drug price transparency.

Federal Employees Health Benefits Access Act - Amends Federal civil service law to prohibit a contract for health benefits under the Federal Employees Health Benefit Program (FEHBP) from being made or a plan approved unless the carrier agrees to offer to the general public, throughout each term for which the contract or approval remains effective, the same benefits as would be offered under such contract or plan to employees and annuitants and their family members. 
Requires premiums for coverage under this Act to be established in conformance with requirements prescribed by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), including provisions to ensure conformance with generally accepted standards and practices associated with community rating. 
Prohibits any increase in the level of individual or Government contributions required under FEHBP, any decrease in the types of benefits offered, or any other change that would adversely affect the coverage afforded to employees and annuitants and their family members. 
Requires benefits under this Act, with respect to an individual who is entitled to benefits under part A (Hospital Insurance) of title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act, to be offered to the same extent and in the same manner as if coverage were under the preceding provisions of FEHBP, rather than under this Act. 
Authorizes a carrier to file an application with OPM setting forth reasons why it, or a plan provided by such carrier, should be excluded from the requirements of this Act.  Authorizes OPM, in reviewing any such application, to consider factors such as:  (1) any bona fide enrollment restrictions which would make the application of this Act inappropriate; (2) whether compliance with this Act would jeopardize the financial solvency of the plan or carrier, or otherwise compromise its ability to offer health benefits under the preceding provisions of FEHBP; and (3) the anticipated duration of the requested exclusion, and what efforts the plan or carrier proposes to take in order to be able to comply with this Act. 
Requires a claim for payment or reimbursement under FEHBP to be submitted on a standard form or in a standard manner as may be required by OPM in relation to health benefit plans. 
Directs OPM to:  (1) prepare information relating to the use of advance directives regarding the type or intensity of care which an individual desires in the event that such individual becomes unable to communicate by reason of incapacity due to illness or injury; and (2) require, as a condition for approval of any contract, that appropriate provisions be included so that such information may be made available to enrollees of the plan involved. 
Directs OPM to conduct a demonstration project to assess the feasibility and desirability of offering the use of arbitration, instead of litigation, to resolve medical malpractice claims arising out of covered health care services.

Medicare Home Infusion Site of Care Act of 2014 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for Medicare coverage of home infusion therapy. Defines "home infusion therapy" as the items and services provided by a qualified home infusion therapy supplier under a plan established and periodically reviewed by a physician, which are provided in an integrated manner in the individual's home in conformance with uniform standards of care established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) and in coordination with the provision of covered infusion drugs under part D (Voluntary Prescription Drug Benefit Program). Requires the Secretary to establish such standards after taking into account the standards commonly used for home infusion therapy by Medicare Advantage plans and in the private sector and after consultation with all interested stakeholders. Includes among the items and services provided: (1) professional services, including nursing services, provided in accordance with the plan and all necessary supplies and equipment; and (2) other items and services the Secretary determines appropriate to administer infusion drug therapies to an individual safely and effectively in the home. Directs the Secretary to determine a per diem schedule for payment for the professional services, supplies, and equipment for each infusion therapy type that reflects the reasonable costs which must be incurred by efficiently and economically operated qualified home infusion therapy suppliers to provide such services, supplies, and equipment in conformity with applicable state and federal laws, regulations, and the uniform quality and safety standards developed under this Act and to assure that Medicare beneficiaries have reasonable access to such therapy. Requires the Secretary to update such schedule from year to year by the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers for the 12-month period ending with June of the preceding year. Allows the Secretary to modify the per diem schedule with respect to beneficiaries who qualify for home infusion therapy services but who receive nursing services as home health services. Excludes supplies used in the provision of home infusion therapy after excluding other drugs and biologicals from the definition of medical equipment. Applies accreditation requirements to the accreditation of qualified home infusion therapy suppliers in the same way as they apply to other suppliers. Provides for Medicare coverage of infusion drugs administered via an intravenous, intraspinal, intra-arterial, intrathecal, epidural, subcutaneous, or intramuscular access device or injection. Requires the Secretary to implement the Medicare home infusion therapy benefit under the amendments made by this Act in a manner that ensures that Medicare beneficiaries have timely and appropriate access to infusion therapy in their homes and that there is rapid and seamless coordination between drug coverage under part D and coverage for home infusion therapy services under part B to avoid the filing of duplicative or otherwise improper claims. Requires the Comptroller General to report to Congress on Medicare beneficiary access to home infusion therapy.

Environmental Finance Act of 1995 - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to establish an Environmental Financial Advisory Board to provide expert advice on issues affecting the costs and financing of environmental activities at the Federal, State, and local levels. 
Directs the Administrator to establish and support an Environmental Finance Center in an institution of higher education in each of the regions of the Environmental Protection Agency.

Railroad Infrastructure Financing Improvement Act of 1997 - Amends Federal transportation law to authorize the Secretary of Transportation to provide direct loans and loan guarantees to State and local governments, government sponsored authorities and corporations, and railroad carriers. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) eligible purposes; (2) priority projects; (3) rates of interest; (4) infrastructure partners; (5) prerequisites for assistance; (6) conditions of assistance; (7) administration of direct loans and loan guarantees; (8) rights of the Secretary; (9) action against obligor; (10) breach of conditions; (11) attachment; and (12) investigation charge. 
Repeals title V (Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976) of the Federal transportation code.

Speak Up to Protect Every Abused Kid Act - Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (CAPTA) to revise the definition of "child abuse or neglect" to include: (1) any deliberate act, on the part of an individual other than a parent or caretaker, that results in death, serious physical or emotional harm, or sexual abuse or exploitation, or that presents an imminent risk of serious harm to a child; and (2) any recent act or failure to act, on the part of a parent or caretaker, that results in death, serious physical or emotional harm, or sexual abuse or exploitation, or an act or failure to act that presents an imminent risk of serious harm.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to eligible entities to carry out educational campaigns and provide training regarding state laws for mandatory reporting of incidents of child abuse or neglect. Requires the Secretary to develop and disseminate guidance and information on best practices for such campaigns and training programs.

Revises requirements for grants to states for child abuse or neglect prevention and treatment programs to require a state to certify that it has in effect and is enforcing a state law, or is operating a statewide program, relating to child abuse and neglect that includes provisions or procedures for an individual to report suspected or known incidents of child abuse or neglect to a state child protective service agency or to law enforcement agencies, which shall include a state law for mandatory reporting of such incidents, to either type of agency, by any adult.

Requires a state to train adults who work with children in a professional or volunteer capacity to report suspected and known incidents of child abuse or neglect under state law.

Requires a state task force to evaluate the state's efforts to train adults who work with children in a professional or volunteer capacity to report suspected and known incidents of child abuse or neglect under state law.

Requires a state to adopt experimental, model, and demonstration programs for testing innovative approaches and techniques that may improve reporting of and response to suspected and known incidents of child abuse or neglect by adults to the state child protective service agencies or to law enforcement agencies.

Requires a state to include in its plan or application for general program grants an assurance that the state has in effect a state law for mandatory reporting.

Requires the Secretary to collect information on and otherwise study the efforts of states relating to state laws for mandatory reporting of incidents of child abuse or neglect.

Requires a state to include in its plan or application for community-based grants an assurance that the state has in effect a state law for mandatory reporting.

Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993 - Amends Federal law to require that all appropriations for salaries and expenses be apportioned as necessary to carry out this Act. 
Requires a reserve to be established in an amount equal to five percent of the actual amount incurred for those salaries and expenses in the immediately preceding fiscal year, with a reduction in the size of each reserve if applicable. 
Directs the head of each agency that has an appropriation for salaries and expenses for a fiscal year subject to this Act to make recommendations to the President of changes in laws or regulations or other changes that should be made to bring about a more efficient and cost-effective operation and thereby reduce salaries and expenditures without jeopardizing any programs that agency administers. 
Requires the President's annual budget submission for a budget year to include a special message which sets forth on an agency-by-agency basis a recommendation for the current fiscal year of whether:  (1) for the programs that agency administers to be maintained at a proper administrative level the release of all or part of those funds held in reserve is necessary; (2) those programs can function effectively at reduced levels and the funds held in reserve should be rescinded and returned to the Treasury; or (3) supplemental appropriations for other programs are necessary and can be offset by rescissions of the funds held in reserve. 
Provides for fast-track supplemental appropriation of amounts not to exceed the aggregate amount rescinded under this Act.

Economic Recovery Adjustment Act of 2009 - Establishes within the Department of Justice (DOJ) the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate, headed by an Advocate appointed by the Attorney General.

Authorizes the Advocate to conduct ongoing audits and oversight of recipients of Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) funds with respect to compensation of their officers and directors.

Requires the Advocate to assist the Secretary of the Treasury in negotiating TARP assistance to assure that fair and reasonable executive compensation is paid by entities receiving such funds. Requires the Advocate to negotiate a reduction in the executive compensation obligations of an assisted entity as a condition of the continuing use or future receipt of TARP assistance if, after an audit, the Advocate finds reason to believe that any assisted entity would have become insolvent if not for the receipt of TARP assistance.

Establishes the Temporary Economic Recovery Oversight Panel to: (1) evaluate each proposed settlement reached under this Act; (2) approve or deny such proposed settlement; and (3) issue an order establishing an executive compensation program for individuals subject to the actions of the Advocate if no settlement is reached.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: 
     Title I:  Nicodemus National Historic Site 
     Title II:  New Bedford National Historic Landmark District 
Title I:  Nicodemus National Historic Site
 - Establishes the Nicodemus National Historic Site in Nicodemus, Kansas. 
(Sec. 104) Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into a cooperative agreement with any interested individual, public or private agency, organization, or institution to further the purposes of this title. 
Authorizes the Secretary to provide technical assistance for the preservation of historic structures of, the maintenance of the cultural landscape of, and local preservation planning for, the Site. 
(Sec. 105) Authorizes the Secretary to acquire by donation, exchange, or purchase such lands or interests in lands as may be necessary to allow for the interpretation, preservation, or restoration of the First Baptist Church, the St. Francis Hotel, the Nicodemus School District Number 1, the African Methodist Episcopal Church, or the Township Hall, or any combination thereof. 
Limits to donations the acquisition of real property that is owned by the State of Kansas or a political subdivision of the State of Kansas. 
(Sec. 106) Directs the Secretary to prepare a general management plan for the Site. 
(Sec. 107) Authorizes appropriations. 
Title II:  New Bedford National Historic Landmark District
 - Establishes the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park in New Bedford, Massachusetts. 
(Sec. 203) Sets forth the boundaries of the Park. 
(Sec. 204) Authorizes the Secretary to consult and enter into cooperative agreements with interested entities and individuals to provide for the preservation, development, interpretation, and use of the Park. 
Sets forth non-Federal matching requirements. 
Authorizes the Secretary to accept donated funds, property, and services to carry out this title. 
(Sec. 205) Directs the Secretary to submit to specified congressional committees a general management plan for the Park and implement such plan as soon as practicable. 
(Sec. 206) Authorizes appropriations.

Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013 - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to extend through June 30, 2014, the interest rate for student loans made by the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program and the Federal Family Education Loan Program. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise rules governing required distributions from pension plans upon the death of an employee before the entire interest is distributed.

Grow Research Opportunities With Taxcredits' Help Act or GROWTH Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend through 2010 the tax credit for increasing research activities; and (2) increase the alternative simplified research credit rate.

Troop Talent Act of 2013 - Directs the Secretaries of the military departments, in coordination with the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, to make information on civilian credentialing opportunities available to members of the Armed Forces beginning with, and at every stage of, training for military occupational specialties (MOS) in order to permit members to: (1) evaluate the extent to which such training correlates with the skills and training required in connection with various civilian certifications and licenses; and (2) assess the suitability of such training for obtaining or pursuing such civilian certifications and licenses. Requires such information to be made available in a manner consistent with the Transition Goals Plans Success (GPS) program. Requires such information to include: (1) information on the civilian occupational equivalents of MOS; (2) information on civilian license or certification requirements, including examination requirements; and (3) information on the availability and opportunities for use of educational benefits available to members of the Armed Forces, as appropriate, corresponding training, or continuing education that leads to a certification exam in order to provide a pathway to credentialing opportunities. Authorizes the Secretaries to use and adapt appropriate portions of the Credentialing Opportunities On-Line (COOL) programs of the Army and the Navy and the Credentialing and Educational Research Tool (CERT) of the Air Force. Directs the Secretaries to make available to accredited civilian credentialing agencies that issue certifications or licenses, upon request, information such as military course training curricula, syllabi, and materials, levels of military advancement attained, and professional skills developed. Authorizes the actions taken pursuant to this Act to include the establishment of a central repository of information on training and training materials provided members in connection with MOS that is readily accessible by accredited civilian credentialing agencies. Amends federal military law to authorize the use of certain Department of Defense (DOD) educational assistance for courses in pursuit of civilian certifications or licenses. Amends federal veterans' benefits law to authorize the use of certain Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) educational assistance for courses in pursuit of civilian certifications or licenses. Includes military occupational specialties relating to the military information technology workforce under the pilot program on receipt of civilian credentials for skills required for MOS. Directs the VA to reestablish the Professional Certification and Licensure Advisory Committee.
Competitiveness Tax Credit Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a temporary investment tax credit for new manufacturing and other productive equipment.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture to develop and implement a process to expedite access to federal lands under the administrative jurisdiction of the Secretary for eligible organizations and individuals to request access to conduct good Samaritan search-and-recovery missions.  Defines "good Samaritan search-and-recovery mission" as a search for one or more missing individuals believed to be deceased at the time that the search is initiated.

Amends the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 to establish a microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building grant program. 
Authorizes appropriations.

District of Columbia Land Use Notification Act of 1993 - Amends the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 to prohibit the Administrator of General Services from carrying out any activity that affects real property located in the District of Columbia (including transferring excess property or disposing of surplus property) unless:  (1) not later than 60 days before carrying out such activity, the Administrator provides a notice describing such activity and the property affected to the Mayor of the District, the Chair of the Council of the District, and the Chair of the Advisory Neighborhood Commission in whose neighborhood such property is located; and (2) the Administrator provides the individuals described with the opportunity to present oral or written comments on the activity to the Administrator (or the Administrator's designee) before the Administrator carries out the activity. 
Authorizes the Administrator to waive such requirements if compliance would jeopardize the public safety or the national security interests of the United States, but only if the Administrator:  (1) certifies such finding and the reasons for such finding to the individuals and to the Congress; and (2) at the earliest time practicable, provides such individuals with the notice and the opportunity to present comments. 
Prohibits a covered agency (the Architect of the Capitol, the National Park Service, or the Smithsonian Institution) from carrying out any activity that affects real property located in the District unless:  (1) not later than 60 days before carrying out such activity, such agency provides a notice describing such activity and the property affected to the Mayor, the Chair of the Council, and the Chair of the Advisory Neighborhood Commission in whose neighborhood such property is located; and (2) the agency provides the individuals described with the opportunity to present oral or written comments on the activity to a representative of the agency before the agency carries out the activity. 
Authorizes a covered agency to waive such requirements if compliance would jeopardize the public safety or the national security interests of the United States, but only if the agency:  (1) certifies such finding and the reasons for such finding to the individuals and to the Congress; and (2) at the earliest time practicable, provides such individuals with the notice and the opportunity to present comments. 
Prohibits an event from being held at the William H. G. Fitzgerald Tennis Center at Rock Creek Park without the prior approval of the Director of the National Park Service and the Mayor of the District.

Oregon Coastal Land Conveyance Act This bill directs the Department of the Interior to convey specified federal land in Oregon to the Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua, and Siuslaw Indians.  The bill prohibits: (1) the export of unprocessed logs harvested from such land, and (2) gaming activity on such land.  The Department of Agriculture (USDA) and Interior must identify any land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad that is conveyed under this bill.  USDA and Interior must also identify public domain land that is approximately equal in acreage and condition as the land identified by USDA and Interior and that is located within a specified planning area.  After providing an opportunity for public comment, Interior must reclassify the public domain land as land owned by the Oregon and California Railroad.

Information Technology Partnerships Act - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to institutions of higher education (IHEs) to establish, oversee the operation of, and provide technical assistance to, projects implemented by a community-based organization or by the IHE receiving the grant to provide postsecondary information technology education and employment procurement assistance to eligible individuals. 
Authorizes the Secretary to make a grant to an IHE that desires to implement a project without the participation of a community-based organization if the IHE agrees to carry out all of the duties required of such an organization under this Act, in addition to the duties otherwise required of an IHE.  Gives priority to IHEs whose grant application includes an assurance that the IHE will contract with one or more community-based organizations in accordance with this Act. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Growing Our Manufacturing Employment Act or the GoMe Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) establish a manufacturer's jobs credit for an increase in W-2 wages paid by a taxpayer during the taxable year over the W-2 wages paid during the preceding taxable year, or for W-2 wages paid to any employee who is an eligible Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) recipient or an eligible alternative TAA recipient; and (2) extend through 2012 the research tax credit.

Provides that a transaction shall have economic substance only if: (1) it changes in a meaningful way the taxpayer's economic position apart from federal tax effects; and (2) the taxpayer has a substantial nontax purpose for entering into such transaction and the transaction is a reasonable means of accomplishing such purpose.

Older Americans Act Technical Amendments of 1993 - Amends the Older Americans Act of 1965 to:  (1) include the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands within the scope of such Act; (2) revise provisions regarding the Assistant Secretary for Aging; (3) extend through FY 1994 certain provisions regarding the National White House Conference on Aging; and (4) make technical amendments to other specified Acts. 
Amends the Native American Programs Act of 1974 to revise provisions regarding grants to Indian tribes and Alaska Native villages. 
Amends the Older Americans Amendments of 1987 to extend through May 31, 1995, the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to States for the National White House Conference on Aging. 
Amends the Community Services Block Grant Act to revise provisions regarding:  (1) the use of such grants; (2) annual reports; and (3) technical amendments. 
Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to revise provisions regarding child care. 
Amends the Child Abuse, Domestic Violence, Adoption and Family Services Act of 1992 to extend through September 30, 1993, the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to States for the National White House Conference on Aging.

Directs the Assistant Attorney General to award a grant to the League for FY 2000 through 2004 to establish PAL chapters to serve public housing projects and other distressed areas, and expand existing PAL chapters to serve additional youths.
Requires each new or expanded PAL chapter assisted under this Act to carry out at least four programs during non-school hours, of which: (1) at least two shall provide mentoring assistance, academic assistance, recreational and athletic activities, or technology training; and (2) any remaining programs shall provide drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, cultural and social programs, conflict resolution training, anger management, and peer pressure training, job skill preparation activities, or Youth Police Athletic League Conferences or Youth Forums.

Civilian Volunteer Service Reserve Act - Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish the Civilian Volunteer Service Reserve, a national volunteer service corps ready for service in response to domestic or international emergencies, or other circumstances determined by the President.

Requires all U.S. citizens and legal residents over the age of 18 to be eligible to serve in the Reserve. Requires individuals who volunteer with the Reserve to be enrolled for a five-year period, and to be expected during such period to serve in full-time active duty status for a total period of six months when called to such service. Allows an individual to register for multiple five-year periods of service.

Authorizes the President to issue a voluntary call to action by issuing an executive order to mobilize certain members of the Reserve to full-time active duty status for up to six months in order to meet the pressing needs of the Nation in times of emergency. Authorizes the President, under extreme circumstances, to issue a mandatory mobilization of members of the Reserve, requiring such members to begin full-time active duty service for up to six months. Allows exemptions from such mandatory service for hardship due to family or other circumstances, upon appeal by an individual member of the Reserve.
