Requires members of the Reserve serving in full-time active duty status to work side-by-side with officers and agencies of the Federal, State, and local governments, non-profit and non-governmental organizations, supplementing but not supplanting existing systems for responding to emergencies and other pressing needs. Provides for transportation and accommodations, a stipend, health insurance, and reemployment protection and other benefits for members of the Reserve who complete a period of full-time active duty service.

Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997 - Prohibits the use of Federal funds to:  (1) seek the removal or reduction by any foreign country of any nondiscriminatory law or regulation, or any proposed nondiscriminatory law or regulation, in that country that restricts the advertising, manufacture, packaging, taxation, sale, importation, labeling, or distribution of tobacco products; or (2) encourage or promote the export, advertising, manufacture, sale, or distribution of tobacco products. 
Makes it unlawful for any domestic concern to export from the United States, or to sell or distribute in, or export from, any other country, any cigarettes whose package does not contain a warning label that:  (1) complies with Federal labeling requirements for cigarettes manufactured, imported, or packaged for sale or distribution within the United States; and (2) is in the primary language of the country in which the cigarettes are intended for consumption.  Authorizes the President to waive such labeling requirements if the cigarettes are exported to a foreign country included in a list of countries that have in effect requirements for the labeling of cigarette packages substantially similar to or more stringent than those set forth in this Act.  Sets penalties for violations. 
Repeals certain provisions of the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act.

Cosmetology Tax Fairness and Compliance Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to expand the tax credit for social security taxes paid with respect to employee tips to include tips received from customers or clients in connection with the providing of any cosmetology service for customers or clients at a facility licensed to provide such service if the tipping of employees providing such service is customary. Defines "cosmetology service" as hairdressing, haircutting, manicures and pedicures, body waxing, facials, mud packs, wraps, and other similar skin treatments, and any other beauty related service provided at a facility at which a majority of the services provided are described above.

Requires every person who employs one or more cosmetologists to provide any cosmetology service, rents a chair to one or more cosmetologists to provide any cosmetology service on at least five calendar days during a calendar year, or otherwise receives compensation from, or pays compensation to, one or more cosmetologists for the right to provide cosmetology services to, or for cosmetology services provided to, third-party patrons to comply with specified return requirements and taxpayer education requirements.

Caribbean National Forest Wild and Scenic Rivers Act of 2002 - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate specified segments of the Rio Mameyes, Rio de la Mina, and Rio Icacos in Puerto Rico as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

Employee Free Choice Act of 2016 This bill amends the National Labor Relations Act to require the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) to certify a labor organization as the exclusive bargaining representative for an appropriate unit of employees if: (1) a petition has been filed by an employee or group of employees alleging that a majority of employees in such unit wish to be represented by the labor organization, and (2) the NLRB finds that a majority of the employees in such unit have signed valid authorizations designating the labor organization as their bargaining representative and that no other individual or labor organization is currently certified or recognized as the exclusive representative of any of the employees in the unit. The NLRB shall develop guidelines and procedures for the designation by employees of a bargaining representative. Whenever collective bargaining is for the purpose of establishing an initial agreement following certification or recognition, the parties shall meet and commence to bargain collectively within 10 days after receiving a written request for collective bargaining from an individual or labor organization that has been newly organized or certified as a representative. If the parties fail to reach an agreement within 90 days, either party may notify the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service of the existence of a dispute and request mediation. If the Service is not able to bring the parties to agreement by conciliation within 30 days, the Service shall refer the dispute to an arbitration board. The arbitration panel shall render a decision settling the dispute and such decision shall be binding upon the parties for a period of two years, unless amended during such period by written consent of the parties. The NLRB shall award back pay and liquidated damages to an employee who was discriminated against while seeking representation by a labor organization or during the period after a labor organization was recognized as a representative until the first collective bargaining contract was entered into between the employer and the representative. Any employer who willfully or repeatedly commits any unfair labor practice while employees are seeking representation by a labor organization or during the period after a labor organization has been recognized as a representative until the first collective bargaining contract is entered into between the employer and the representative shall be subject to a civil penalty of up to $20,000 for each violation.

Equal Access to Medicare Options Act of 2009 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to guarantee the issuance of a Medicare supplemental policy to all Medicare beneficiaries, regardless of age.

Requires the Secretary to establish a one-time enrollment period for certain individuals who would not be eligible for such guaranteed issue of a Medicare supplemental policy but are entitled to hospital insurance benefits under part A and enrolled for benefits under part B.

Guarantees the issuance of a Medicare supplemental policy to an individual who: (1) was enrolled in a Medicare Advantage plan for at least 12 months and subsequently disenrolled from such plan and elects to receive benefits through the original Medicare fee-for-service program; or (2) is entitled to, or enrolled for, benefits under part A and enrolled for benefits under part B, was eligible for medical assistance under a state plan or waiver under title XIX (Medicaid), and subsequently lost eligibility for such medical assistance.

Revises the definition of "Medicare+Choice eligible individual" to mean an individual who is entitled to benefits under part A and enrolled under part B.

Directs the Attorney General to provide for the granting of posthumous U.S. citizenship to a person who: (1) while an alien or noncitizen national, died as a result of an injury incurred in one or more of the events described in this Act; (2) was not culpable for any of such events; and (3) on September 11, 2001, had pending an application for naturalization or for a certificate of citizenship filed with the Attorney General by the person or by a parent of the person.

Requires that the events described be the following: (1) the hijacking of American Airlines Flight 11 on September 11, 2001, the crash of that aircraft into the World Trade Center in New York, New York, and the subsequent destruction that resulted; (2) the hijacking of United Airlines Flight 175 on such date, the crash of that aircraft into the World Trade Center in New York, New York, and the subsequent destruction that resulted; (3) the hijacking of American Airlines Flight 77 on such date, the crash of that aircraft into the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia, and the subsequent destruction that resulted; and (4) the hijacking of United Airlines Flight 93 on such date, and the crash of that aircraft in Stony Creek Township, Pennsylvania.

States that any person who died as a result of an injury incurred while assisting in the emergency response to such event shall be considered to have died as a result of an injury incurred in such event.

Prohibits requiring a demonstration of an understanding of the English language or a knowledge and understanding of the fundamentals of the history, and of the principles and form of government, of the United States in order to be naturalized.

Prohibits requiring an oath of renunciation or allegiance.

Requires that the investigation and examination of applications be conducted in the same manner as they otherwise would have been conducted if the subject of the application had not died.

Permits requests for posthumous citizenship to be filed only by the next of kin or another representative, and requires that such requests be filed within two years after the later of the enactment of this Act or the death of the person.

Provides that nothing in this Act shall be construed as providing for any benefits under the Immigration and Nationality Act for any spouse, son, daughter, or other relative of a person granted posthumous citizenship.

Protecting Pregnant Women and Children From Perchlorate Act of 2011 - Amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to publish a health advisory for perchlorate that is fully protective, with an adequate margin of safety, of the health of vulnerable persons (including pregnant women, infants, and children), taking into consideration body weight, exposure patterns, and all routes of exposure.

Requires the Administrator to propose and finalize a national primary drinking water regulation for perchlorate that: (1) is protective, with an adequate margin of safety, of vulnerable persons; and (2) has a maximum contaminant level as close to the maximum contaminant level goal for perchlorate, and as protective of vulnerable persons, as feasible.

Moving to Work Reform Act of 2015 This bill prohibits the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) from entering into or extending any Moving to Work agreement for any public housing agency (PHA) for participation in the demonstration established under the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996, unless such agreement is subject to specified terms and conditions.  A PHA may not newly establish any rent policy that raises rent burdens for a significant portion of participating families, any time limitation on the term of housing assistance, or any policy that conditions receipt of housing assistance from program funds on employment status, unless: (1) the policy change will be subject to a detailed evaluation using a rigorous research methodology which includes random assignment to treatment and control groups to compare the impact on assisted families to similar families not subject to such policy change; and (2) HUD determines that adequate federal or other resources are available to undertake the required evaluation. A PHA may use funds appropriated for renewal of tenant-based rental assistance only for payments to or on behalf of eligible families that assist such families with housing costs, except that up to 10% of such funds may be used for other eligible purposes. A PHA shall receive funding for renewal of tenant-based rental assistance determined using the same formula applied to PHAs that do not participate in the demonstration, except that up to 10% of such funds may be renewed by adjusting the prior year's funding by an inflation factor determined by HUD. A PHA shall provide ongoing housing assistance resulting in average cost burdens no higher than those of families assisted under the United States Housing Act of 1937 to substantially the same number of eligible low-income families as the agency could assist if it expended the full amount of funding it receives under such sections pursuant to the requirements of such sections. If HUD determines that a disproportionately low share of families assisted by a PHA using funds appropriated pursuant to the United States Housing Act of 1937 lives in neighborhoods with low crime, high-performing schools, or other indicators of high opportunity, the PHA shall develop and implement a plan to expand families' access to such neighborhoods. A PHA shall receive funding for operation and management of public housing determined using the same formula applied to PHAs that do not participate in the demonstration, except that, for an agency that currently receives such funding under an alternative formula established by its Moving to Work agreement, HUD shall phase in the requirements of this paragraph in a manner sufficient so as to avoid reducing funding by more than 10% per year.  HUD shall conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the Moving to Work demonstration and submit to Congress a report describing and analyzing the risks and potential benefits of expanding the Moving to Work demonstration program to additional agencies compared to those of maintaining the demonstration program at its current size and identifying reforms, and selection criteria in case the demonstration program is expanded, that would improve the program's effectiveness in testing innovative policies while minimizing adverse effects on low-income families and ensuring efficient use of federal funds to meet the most pressing housing needs.

Deter Revolving-door Appointments In our Nation; Stop Washington Appointees from becoming Manipulative Petitioners Act or the DRAIN the SWAMP Act This bill amends the federal criminal code to prohibit a former political appointee of the executive branch (including an independent agency) from serving as a registered lobbyist for five years after the termination of such service or employment.  The Office of Government Ethics may waive such prohibition if it would create an undue hardship on the department or agency in obtaining qualified personnel to fill such position and granting the waiver would not create the potential for use of undue influence or unfair advantage.  The Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 is amended to prohibit a former political appointee from registering as an agent of a foreign principal or otherwise serving as the agent of a foreign principal.

Fair And Immediate Release of Generic Drugs Act or the FAIR Generics Act - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to revise provisions regarding the 180-day exclusivity period for generic drugs.

Defines "first applicant" as an applicant that: (1) submits a substantially complete application containing a certification that the drug is not infringing any patent; and (2) has not entered into a disqualifying agreement to defer commercial marketing.

Requires the first applicant to submit and maintain such certification for each unexpired patent for which a first applicant had submitted a certification on the first day on which a substantially complete application containing such certification was submitted. Prohibits an action for patent infringement from being brought against such applicant within 45 days after submission of the application, unless it is withdrawn or dismissed by a court without a decision that the patent was valid and infringed, or if the applicant has obtained a court decision that the patent is invalid or not infringed.

Prohibits the second applicant from beginning commercial marketing of such drug until 30 days after the date on which the first applicant began such commercial marketing.

Limits agreements between a first applicant and the holder of the application for the listed drug or an owner of one or more of the patents as to which any applicant submitted a certification qualifying such applicant for the 180-day exclusivity period whereby that applicant agrees: (1) not to seek an approval of its application that is made effective on the earliest possible date; (2) not to begin the commercial marketing of its drug on the earliest possible date after receiving an approval of its application that is made effective; or (3) to both items (1) and (2).

Requires the holder of an abbreviated application to submit to the Secretary of Health and Human Services a notification that includes: (1) the text of any agreement entered into by such holder; or (2) if such an agreement has not been reduced to text, a written detailed description of such agreement that is sufficient to disclose all the terms and conditions of the agreement. Requires such notification to be submitted not later than 10 business days after execution of the agreement.

Makes the exclusive remedy under patent law for an infringement of a patent for which the Secretary has published information pursuant to this Act an action brought within 45 days after submission of the application.

Public Health Equity Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the President to ensure that no person shall be excluded from participation in, denied the benefits of, or subject to discrimination under, any program or activity on the ground of race, color, or national origin. 
Requires the Secretary of Labor, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and any other head of a Federal agency with responsibility for providing Federal financial assistance to a program or activity to issue regulations implementing such nondiscrimination requirements.  Requires such regulations to: (1) bar acts with discriminatory effects as well as intentionally discriminatory acts; and (2) address actions of programs or activities that result in disproportionate exposure to a covered substance on the basis of race, color, or national origin.

Consumer Assurance of Radiologic Excellence Act of 2003 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish standards to assure the safety and accuracy of medical imaging or radiation therapy. Exempts physicians, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants from such standards.Requires individuals prior to performing or planning such imaging or therapy to have successfully completed a national examination approved by the Secretary for individuals who perform or plan medical imaging or radiation therapy and meet other requirements relating to medical imaging or radiation therapy as the Secretary may prescribe.Directs the Secretary to certify private nonprofit organizations or State agencies as approved bodies with respect to the accreditation of educational programs or the administration of examinations if they meet the standards established by the Secretary and provide the assurances required. Authorizes the Secretary to withdraw the certification of an approved body if it does not meet the standards.Declares that existing State standards for the licensure or certification of personnel, accreditation of educational programs, or administration of examinations shall be deemed to be in compliance with this Act unless the Secretary determines that such State standards do not meet the minimum standards prescribed by the Secretary or are inconsistent with the purposes of this Act.

Homeland Security Professional Development Act of 2006 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish the Homeland Security Mentoring Program and the Homeland Security Rotation Program for Department of Homeland Security (DHS) employees. Requires the Training Leaders Council established by the Chief Human Capital Officer to administer such programs.

Requires the Director of the Office of Personnel Management to report annually to specified congressional committees on the training, mentoring, and succession plans and programs of federal agencies.

HMO Guaranty Act of 2000 - Establishes in the Treasury the HMO Guaranty Fund to be used to make payments to a State to enable such State to pay the claims of health care providers for health care services provided to covered individuals prior to the declaration of insolvency of a health maintenance organization (HMO) and to provide for a temporary continuation of health care coverage for such individuals. 
Requires each licensed HMO to pay to the Fund an amount to be determined in accordance with an assessment schedule established by the Secretary of the Treasury.

Global Autism Assistance Act of 2008 - Directs the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to establish and administer a health and education grant program, to be known as the Global Autism Assistance Program, to: (1) support activities by nongovernmental organizations and other service providers focused on treating autism in developing countries; and (2) establish the "Teach the Teachers" program to train health and education professionals working with children with autism in developing countries.

Requires the Administrator to designate at least two regions in developing countries that require assistance in dealing with autism and have health and education professionals who are sufficiently familiar with issues related to autism to make effective use of the Program.

Directs the Administrator to select and provide funding to a nongovernmental organization with experience in autism-related issues to implement the Program by awarding grants to local service providers and advocacy groups focused on autism.

Requires the implementing nongovernmental organization to establish a Project Advisory Board to review and evaluate grant applications.

Requires the implementing nongovernmental organization to establish the Teach the Teachers Program to: (1) identify health and education professionals to receive specialized training for teaching and working with youth with autism; and (2) conduct training through two- or three-day biomedical conferences in the two designated regions.

Amends the Commodity Exchange Act to direct the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to maintain a liaison with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). 
Exempts from CFTC regulation certain energy and metal commodity transactions.  Requires bilateral dealer markets to:  (1) provide notice to the CFTC; (2) file reports; (3) maintain books and records for five years; (4) make such records available to representatives of the CFTC and the Department of Justice for inspection for five years; and (5) make certain information available to the public on a daily basis.  Requires a bilateral dealer market to adopt a value-at-risk model approved by the CFTC. 
Makes it unlawful for any member of a registered entity, or for any correspondent, agent, or employee of any member, in or in connection with any order to make, or the making of, any contract of sale of any commodity in interstate commerce, made, or to be made on or subject to the rules of any registered entity, or for any person, in or in connection with any order to make, or the making of, any agreement, transaction, or contract in a commodity subject to this Act, to cheat or defraud or attempt to cheat or defraud any person, willfully to make or cause to be made to any person any false report or statement, or willfully to enter or cause to be entered any false record, willfully to deceive or attempt to deceive any person by any means, or to bucket the order, or to fill the order by offset against the order of any person, or willfully, knowingly, and without the prior consent of any person to become the buyer in respect to any selling order of any person, or to become the seller in respect to any buying order of any person. 
Amends the Department of Energy Organization Act to direct FERC to refer to the appropriate Federal agency any contract that comes before it that is not under its jurisdiction.  Requires FERC to meet quarterly with a designee of the CFTC, the Securities Exchange Commission, the Federal Trade Commission, and the Federal Reserve Board to discuss conditions and events in energy trading markets and any changes in Federal law (including regulations) that may be appropriate to regulate energy trading markets.

International Remittance Services Enhancement and Protection Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal Credit Union Act to authorize a credit union to sell or provide for a fee negotiable checks (including travelers checks), money orders, international money transfer services, and other similar money transfer instruments and services.

Directs the appropriate Federal agencies to jointly prescribe regulations that require any financial institution or money transmitting business which initiates an international money transfer on behalf of a consumer to provide specified disclosures to the consumer before the consummation of the transaction.

New Economy Workforce Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide for an educational priority for certain family-sponsored immigrants.Requires a bachelor's degree (or higher degree) for diversity immigrants.Directs the Secretary of State to make determinations with respect to foreign degree equivalence and verification of educational credentials.

Select Agent Program and Biosafety Improvement Act of 2008 - Amends the Public Health Service Act and the Agricultural Bioterrorism Protection Act of 2002 to reauthorize through FY2013 the select agent program.

Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to contract with the National Academy of Sciences to review the select agent program.

Amends such Acts to require the Secretary to include in the list of biological agents and toxins: (1) whether the agent or toxin is endemic to the United States; (2) information available from biological risk assessments conducted by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS); and (3) newly discovered agents of disease, including genetically modified organisms or agents created synthetically.

Authorizes the Secretary to withhold information regarding a state that will assist with the state's emergency preparedness planning from the health director of such state if the state has in place a law to protect against the further release of such information.

Directs the Secretary to issue guidance on inventorying and monitoring the biological agents listed under such Acts.

Directs the Attorney General to issue public guidance regarding how the Attorney General interprets the scope of the statutory definition of "variola virus."

Directs the Secretary to develop and disseminate guidelines for how laboratories and laboratory personnel that do not regularly test for listed agents and toxins may be rapidly accessed and utilized during emergencies in which laboratories and laboratory personnel that regularly test for such agents and toxins are overwhelmed by a surge of samples of such listed agents and toxins.

Directs the Secretary to evaluate national needs of, and oversight of, high containment biological laboratories.

Directs the Secretary, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), to develop minimum standards for laboratory biosafety and biosecurity training for relevant personnel of high containment biological laboratories. Prohibits a person from registering with the Secretary or the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) for the possession, use, or transfer of listed agents unless the person provides to its appropriate personnel biosafety and biosecurity training that meets the minimum standards in addition to any other requirements determined appropriate by the Secretary or the Secretary of Agriculture.

Directs the Secretary to establish an integrated Biological Laboratory Incident Reporting System through which personnel of biological laboratories may voluntarily report biosafety or biosecurity incidents of concern and the Secretaries may identify trends in such incidents and protocols for biosafety or biosecurity improvements.

Military Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2003 - Amends Federal military law to provide for a phased increase in the basic annuity under the Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP) for surviving spouses over age 62. Provides for a corresponding phased elimination of the supplemental annuity.

Requires the Secretary of Defense to take actions to ensure that the reductions in retired pay are adjusted to achieve the objectives set forth in this Act.

Provides for an open enrollment period for SBP commencing October 1, 2004.

Fixed Asset Relief Act of 2015  This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase from 50% to 100% the bonus depreciation allowance for depreciable business assets. The bill also makes such increased bonus depreciation allowance permanent.

Preserve Rights of States and Political Subdivisions to Encourage Retirement Savings Act or the PROSPERS Act - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to exclude from the definition of "employee pension benefit plan" an individual retirement plan established and maintained pursuant to a payroll deduction savings program of a State or qualified political subdivision of a State, provided that certain requirements are met.

Houthis and Iran Sanctions Accountability Act of 2017 This bill declares that it shall be U.S. policy to condemn Iranian activities in Yemen in violation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 2216 (2015) and call on all responsible countries to take appropriate measures against the government of Iran, including the interdiction of Iranian weapons to the Houthis, and the bilateral and multilateral application of sanctions against Iran for its violations of such resolution. The bill continues in effect certain U.S. sanctions with respect to Yemen provided for in Executive Order 13611 (Blocking Property of Persons Threatening the Peace, Security, or Stability of Yemen). The President shall determine whether specified Iranian persons are responsible for engaging in activities described in such executive order. The President shall impose such sanctions on each Iranian person identified in the report submitted to Congress. The President shall impose specified sanctions on a foreign person that knowingly provides significant financial, material, or technological support for: (1) Ansar Allah in Yemen; (2) a person designated pursuant to an applicable executive order; (3) a person that is in violation of an applicable United Nations Security Council resolution; (4) an Iranian person identified in the report submitted to Congress; or (5) a foreign person owned or controlled by a foreign person described in the preceding categories. The President shall submit to Congress a report on Iranian activities in Yemen.

Skilled Workforce Enhancement Act of 1998 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small business employer a tax credit for 80 percent of the training expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the training period with respect to each qualified trained employee.  Limits the total amount of such credit per employee to $100,000.

Open Fuel Standard Act of 2009 or the OFS Act - Requires each light-duty automobile manufacturer's annual covered inventory to be comprised of: (1) at least 50% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2012, 2013, and 2014; and (2) at least 80% fuel choice-enabling automobiles in 2015 and in each subsequent year.

Defines "fuel choice-enabling automobile" as a flexible fuel automobile or an automobile that has been warranted by its manufacturer to operate on biodiesel.

Allows a manufacturer to request an exemption from such requirement if unavoidable events that are not under the control of the manufacturer prevent the manufacturer from meeting its required production volume of fuel choice-enabling automobiles. Conditions any such exemption upon the manufacturer's commitment to recall the exempted automobiles for installation of the omitted components within a reasonable time proposed by the manufacturer and approved by the Secretary of Transportation after such components become available in sufficient quantities to satisfy both anticipated production and recall volume requirements.

Provides limited liability protection for renewable fuel and ethanol manufacture, use, or distribution.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a limited charitable deduction for contributions of computer equipment and software to elementary and secondary schools and to qualified organizations providing assistance to individuals with disabilities. 
Requires the Comptroller General to study and report to specified congressional committees on the effectiveness of such enhanced charitable contribution in meeting educational needs of students in the United States. 
Expresses the sense of the Congress that one of the main purposes of such enhanced charitable deduction is to encourage the donation of computer equipment and software to:  (1) schools serving low income communities; (2) schools whose fiscal year budgets are below the applicable State-wide norm; and (3) schools at which student test scores are substantially below the State-wide norm.

Legacy IRA Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow tax-free distributions from individual retirement accounts for charitable purposes.  The aggregate amount excluded from gross income by such distributions shall not exceed $400,000.  The amount excluded from gross income shall not exceed: (1) $100,000 in the case of a distribution made directly by the trustee to a specified charitable organization; and (2) $400,000 in the case of a distribution made directly by the trustee to a split-interest entity.  A distribution from an individual retirement account shall be treated as a qualified charitable distribution only to the extent that the distribution would be includible in gross income without regard to this bill.  A distribution from an individual retirement account to a split-interest entity may only be treated as a qualified charitable distribution if: (1) no person holds an income interest in the split-interest entity other than the individual for whose benefit such account is maintained, the spouse of such individual, or both; and (2) the income interest in the split-interest entity is nonassignable.  A distribution from an individual retirement account to a specified charitable organization may be treated as a qualified charitable distribution only if: (1) in the case of a distribution to a charitable remainder annuity trust or a charitable remainder unitrust, a deduction for the entire value of the remainder interest in the distribution for the benefit of a specified charitable organization would be allowable under the tax code; and (2) in the case of a charitable gift annuity, a deduction in an amount equal to the amount of the distribution reduced by the value of the annuity would be allowable under the tax code.  Distributions made from a charitable remainder annuity trust or a charitable remainder unitrust shall be treated as ordinary income in the hands of the beneficiary to whom is paid the annuity.  Qualified charitable distributions made for a charitable gift annuity shall not be treated as an investment in the contract for purposes of determining the penalty for early withdrawal from an individual retirement account.  The entire amount of a qualified charitable distribution shall be taken into account for purposes of determining required minimum distributions.  This bill terminates the tax exclusion for distributions to a split-interest entity after December 31, 2020.

Promoting Financial Literacy and Economic Opportunity Act of 2015 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a business-related tax credit for up to $60 million in expenses incurred by an eligible for-profit organization to carry out a program that awards grants to promote economic and financial literacy. The Department of the Treasury must determine which for-profit organizations are allowed the credit, giving priority to taxpayers that have qualified programs which serve either urban or rural underserved areas. The majority of the taxpayers allowed the credit must be entities that: (1) are socially and economically disadvantaged small businesses, women-owned small businesses, or veteran-owned small businesses; or (2) do not have more than $60 billion in assets.

San Francisco Old Mint Commemorative Coin Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins emblematic of the San Francisco Old Mint Building, its importance to California and the history of the United States, and its role in rebuilding San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake and fire.

Requires all surcharges received from coin sales to be paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for use for rehabilitating the Historic Old Mint in San Francisco as a city museum and an American Coin and Gold Rush Museum.

Amends the Department of Transportation and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996 to provide whistleblower protection for Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) employees. 
Prohibits an employer from spending funds to implement or enforce the agreements in Standard Forms 312 and 4355 of the Federal Government or any other nondisclosure policy, form, or agreement if such policy, form, or agreement does not contain a specified statement regarding employee obligations, rights, or liabilities created by Executive Order No. 12958, the Intelligence Identities Protection Act of 1982, and statutes which protect against disclosures which may compromise national security.

Pay Stub Disclosure Act - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to require employers to provide employees with pay stubs that include: (1) the rate or rates of pay and whether the employee is paid by the hour, shift, day, week, or job, or by salary, piece rate, commission, or other form of compensation; (2) the name of the employer and any other name used by the employer to conduct business; (3) the physical address and telephone number of the employer's main office or principal place of business, and a mailing address if such mailing address is different from the address of the main office or principal place of business; (4) the pay period covered; (5) the name of the employee and the last four digits of the employee's Social Security number; (6) the total hours worked by the employee, including the number of hours worked per workweek in the pay period; (7) the total gross and net wages paid, the rate of pay for each hour worked, the amount of salary paid during the pay period, the number of piece-rate units earned, the applicable piece rate, and the total amount paid in accordance with such piece rate; (8) the number of overtime hours worked during each workweek of the pay period and the hourly rate of pay for each such overtime hour, or the piece rate paid for each such overtime hour; (9) any additional compensation paid or benefits provided, including an explanation of each type of compensation or benefit; and (10) any deductions, with an explanation of each deduction, and any allowances or reimbursements, with an explanation of each allowance or reimbursement.

Requires employers to keep records of the information disclosed in an employee's pay stub for three years from the date of issuance of each pay stub. Requires employers to provide copies of such records for up to three years prior to an employee's request for inspection.

Requires employers to provide a notice to each employee within 15 days of the date of hire that includes: (1) a description of the employee's right to receive a pay stub and the information which the pay stub must contain; (2) the address and telephone number for the applicable local office of the Department of Labor; and (3) such additional information as the Secretary of Labor shall require by regulation.

Sets forth penalties for violations of this Act.

United States Grain Standards Act Reauthorization Act of 2015 This bill amends the United States Grain Standards Act to: (1) require official grain inspections and weighings at export elevators, (2) direct the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to report on disruptions in federal inspection of grain exports at the Port of Vancouver in the summer of 2014, and (3) direct USDA to report on policy barriers to U.S. grain producers in countries that receive official grading for their grain but do not offer official grading for U.S. grain or provide only the lowest designation for U.S. grain.

Obamacare Marriage Penalty Elimination Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) eliminate the marriage penalty in the health insurance premium tax credit, and (2) reduce the poverty line eligibility limitation for such credit.

Lebanon and Syria Liberation Act - Declares that the actions of the government of the Syrian Arab Republic are a threat to U.S. national security interests and international peace.

Declares that U.S. policy shall be to deny Syria the ability to: (1) finance, provide safe-haven, or otherwise support terrorist organizations; (2) develop biological, chemical, or nuclear weapons and long-range ballistic missiles; (3) continue to occupy and otherwise interfere in the affairs of the government of Lebanon in contravention of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 425 (1978), 426 (1978), 520 (1982), and 1559 (2004), and other pertinent obligations; and (4) continue to oppress the people of Syria.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of State should ensure that U.S. diplomatic personnel abroad understand and communicate the reasons for U.S. policy and sanctions against the government of Syria, and urge foreign governments to cooperate more effectively with the United States.

Directs the President to: (1) direct the U.S. Permanent Representative to the United Nations to continue to use the voice and vote of the United States to oppose Syria's membership and candidacy for leadership posts in such institutions, and engage in diplomatic efforts to secure multilateral support for such efforts; (2) take necessary steps to secure support for a resolution at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights holding the government of Syria accountable for its systematic violations of human rights of Syrian and Lebanese citizens and calling for the appointment of a United Nations Special Rapporteur to investigate these human rights violations; (3) instruct the U.S. Executive Director at each international financial institution to use the voice and vote of the United States to oppose any loan or other assistance to Syria and to oppose Syria's membership in the institution; (4) instruct the U.S. Permanent Representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency to seek the adoption of a resolution calling on Syria to declare all nuclear related facilities, immediately and unconditionally suspend any activity which could be used to develop nuclear weapons capability, and provide full access to IAEA inspectors to its nuclear-related facilities; and (5) seek to establish contact groups with relevant countries in the Middle East to provide forums in which U.S. officials who are responsible for counter-proliferation efforts are able to meet, at least twice each year, with their counterpart from such countries to discuss the global threats presented by Iranian nuclear proliferation and sponsorship of international terrorism, and develop strategies to effectively address these threats.

Requires the President to report annually to the appropriate congressional committees on assistance to, and commerce with, Syria by other foreign countries during the preceding 12-month period.

States that it shall be U.S. policy to: (1) support independent human rights and pro-democracy forces in Syria to promote the emergence of a democratic government that will denounce and combat terrorism, dismantle its biological, chemical, and nuclear weapons programs and commit to combat the proliferation of such weapons, respect the boundaries and sovereignty of its neighbors and live in peace and security with all the countries in the region, and uphold and defend the human rights and civil liberties of its citizens; and (2) initiate efforts to restore Lebanese sovereignty, including the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of all Syrian personnel from Lebanon, and to support Lebanese civil society and pro-democracy forces in restoring a freely-elected, internationally recognized democratic government in Lebanon.

Authorizes the President to provide assistance and other support for individuals and independent nongovernmental organizations to support a transition to a freely-elected, internationally recognized democratic government in Syria and the restoration of sovereign, democratic rule in Lebanon.

Drug Trafficking Elimination Act of 2007 - Amends the Controlled Substances Act to increase penalties for: (1) unlawful manufacturing, distributing, dispensing, or possessing with intent to manufacture, distribute, or possess large amounts of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine; (2) unlawful importation and exportation of such substances; (3) manufacturing controlled substances on federal property; (4) use of hazardous substances on federal land; and (5) listed chemicals.

Amends the Controlled Substances Act to provide for: (1) murder and other violent crimes committed during and in relation to a drug trafficking crime; and (2) dangerous drug trafficking organizations.

Title II: Protecting Children from Drug Traffickers - Amends the Controlled Substances Act to increase penalties for: (1) distribution to persons under age 21 and pregnant persons; (2) distribution in or near schools; and (3) employment or use of persons under 18 years of age in drug operations.

Increases penalties for maintaining drug-involved premises in relation to involvement of children.

Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit a reduction in sentence for a defendant who was not engaged in a dangerous drug trafficking organization and whose offense or relevant conduct did not involve manufacturing, possessing with intent to distribute, or distributing any controlled substance in or near the presence of a child or conduct constituting an offense involving persons under age 21, pregnant persons, or persons under 18 years of age.

Title III: National Drug Trafficking Enforcement Strategy - Directs the Attorney General to develop a National Drug Trafficking Enforcement Strategy.

Portable Fuel Container Safety Act of 2017 This bill directs the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) to promulgate a final rule for flame mitigation devices in portable fuel containers that impedes the propagation of flame into the container. The CPSC shall treat such rule as a consumer product safety rule promulgated under the Consumer Product Safety Act. The bill provides an exception if the CPSC determines that there is a voluntary standard for flame mitigation devices in portable fuel containers that impedes the propagation of flame into the container, which is or will be in effect within 18 months after enactment of this bill, and which is developed by Subcommittee F15 of ASTM International or another standard development organization that the CPSC determines to have met the intent of this bill. If the CPSC determines that a voluntary standard meets the conditions described above, the requirements of such voluntary standard shall be treated as a consumer product safety rule promulgated under the Consumer Product Safety Act beginning on the later of: (1) 180 days after publication of the CPSC's determination; or (2) the effective date contained in the voluntary standard. If the requirements of a voluntary standard that meet the conditions are subsequently revised, the organization that revised the standard shall notify the CPSC not later than 60 days after the final approval of the revision. Not later than 180 days after the CPSC is notified of a revised voluntary standard, such revised voluntary standard shall become enforceable as a consumer product safety rule promulgated under the Consumer Product Safety Act, in place of the prior version, unless within 90 days after receiving the notice the CPSC determines that the revised voluntary standard does not meet the requirements described above. The CPSC may initiate a rulemaking at any time after publication of the consumer product safety rule required by this bill, a voluntary standard is treated as a consumer product safety rule, or a revision is enforceable as a consumer product safety rule to modify the requirements or to include any additional provision that the CPSC determines is reasonably necessary to protect public health or safety. Any rule promulgated under this section shall be treated as a consumer product safety rule promulgated under the Consumer Product Safety Act. The CPSC shall undertake a campaign to educate consumers about the dangers associated with using or storing portable fuel containers for flammable liquids near an open flame or any other source of ignition. The Children's Gasoline Burn Prevention Act is amended to require the CPSC to establish performance standards for gasoline receptacles, including spouts, caps, and other closure mechanisms and components, produced or distributed for sale to or use by consumers for transport of, or refueling of internal combustion engines with, gasoline, kerosene, or diesel fuel.

Local Control of Broadcast Towers Act - Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) from adopting as a final rule or otherwise implementing any portion of the proposed rule set forth in "Preemption of State and Local Zoning and Land Use Restrictions on Siting, Placement and Construction of Broadcast Station Transmission Facilities," MM Docket No. 97-182, released August 19, 1997. 
Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to authorize a State or local government to deny an application to place, construct, or modify broadcast transmission facilities on the basis that alternative technologies, delivery systems, or structures are capable of delivering broadcast signals comparable to that proposed to be delivered by such facilities in a manner that is less intrusive to the community concerned than such facilities. 
Authorizes a State or local government to regulate the location, height, or modification of broadcast transmission facilities in order to address the effects of radio frequency interference caused by such facilities on local communities and the public. 
Prohibits any provision of this Act from being interpreted to prohibit a State or local government from:  (1) requiring a person seeking authority to place, construct, or modify broadcast transmission facilities to produce environmental, biological, and health studies, engineering reports, or other documentation of the compliance of such facilities with radio frequency exposure limits, radio frequency interference impacts, and compliance with applicable laws, rules, and regulations governing the effects of such facilities on the environment, public health and safety, and the general welfare of the community and the public; and (2) refusing to grant authority to such person to place, construct, or modify such facilities within the jurisdiction of such government if such person fails to produce studies, reports, or documentation required under this Act.

Stopping Abuse and Fraud in Electronic Lending Act of 2018 or the SAFE Lending Act of 2018 This bill amends the Electronic Fund Transfer Act to prohibit a remotely created check from being issued by any person other than one designated in writing by a consumer. A designation may be revoked at any time by the consumer. No payment order, including a remotely created check, may be issued by any person in response to the exercise of, or attempt to exercise, any right by a consumer under: (1) federal consumer financial law, or (2) any other provision of any law or regulation within the jurisdiction of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). The bill amends the Truth in Lending Act to require a person to register with the CFPB before issuing credit in a small-dollar consumer credit transaction. A small-dollar consumer credit transaction is defined as any transaction that extends credit that is: (1) made to a consumer in an amount not more than $5,000 (or such greater amount as the CFPB may determine), adjusted annually to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers published by the Department of Labor; and (2) extended pursuant to an agreement that is other than an open end credit plan, payable in one or more installments of less than 12 months (or such longer period as the CFPB may determine), an open end credit plan in which each advance is fully repayable within a defined time or in connection with a defined event, or both, or any other plan as the CFPB determines. Any small-dollar consumer credit transaction shall comply with the laws of the state in which the consumer resides with respect to annual percentage rates, interest, fees, charges, and other similar matters if the transaction is made over the Internet, telephone, facsimile, mail, electronic mail, or other electronic communication, or conducted by a national bank. The bill prohibits charging a fee for an overdraft on a prepaid account. The bill amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit facilitating, brokering, arranging for, or gathering applications for the distribution of sensitive personal financial information in connection with a small-dollar consumer credit transaction unless the person is directly providing the small-dollar consumer credit to a consumer. The Government Accountability Office must study: (1) the availability of capital on reservations of Indian tribes, and (2) the impact that small-dollar consumer credit extended through Internet and non-Internet means to members of Indian tribes has had on economic opportunity and wealth for members of Indian tribes.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to:  (1) impose a tax on the income of every individual equal to 20 percent of the excess of taxable earned income over the standard deduction; (2) increase the standard deduction; (3) allow an income tax deduction for cash charitable contributions not to exceed $2,500 ($1,250 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return); (4) limit the home mortgage deduction to acquisition indebtedness; and (5) impose a tax on business activities.

ANCSA Unrecognized Community Landless Natives Authorization Act of 2017 This bill amends the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to authorize the Native residents of each of the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, Alaska, to organize as Urban Corporations. The Department of the Interior shall enroll to each of such Urban Corporations those individual Natives who enrolled under the Act to the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell, respectively. Each Native who is enrolled to an Urban Corporation for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell and who was enrolled as a shareholder of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska on or before March 30, 1973, shall receive 100 shares of Settlement Common Stock in the respective Urban Corporation. If a Native received shares of stock in the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska through inheritance from a decedent Native who originally enrolled to the Native Village of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell and the decedent Native was not a shareholder in a Village or Urban Corporation, the Native shall receive the identical number of shares of Settlement Common Stock in the Urban Corporation for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell as the number of shares inherited by that Native from the decedent Native who would have been eligible to be enrolled to the respective Urban Corporation.  Native members of the Native Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell who become shareholders in an Urban Corporation for such a Native Village shall continue to be eligible to receive distributions under the Act as at-large shareholders of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska.  On incorporation of the Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, Interior shall offer as compensation: (1) one township of land (23,040 acres) to each of the Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell; and (2) local areas of historical, cultural, traditional, and economic importance to Alaska Natives from the Villages of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, or Wrangell.

Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning Act of 2011 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require the Teacher and Principal Training and Recruiting Fund to train teachers and principals in practices that have demonstrated effectiveness in improving student achievement, attainment, and behavior through addressing the social and emotional development needs of students, such as through social and emotional learning programming.

Defines "social and emotional learning" as the process through which children and adults acquire the knowledge, attitudes, and skills associated with the core areas of social and emotional competency, including: (1) self-awareness and self-management to achieve school and life success; (2) social awareness and interpersonal skills to establish and maintain positive relationships; and (3) decisionmaking skills and responsible behaviors in personal, academic, and community contexts.

Redundant Remapping Reform Act of 2011 - Prohibits the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) from updating or publishing a National Flood Insurance Program rate map during a covered period with respect to an area that is protected by a levee: (1) for which a community or other party has sought recognition under specified regulations, and (2) with respect to which the Administrator has not issued a Letter of Final Determination.

Prohibits the Administrator from updating or publishing a National Flood Insurance Program rate map during a covered period with respect to an area that is protected by a qualified levee that is being planned, constructed, or rehabilitated, if the scheduled completion date for the planning, construction, or rehabilitation occurs during the covered period. Allows the Administrator to update or publish such a map during a covered period with respect to an area that is protected by a qualified levee: (1) on or after the date on which the construction or rehabilitation of the qualified levee is completed; or (2) on or after the date on which the Administrator determines that the planning, construction, or rehabilitation of the qualified levee is experiencing an indefinite delay.

Requires the Administrator to publish a notice to be used by owners of qualified levees subject to this Act to disclose to persons affected by the qualified levees information relating to the possible dangers of living in an area affected by the qualified levees without flood insurance coverage, information relating to the availability of flood insurance coverage, and any other information that the Administrator determines is necessary.

Requires the owner of the qualified levee to which the covered period relates to provide the notice published under this Act to each person identified by the owner of the qualified levee as a person affected by the qualified levee within 30 days after the commencement of a covered period. Requires the owner of the qualified levee to submit to the Administrator a quarterly report that contains: (1) a description of the progress of the construction or modification of the qualified levee; and (2) an estimate of the scheduled completion date of the construction or modification of the qualified levee.

Federal Energy Price Protection Act - Makes it unlawful for any supplier to increase the price at which that supplier sells, or offers to sell, crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates in an area covered by a Presidential proclamation issued under this Act by an unconscionable amount during the period beginning on the date the proclamation is issued and ending on the date specified in the proclamation.

Exempts from such prohibition increases in the price of the crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillate that are substantially attributable to: (1) an increase in the wholesale cost of such products to a supplier; (2) an increase in the replacement costs for such products sold; (3) an increase in operational costs; or (4) local, regional, national, or international market conditions. Requires consideration of other mitigating factors in determining whether a violation has occurred.

Authorizes the President to issue an emergency proclamation when an abnormal market disruption has occurred or is reasonably expected to occur. Limits the duration of such proclamation or order to 30 consecutive days (renewable for another 30 consecutive days), with a maximum of seven days preceding the occurrence of the event, circumstance, or condition that is the reason such proclamation or order is necessary.

Treats violations of this Act as unfair or deceptive acts or practices under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Directs the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to prevent any supplier from violating this Act in the same manner, by the same means, and with the same jurisdiction, powers, and duties as though all applicable terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act were incorporated into and made a part of this Act. Subjects any entity that violates any provision of this Act to the penalties and entitled to the privileges and immunities provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act in the same manner, by the same means, and with the same jurisdiction, power, and duties as though all applicable terms and provisions of the Federal Trade Commission Act were incorporated into and made a part of this Act.

Sets forth civil and criminal penalties for violations of this Act.

Requires amounts collected in fines and penalties under this Act to be deposited in a separate fund in the Treasury to be known as the Consumer Relief Trust Fund. Requires such amounts to be used to provide assistance under the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program administered by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Homeland Security Volunteerism Enhancement Act of 2005 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish: (1) a program to be known as the Citizen Corps to coordinate homeland security volunteer activities; and (2) a Border Corps, to be administered by the Commissioner of the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection.

Requires the Secretary to recruit, train, and accept volunteers for the Citizen Corps and the Border Corps.

Embassy Employee Compensation Act - Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Special Master appointed under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001, to administer a compensation program for individuals who were physically injured or killed as a result of the bombings of U.S. embassies in East Africa on August 7, 1998.

Authorizes appropriations.

Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) filing and review of claims; (2) eligibility for compensation; (3) waiver of the right to file a civil action; (4) payments to eligible individuals; and (5) regulations.

Grants the United States the right of subrogation with respect to any claim paid by the United States under this Act.

Targeting Child Predators Act of 2016 This bill amends the federal criminal code to revise provisions regarding the nondisclosure of administrative subpoenas. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) must issue an administrative subpoena for information or records relating to a person who is a child sex offender or a person who has been convicted of a felony involving a minor. A recipient of such a subpoena may not disclose that the federal official who issued the subpoena has sought or obtained access to information or records under this bill for 180 days if the federal official certifies that the absence of a prohibition of disclosure may result in: (1) endangering the life or physical safety of an individual, (2) flight from prosecution, (3) destruction of or tampering with evidence, (4) intimidation of potential witnesses, or (5) otherwise seriously jeopardizing an investigation or unduly delaying a trial. A recipient of a subpoena may disclose information otherwise subject to any applicable nondisclosure requirement to: (1) those persons to whom disclosure is necessary in order to comply with the request, (2) an attorney in order to obtain legal advice or assistance regarding the request, or (3) other persons as permitted by the federal official who issued the subpoena. A person to whom disclosure is made shall be subject to the nondisclosure requirements applicable to a person to whom a subpoena is issued in the same manner as the person to whom the subpoena was issued. Any recipient that discloses to a person described above information otherwise subject to a nondisclosure requirement shall notify the person of the applicable nondisclosure requirement. At the request of the federal official who issued the subpoena, any person making or intending to make a disclosure under this bill shall identify to the individual making the request the person to whom such disclosure will be made or to whom such disclosure was made prior to the request. A nondisclosure requirement imposed under this bill shall be subject to judicial review. A subpoena issued under this bill, in connection with which a nondisclosure requirement is imposed, shall include notice of the availability of judicial review. A nondisclosure requirement imposed under this bill may be extended. If a recipient of a subpoena wishes to have a court review a nondisclosure requirement imposed in connection with the subpoena, the recipient may notify the government or file a petition for judicial review in any U.S. district court. The government shall apply for an order prohibiting the disclosure of the existence or contents of the relevant subpoena within 30 days after receipt of a notification. The applicable nondisclosure requirement shall remain in effect during the pendency of proceedings relating to the requirement. A district court that receives a petition or an application shall rule expeditiously and issue a nondisclosure order that includes conditions appropriate to the circumstances. A district court shall issue a nondisclosure order or extension thereof if it determines that there is reason to believe that disclosure of the information subject to the nondisclosure requirement during the applicable time period may result in: (1) endangering the life or physical safety of an individual, (2) flight from prosecution, (3) destruction of or tampering with evidence, (4) intimidation of potential witnesses, or (5) otherwise seriously jeopardizing an investigation or unduly delaying a trial. Upon a showing that the circumstances continue to exist, a district court may issue an ex parte order extending a nondisclosure order for additional periods of 180 days or longer. In all proceedings under this bill, the court must close any hearing to the extent necessary to prevent an unauthorized disclosure of a request for records, a report, or other information made to any person or entity under this bill. Petitions, filings, records, orders, certifications, and subpoenas must also be kept under seal to the extent and as long as necessary to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of a subpoena.

University Transit Rider Innovation Program Act of 2015 or UTRIP Act This bill authorizes the Department of Transportation to make grants to increase the use of public transportation by college students. The bill requires a grant recipient or subrecipient to provide a discounted fare for public transportation that is: (1) not more than 75% of the fare, and (2) applicable to both monthly and single-ride fares. The bill sets forth an apportionment formula for the distribution of funds among large urbanized areas, small urbanized areas, and rural areas.

Directs the Under Secretary for Science and Technology in the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to provide for an independent study of the effects on human health caused by the use of backscatter x-ray machines at airline checkpoints operated by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

Requires the Administrator of TSA to ensure that large, easily readable signs or equivalent electronic displays are placed at the front of airline passenger check point queues where backscatter advanced imaging technology machines are used for screening to inform airline passengers, particularly those who may be sensitive to radiation exposure, that they may request to undergo alternative screening procedures instead of passing through a backscatter x-ray machine.

Tenth Amendment Enforcement Act of 1998 - Requires any statute enacted by the Congress on or after January 1, 1999, to include a declaration that:  (1) authority to govern in the area addressed by the statute is delegated to the Congress by the Constitution; (2) the Congress specifically finds that it has a greater degree of competence than the States to govern in such area; and (3) if the statute interferes with State powers or preempts any State or local government law, regulation, or ordinance, that the Congress specifically intends to do so and that such preemption is necessary. 
Makes it out of order in either the Senate or House of Representatives to consider any bill, joint resolution, or amendment that does not include such a declaration. 
Amends Federal civil service law to prohibit an agency from construing any statutory authorization to issue rules as authorizing preemption of State law or local ordinance by rulemaking or other agency action unless:  (1) the statute expressly authorizes issuance of preemptive rules; and (2) the agency concludes that the exercise of State power directly conflicts with the exercise of Federal power under the Federal statute, such that the State statutes and the Federal rule promulgated under the Federal statute cannot be reconciled or consistently stand together. 
Requires any regulatory preemption of State law to:  (1) be narrowly written to achieve the objectives of the statute under which the rules are promulgated; and (2) explicitly describe the scope of preemption. 
Sets forth requirements for notice and opportunity for comment when an agency proposes to act through rulemaking or other agency action to preempt State law. 
Requires each agency to publish in the Federal Register a plan for periodic review of the rules issued by the agency that preempt, in whole or in part, State or local government powers. 
Declares that any Federal rule or regulation promulgated after January 1, 1999, that is promulgated in a manner inconsistent with this Act shall not be binding on any State or local government, and shall not preempt any State or local government law, ordinance, or regulation. 
Prohibits any statute enacted after the date of enactment of this Act (or rule promulgated under such statute), from being construed by courts or other adjudicative entities to preempt, in whole or in part, any State or local government law, ordinance, or regulation unless:  (1) the statute, or rule promulgated under such statute, contains an explicit declaration of intent to preempt; or (2) there is a direct conflict between such statute and a State or local government law, ordinance, or regulation, such that the two cannot be reconciled or consistently stand together. 
Directs the Congressional Research Service to prepare and make available to the public a report on the extent of Federal statutory preemption of State and local government powers enacted into law during the preceding Congress or adopted through judicial interpretation of Federal statutes.

Directing Dollars to Disaster Relief Act of 2015 (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to: (1) develop and implement an integrated plan to control and reduce administrative costs for major disasters, (2) compare the costs and benefits of tracking the administrative cost data for major disasters by the public assistance, individual assistance, hazard mitigation, and mission assignment programs, and (3) clarify FEMA guidance and minimum documentation requirements for a direct administrative cost claimed by a grantee or subgrantee of a public assistance grant program. The bill requires FEMA to report annually on the development and implementation of the integrated plan for seven years. (Sec. 4) The bill requires FEMA to make such reports publicly available on its website.

Unfair Foreign Competition Act of 2007 - Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to authorize a petitioning party, within 30 days after an antidumping or countervailing duty investigation is initiated, to elect to bring a civil action in U.S. district court for a determination that: (1) an industry in the United States is materially injured, threatened with material injury, or has its establishment materially retarded by reason of imports, or sales (or the likelihood of sales) for importation, of the merchandise subject to the investigation; and (2) such imports are not negligible.

Authorizes a party who was a petitioning party in the initial investigation that resulted in the antidumping or countervailing duty order to bring a civil action in U.S. district court for a determination of whether revocation of the antidumping or countervailing duty order or termination of the investigation suspended would likely lead to continuation or recurrence of material injury based on specified standards.

Requires the International Trade Commission (ITC) to compile evidence with respect to the petition in the same manner and to the same extent as if an election had not been made. Requires any information compiled by the ITC to be made available to the parties to the proceeding and furnished to the district court in a timely manner.

Requires the district court to apply the same standards and make the same determinations and findings that would be made by the ITC if an election had not been made.

Sets forth special rules for actions initiated under this Act, including: (1) appealability to a U.S. Court of Appeals; (2) no stay pending appeal; (3) no binding effect of ITC decisions in other investigations; (4) opportunity for a petitioning party and any interested party to file briefs and argue orally to the court based on the information compiled by the ITC; (5) no obligation on any defendant interested party to attend a meeting or hearing; (6) no default judgment for failure to intervene in an action or otherwise participate in the proceedings; and (7) venue in a judicial district where a manufacturing facility, sales office, or administrative headquarters of any plaintiff who is a petitioning party is located.

Requires the court, upon motion, to issue a preliminary order that contains a determination of whether there is a reasonable indication that an industry in the United States is materially injured, threatened with material injury, or the establishment of an industry in the United States is materially retarded by reason of imports of the subject merchandise and that such imports are not negligible.

Requires an action brought under this Act to be advanced on the docket and expedited in every way practicable.

Requires the court to make arrangements to protect the confidentiality of information designated as proprietary by an interested party pursuant to a judicial protective order.

Requires the court to retain jurisdiction over the injury determination for purposes of changed circumstances reviews if the injury determination at issue was initially made by a U.S. district court.

Applies this Act to goods from Canada and Mexico.

Directs the Secretary of State to notify the appropriate officials of the World Trade Organization of the amendments made by this Act and that U.S. district courts shall be treated as competent authorities for purposes of injury determinations under title VII of the Tariff Act of 1930.

1998 Supplemental Appropriations Act for the International Monetary Fund - Makes appropriations to the President and to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) under the New Arrangements to Borrow. 
Makes appropriations for an increase in the U.S. quota in the IMF. 
Sets forth conditions for the use of quota resources. 
Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to certify to the appropriate congressional committees that the Board of Executive Directors of the IMF has agreed to provide timely access by the Comptroller General to information and documents relating to the Fund's operations, program and policy reviews and decisions regarding stand-by agreements and other uses of the Fund's resources. 
Requires the Secretary to develop and implement a plan to obtain timely public access to such information and documents. 
Directs the Secretary to report to the appropriate congressional committees on the status of timely publication of Letters of Intent and Article IV consultation documents and the availability of such information. 
Directs the President to establish an International Financial Institution Advisory Commission which shall report to the appropriate congressional committees on the future role and responsibilities of the IMF and the merit, costs and related implications of consolidation of the organization, management, and activities of the IMF, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), and the World Trade Organization. 
Directs the President to call for a conference of representatives of the governments of the member countries of the IMF, the World Bank, and the World Trade Organization to consider the structure, management and activities of the institutions, their possible merger, and their capacity to contribute to exchange rate stability and economic growth and to respond effectively to financial crises. 
Directs the Secretary to report to the appropriate congressional committees:  (1) following the extension of a stand-by agreement or other uses of the resources by the IMF, on specified information; and (2) following the extension of a stand-by agreement or other use of the Fund's resources, on an account of the direct and indirect institutional recipients of such resources. 
Directs the Secretary to submit a report to the appropriate congressional committees providing such information for South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines. 
Directs the Secretary to certify to the appropriate congressional committees that certain conditions have been met with respect to the disbursement of any Fund resources to the borrower.

Asthma Act - Authorizes additional appropriations to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute for FY2010-FY2014 to carry out the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program.

Requires the coordinating committee of such Program to report to Congress on: (1) the scope of asthma in the United States; (2) all federal programs that carry out asthma-related activities; and (3) recommendations for strengthening and better coordinating such activities.
