Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to collaborate with states to expand the scope of: (1) activities to determine the incidence and prevalence of asthma; and (2) activities to prevent the health consequences of asthma, including through the provision of information and education to the public regarding asthma. Requires the Secretary to conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on the prevalence and severity of asthma and the quality of asthma management.

Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to nonprofit private entities for projects to carry out outreach activities to provide residents of communities with: (1) information and education on asthma; and (2) referrals to health programs of public and nonprofit private entities that provide asthma-related services, including services for low-income individuals.

Directs the Secretary to carry out a program to encourage states to implement plans to assist children with respect to asthma in accordance with guidelines of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. Provides for matching funds for state plans under title XXI (Children's Health Insurance) of the Social Security Act.

Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make grants to local educational agencies to carry out at elementary and secondary schools located in communities with a significant number of low-income or underserved individuals programs for asthma-related activities for children who attend such schools.

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) hospitals should be encouraged to offer asthma-related education and training to asthma patients and families upon discharge from the hospital of such patients; (2) hospitals should establish telephone services for patients and communicate with providers of primary health services; and (3) managed care organizations should be encouraged to disseminate to health care providers asthma clinical practice guidelines developed or endorsed by the Public Health Service, collect and maintain asthma data, and offer asthma-related education and training to asthma patients and their families.

Expresses the sense of Congress that all federal, state, and local asthma-related activities should: (1) promote the guidelines and other recommendations of the Public Health Service on asthma diagnosis and management; and (2) be designed in consultation with national and local organizations representing the medical, educational, and environmental communities, as well as advocates that represent those affected by asthma.

Oil Subsidy Elimination Act of 2006 - Requires certain large integrated oil companies to: (1) increase the value of each historic LIFO layer of inventories of crude oil, natural gas, or any other petroleum product by a specified amount; and (2) decrease its cost of goods sold for such taxable year by the aggregate amount of the increases.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to eliminate the amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures for major integrated oil companies.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to modify foreign tax credit rules applicable to large integrated oil companies which are dual capacity taxpayers.

Repeals specified provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 relating to: (1) temporary expensing for equipment used in refining of liquid fuels; (2) determination of small refiner exception to oil depletion deduction; and (3) amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures.

Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty Preservation Act of 2017 This bill declares that: (1) the actions undertaken by Russia in violation of the INF Treaty constitute a material breach of the treaty, and (2) the United States is legally entitled to suspend the operation of the INF Treaty in whole or in part for so long as Russia continues to be in material breach. The Department of Defense shall establish a program of record to develop a dual-capable road-mobile ground-launched cruise missile system with a range of between 500 to 5,500 kilometers. The Director of National Intelligence shall report to Congress and the President on whether Russia has flight tested, produced, or possesses a system that is inconsistent with the INF Treaty.  The bill limits the availability of funds for FY2018 or any other fiscal year for the Department of Defense to extend the implementation of the New START Treaty for any year after 2021, permit flights by Russia over the United States or its allies pursuant to the Open Skies Treaty, or permit the approval of new or updated implementation decisions of the Open Skies Consultative Commission pursuant to Article X of the Open Skies Treaty, or any license or authorization to export any item or technology to a person or entity in Russia unless the President certifies to Congress that Russia has verifiably eliminated all missiles that are in violation of or may be inconsistent with the INF Treaty. The Department of State shall review the RS-26 ballistic missile of Russia. If the Department determines that the RS-26 ballistic missile is covered under the New START Treaty and that Russia has not taken specified steps, the U.S. government shall consider for purposes of all policies and decisions that the RS-26 ballistic missile of Russia is a violation of the INF Treaty.

Department of Veterans Affairs Major Medical Facility Lease Authorization Act of 2013 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to carry out major medical facility leases at specified locations, including for a clinical research and pharmacy coordinating center in Albuquerque, New Mexico; a community-based outpatient clinic in Brick, New Jersey; a new primary care and dental clinic annex in Charleston, South Carolina; the Cobb County community-based Outpatient Clinic in Cobb County, Georgia; the Leeward Outpatient Healthcare Access Center in Honolulu, Hawaii; a community-based outpatient clinic in Johnson County, Kansas; a replacement community-based outpatient clinic in Lafayette, Louisiana; a community-based outpatient clinic in Lake Charles, Louisiana; outpatient clinic consolidation in New Port Richey, Florida; an outpatient clinic in Ponce, Puerto Rico; lease consolidation in San Antonio, Texas; a community-based outpatient clinic in San Diego, California; an outpatient clinic in Tyler, Texas; the Errera Community Care Center in West Haven, Connecticut; the Worcester community-based Outpatient Clinic in Worcester, Massachusetts; the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic in Cape Girardeau, Missouri; a multispecialty clinic in Chattanooga, Tennessee; the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic in Chico, California; a community-based outpatient clinic in Chula Vista, California; a new research lease in Hines, Illinois; a replacement research lease in Houston, Texas; a community-based outpatient clinic in Lincoln, Nebraska; a community-based outpatient clinic in Lubbock, Texas; a community-based outpatient clinic consolidation in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina; a community-based outpatient clinic in Phoenix, Arizona; the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic in Redding, California; and the expansion of a community-based outpatient clinic in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Requires the Secretary, in exercising the authority to enter into such leases, to record as the full cost of the contractual obligation at the time a contract is executed either: (1) an amount equal to total payments under the full term of the lease; or (2) if the lease specifies payments to be made in the event the lease is terminated before its full term, an amount sufficient to cover the first year lease payments plus the specified cancellation costs. Amends federal veterans' benefits law to require a prospectus proposing funding for a major medical facility lease to include a detailed analysis of how the lease is expected to comply with Office of Management and Budget Circular A-11 and the Anti-Deficiency Act. Directs the Secretary to submit to the congressional veterans' committees: (1) notice of the Secretary's intention to enter into the lease, a copy of the proposed lease, a description and analysis of any differences between the prospectus submitted and the proposed lease, and a scoring analysis demonstrating that the proposed lease fully complies with Office of Management and Budget Circular A-11; and (2) a report on any material differences between the lease that was entered into and the proposed lease, including how the lease that was entered into changes the previously submitted scoring analysis.

Aviation Industry Stabilization Act of 2003 - Amends Federal aviation law to: (1) require the Secretary of Transportation to extend through December 31, 2007, the authority of the Air Transportation Stabilization Board to issue aviation insurance policies; and (2) revise coverage requirements for such policies.

Authorizes applications for Federal credit instruments to be filed for a period of 30 days following the date on which the President authorizes the military to use force against Iraq in calendar year 2003, and the Board determines that an extraordinary increase in jet fuel prices has occurred. Limits such credit instruments to six months or until the Secretary determines that the average price for jet fuel in calendar year 2003 is equal to or less than the average price reported by major air carriers for calendar year 2002, whichever period ends sooner. Limits the maximum amount of Federal credit instruments that may be issued by the Board to $3 billion. Requires the Board to establish a formula setting the maximum amount of Federal credit instruments that may be issued to any air carrier based on the percentage of gallons of aviation fuel consumed by that air carrier in proportion to the total gallons of aviation fuel consumed by all air carriers during calendar year 2002.

Directs the Under Secretary for Border and Transportation Security of the Department of Homeland Security to consider whether it is necessary to require Federal air marshals to be seated in the first class cabin of an aircraft with strengthened cockpit doors.

Requires the Under Secretary to undertake, without a decrease in aviation security, such action as may be necessary to improve the screening of mail so that it can be carried on passenger flights of air carriers.

Directs the Under Secretary to reimburse air carriers and airports for: (1) all screening and related activities that the air carriers or airports perform or are responsible for performing, including the screening of catering supplies, checking documents at security checkpoints, screening of passengers, and screening of persons with access to aircraft; and (2) the provision of space and facilities used to perform screening functions if such space and facilities have been previously used, or were intended to be used, for revenue-producing purposes.

Directs the Under Secretary to reimburse air carriers for the cost of fortifying cockpit doors.

Directs the Secretary of Transportation to reimburse an air carrier for any financial losses that the Secretary determines are attributable to the loss of air traffic resulting from the use of force against Iraq in calendar year 2003.

Amends Federal law to require an airlift services contract entered into by the Secretary of Defense and an air carrier to ensure that the air carrier is compensated for the positioning, de-positioning, and other ferry portions of missions performed under the contract.

Directs the Secretary of Energy, if the President authorizes the military to use force against Iraq in calendar year 2003, to drawdown and distribute petroleum from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in quantities of not less than 500,000 barrels per day, to the extent necessary to remedy a dislocation in the jet fuel market or an extraordinary increase in the price of jet fuel.

Directs the Under Secretary to establish an air cargo security working group with industry experts from the Transportation Security Administration, passenger airlines, indirect air carriers, shippers, small businesses, and other related groups to develop recommendations on the enhancement of the current known shipper program.

Directs the Comptroller General to analyze the factors contributing to the financial difficulties of air carriers for the purpose of determining possible approaches to alleviate such difficulties.

Scenic Columbia Gorge Restoration Act of 2017 This bill directs the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to begin proposing response activities for lands within a National Scenic Area adversely impacted by a catastrophic event within 30 days after the conclusion of such event. A "catastrophic event" is any natural disaster or any fire, flood, or explosion, regardless of cause. USDA shall allow 30 days for public scoping and comment regarding a National Scenic Area response activity, 15 days for filing an objection to the response activity, and 15 days for the agency response to the filing of an objection. Upon completion of this process and expiration of the period specified in the bill, USDA shall implement the response activity. An environmental assessment prepared by USDA for a National Scenic Area response activity shall be completed within 60 days after the conclusion of the catastrophic event. A categorical exclusion is available for any National Scenic Area response activity that: (1) does not exceed 10,000 acres within the National Scenic Area, and (2) includes lands that are visible from key viewing areas, provide screening for human development, are part of a municipal watershed, or contain utility or power transmission right-of-ways. Consultation under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 shall not be required if USDA determines that a response activity is not likely to adversely affect a listed species or designated critical habitat. With respect to a response activity that is not covered by the previous sentence, consultation required under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 shall be concluded within the 90-day period beginning on the date on which such consultation was requested by USDA. In the case of a consultation that is not concluded within the 90-day period, the response activity for which such consultation was initiated: (1) shall be deemed to have not violated the Endangered Species Act of 1973, and (2) may be carried out. No restraining order, preliminary injunction, or injunction pending appeal shall be issued by any U.S. court with respect to any decision to prepare or conduct a response activity. Amounts in the special fund established pursuant to the Knutson-Vandenberg Act shall be available to USDA for response activities. In the case of response activities conducted on National Scenic Area lands adversely impacted by a catastrophic event, USDA shall achieve reforestation of at least 75% of the impacted lands before the end of the two-year period following the conclusion of the catastrophic event.

Foreign-Held Debt Transparency and Threat Assessment Act - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the growing federal debt has the potential to jeopardize U.S. national security and economic stability; (2) increasing dependence on foreign creditors has the potential to make the United States vulnerable to undue influence by certain foreign creditors in national security and economic policymaking; (3) China is the largest foreign creditor of the United States, in terms of its overall holdings of U.S. debt instruments; (4) the current level of transparency in the scope and extent of foreign holdings of U.S. debt instruments is inadequate and needs to be improved, particularly regarding China's holdings; (5) through China's large holdings of U.S. debt instruments, China has become a super creditor of the United States; (6) under certain circumstances, China's holdings could give China a tool with which it can try to manipulate U.S. domestic and foreign policymaking, including the U.S. relationship with Taiwan; (7) under certain circumstances, if China were displeased with a given U.S. policy or action, China could attempt to destabilize the U.S. economy by rapidly divesting large portions of China's holdings of U.S. debt instruments; and (8) China's expansive holdings of such debt instruments could potentially pose a direct threat to the U.S. economy and to U.S. national security.

Directs the President to report quarterly to Congress on the risks posed by foreign holdings of U.S. debt instruments.

Requires the Comptroller General to report annually to Congress on the risks to the United States posed by the federal debt.

Requires the President, within 30 days of determining that a foreign country's holdings of U.S. debt instruments pose an unacceptable risk to the long-term national security or economic stability of the United States, to: (1) formulate a plan of action to reduce the risk level to an acceptable and sustainable level, in a manner that results in a reduction in federal spending; (2) submit to Congress a report on the plan of action that includes a timeline for implementation and recommendations for any legislative action that would be required to fully implement the plan; and (3) move expeditiously to implement the plan in order to protect the long-term national security and economic stability of the United States.

Federal Spectrum Incentive Act of 2013 - Amends the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act to revise requirements for the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to notify the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) of estimated relocation or sharing costs and timelines for the relocation or sharing of eligible frequencies. Requires the NTIA, instead, to notify the FCC that a federal entity will receive payment from the Federal Spectrum Incentive Fund established by this Act because such entity is discontinuing operations on such eligible frequencies without relocating them to other frequencies or relocating them to frequencies assigned to another federal entity in order for such entities to share such frequencies. Exempts such discontinuance or relocation from the requirement that the NTIA notify the FCC of estimated relocation or sharing costs and timelines. Requires a federal entity authorized to use any eligible frequency to submit to the NTIA and to the Technical Panel a transition plan in which the entity: (1) declares its intention to share such eligible frequencies with a non-federal user or to relocate to other frequencies, and to receive relocation or sharing costs from the Spectrum Relocation Fund; or (2) declares its intention to discontinue the operations that the entity conducts on such eligible frequencies without relocating them to other frequencies or to relocate them to frequencies assigned to another federal entity in order for such entities to share such frequencies, and to receive payment from the Federal Spectrum Incentive Fund. Requires the NTIA to specify, after public input, a common format for all federal entities to follow in preparing transition plans. Revises the definition of "relocation or sharing costs" to include the costs incurred by an incumbent federal entity to accommodate sharing the spectrum frequencies assigned to such entity with a federal entity the operations of which are being relocated from eligible frequencies, unless the FCC receives notice under this Act with respect to the relocation of such operations. Revises the definition of "eligible federal entity" to include an incumbent federal entity. Revises the definition of "incumbent federal entity" to include an eligible federal entity the operations of which are being relocated from eligible frequencies. Revises the definition of "relocation or sharing costs" to include the costs incurred by an incumbent federal entity to accommodate sharing the spectrum frequencies assigned to such entity with a federal entity the operations of which are being relocated from eligible frequencies, unless the FCC receives notice under this Act with respect to the relocation of such operations. Revises the definition of "eligible federal entity" to include an incumbent federal entity. Revises the definition of "incumbent federal entity" to include an eligible federal entity the operations of which are being relocated from eligible frequencies.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from taxation a qualified State tuition program.  Defines such program as one established and maintained by a State or agency or instrumentality thereof under which a person may:  (1) purchase tuition credits or certificates on behalf of a designated beneficiary which entitle the beneficiary to the waiver or payment of qualified higher education expenses of the beneficiary; or (2) make contributions to an account which is established for the sole purpose of meeting the qualified higher education expenses of the designated beneficiary of the account. 
Excludes from gross income any amount received by a designated beneficiary or a contributor to such program with respect to any distribution from, or earnings under, such program.  Provides for the tax treatment of distributions, in-kind distributions, changes in beneficiaries, and gift tax treatment. 
Sets forth reporting requirements.

Flexible Refinancing for American Families Act of 2012 - Directs the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) to carry out a program to provide for the refinancing of qualified mortgages on single-family housing owned by such enterprise through a refinancing mortgage having a 50-year term, and for the purchase of and securitization of such refinancing mortgages. Requires such program to require such refinancing of a qualified mortgage upon the request of the mortgagor made to the applicable enterprise and a determination by the enterprise that the mortgage is a qualified mortgage.

Defines "qualified mortgage" as a mortgage, without regard to whether the mortgagor is current on or in default on payments due under the mortgage, that: (1) is an existing first mortgage that was made for purchase of, or refinancing another first mortgage on, a one- to four-family dwelling, including a condominium or a share in a cooperative ownership housing association, that is occupied by the mortgagor as the principal residence of the mortgagor; (2) is owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac; and (3) was originated on or before the date of enactment of this Act.

Requires the refinancing mortgage to have a term to maturity of 50 years from the date of the beginning of the amortization of the mortgage and to fully amortize over such term, except that the mortgagee may, at the sole option of the mortgagee, require payment in full of all amounts of principal and interest owed under the mortgage on the date that is 30 years after the date of the beginning of the amortization of the mortgage, but only if the mortgagee provides written notice to the mortgagor of such acceleration of indebtedness not fewer than 90 days in advance of such acceleration.

Requires the mortgage to bear interest at a single rate that is fixed for the entire term of the mortgage, which shall be equivalent to the premium received by the enterprise on the qualified mortgage being refinanced plus the cost of selling a newly issued mortgage having comparable risk and term to maturity in a mortgage-backed security, as such rate may be increased to the extent necessary to cover, over the term to maturity of the mortgage, any fee paid to the servicer pursuant to this Act, the cost of any title insurance coverage issued in connection with the mortgage, and, as determined by the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, a portion of any administrative costs of the program under this Act as may be attributable to the mortgage.

Waives or forgives all penalties for prepayment or refinancing of the qualified mortgage that is refinanced by the mortgage, and all fees and penalties related to the default or delinquency on such mortgage.

Prohibits the servicer conducting the refinancing from charging the mortgagor any fee for the refinancing of the qualified mortgage through the refinancing mortgage.

Requires the fee for title insurance coverage issued in connection with the mortgage to be reasonable in comparison with fees for such coverage available in the market for mortgages having similar terms.

Directs each enterprise to pay the servicer a fee not exceeding $1,000 for each qualified mortgage of an enterprise that the servicer of the qualified mortgage refinances through a refinancing mortgage pursuant to this Act.

Prohibits the enterprises from requiring an appraisal of the property subject to a refinancing mortgage to be conducted in connection with such refinancing.

Terminates the requirement for the enterprises to refinance qualified mortgages after the expiration of the one-year period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act.

Creating Opportunities for Rural Economic Expansion Act or the CORE Act This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to require that at least 5% of the new markets tax credit limitation be allocated to qualified community development entities in connection with qualified investments the proceeds of which are substantially used to make qualified coal community investments. A "qualified coal community investment" is: (1) any capital or equity investment in, or loan to, any qualified active distressed coal community business; (2) the purchase from another community development entity of any loan made by such entity which is a qualified coal community investment; (3) financial counseling and other services specified in regulations prescribed by the Department of the Treasury to businesses located in, and residents of, distressed coal communities; and (4) any equity investment in, or loan to, any qualified community development entity in connection with qualified investments the proceeds of which are substantially used to make qualified coal community investments. A "qualified active distressed coal community business" is any business which would be a qualified active low-income community business if certain requirements were applied by substituting "distressed coal community" for "low-income community" each place it appears. A "distressed coal community" is any low-income community located in a county that: (1) was one of the 30 counties with the biggest employment decrease among coal operators for an applicable period, or (2) is contiguous to a county that is described in this paragraph and is within the same state as such county and contains not less than one low-income community. The applicable periods are calendar year 2013 compared to calendar year 2012, calendar year 2014 compared to calendar year 2013, and calendar year 2015 compared to calendar year 2014.

Canine Members of the Armed Forces Act - Directs the Secretary of Defense to classify military working dogs as canine members of the armed forces and not as equipment. Authorizes the Secretary of the military department concerned to transfer a retired military working dog to: (1) the 341st Training Squadron; or (2) another location for adoption if no suitable adoption is available at the military facility where the dog is located.

Authorizes the use of frequent traveler miles to facilitate the adoption of a military working dog.

Directs the Secretary to establish and maintain a system to provide for the veterinary care of retired military working dogs.

Requires the Secretary to create a decoration or other appropriate recognition to recognize military working dogs under the jurisdiction of the Secretary that are killed in action or perform an exceptionally meritorious or courageous act in service to the United States.

Aggregate Risk and Revenue Management Act of 2011 or the ARRM Act of 2011 - Amends the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 to replace direct and counter-cyclical payments for covered commodities and peanuts with an aggregate risk and revenue management (ARRM) program.

Requires the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to give producers on a farm an opportunity to make an annual election for all producers on the farm to receive ARRM payments during each of crop years 2013 through 2017. Requires the total number of planted acres for which producers may receive ARRM payments to be equal to the total number of acres planted to all covered commodities and peanuts on the farm.

Excludes native sod acreage that is tilled for the purpose of producing an annual crop after enactment of this Act from consideration as acreage planted to the covered commodity or peanuts for harvest on a farm in a crop year for purposes of making ARRM payments during the first five crop years of planting.

Requires the Secretary to review crop reporting districts (CRDs) in western states that have seven or fewer CRDs to assess whether additional CRDs are necessary.

Repeals provisions authorizing: (1) direct and counter-cyclical payments for covered commodities and peanuts; and (2) permanent price support authority for covered commodities and peanuts.

Amends the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 to require that at least 50 percent of all microenterprise assistance under such Act be targeted to the very poor (defined as individuals living in the bottom 50 percent below the poverty line established by the national government of the country in which those individuals live or living on the equivalent of less than $1 per day).

Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to authorize the President to provide assistance to increase the availability of financial services to microenterprise households lacking full access to credit, including through: (1) loans and guarantees to microfinance institutions for the purpose of expanding the availability of savings and credit to poor and low-income households; (2) training programs for microfinance institutions in order to enable them to better meet the financial services needs of their clients; and (3) training programs for clients in order to enable them to make better use of credit, increase their financial literacy, and to better manage their enterprises to improve their quality of life.

Requires the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), in consultation with microenterprise institutions and other appropriate organizations, to develop no fewer than two low-cost methods for partner institutions to use to assess the poverty levels of their current or prospective clients. Requires USAID to develop poverty indicators that correlate with the circumstances of the very poor. Requires the Administrator to field-test the methods developed. Requires the Administrator to certify no fewer than two such methods as approved methods for measuring the poverty levels of current or prospective clients of microenterprise institutions for purposes of assistance under the Microenterprise Development Grant Assistance Program. Requires the Administrator to require that, with reasonable exceptions, all organizations applying for microenterprise assistance under such Program use one of the certified methods, beginning no later than October 1, 2005, to determine and report the poverty levels of current or prospective clients.

Caring Family Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an additional personal tax exemption for each qualified family member of the taxpayer who is: (1) a spouse or dependent; (2) age 60 or older; (3) an individual with long-term care needs; and (4) who, for more than one-half of the taxable year, has as such individual's principal place of abode the home of the taxpayer and is a member of the taxpayer's household.

(Sec. 1) This bill extends through January 31, 2014, the authorities provided by each provision of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (FCEA) and each amendment made by that Act (and for mandatory programs at such funding levels), as in effect on September 30, 2013, pursuant to the extension and amendments made by the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. The Secretary of Agriculture shall carry out such authorities until January 31, 2014, except as provided in this bill.  The bill suspends through January 31, 2014, the provisions of law relating to: (1) permanent price support authorities; and (2) supplemental agricultural disaster assistance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act.  The bill provides exceptions to such extension with respect to: (1) nutrition, conservation, trade, survey of foods purchased by school food authorities, rural development, market loss assistance for asparagus producers, supplemental agricultural disaster assistance, Pigford claims, and the Heartland, Habitat, Harvest, and Horticulture Act of 2008.

International Statistical Information and Analysis Act of 1993 - Amends Federal law to direct the Secretary of Commerce to prepare and submit to the Congress each year a report analyzing the progress being made by the independent states of the former Soviet Union and the Baltic States in establishing a free market economy. 
Directs the President to establish an International Statistical Assistance Coordinating Committee to:  (1) determine priorities for providing training and other technical assistance to develop capabilities to monitor economic performance in such countries through the collection, analysis, and dissemination of economic statistical data; (2) use the expertise of its constituent agencies in providing such assistance; (3) be responsible for coordinating such assistance with comparable assistance provided or coordinated by international or multilateral organizations or agencies; and (4) provide for the analysis by its constituent agencies of economic statistical data regarding such countries and for the dissemination of such analysis to U.S. businesses and other interested parties, including dissemination through the annual report required by this Act. 
Requires U.S. assistance that is provided to encourage the development of a free-market economic system in such countries to include training and other technical assistance to develop capabilities to monitor economic performance in those republics and states through the collection, analysis, and dissemination of economic statistical data. 
Expresses the sense of the Congress that at least $3 million of the funds allocated for each of FY 1994 through 1998 for U.S. economic assistance to encourage the development of a free-market economic system in such countries should be used for training and other technical assistance pursuant to this Act.

Travelling Sales Crew Protection Act - Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to exclude from its definition of "outside salesman" any individual employed in the position of a salesman if such individual travels with a group of salespeople, including a supervisor, team leader or crew leader, and the employees in the group do not return to their permanent residences at the end of the work day. 
Prohibits the employment of individuals under age 18 in positions requiring them to engage in door-to-door sales or in related support work in a manner that requires them to remain away from their permanent residence for more than 24 hours. 
Defines "travelling sales crew worker" as an individual who: (1) is employed as a salesperson or in related support work; (2) travels with a group of salespersons, including a supervisor; and (3) is required to be absent overnight from his or her permanent place of residence. Excludes from such definition any individual who meets such requirements if he or she is travelling to a trade show or convention, or any immediate family member of a travelling sales crew employer. 
Directs the Secretary of Labor to prescribe rules governing the protection of travelling sales crews. 
Sets forth criminal sanctions for employers that willfully and knowingly violate such rules.

Tick-Borne Disease Research Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) conduct or support epidemiological, basic, translational, and clinical research regarding Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases; and (2) ensure that each biennial report on the activities of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) includes information on actions undertaken by NIH to carry out such research. Directs the Secretary to establish a permanent Interagency Lyme and Tick-Borne Disease Working Group to review all efforts within HHS concerning Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases to ensure interagency coordination, minimize overlap, and examine research priorities. Requires the Working Group to develop or update every two years a summary of: (1) ongoing Lyme disease and other tick-borne disease research related to causes, prevention, treatment, surveillance, diagnosis, diagnostics, duration of illness, intervention, and access to services and supports for individuals with Lyme disease or other tick-borne diseases; (2) advances made pursuant to such research; (3) the engagement of HHS with persons that participate at public meetings; and (4) the comments received by the Working Group at such public meetings and the Secretary's response to such comments. Requires the Working Group to: (1) monitor federal activities with respect to Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases; (2) make recommendations to the Secretary regarding any appropriate changes to such activities; and (3) ensure public input by holding annual public meetings that address scientific advances, research questions, surveillance activities, and emerging strains in species of pathogenic organisms. Requires the Secretary to submit to Congress a strategic plan, informed by the most recent summary, for the conduct and support of Lyme disease and tick-borne disease research. Prohibits additional funds from being authorized to be appropriated to carry out this Act.
Homeowner Empowerment Act of 2008 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income distributions from qualified retirement plans used for mortgage payments.

Comprehensive TB Elimination Act of 2014 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to include in its annual report on drug shortages plans for enhanced interagency and intra-agency coordination, communication, and decisionmaking, including by ensuring coordination between the task force established under this Act and the Federal Tuberculosis Task Force in the development and implementation of strategies and systems to prevent and mitigate shortages of drugs used in connection with tuberculosis. Amends the Public Health Service Act to: (1) direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), in making grants to state health departments for programs to prevent, control, and eliminate tuberculosis, to give priority to awarding grants to state health departments proposing to focus on the prevention, control, and elimination of tuberculosis in high-risk populations, including foreign-born, homeless, and uninsured populations; (2) authorize the Secretary, acting through the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, to award grants to state and local governments and federally qualified health centers for coordinating their programs and services to ensure timely and appropriate prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of tuberculosis; (3) revise the duties of the Federal Tuberculosis Task Force to include providing advice on research into new tools and ensuring access to such new tools, as well as on the development and implementation of strategies and systems to prevent and mitigate shortages of drugs used in connection with tuberculosis; and (4) reauthorize through FY2019 the National Strategy for Combating and Eliminating Tuberculosis. Requires the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to enhance basic, clinical, and operational research on tuberculosis, including with respect to drug resistant tuberculosis, infection with, and the progression of, tuberculosis, and pediatric tuberculosis.

Campaign Information Improvement Act - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to revise requirements for nonpreemptible advertising. 
Requires a licensee to make available free broadcast time for policy debates.

America's Cup Act of 2011 - Authorizes an eligible vessel, operating only in preparation for, or in connection with, the 34th America's Cup competition, to position competing vessels and transport individuals and equipment and supplies utilized for the staging, operations, or broadcast of the competition from and around U.S. ports.

Defines "eligible vessel" as a competing vessel or supporting vessel of any registry that: (1) is recognized by the America's Cup Race Management as an official competing vessel or supporting vessel of the 34th America's Cup; (2) transports not more than 25 individuals, in addition to the crew; (3) is not a ferry; (4) does not transport individuals in point-to-point service for hire; and (5) does not transport merchandise between U.S. ports.

Authorizes the Administrator of the Maritime Administration of the Department of Transportation to issue an Eligibility Certification with respect to any vessel that meets such requirements.

Makes an Eligibility Certification conclusive evidence to the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) of the qualification of the vessel for which it has been issued to participate in the 34th America's Cup as a competing vessel or a supporting vessel.

Subjects any vessel participating in the 34th America's Cup as a competing vessel or supporting vessel that has not received an Eligibility Certification or is not in compliance with certain federal law to specified penalties.

Authorizes the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for each of the following vessels: (1) LNG GEMINI (United States official number 595752); (2) LNG LEO (United States official number 595753); and (3) LNG VIRGO (United States official number 595755). Limits coastwise trade authorized under this Act to carriage of natural gas.

Terminates the coastwise endorsement issued under this Act for a vessel on the date of the sale of the vessel by the owner of the vessel to a person who is not related by ownership or control to such owner.

Declares that a vessel transported in Dry Dock #2 (State of Alaska registration AIDEA FDD-2) is not merchandise if, during such transportation, Dry Dock #2 remains connected by a utility or other connecting line to pierside moorage located in Ketchikan, Alaska.

Women Veterans Bill of Rights Act - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to ensure that the Women Veterans Bill of Rights and the Injured and Amputee Veterans Bill of Rights are printed on signs in accessible formats and displayed prominently and conspicuously in each VA facility and distributed widely to women veterans.

Requires the Secretary, acting through the veteran liaison at each VA medical center, to collect information relating to the alleged mistreatment of injured and amputee veterans. Requires the Chief Consultant of Prosthetics and Sensory Aids to investigate and address any such information collected.

Directs the Secretary to: (1) ensure that all VA employees receive training on the Women Veterans Bill of Rights; and (2) conduct outreach to inform veterans about the Women Veterans Bill of Rights and the Injured and Amputee Veterans Bill of Rights.

Improving Treatment for Pregnant and Postpartum Women Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize through FY2021 the residential treatment program for pregnant and postpartum women with a primary diagnosis of a substance use disorder, including opioid use disorders. (Sec. 3) The bill directs the Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Treatment to carry out a five-year pilot program under which competitive grants are made to state substance abuse agencies to: (1) enhance flexibility in the use of funds designed to support family-based services for such women; (2) help address identified gaps in services furnished to such women along the continuum of care; and (3) promote a coordinated, effective, and efficient state system managed by state substance abuse agencies by encouraging new approaches and models of service delivery. The bill requires the Director to specify a minimum set of services required to be made available to eligible women through a grant awarded under the pilot program. The bill also requires the Director of the Center for Behavioral Health Statistics and Quality to fund an evaluation of the pilot program at the conclusion of the first grant cycle funded by the pilot program. (Sec. 4) The bill extends through FY2018 the authorization of appropriations for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to carry out the cut-gone compliance program.

Home Energy Loss Prevention Act - Prohibits a seller of single-family or multifamily housing that will be purchased with the assistance of a federally related housing loan from selling such housing, unless: (1) at least five years before the time of sale an energy audit is conducted; (2) the seller provides the purchaser a copy of the results of the energy audit; and (3) the results are submitted to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

Exempts from such requirements any seller of single-family or multifamily housing that will be purchased with the assistance of a federally related housing loan if such housing: (1) was constructed not more than five years before the time of sale involving such loan; and (2) is Energy Star qualified, certified under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Green Building Rating System of the United States Green Building Council, or certified under an equivalent certification system approved by the Secretary.

Directs the Secretary to coordinate with appropriate local recorders of deeds to maintain copies of the results of energy audits on-file in conjunction with the deeds to such housing. Directs the Secretary to establish and maintain a database containing copies of the results of energy audits and ensure such database is accessible to the public on an Internet website.

Authorizes the Secretary to grant a seller an exemption from any requirement of this Act if the Secretary determines that such requirement would cause undue hardship for the seller.

Sets forth civil penalties for violations of this Act.

Establishes the Home Energy Loss Prevention Fund.

Hope Offered through Principled, Ethically-Sound Stem Cell Research Act or the HOPE Act - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to conduct and support basic and applied research to develop techniques for the isolation, derivation, production, or testing of pluripotent stem cells that have the flexibility of embryonic stem cells (whether or not they have an embryonic source), and may result in improved understanding of or treatments for diseases and other adverse health conditions, provided that such isolation, derivation, production, or testing will not involve: (1) the creation of a human embryo or embryos for research purposes; or (2) the destruction or discarding of a human embryo or embryos, or knowingly subjecting a human embryo or embryos to risk of injury or death greater than that allowed for research on fetuses in utero.

Requires the Secretary to issue final guidelines that: (1) provide guidance concerning the next steps required for additional research, which shall include a determination of the extent to which specific techniques may require additional basic or animal research to ensure that any research involving human cells using these techniques would clearly be consistent with this Act; (2) prioritize research with the greatest potential for near-term clinical benefit; and (3) take into account techniques outlined by the President's Council on Bioethics and any other appropriate techniques and research.

Establishes within the Department of Health and Human Services the National Stem Cell Research Review Board to monitor research to ensure that it is in compliance with the principles of this Act, prioritize research with the greatest potential for near term benefits, and ensure fair consideration of both embryonic stem cell and adult stem cell research for funding.

Requires consent from an individual for the donation of materials for research described in this Act to be obtained from such individual, in writing, at the time of the proposed transfer of the donated materials from the storage site to the research team. Requires the donor to be informed, verbally and in writing, that the donor retains the right to withdraw such consent until such time as the donated materials involved are actually utilized in research.

Applies provisions protecting individually identifiable information under the regulations promulgated under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 to donors under this Act.

Amends the National Organ Transplant Act to prohibit the sale of human ovum, human blastocyst, human embryo, or stem cell derived from a human embryo.

Amends the Public Health Service Act to make it unlawful for any person to knowingly receive any valuable consideration for any therapy that: (1) affects interstate commerce or is funded, in full or in part, by federal assistance; and (2) utilizes cells from a human embryo, if the process of deriving such cells destroyed the embryo.

Authorizes appropriations.

Richmond National Battlefield Park Act of 2000 - Establishes the Richmond National Battlefield Park in Virginia, consisting of approximately 7,307 acres of land. Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to make minor boundary adjustments consistent with the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965.Authorizes the Secretary to acquire lands, waters, and interests within the boundaries of the park from willing landowners by donation, purchase with donated or appropriated funds, or exchange. Allows privately owned lands or interests to be acquired only with the owner's consent. Authorizes the Secretary to acquire an easement on property outside the boundaries of the park and around the city of Richmond, with the owner's consent, if the Secretary determines that the easement is necessary to protect core Civil War resources as identified by the Civil War Sites Advisory Committee. Requires the Secretary to revise the park's boundaries to include the property subject to the easement. Directs the Secretary to use permanent conservation easements to acquire interests in land in lieu of acquiring land in fee simple and thereby removing land from non-Federal ownership. Authorizes the Secretary to acquire the Tredegar Iron Works buildings and associated land in the city of Richmond for use as a visitor center for the park.Directs the Secretary, acting through the Director of the National Park Service, to administer the park in accordance with this Act and laws generally applicable to units of the National Park System. Requires the Secretary to provide for the establishment of a monument or memorial suitable to honor the 14 Medal of Honor recipients from the United States Colored Troops who fought in the Battle of New Market Heights. Requires the Secretary to include the Battle of New Market Heights and the role of black Union soldiers in the battle in historical interpretations provided to the public at the park.Authorizes the Secretary to enter into cooperative agreements with the Commonwealth of Virginia, its political subdivisions (including the city of Richmond), private property owners, and other members of the private sector to develop mechanisms to protect and interpret the historical resources within the park in a manner that would allow for continued private ownership and use where compatible with the purposes for which the park is established. Authorizes the Secretary to provide technical assistance to the Commonwealth of Virginia, its political subdivisions, nonprofit entities, and private property owners for the development of comprehensive plans, land use guidelines, special studies, and other activities that are consistent with the identification, protection, interpretation, and commemoration of historically significant Civil War resources located inside and outside of the park's boundaries.

Directs the U.S. Customs Service to liquidate or reliquidate certain entries of 13-inch televisions which, at the time of the original liquidation, were classified under specified subheadings of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States with respect to which there would have been no duty or a lesser duty if the amendments made by the Miscellaneous Trade and Technical Corrections Act of 1999 had applied to such entry or withdrawal.

Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017 This bill repeals the retirement earnings test for Social Security benefits. The retirement earnings test limits the amount of outside income that a person who is receiving Social Security benefits can earn without incurring a reduction in benefits. The bill also repeals the deduction from Social Security benefits for railroad workers under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974.

Northern Yukon-Arctic International Wildlife Refuge Act - Establishes the Northern Yukon-Arctic International Wildlife Refuge, which shall include the entire Arctic National Wildlife Refuge administered under the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966. 
Makes the establishment of the Refuge and the inclusion in the Refuge of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge effective upon: (1) enactment by the Government of Canada of a provision similar to this Act concerning the Northern Yukon National Park in or near the Yukon Territory, Canada; and (2) issuance of a proclamation by the President declaring that such an enactment has taken place.

National Icebreaker Fund Act of 2015 This bill establishes the National Icebreaker Fund in the Treasury to be used for: (1) construction, alteration, and renovation of icebreakers for the Coast Guard; and (2) lease or charter of such icebreakers. The Department of the military department in which the Coast Guard is operating shall enter into an agreement with nations that operate facilities in Antarctica to establish a mechanism to provide icebreaking services necessary to supply those facilities by constructing, leasing or chartering, renovating, operating, or maintaining an icebreaker capable of performing such services.

Authorizes the Managing Trustee to purchase U.S. obligations or obligations guaranteed as to both principal and interest by the United States, on original issue or at the market price, if such purchase is in the best interest of paying current and future benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act and will not jeopardize the payment of such benefits.
Requires the Commissioner of Social Security to promptly inform the President and Congress in writing if the Commissioner does not concur with the investment decisions of the Managing Trustee, or believes that other investment strategies are appropriate.
Prohibits the Managing Trustee from investing contributions made to the Trust Funds in private financial markets. Prohibits any Federal officer or employee from directing private pension plans as to what type of investments to make or in which financial markets to invest.
Extends the purposes for which public-debt obligations may be issued to authorize the issuance at par of public-debt obligations for purchase by the Trust Funds. Requires such obligations to have maturities fixed with due regard for the needs of the Trust Funds and to bear interest at a rate equal to the average market yield on all marketable interest-bearing obligations of the United States then forming a part of the public debt which are not due or callable until after the expiration of four years from the end of the calendar month next preceding the date of such issue.
Amends SSA title XI to require social security account statements to include: (1) a separate estimate of the amount of interest earned on the contributions; (2) the name, age, gender, mailing address, and marital status of the eligible individual; (3) the total amount of the employer and employee contributions for the eligible individual for OASDI benefits, as of the end of the month preceding the date of the statement, in both actual dollars and dollars adjusted for inflation; (4) the projected value of certain amounts of employer and employee contributions, annual amounts of OASDI benefits, and total amounts of OASDI benefits payable on the eligible individual's account for the individual's life expectancy; (5) the average annual rate of return, adjusted for inflation, on the Treasury 10-year saving bond as of the date of the statement; (6) the average annual rate of return, adjusted for inflation, on the Standard and Poor's 500, or an equivalent portfolio of common stock equities that are based on a broad index of U.S. market performance, for the preceding 25 years; (7) a brief statement that identifies the balance of the trust fund accounts as of the end of the month preceding the date of the statement, the annual estimated balance of the trust fund accounts for each of the succeeding 30 years, and the assumptions used to provide the information described above; and (8) a simple one-page summary and comparison of the information provided to an eligible individual under the above requirements.
Requires the Commissioner to notify an individual who receives a social security account statement that the individual may request that the information described above be determined on the basis of relevant information provided by the individual, including information regarding the individual's future income, marital status, date of retirement, or race.
Requires the Commissioner to provide such statements through means such as the Internet as soon as adequate measures are in place to protect the confidentiality of the information contained in the statement.

United States Specialty Crop Export Opportunities Act of 2007 - Amends the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 to authorize the Secretary of Agriculture to regulate plants, plant products, biological control organisms, and noxious weeds for export purposes.

Directs the Secretary to: (1) coordinate fruit and vegetable market analyses with the private sector and the Administrator of the Foreign Agricultural Service; and (2) make publicly available on an Internet website the status of all export petitions, an explanation of the sanitary or phytosanitary issues associated with each pending petition, and information on the import requirements of foreign countries for fruits and vegetables.

Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to repeal the transfer of certain agricultural inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture (USDA) to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Directs the Secretaries of Agriculture and Homeland Security to enter into an agreement to effectuate the return of such functions. Requires the Secretary of Agriculture to establish within the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service a program under which the Administrator of the Service shall carry out import and entry agricultural inspections. Requires the Administrator to establish a program to support the development of long-term career professionals with expertise in import and entry agriculture inspection.

Requires the Secretary of Agriculture to: (1) develop standard operating procedures for inspection, monitoring, and auditing relating to import and entry agricultural inspections; (2) ensure that the Service has a national electronic system with real-time tracking capability for monitoring, tracking, and reporting inspection activities; (3) develop and maintain an integrated, real-time communication system with respect to import and entry agricultural inspections to alert state departments of agriculture of significant inspection findings of the Service; and (4) establish an International Trade Inspection Advisory Committee to advise the Secretary on policies and other issues relating to import and entry agricultural inspection.

Requires the Secretary to report to Congress on: (1) the ability of the Foreign Agricultural Service to adequately monitor other countries' compliance with the terms of the Uruguay Round Agreements and the terms of other agreements to ensure that the United States realizes the full benefits of these agreements as they relate to agricultural commodities; and (2) whether current vacancies in the monitoring office of the Service should be filled.

Requires the Secretary to report to Congress on the feasibility and cost of establishing an indemnity program for exporters of articles classified under chapters 7 and 8 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States that will provide compensation to those exporters when they comply fully with U.S. export and foreign country import requirements for the articles, but the articles are wrongfully denied entry into the foreign country.

Directs the United States Trade Representative (USTR) to propose in the Doha Round of negotiations conducted under the auspices of the World Trade Organization (WTO) that all articles classified under chapters 7 and 8 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States be excluded from coverage under article 13 of the Agreement on Agriculture referred to in the Uruguay Round Agreements Act.

Directs the Secretary to establish and maintain a program of export credits that is, as nearly as may be, identical to the program administered under specified regulations, except that: (1) either an exporter to, or an importer in, a foreign place shall be eligible for a credit guarantee; (2) the guarantee shall be for a period of 45 days beginning on the date of issuance of the guarantee; and (3) the cost of the guarantee shall not exceed 45 cents for each $100 of coverage purchased.

Amends the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 to extend through FY2013 the authorization levels for emerging market credit programs.

Military Reservists Small Business Relief Act of 1999 - Amends the Small Business Act to direct the Small Business Administration (SBA) to defer repayment of principal and interest on a direct loan made under the SBA's small business administration program if such loan was incurred by an individual who is an eligible reservist and who received a direct loan before being ordered to active duty, or by a small business concern that received a direct loan before an eligible reservist, who is an essential employee, was ordered to active duty. Defines "eligible reservist" as a member of a reserve component of the Armed Forces ordered to active duty during a period of military conflict. 
Directs the SBA to: (1) encourage intermediaries participating in the SBA's disaster loan program to defer repayment of a loan made with proceeds made available under that program if such loan was incurred by a small business concern that is eligible to apply for assistance; and (2) establish guidelines to encourage lenders and other intermediaries to defer repayment of, or provide other relief relating to, loan guarantees and financings that were incurred by small businesses that are eligible to apply for assistance, and loan guarantees provided under the disaster loan program if the intermediary provides relief to a small business borrower. 
Authorizes the SBA to make disaster loans to assist a small business concern that has suffered or that is likely to suffer substantial economic injury as the result of an essential employee of such small business being ordered to active military duty during a period of military conflict. 
Directs the SBA to utilize its entrepreneurial development and management assistance programs to provide business counseling and training to any small business adversely affected by the deployment of U.S. Armed Forces units in support of a period of military conflict.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow an enterprise zone business located within an area that is an empowerment zone or enterprise community and that is within a nonattainment area (as defined by the Clean Air Act) a tax credit for the cost of qualified clean-fuel vehicle property, plus the cost of qualified clean-fuel vehicle refueling property. Defines "qualified clean-fuel vehicle property" as property that is a motor vehicle propelled by a fuel that is not a clean-burning fuel.

Grand Jury Reform Act of 1998 - Amends the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure to require a court, upon impaneling a grand jury, to instruct and charge the grand jury on its rights, responsibilities, and duties. 
Requires that, upon service of any subpoena requiring any witness to testify or produce information at any proceeding before a grand jury impaneled before a district court, the witness be given adequate and reasonable notice of:  (1) his or her right to counsel; (2) his or her privilege against self-incrimination; (3) the subject matter of the grand jury investigation; (4) whether his or her own conduct is under investigation by the grand jury; (5) the criminal statute, the violation of which is under consideration by the grand jury, if such statute is known at the time of issuance of the subpoena; (6) his or her rights regarding immunity; and (7) any other rights and privileges which the court deems necessary or appropriate. 
Allows each witness subpoenaed to appear and testify before a grand jury in a district court, or to produce books, papers, documents, or other objects before that grand jury, to be allowed the assistance of counsel during such time as the witness is questioned in the grand jury room.  Allows such counsel to be retained by the witness or appointed by the court if the witness is determined to be financially unable to obtain counsel.  Sets forth provisions regarding the powers and duties of such counsel. 
Requires an attorney for the Government to disclose to the grand jury any substantial evidence of which that attorney has knowledge that directly negates the guilt of the accused.  Provides that failure to disclose such evidence may be the basis for a motion to dismiss the indictment, if the court determines that the evidence might reasonably be expected to lead the grand jury not to indict. 
Entitles a defendant, upon request, and as the court determines to be reasonable, to examine and duplicate a transcript or electronic recording of:  (1) the grand jury testimony of all witnesses to be called at trial; (2) all statements relating to the defendant's case made to the grand jury by the court, the attorney for the Government, or a special attorney; (3) all grand jury testimony or evidence which in any manner could be considered exculpatory; and (4) all other grand jury testimony or evidence that is determined by the court to be material to the defense.  Authorizes the court to refuse to allow a defendant to examine and duplicate a transcript or electronic recording of any testimony, statement, or evidence described above if the court determines that such examination or duplication would endanger any witness.

Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to establish a task force within the Department of Education to study modeling and simulation and to support the development of the modeling and simulation field.

Authorizes the Secretary to award competitive grants to eligible institutions of higher education (IHEs) to enhance modeling and simulation degree programs at such IHEs. Defines "modeling and simulation" as a field of study related to the application of computer science and mathematics to develop a level of understanding of the interaction of the parts of a system and of a system as a whole.

Authorizes the Secretary to award competitive grants to IHEs to establish a modeling and simulation program, including a major, minor, career-track, certificate, or concentration program.

Emergency Mortgage Loan Modification Act of 2008 - Provides that, absent contractual provisions to the contrary: (1) the duty to maximize, or to not adversely affect, the recovery of total proceeds from pooled residential mortgage loans is owed by a servicer of such loans to the securitization vehicle for the benefit of all investors and holders of beneficial interests in the pooled loans, in the aggregate, and not to any individual party or group of parties; and (2) a servicer of such loans shall be deemed to be acting on behalf of the securitization vehicle in the best interest of all investors and holders of beneficial interests in the pooled loans, in the aggregate, if for a loan that is in payment default under the loan agreement or for which payment default is imminent or reasonably foreseeable, the loan servicer makes reasonable and documented efforts to implement a modification or workout plan or, if such efforts are unsuccessful or such plan would be infeasible, engages in other loss mitigation, including accepting a short payment or partial discharge of principal, or agreeing to a short sale of the property, to the extent that the servicer reasonably believes the particular modification or workout plan or other mitigation actions will maximize the net present value to be realized on the loan, including over that which would be realized through foreclosure.

Provides that a servicer of a residential mortgage loan that acts in a manner consistent with such duty shall not be liable for entering into a qualified loan modification or workout plan, to: (1) any person, based on that person's ownership of a residential mortgage loan or any interest in a pool of residential mortgage loans or in securities that distribute payments out of the principal, interest and other payments in loans on the pool; (2) any person who is obligated pursuant to a derivatives instrument to make payments determined in reference to any loan or any interest referred to in paragraph (1); or (3) any person that insures any loan or any interest referred to in paragraph (1) under any law or regulation of the United States or any law or regulation of any state or political subdivision of any state.

Defines "qualified loan modification or workout plan" as a modification or plan that: (1) is scheduled to remain in place until the borrower sells or refinances the property, or for at least five years from the date of adoption of the plan, whichever is sooner; (2) does not provide for a repayment schedule that results in negative amortization at any time; and (3) does not require the borrower to pay additional points and fees.

Securing Protections for the Injured from Limitations on Liability Act - Amends the Death on the High Seas Act to: (1) allow recovery of nonpecuniary loss, including loss of care, comfort, and companionship; and (2) repeal provisions limiting liability for damages.

Amends federal shipping law to provide that the recovery for a seaman who dies shall include recovery for loss of care, comfort, and companionship.

Repeals provisions limiting liability for oil pollution damage.

Amends the bankruptcy code to prohibit a trustee or debtor from selling or leasing significant property of the estate unless: (1) creditors holding at least two-thirds in amount, and more than one-half in number, of all such claims not paid by the debtor consent to such sale or lease; or (2) the court finds, after notice and a hearing, that sufficient property will remain in the estate or the debtor's anticipated future income will be sufficient that all such claims will be paid in full.

TABLE OF CONTENTS: 
     Title I:  Pharmacotherapy Research 
     Title II:  Patent Protections for Pharmacotherapies 
     Title III:  Encouraging Private Sector Development of 
          Pharmacotherapies 
New Medications to Treat Addiction Act of 1998 - 
Title I:  Pharmacotherapy Research
 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize appropriations through FY 2001 for the medication development program. 
Title II:  Patent Protections for Pharmacotherapies
 - Amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA) to provide for the investigation of drugs for treatment of an addiction to illegal drugs. 
Title III:  Encouraging Private Sector Development of Pharmacotherapies
 - Amends the FFDCA to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish criteria for an acceptable drug for the treatment of an addiction to cocaine and for an acceptable drug for the treatment of an addiction to heroin. 
Authorizes a patent owner of a drug to treat an addiction to cocaine or heroin to submit an application to the Secretary to enter into a contract to sell to the Secretary the patent rights of the owner relating to the drug, or in the case in which the drug is approved by the Secretary for more than one indication, to enter into an exclusive licensing agreement with the Secretary for the manufacture and distribution of the drug to treat an addiction to cocaine or heroin. 
Directs the Secretary to develop a plan for the manufacture and distribution of the drug.

Alcohol Advertising Accountability Act of 1996 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to report annually to the Congress on alcohol advertising, its profile, and its effects. 
Requires the Secretary to establish a panel to review alcohol advertising in all media and promotional activities undertaken to promote the sale of alcoholic beverages.

Strengthening and Focusing Enforcement to Deter Organized Stealing and Enhance Safety Act of 2012 or the SAFE DOSES Act - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit, in interstate or foreign commerce: (1) embezzling, stealing, or fraudulently obtaining, or knowingly and unlawfully taking, carrying away, or concealing a pre-retail medical product; (2) knowingly and falsely making, altering, forging, or counterfeiting the labeling or documentation of a pre-retail medical product; (3) knowingly possessing, transporting, or trafficking in a pre-retail medical product that was involved in such conduct; (4) with intent to defraud, buying, or otherwise obtaining, a pre-retail medical product that has expired or been stolen; (5) with intent to defraud, selling, or distributing, a pre-retail medical product that is expired or stolen; or (6) attempting or conspiring to violate any of these prohibitions.

Defines "pre-retail medical product" as a medical product that has not yet been made available for retail purchase by a consumer. Defines "medical product" as a drug, biological product, device, medical food, or infant formula.

Sets forth criminal penalties for violations of this Act, including: (1) a fine and/or imprisonment for up to 30 years for aggravated offenses involving the use of violence, force, or a threat of violence or force, the use of a deadly weapon, or resulting in serious bodily injury or death; (2) a fine and/or imprisonment for up to 15 years for violations involving medical products valued at $5,000 or greater; and (3) a fine and/or imprisonment for up to 3 years for other violations.

Subjects violators to civil penalties of up to three times the economic loss attributable to the violation or $1 million, whichever is greater.

Makes this Act applicable to: (1) interstate or foreign shipments by carrier; (2) racketeering; (3) breaking or entering carrier facilities; and (4) transportation and sale or receipt of stolen goods.

Directs the Attorney General to give increased priority to efforts to investigate and prosecute offenses under this Act.

Extends wiretapping authority to violations of this Act.

Requires restitution for losses attributable to violations of this Act.

Directs the U.S. Sentencing Commission to review and amend the federal sentencing guidelines and policy statements applicable to persons convicted of offenses under this Act to reflect the intent of Congress that penalties for such offenses be sufficient to deter and punish such offenses, and appropriately account for the actual harm to the public from these offenses.

Small Business Jobs Act of 2015 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small business employer who hires at least five new employees in a taxable year a tax credit for the wages paid to such employees. The credit is limited to employers who: (1) have a place of business in a county with an annual unemployment rate for the preceding calendar year of at least one percentage point greater than the national annual unemployment rate for the preceding calendar year, and (2) employed between two and 100 employees on no business day of the preceding calendar year. The bill also allows a tax-exempt small business employer to claim the credit.

Drug Rebate Equalization Act of 2009 - Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require a Medicaid managed care organization's contract with a state to provide that: (1) payment for covered outpatient drugs dispensed to individuals eligible for medical assistance who are enrolled with the entity shall be subject to the same rebate required by the agreement entered into under the Medicaid Drug Rebate Program as the state is subject to; and (2) capitation rates paid to the entity shall be based on actual cost experience related to rebates and subject to federal regulations requiring actuarially sound rates.

Authorizes a Medicaid managed care organization with a contract to exclude or otherwise restrict coverage of a covered outpatient drug on the basis of policies or practices of the organization, such as those affecting utilization management, formulary adherence, and cost sharing or dispute resolution, in lieu of any state policies or practices relating to the exclusion or restriction of coverage of such drugs, provided that any such exclusions and restrictions of coverage shall be subject to any contractual requirements and oversight by the state as contained in the Medicaid managed care organization's contract with the state, and the state shall maintain approval authority over the formulary used by the Medicaid managed care organization.

Enhanced Dental Care for Veterans Act of 2013 - Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to furnish dental services and treatment, and dental appliances, needed to restore functioning in a veteran that is lost as a result of any services or treatment furnished under current VA dental care provisions. Directs the Secretary to carry out a three-year pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of furnishing dental care to veterans enrolled in the VA patient enrollment system who are not eligible for dental services and treatment, and related dental appliances, under current authorities. Requires the Secretary to carry out a program of education to promote dental health for veterans who are enrolled in the VA patient enrollment system. Directs the Secretary to expand the VA dental insurance pilot program to establish a mechanism by which private sector dental care providers may forward to the VA information on dental care furnished to individuals under the pilot program for inclusion in the VA electronic medical records of such individuals.

Captain James A.
