Lovell Federal Health Care Center Act of 2008 - Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to transfer, without reimbursement, to the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) the Navy ambulatory care center, parking structure, and supporting facilities, and related medical personal property and equipment located in Great Lakes, Illinois, upon the conclusion of a resource-sharing agreement between the Secretaries providing for joint use by the Departments of Defense (DOD) and VA of a facility and supporting facilities in North Chicago, Illinois, and Great Lakes, Illinois, and for joint use of related medical personal property and equipment.

Designates such facility and supporting facilities as the "Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center."

Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to transfer to the VA functions necessary for the effective operation of the Center. Allows such transfer to be effectuated in a resource-sharing agreement between the Secretaries.

Amends federal veterans' benefits law to extend through FY2020 the authority for the Joint Incentives Program. Includes real property maintenance and minor construction projects that are not required to be specifically authorized by law under such law and under military law within the purposes for which the Program may be used.

Deems the Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center to be a facility of the uniformed services for purposes of eligibility for health care under military law if provided in an agreement between the Secretaries.

Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to provide for temporary duty reductions for certain cotton shirting fabric.

Establishes in the Treasury the Pima Cotton Trust Fund.

Local Government Landfill Compliance Deadline Act - Provides for a temporary exemption from certain revised criteria for municipal solid waste landfills. 
Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to issue regulations that:  (1) revise financial assurance requirements to broaden mechanisms available to owners or operators of such landfills for demonstrating financial responsibility; and (2) exempt small landfills in communities that experience an annual interruption of at least three consecutive months of surface transportation that prevents access to a regional waste management facility, or in communities that have no practicable waste management alternative and that have a small landfill unit located in an area that annually receives less than or equal to 25 inches of precipitation, from ground water monitoring requirements.

End Tax Uncertainty Act of 2010 - Repeals the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 (EGTRRA) and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 (JGTRRA), making their tax relief permanent.

Repeals the estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) increase the alternative minimum tax (AMT) exemption amount for individuals and married couples filing joint returns; (2) limit the AMT credit to the sum of the taxpayer's regular tax liability reduced by the foreign tax credit and the tax imposed by the AMT; and (3) reduce the maximum corporate income tax rate to 25%.

American Super Computing Leadership Act - Amends the Department of Energy High-End Computing Revitalization Act of 2004 to require the Department of Energy (DOE) to: (1) partner with universities, national laboratories, and industry to ensure the broadest possible application of the technology developed in its high-end computing research and development program to other challenges in science, engineering, medicine, and industry; and (2) conduct a coordinated research program to develop exascale computing systems to advance DOE's missions. Requires the Secretary of Energy to establish two or more national laboratory-industry-university partnerships to conduct integrated research, development, and engineering of multiple exascale architectures. Requires the Secretary to provide access for researchers in U.S. industry, institutions of higher education, national laboratories, and other federal agencies to these exascale systems on a competitive, merit-reviewed basis. Directs the Secretary to submit to Congress: (1) an integrated strategy and program management plan, including target dates for prototypical and production exascale platforms, interim milestones to reaching these targets, functional requirements, roles and responsibilities of national laboratories and industry, acquisition strategy, and estimated resources required to achieve this exascale system capability; (2) a report that describes the status of milestones and costs in achieving the objectives of the exascale computing program at the time of DOE's budget submission for each fiscal year; and (3) a plan detailing the proposed facility's cost projections and capabilities to significantly accelerate the development of new energy technologies, technical risks and challenges that must be overcome to achieve successful completion and operation of the facility, and an independent assessment of the scientific and technological advances expected from such a facility relative to those expected from a comparable investment in expanded research and applications at terascale-class and petascale-class computing facilities, including an evaluation of where investments should be made in the system software and algorithms to enable these advances, at least 18 months prior to the initiation of construction or installation of any exascale-class computing facility.

Protect Marriage from the Courts Act of 2015 This bill amends the federal judicial code to prohibit any court created by federal law from having jurisdiction, and the Supreme Court from having appellate jurisdiction, to adjudicate or enforce any claim pertaining to the validity under the Constitution of a state law, or state administrative or judicial decision, that: (1) defines marriage as limited to the union of one man and one woman; or (2) refuses state recognition of, or allows the state to refuse recognition of, same-sex marriages performed and licensed in other states.  A final judgment entered by either a federal court or the Supreme Court on such a claim before this bill's effective date binds only the parties to the case. No person who is not a party to the case shall have any obligation to comply with the decision in the case.

Accessing Medicare Therapies Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to include the negotiated price of a covered part D drug if: (1) the drug is classified in the highest copayment tier; (2) the drug is furnished to the individual free or at nominal charge under a compassionate treatment program; and (3) the drug, if furnished other than through such program, is covered under the formulary of the plan or is available through exception or appeal. Defines "compassionate treatment program" as a program that: (1) is administered by a tax-exempt entity; (2) takes title to the drugs and distributes them to eligible part D individuals free or at nominal charge on the basis of the entity's assessment of financial need of such individuals; (3) does not distribute the drugs to an individual unless the individual's household income is less than the maximum income level for the taxpayer in the household to be eligible for a refundable credit; and (4) meets additional requirements established by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services to prevent fraud or abuse in the application of this Act.

Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey works, facilities, and lands of the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project, the Intake Irrigation Project, and the Savage Unit (Projects) to the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Districts in Montana and North Dakota and the Savage Irrigation District in Montana pursuant to a Memorandum of Understanding.Requires the Secretary to: (1) transfer water rights held in part or wholly in the name of the United States that are used to serve the lands within the Irrigation Districts; (2) require the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Districts to convey a perpetual conservation easement to the State of Montana for the purposes of protecting, preserving, and enhancing the conservation values and permitting recreation on Federal lands in part to be conveyed under this Act; (3) sustain the irrigation developments established by the Lower Yellowstone and Intake Projects and the Savage Unit as components of the irrigation plan under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program; and (4) continue to provide the Irrigation Districts with Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project Use power at the Irrigation Districts' pumping plants, except that the rate shall be at the preference power rate and there shall be no ability-to-pay adjustment.Directs the Secretary, prior to the transfer of title of the Diversion Works and in cooperation with the Irrigation Districts, to provide fish protection devices to prevent juvenile and adult fish from entering the Main Canal of the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project and allow bottom dwelling fish species to migrate above the Project's Intake Diversion Dam.

Savings for Seniors Act of 2017 This bill amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to establish in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund a Social Security Surplus Protection Account. The Managing Trustee shall transfer to the Account, from amounts otherwise available in the Trust Fund, amounts equivalent to the social security surplus for each fiscal year after FY2017. The balance in the Account shall not be available for investment by the Managing Trustee. The bill establishes in the executive branch a Social Security Investment Commission to study and report to Congress on the most effective vehicles for investment of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund, other than investment in the form of obligations of the United States resulting in the transfer of Trust Fund assets to the general fund of the Treasury.

Directs the Attorney General to establish and implement a program to identify, from among individuals who are incarcerated in local governmental incarceration facilities prior to arraignment on criminal charges, those individuals who are within one or more of the following classes of deportable aliens:  (1) aliens unlawfully present in the United States; and (2) certain other specified aliens. 
Requires the program to include:  (1) the detail, to each selected facility, of at least one employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Service who has expertise in the identification of such aliens; and (2) provision of funds sufficient to provide for the detail of such employees to each selected facility on a full-time basis, access for such employees to records of the Service and other Federal law enforcement agencies that are necessary to identify such aliens, and pre-arraignment reporting to the court regarding the Service's intention to remove the alien from the United States. 
Directs the Attorney General to select for participation in the program each incarceration facility that satisfies the following requirements:  (1) the facility is owned by the government of a local political subdivision that has submitted a request for such selection to the Attorney General; (2) the facility is located in a county or city, town, or other analogous local political subdivision that is determined by the Attorney General to have a high concentration of such aliens; and (3) the facility incarcerates or processes individuals prior to their arraignment on criminal charges. 
Sets forth provisions regarding the number of qualifying subdivisions. 
Requires that not less than 20 percent of the qualifying local political subdivisions be in States that are not contiguous to a land border. 
Requires all of the incarceration facilities within the counties of Orange and Ventura, California, that are owned by the government of a local political subdivision and satisfy the requirements of this Act to be selected for participation in the program. 
Directs the Attorney General to complete a study and report to the Congress concerning the logistical and technological feasibility of implementing the program in a greater number of locations than those selected through:  (1) the assignment of a single Immigration and Naturalization Service employee to more than one incarceration facility; and (2) the development of a system to permit the Attorney General to conduct off-site verification, by computer or other electronic means, of the immigration status of individuals who are incarcerated in local governmental incarceration facilities prior to arraignment on criminal charges.

Agricultural Equity Act of 1995 - Expresses the sense of the Congress that:  (1) the continuation of significant Federal budgetary deficits harms the economic well-being of the United States and is detrimental to the development of sound, long-term agricultural policy; (2) agricultural price support and production adjustment programs are necessary for the continued economic health of U.S. agriculture, which must compete in international markets against subsidized foreign competition; and (3) such programs should be implemented in a manner consistent with the primary goal of the concurrent resolution on the budget for FY 1996 to end Federal budget deficits. 
Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to make nonrecourse loans available to producers on a farm for each of the 1996 through 2002 crops of rice, upland cotton, feed grains, wheat, and oilseeds at specified loan levels.  Prohibits the Secretary from making available a marketing loan or loan deficiency payment to any producer on a farm for any of the 1996 through 2002 crops of covered commodities. 
Directs the Secretary to make deficiency payments available to producers for each of the 1996 through 2002 crops of each covered commodity (other than oilseeds) in an amount computed by multiplying:  (1) the payment rate for the covered commodity; (2) the payment acres for the crop of that covered commodity; and (3) the farm program yield for the crop of that covered commodity for the farm.  Continues the minimum established price in effect for the 1991 through 1995 crops of each covered commodity for the 1996 through 2002 crops of that covered commodity.  Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) the payment rate for each of the 1996 through 2002 crops of each covered commodity; (2) payment acres; and (3) elimination of certain partial payment programs. 
Directs the Secretary to increase producer planting flexibility by increasing the mandatory flex acreage percentage for each covered commodity from 15 percent to 20 percent and by offering producers an additional voluntary increase in flex acres of between 10 percent to 25 percent. 
Requires producers on a farm to obtain catastrophic risk protection insurance coverage as a condition for eligibility for crop loans and deficiency payments under this Act. 
Repeals certain provisions of the Agricultural Act of 1949. 
Directs the Secretary to conduct a comprehensive review of the status and future of production agriculture and farming communities in the United States and the extent to which the program changes made by this Act will impact production agriculture and farming communities in the United States.

Transit in Parks Act - Directs the Secretaries of the Interior and Transportation to enter into a memorandum of understanding to establish a transit in parks program to encourage and promote the development of transportation systems within units of the National Park System (NPS) to improve visitor mobility and enjoyment, reduce pollution and congestion, and enhance resource protection through the use of transit. Requires the program to be administered by the Secretary of the Interior, in conjunction with the Secretary of Transportation.

Requires the program to provide for: (1) development of transportation plans and programs for NPS units by the Secretary of the Interior instead of a metropolitan planning organization; (2) development of a long-range transportation plan for such units by the Secretary of the Interior instead of a metropolitan planning organization; (3) making contracts and grants by the Secretary of Transportation to the Secretary of the Interior for planning, engineering, design, and evaluation of mass transportation projects in such units, and for technical studies; (4) development and updating of a transportation improvement program for such units, and the selection and carrying out of projects in such units, by the Secretary of the Interior instead of a metropolitan planning organization; (5) making grants by the Secretary of Transportation to the Secretary of the Interior for capital projects by financing the planning and improvement costs of equipment, facilities, and associated capital maintenance in mass transportation for such units; (6) making grants by the Secretary of Transportation to the Secretary of the Interior for capital investment relating to local financial commitment; (7) projects for bicycle access; (8) making contracts and grants by the Secretary of Transportation to the Secretary of the Interior for crime prevention and security; (9) making contracts and grants by the Secretary of Transportation to the Secretary of the Interior for human resources programs; (10) grants under the program to pay the operating cost of equipment and facilities used in mass transportation for such units; (11) projects for which grants may be made under the program to include turnkey system projects; and (12) labor protection.

Sets forth provisions regarding the Federal share of project or activity costs carried out under this Act.

Makes available from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund $90 million for each of FY 2004 through 2010 to carry out this Act.

Charitable Pension Flexibility Act of 2013 - Amends the Pension Protection Act of 2006, as amended by the Preservation of Access to Care for Medicare Beneficiaries and Pension Relief Act of 2010, to allow a plan sponsor to elect for a plan to cease to be treated as an eligible charity plan for plan years beginning after December 31, 2013. Allows such election to be revoked only with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury.  Allows a plan sponsor that makes such election to also elect for a plan to apply certain rules for plan years beginning after December 31, 2013. Sets forth applicable shortfall amortization bases and determination of installments under such rules.

National September 11 Memorial & Museum Commemorative Medal Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to strike and make available for sale up to 2 million silver medals emblematic of the courage, sacrifice, and strength of those individuals who perished in the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, the bravery of those who risked their lives to save others that day, and the endurance, resilience, and hope of those who survived.

Requires the design for such medals to be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center and the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee.

Expresses the sense of Congress that, to the extent possible, approximately one-half of the medals should be struck at the U.S. Mint at West Point, New York, and approximately one-half struck at the U.S. Mint at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Authorizes the Secretary to make the medals available for sale beginning on January 1, 2011.

Terminates the authority to strike such medals after December 31, 2012.

Requires all sales of such medals to include a surcharge of $10 per medal. Requires all surcharges received from the sale of such medals to be paid to the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center to support its operations and maintenance following its completion.

No Second Chances for Murderers, Rapists, or Child Molesters Act of 1998 - Directs the Attorney General to transfer specified amounts from Federal law enforcement assistance funds of a State that convicted a person of murder, rape, or a dangerous sexual offense who has a prior conviction for one of these offenses in another State. 
Directs the United States Sentencing Commission to amend the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to provide that:  (1) whoever is guilty of murder shall be punished by death or by imprisonment for life; and (2) whoever is guilty of rape or a dangerous sexual offense shall be punished by imprisonment for life. 
Directs the Attorney General to collect and distribute data to the President, Members of the Congress, State governments, and officials of localities and penal and other institutions participating in the Uniform Crime Reports program which includes:  (1) the number of murders, rapes, and dangerous sexual offenses committed by persons previously convicted of one of these offenses; and (2) the percentage of cases in which a person convicted of murder, rape, or a dangerous sexual offense in one State commits a second offense in another State.

Stop Tuberculosis (TB) Now Act of 2006 - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to: (1) make it a major objective of U.S. foreign assistance to control tuberculosis; and (2) require the President, in furnishing assistance for tuberculosis, to give priority to activities described in the Stop TB Strategy, including expansion and enhancement of DOTS coverage, treatment for individuals infected with both tuberculosis and HIV and treatment for individuals with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), strengthening of health systems, use of the International Standards for Tuberculosis Care by all providers, empowering individuals with tuberculosis, and enabling and promoting research to develop new diagnostics, drugs, and vaccines, and program-based operational research relating to tuberculosis.

Authorizes the President, acting through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), to provide increased resources to the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Stop Tuberculosis Partnership to improve the capacity of countries with high rates of tuberculosis and other affected countries to implement the Stop TB Strategy.

Requires the annual report on the implementation of the Global Plan to Stop TB 2006-2015: Actions for Life to include the percentage of such U.S. foreign assistance provided for diagnosis and treatment of individuals with tuberculosis in countries with the highest rates of tuberculosis, as determined by WHO.

Authorizes appropriations for FY2007-FY2008 for global tuberculosis activities through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in cooperation with other specified Secretaries, to authorize an Indian tribe to coordinate its federally funded alcohol and substance abuse and mental health programs in a manner that integrates program services into a single, coordinated, comprehensive program and reduces administrative costs by consolidating administrative functions.
Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Labor, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of Education, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the United States Attorney General, and the Secretary of Transportation to enter into an interdepartmental memorandum of agreement providing for the implementation of plans authorized under this Act. Makes the Indian Health Service the lead agency under this Act.
Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Labor, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of Education, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the United States Attorney General, or the Secretary of Transportation, as appropriate, to take such action as may be necessary to provide for the interagency transfer of funds otherwise available to a tribe in order to further the purposes of this Act.
Makes any State with an alcohol and substance abuse or mental health program targeted to Indian tribes eligible to receive, at no cost to the State, such Federal personnel assignments as the Secretary may deem appropriate to help insure the success of such program.

Professional Sports Antitrust Clarification Act of 1996 - Authorizes a professional sports league or its member franchises to establish and enforce rules and procedures for deciding whether a member franchise may change its home territory. 
Applies this Act to a professional sports league and its member franchises if such league:  (1) establishes applicable rules and procedures to govern whether a member franchise may change its home territory that are available upon request to any interested party; (2) affords due process, including 180 days notice and an opportunity to be heard, to interested parties prior to deciding whether a member franchise may change its home territory; and (3) promotes comparable economic opportunities by sharing revenue among member franchises to account for disparities in revenue received or costs saved due to direct or indirect public benefits and subsidies, including publicly financed facilities, rent abatement, special tax treatment, favorable arrangements for parking, concessions, and other amenities, and other public benefits not generally available to businesses as a whole within the jurisdiction. 
Requires rules and procedures established under this Act to require consideration of various factors to protect the public interest, including:  (1) the extent to which fan support for a member franchise has been demonstrated through attendance, ticket sales, and television ratings during the period in which the member franchise played in its home territory; (2) the extent to which the member franchise has, directly or indirectly, received public financial support through publicly financed facilities, rent abatement, special tax treatment, favorable arrangements for parking, concessions, and other amenities, and any other public benefits not generally available to businesses as a whole within the jurisdiction, and the extent to which such support continues; (3) the effect that relocation would have on contracts, agreements, and understandings between the member franchise and public and private parties; (4) the extent of any net operating losses experienced by the member franchise in recent years and the extent to which the member franchise bears responsibility for such losses; and (5) any bona fide offer to purchase the member franchise at fair market value, if such offer includes the continued location of such member franchise in its home territory. 
Sets forth provisions regarding judicial review, declaratory actions, and limitations on monetary damages.

United States-Pakistan Security and Stability Act - Directs the President to develop and transmit to Congress a comprehensive interagency strategy and implementation plan for long-term security and stability in Pakistan.

Requires the Director of National Intelligence to provide intelligence support to the development of such plan.

Authorizes appropriations for FY2010-FY2013 for: (1) assistance to Pakistan under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961; and (2) building a more effective counterinsurgency capability in Pakistan's security forces, up to $700 million for the Pakistan Counterinsurgency Capability Fund, for FY2010.

Federal Forage Fee Act of 1993 - Subjects all grazing operations conducted on any Federal lands to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws. 
Directs the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior to calculate annually the Federal forage fee by calculating the average of the weighted average private land lease rate (WAPLLR) for the preceding three years; multiplying it by the private lease forage value ratio (PLFVR); then deducting from that result the nonfee cost differential; and multiplying that result by the net production differential.  Applies such fee to all authorized Federal animal unit months (AUMs) under the jurisdiction of the Departments of Agriculture and the Interior.

Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for mortgage insurance premiums paid or accrued by a taxpayer in connection with acquisition indebtedness with respect to a qualified residence.  Reduces such deduction by ten percent of the amount otherwise allowable for each $1,000 ($500 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return) that the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeds $100,000 ($50,000 in the case of a married individual filing a separate return). 
Allows any amount paid by the taxpayer for qualified mortgage insurance that is properly allocable to any mortgage the payment of which extends to periods after the close of the taxable year in which such amount is paid to be chargeable to capital account and treated as paid in such periods to which so allocated.  Prohibits a deduction for the unamortized balance of such account if such mortgage is satisfied before the end of its term.  Exempts from such rule amounts paid for qualified mortgage insurance provided by the Veterans Administration or the Rural Housing Administration. 
Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to prescribe regulations requiring any person who receives from any individual premiums for mortgage insurance aggregating $600 or more for any calendar year to make a return with respect to each such individual.

Outer Continental Shelf Enhanced Exploration and Deep Water Incentives Act - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to authorize the Secretary of the Interior, at his or her discretion or on a lessee's petition, to reduce, suspend, or eliminate any royalty or net profit share set forth in leases for oil and gas production in order to:  (1) promote development and new production on producing or nonproducing leases; or (2) encourage production of marginal or uneconomic resources on such leases. 
Prohibits royalty payments on new production from any lease located in water depths of 200 meters or greater until the capital costs directly related to such new production have been recovered by the lessee out of the proceeds from such new production.  Provides that, in any month during which the arithmetic average of the closing prices for the earliest delivery month on the New York Mercantile Exchange for Light Sweet crude oil exceeds $28.00 per barrel, any production of oil shall be subject to royalties at the lease stipulated rate.  Provides that, in any month during which the arithmetic average of the closing prices for the earliest delivery month on the New York Mercantile Exchange for natural gas exceeds $3.50 per million British thermal units, any production of natural gas shall be subject to royalties at the lease stipulated rate. 
Directs the Secretary, in each leasing program prepared under the Act, to designate as frontier areas portions of the outer Continental Shelf with respect to which the Secretary will exercise authority to reduce, suspend, or eliminate the requirement to pay royalties.

State Court Interpreter Grant Program Act - Directs the Administrator of the Office of Justice Programs of the Department of Justice to make grants to States to develop and implement programs to assist individuals with limited English proficiency to access and understand State court proceedings in which they are a party. Requires the Administrator to allocate $500,000 annually for a court interpreter technical assistance program to assist States receiving such grants.

Authorizes appropriations.

A Better Chance to Learn Act of 1993 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies and community-based organizations for home-based parent and early childhood education programs. 
Requires that such programs:  (1) enhance parents' awareness of their strengths and potential as the primary educators of their children; (2) provide support, training, and developmentally appropriate educational materials necessary for parents to implement a school-readiness, home instruction program for their children; (3) conduct group meetings with parents to provide support activities related to parenting skills and other topics of interest to participating parents; and (4) provide opportunities for field trips to local sites of educational and cultural benefit. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Joseph Moakley Memorial Fire Safe Cigarette Act of 2002 - Directs the Consumer Product Safety Commission to prescribe one or more fire safety standards for cigarettes to reduce the risk of ignition presented by cigarettes. Requires the Commission to use a specified testing methodology in establishing such standards.Requires the Commission to include in the rule prescribed under this Act a prohibition on the stockpiling of cigarettes to which the fire safety standards will apply.

Health Insurance for Life Act of 2006 - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), the Internal Revenue Code, and the Public Health Service Act to remove the 18 or 36 month limitation on continuation coverage under group health plans.

Allows an increased premium for additional coverage after the 18th month of continuation coverage.

Amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to revise requirements for the loan guarantee program for innovative technologies. Authorizes the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to waive any requirement to provide a third-party credit report if: (1) a third-party credit rating of the applicant or project is not relevant to the determination of the credit risk of a project, and (2) the project costs are not projected to exceed $100 million.

Authorizes the Executive Director of the loan guarantee program to recruit and directly appoint highly qualified critical personnel with specialized knowledge important to the function of the programs into the competitive service if there is a severe shortage of candidates or a severe hiring need for particular positions to carry out the functions of the program. Terminates such authority on September 30, 2011.

Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) retain agents and legal and other professional advisors in connection with guarantees and related activities authorized under this Act; (2) require applicants for and recipients of loan guarantees to pay all fees and expenses of the agents and advisors; and (3) select such advisors in such manner and using such procedures as the Secretary determines to be appropriate to protect U.S. interests and achieve the purposes of this Act.

Allows an eligible project to be located on two or more non-contiguous sites in the United States.

Allows a project applicant or sponsor of an eligible project to submit an application for more than one eligible project.

Includes energy efficiency projects, including projects to retrofit residential, commercial, and industrial buildings, facilities, and equipment, within the scope of the loan guarantee program.

Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to limit administrative costs to $100,000 or 10 basis points of the loan.

Securing America's Facilities, Equipment and Rail: Taking Responsibility for American National Security In Transit Act or the SAFER TRANSIT Act This bill directs the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to report to Congress on its plan to expedite the implementation of certain requirements of the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 to: (1) assign rail carriers to high-risk tiers, and (2) establish a rail security training program. The bill extends through FY2020 the authorization of appropriations for: (1) visible intermodal prevention and response teams; (2) surface transportation security inspectors; (3) public transportation security research and development; (4) railroad security; and (5) over-the-road bus security assistance. DHS shall develop a Local Transit Security Instructor Training Program at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Centers. The bill requires DHS to take steps to ensure that the Federal Air Marshal Service uses its resources to cover the highest-risk flights. DHS shall direct the Department's Directorate of Science and Technology to prioritize research of scalable, cost-effective technology solutions to detect chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and explosive threats aboard public transportation of all modes that are capable continuous, real-time sensing and detection of, and alerting passengers and operating personnel to the presence of such a threat.

Marine Navigation Safety Improvement Act of 1993 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish in the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund a separate Marine Navigation Safety Account. 
Amends the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 to authorize appropriations from such Account for nautical charting and marine navigational safety programs and other activities of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) related to commercial marine navigation.

National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016 This bill prohibits the suspension or revocation of access to classified information by a federal agency as retaliation for whistleblowing. The Department of Defense (DOD) Inspector General shall report to Congress on allegations received that an employee's access to classified information was suspended or revoked in retaliation for whistleblowing.

Uzbekistan Freedom Promotion Act of 2005 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) the actions of the government of Uzbekistan in general and in the case of the Andijan massacre specifically are reprehensible, totalitarian, and unbecoming of an ally of the United States; (2) they are counterproductive to U.S. goals of promoting freedom and democracy; and (3) they justify an end to U.S. assistance for, and an increase in restrictions on, the government of Uzbekistan until it accelerates democratic reforms and fulfills its human rights obligations.

Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to prohibit assistance to the government of Uzbekistan for a fiscal year unless the President certifies to specified congressional committees that the government of Uzbekistan has: (1) permitted and is fully cooperating with and supporting an independent international inquiry into the violence in Andijan, Uzbekistan, has ceased pressuring the government of Kyrgyzstan to return the refugees who fled after the massacre, and is prosecuting those individuals responsible for civilian deaths or injuries in the violence; and (2) accelerated democratic reforms and fulfilled its human rights obligations by releasing from prison all individuals jailed for peaceful political activism or the nonviolent expression of their political or religious beliefs, fully investigating any credible allegations of torture and prosecuting those individuals responsible, permitting the free and unfettered functioning of independent media outlets, independent political parties, and nongovernmental organizations, permitting the free exercise of religious beliefs and ceasing the persecution of members of religious groups and denominations not registered with the government of Uzbekistan, holding internationally-observed, free, transparent, competitive, and fair elections, and making publicly available documentation of its revenues and expenditures and prosecuting those individuals engaged in official corruption.

Prohibits the issuance of a visa to any official of the government of Uzbekistan who is credibly alleged to have ordered, acquiesced to, or participated in human rights abuses or corruption unless the Secretary of State certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that the issuance of the visa is in the national security interests of the United States.

Directs the President to seek to identify and freeze the financial assets and other economic resources in the United States of any official of the government of Uzbekistan, and their family members, who is credibly alleged to have ordered, acquiesced to, or participated in human rights abuses, including the massacre in Andijan.

Directs the President to: (1) prohibit the export to Uzbekistan of any item, including the issuance of a license for the export of any item under the Arms Export Control Act on the United States Munitions List or Commerce Control List or any dual use item under the Export Administration Regulations, unless the President certifies to the appropriate congressional committees and the Committees on Armed Services of the House of Representatives and the Senate that the government of Uzbekistan meets certain requirements; (2) expedite admission to the United States of any national of Uzbekistan who is under threat of severe penalty as a result of participating in pro-democracy activities, including those citizens of Uzbekistan who have fled to Kyrgyzstan, and should encourage other governments to accept Uzbek refugees for resettlement; and (3) transmit to the appropriate congressional committees and the Committees on Armed Services of the House of Representatives and the Senate a plan to move all existing U.S. military operations in Uzbekistan to facilities outside that country.

Health Care Fraud and Abuse Advisory Opinion Act of 1994 - Amends titles XI (Medicaid) and XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue advisory opinions on specified matters, including:  (1) what constitutes prohibited remuneration; (2) whether an arrangement or proposed arrangement satisfies criteria for activities which do not result in prohibited remuneration; (3) what constitutes an inducement to reduce or limit services to individuals entitled to benefits under Medicare or Medicaid; and (4) whether an arrangement, activity, or proposed arrangement or proposed activity violates any other provision of the Act. 
Makes each advisory opinion issued by the Secretary binding as to the Secretary and the party or parties requesting the opinion.  Prohibits the failure of a party to seek an advisory opinion from being introduced into evidence to prove that the party intended to violate provisions of the Act. 
Directs the Secretary to issue regulations establishing a system for the issuance of advisory opinions.  Limits the interval in which the Secretary shall respond to a party requesting an advisory opinion to 30 days.

Accuracy in Medicare Physician Payment Act of 2013 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish an expert outside advisory panel to provide oversight to the processes relating to the valuation of physicians' services under the Medicare physician fee schedule.

Unfunded Mandates Information and Transparency Act of 2008 - Amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require a report on any bill or joint resolution that would impose a federal mandate to include: (1) an assessment of the authorized level of funding to determine if the prospective costs of carrying out changes to a condition of federal assistance being imposed on participating state, local, or tribal governments, and how these costs compare with the funds being authorized or, for reauthorizations, of the additional costs of changes in those conditions and how they compare with the changes in funding being authorized; and (2) an identification and description of any reasonably foreseeable indirect costs to state, local, or tribal governments, or by the private sector, incurred as a result of implementing the federal mandate in the bill or joint resolution.

Amends the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 to require a report on any regulation that would impose a federal mandate to include: (1) the expenditure by state, local, and tribal governments of direct or reasonably foreseeable indirect costs resulting from such regulation; and (2) the expenditure by the private sector of direct or reasonably foreseeable indirect costs resulting from such regulation.

Applies reporting requirements under the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 to independent regulatory agencies.

Energy Conservation Opportunity Fund Act of 2008 or the ECO Fund Act of 2008 - Establishes in the Treasury the Alternative Energy Sources State Revolving Fund to provide loans to states and Indian tribes to provide incentives to owners of single-family and multifamily housing, commercial properties, and public buildings to provide: (1) renewable energy sources for such structures; (2) energy efficiency and energy conserving improvements and features for such structures; or (3) infrastructure related to the delivery of electricity and hot water for structures lacking such amenities.

Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2011 - Directs the Attorney General to make competitive grants to eligible state, tribal, and local governments to establish or maintain programs that provide protection or assistance to witnesses in court proceedings involving: (1) homicide, or a serious violent felony or serious drug offense; and (2) gangs or organized crime.

Requires the Attorney General to develop best practice models to assist states and other relevant entities in addressing witness safety, short-term and permanent witness relocation, financial and housing assistance, and any other services related to witness protection or assistance.

Supporting America's Young Entrepreneurs Act of 2016 This bill amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to allow a borrower of a federal student loan to defer payments for up to three years while employed as a founder of a small business start-up. The Department of Education shall cancel $20,000 of the balance of interest and principal due on any eligible federal Direct Loan not in default for a borrower who: (1) has made 24 monthly payments on such loan after enactment of this bill; (2) has been employed as a founder of a small business start-up in a distressed area during the period in which the borrower makes each of the 24 payments; (3) is employed as a founder of a small business start-up in a distressed area at the time of such cancellation; and (4) is approved for loan cancellation by the young entrepreneurs business center established under this bill. The Department shall also cancel $3,000 of the balance of interest and principal due on any eligible federal Direct Loan not in default for a borrower who: (1) has made 12 monthly payments on such loan after enactment of this bill; (2) has been employed in a small business start-up job during the period in which the borrower makes each of the 012 payments; and (3) is employed in a small business start-up job at the time of such cancellation. The Department shall carry out a program under which it issues a loan to an individual who has an eligible private education loan, pays the proceeds of the loan to the private educational lender of the private education loan, and requires that the qualified borrower undergo loan counseling before the loan is refinanced. The Small Business Act is amended to establish within the Small Business Administration a young entrepreneurs business center that shall certify small business start-ups, identify distressed areas, and approve loan cancellation for founders of small business start-ups in distressed areas. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to exclude from gross income the discharge of certain federal student loans pursuant to the cancellation of such loan by the Department.

Cut Taxes for the Middle Class Act of 2014 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2014: (1) the deduction for state and local general sales taxes, (2) the above-the-line tax deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses, (3) the tax deduction for certain elementary and secondary school teacher expenses, (4) the employer wage tax credit for employees who are active duty members of the uniformed services, (5) the work opportunity tax credit, (6) the new markets tax credit, and (7) the research tax credit. Amends the Housing Assistance Tax Act of 2008 to extend through 2014 the housing allowance exclusion for determining area median gross income for low-income housing credit and qualified residential rental project exempt facility bonds.

Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to revise the home health interim payment formula. 
Directs the Director of the Congressional Budget Office to estimate the amount of savings to the Medicare program resulting from the interim payment system for home health services established by amendments made by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997.

Trade Promotion Authority Extension and Enhancement Act of 2007 - Amends the Bipartisan Trade Promotion Authority Act of 2002 to extend through July 1, 2016, and every fifth year thereafter: (1) the authority of the President to enter into trade agreements with other countries; and (2) the authority of Congress to approve or disapprove implementing bills for such agreements.

Requires the extension of trade authorities procedures to implementing bills submitted with respect to trade agreements entered into under this Act during the five-year period beginning on July 1, 2011, and during each five-year period thereafter, unless Congress adopts an extension disapproval resolution after April 1, and before July 1, of the year in which any such five-year period begins. Terminates such extension if such a resolution is adopted during the period specified.

Requires the President to report to Congress, not later than April 1, 2011, and not later than April 1 of each fifth year thereafter, on the extension of trade authorities procedures during the five-year period beginning on July 1 of the year in which the report is submitted. Terminates such requirement after a disapproval resolution is adopted.

Requires the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations and the International Trade Commission to report to Congress, not later than June 1, 2011, and not later than June 1 of each fifth year thereafter, on: (1) the progress made in negotiations to achieve the purposes, policies, priorities, and objectives of this Act; and (2) whether the trade authorities procedures should be extended for the succeeding five-year period. Terminates such requirements after a disapproval resolution is adopted.

Internet Freedom Act - Title I: Antitrust and Criminal Provisions - (Sec. 101) Provides that, in any civil action based on a claim arising under the Sherman Act, evidence that an incumbent local exchange carrier that has market power in the broadband service provider market has willfully and knowingly failed to provide conditioned unbundled local loops when economically reasonable and technically feasible, or restrains unreasonably the ability of a carrier to compete in its provision of broadband services over a local loop, shall be sufficient to establish a presumption of a violation of such Act.

(Sec. 102) Provides that, in any civil action based on a claim arising under the Sherman Act, evidence that a broadband access transport provider that has market power in the broadband service provider market has offered access to a service provider on terms and conditions, other than those justified by demonstrable cost differentials, that are less favorable than those offered by such operator to itself, to an affiliated service provider, or to another service provider, or restrains unreasonably the ability of a service provider from competing in its provision of broadband services, shall be sufficient to establish a presumption of a violation of such Act.

(Sec. 103) Makes it unlawful for a broadband access transport provider to engage in unfair methods of competition or unfair or deceptive acts or practices, the purpose or effect of which is to discriminate in favor of a service provider that is affiliated with a broadband access transport provider or to restrain unreasonably the ability of a service provider that is not affiliated with a broadband access transport provider from competing in its provision of any of the services provided by a service provider.

(Sec. 104) Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit intentionally and without authorization initiating the transmission of a bulk unsolicited electronic mail message to a protected computer with knowledge that such message falsifies an Internet domain, header information, date or time stamp, originating e-mail address or other identifier, or intentionally selling or distributing any computer program that: (1) is designed or produced primarily for the purpose of concealing the source or routing information of bulk unsolicited electronic mail messages in a manner prohibited by this Act; (2) has only limited commercially significant purpose or use other than to conceal such source or routing information; or (3) is marketed by the violator or another person acting in concert with the violator and with the violator's knowledge for use in concealing the source or routing information of such messages. Sets forth penalties for violations of this Act.

Title II: Additional Provisions - (Sec. 201) Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require each local exchange carrier to submit to the State commission in each State in which such carrier does business a plan to provide broadband telecommunications service in all local exchange areas in which such carrier has telephone exchange service customers as soon as such broadband telecommunications service is economically reasonably and technically feasible. Requires the plan to include all terms and conditions, including pricing, under which the services shall be provided. Requires the test of economic reasonability and technical feasibility to be made separately by the local exchange carrier for each local exchange, and the plan to be considered certified 45 days after submission unless the State commission rejects the plan within such 45 days. Requires successive plans to be submitted until approval is obtained. Requires the plan to be implemented within 180 days of the certification of the plan in each local exchange in which the provision of the service is both economically reasonable and technically feasible. Requires the carrier, upon certification of its plan, to be obligated by terms of the plan but otherwise to provide such services free of Federal and State price, rate, rate of return, and profit regulation. Requires a local exchange carrier to no longer be obligated by the terms of any such plan in such local exchange upon a determination by the State commission that: (1) a local exchange is served by another provider of broadband telecommunications services, or any broadband Internet access transport provider; or (2) the local exchange carrier makes broadband telecommunications services available to 70 percent of the access lines in an exchange.

Prohibits the State commission from having authority to modify any plan submitted pursuant to this Act except upon request of the carrier. Prohibits the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) from having authority with respect to the terms of any plan and with respect to the approval or rejection of any such plan.

Provides that an incumbent local exchange carrier's provision of broadband local telecommunications services shall not be subject to certain requirements of the Act in any State in which that carrier certifies to the State commission that: (1) in central offices in which it provides local loops that are conditioned for broadband services, it provides such loops to other carriers at least as quickly as it provides them for its own customers; (2) in central offices in which it does not currently provide local loops that are conditioned for broadband services, but in which such service is economically reasonable and technically feasible, it will provide such loops within 120 days of a request for such conditioning from another carrier; and (3) conditioned loops are provided upon such prices and other terms and conditions as the parties shall agree, or in any event of disagreements, as are determined through commercial arbitration, in which the commercial arbitrator shall establish the price based upon the cost of the loops and the costs for such conditioning that have been incurred by the local exchange carrier plus a reasonable profit.

(Sec. 202) Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to exclude from the definition of interLATA service services that consist of or include the transmission of any data or information, including any writing, signs, signals, pictures, or sounds related to the transmission of such data or information, by means of the Internet or any other network that employs Internet Protocol-based or other packet-switched technology.

Prohibits a Bell operating company, nor any affiliate of a Bell operating company, from providing, by means of the Internet or any other network that employs Internet Protocol-based or other packet-switched technology, two-way voice-only interLATA telecommunications services originating in any of its in-region States until such time as the FCC approves the application of such company for such State.

Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to: (1) establish a program to screen veterans who are eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care for symptoms of traumatic brain injury; (2) develop and carry out a comprehensive program of long-term care for post-acute traumatic brain injury rehabilitation that includes residential, community, and home-based components utilizing interdisciplinary treatment teams; (3) establish a traumatic brain injury transition office at each Department of Veterans Affairs polytrauma network site for coordinating the provision of health-care and services to veterans who suffer from moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries and are in need of health-care and services not immediately offered by the Department; and (4) establish and maintain the Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry.

National Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Preparedness Act of 2008 - Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish in the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) an Office for Bombing Prevention, which shall have primary responsibility within DHS for enhancing the ability, and coordinating the efforts, of the nation to deter, detect, prevent, protect against, intercept, and respond to terrorist improvised explosive device attacks.

Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to ensure that a subcommittee of the Homeland Security Advisory Council is established that is responsible for improvised explosive device prevention and response, to be known as the Senior Advisory Committee on Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Response.

Establishes a First Responder IED Prevention and Response Grant Program under which the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration may make grants to state and local governments.

Restore Opportunity, Strengthen, and Improve the Economy Act - Defines a "Good Jobs Model Employer" as one which: (1) respects employees' rights to bargain collectively with their employers without being forced to take strike action to win better wages and working conditions; (2) offers to each employee living wages, decent benefits including health care, paid leave for sickness and caregiving, and fair work schedules that are predictable and stable; (3) demonstrates an exemplary standard of compliance with workplace protection laws; (4) limits executive compensation to 50 times the median salary paid to the company's workers; (5) employs a workforce not less than 35% of which reside within one or more Historically Underutilized Business Zones; and (6) subcontracts only with other Good Jobs Model Employers. Prohibits an executive agency from awarding a contract for the acquisition of supplies or services to a source that is not a Good Jobs Model Employer, unless there is no offer from a source that is a Good Jobs Model Employer. Prohibits an executive agency from providing other forms of financial or nonfinancial assistance to entities that are not model employers when there is a similarly situated Good Jobs Model Employer that could receive the assistance, unless doing so would substantially undermine the value of the assistance to the public good. Requires executive agencies to incorporate into each new contract, contract-like instrument, or assistance agreement a clause requiring the contractor or recipient to conduct itself as a Good Jobs Model Employer for the duration of the contract. Directs the Secretary of Labor to promulgate regulations implementing the Good Jobs Model Employer Standards. Directs the Administrator of General Services, the Secretary of Defense, and the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to effect the policy and purposes of this Act. Requires organizations that acquire any form of financial or nonfinancial benefit or a contract from an executive agency through the operation of the procedure described in this Act to be placed on the Excluded Parties List enacted by Executive Orders 12549 and 12689 for at least two years if they fail to remain a model employer for the duration of the benefit. Requires organizations that violate a Good Job Model Employer clause in a contract or agreement required by this Act to be placed on such List for three years.

Welfare and Medicaid Responsibility Exchange Act of 1994 - Provides for the exchange of Federal funds received by a State under specified provisions of title IV (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of the Social Security Act (SSA) for FY 1996 through 2000 for cash and non-cash assistance to low income individuals. 
Amends SSA title IV part A (Aid to Families with Dependent Children) (AFDC), part F (Job Opportunities and Basic Skills Training), and the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 to terminate authority for such programs on October 1, 1995. 
Amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to terminate authority for the food stamp program on October 1, 1995. 
Provides for the Federalization of the Medicaid program beginning on October 1, 2000.

Charles August Long Undiagnosed Diseases Research and Collaboration Network Act of 2011 or the CAL Undiagnosed Diseases Research and Collaboration Network Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), acting through the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), to establish and maintain an undiagnosed diseases patient network (CAL Network) to: (1) provide physicians who are handling cases of undiagnosed diseases with a means to search for similar cases and to network and collaborate with other physicians in order to find a diagnosis and improve patient care and outcomes; (2) better enable and examine cross-disease research whereby cases of undiagnosed diseases can be cross-referenced against attributes of common diseases and rare diseases to assist in the rendering of a diagnosis; (3) better describe the types and prevalence of cases of undiagnosed diseases in the United States; (4) make necessary data available to elucidate appropriate factors that may be associated with the various types of cases of undiagnosed diseases reported by individuals specified by the NIH Director; (5) better outline key demographic factors of individuals who are undiagnosed; (6) provide such data necessary to better understand the length of time for a diagnosis to be rendered in cases of undiagnosed diseases and to identify barriers to diagnoses and reasons for misdiagnosis of diseases; and (7) provide such information necessary to determine, in order to improve access of individuals with undiagnosed diseases throughout the United States (including those with severe illnesses which limit or restrict travel) to programs similar to the Undiagnosed Disease Program conducted at NIH, if the needs and number of such individuals support the expansion of such Program to include the establishment of additional undiagnosed diseases programs of like scope and nature at other locations throughout the United States and the establishment by entities other than NIH of separate undiagnosed disease programs of like scope and nature to the Undiagnosed Disease Program at locations throughout the United States under the guidance of and through grants provided by and through such Program.

Authorizes the Secretary, acting through the NIH Director, to award grants to, and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with, public or private nonprofit entities for: (1) the collection, analysis, and reporting of data on cases of undiagnosed diseases and other disorders that can often go undiagnosed or be misdiagnosed as other diseases or disorders; and (2) the establishment of separate undiagnosed disease programs.

Authorizes a magistrate judge to enter a sentence for a petty offense and for a class A misdemeanor in a case in which the parties have consented.
Authorizes a magistrate judge, in a petty offense case involving a juvenile, to exercise all powers granted to the district court under the Federal criminal code.

Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act of 2009 - Amends the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA) to: (1) reduce from 50 to 25 the number of employees in a covered employer's workforce required for an employee to be eligible for FMLA leave; and (2) provide an additional entitlement to up to four hours of leave during any 30-day period, and up to 24 hours during any 12-month period, for parental involvement and family wellness.

Provides federal employees with the same entitlement.

Small Business Employment and Education Enhancement Act of 2001 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) locally-driven initiatives to improve education are crucial; (2) the views of small business should be taken into account in the debate over education; (3) in order to create jobs, our Nation must encourage small business expansion and foster small business entrepreneurship and job creation, and education initiatives are key to this effort; (4) the Department of Education should facilitate the sharing of ideas and best practices at the State and local level, particularly with respect to partnerships between small businesses and school systems; and (5) when and where Department of Education approval of a program or proposal is required, the Department should expedite such approval.Directs the Secretary of Education to disseminate information and facilitate the sharing of information designed to assist small businesses in working with school systems to improve the education system through publication of guidance materials, best practices, checklists, and other formats on the World Wide Web, in Department publications and articles, in letters, through links to other related World Wide Web sites, through public service announcements, and through other means at the Department's disposal.Directs the Secretary to establish a centralized database of materials to act as a clearinghouse for information on successful initiatives and best practices regarding the involvement of small businesses in education.Amends the Department of Education Organization Act to establish an Office of Small Business Education within the Department. Requires the Director of the Office to: (1) review the needs of small businesses and the contributions the small business community may make with respect to efforts to improve education; (2) promote efforts to address the needs of small businesses through education programs; (3) work to remove impediments to partnerships between school systems and small businesses; and (4) propose solutions to education-related problems facing small businesses.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small business tax credit for 15 percent of qualified education opportunity expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the taxable year. Defines "qualified education opportunity expenses" as an amount paid or incurred in connection with an eligible work study program, including administrative expenses of the taxpayer and remuneration paid to participants in such program for services performed by such participant. Defines "eligible work study program" as a written program approved by the appropriate State educational agency and involving a partnership with a secondary school to provide work study and internship opportunities for eligible individuals. Defines "eligible individual" as an individual who is a full-time student or teacher in a secondary school.

United States Secret Service Accountability and Improvement Act of 2014 - Establishes in the legislative branch an independent advisory panel to: (1) examine the efficiency and effectiveness of the leadership structure, protocols, training, tools, and capabilities of the Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) mission to protect national leaders, visiting heads of state and government, designated sites, and special events of national significance; and (2) make recommendations to improve the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the U.S. Secret Service.

Customs Training Enhancement Act - Directs the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to establish and carry out educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to improve the ability of CBP personnel to classify and appraise articles imported into the United States in accordance with U.S. customs laws, including to improve the ability of CBP personnel to identify and prevent the mislabeling and transshipment of articles.

Requires the Commissioner to: (1) pay the costs to establish and carry out each seminar; and (2) pay expenses for CBP personnel, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement personnel, and interested parties to provide instruction in or receive training at the seminar.

Directs the Commissioner to establish a process to solicit, evaluate, and select interested parties to assist in providing instruction in the educational seminars. Requires the Commissioner to publish in the Federal Register a detailed description of the process and the criteria used to select interested parties.

Promise for Antibiotics and Therapeutics for Health Act or the PATH Act This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to direct the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to establish a program under which it may approve an antibacterial drug as a limited population antibacterial drug upon a determination that such drug is intended to treat a serious or life-threatening disease, condition, or infection and address an unmet medical need for such disease, condition, or infection within an identifiable limited population. The FDA shall determine the safety and effectiveness of an antibacterial drug under the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs in accordance with specified considerations.  The FDA shall require: (1) labeling of such antibacterial drug to indicate that the drug has been approved for use only in a limited population and that the safety and efficacy of the drug has been demonstrated only with respect to such limited population; and (2) the sponsor to submit copies of all promotional materials related to the limited population antibacterial drug at least 30 days prior to dissemination of the materials. A sponsor of a drug that seeks approval of a drug through the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs may also seek approval of such drug under other programs. The FDA shall issue draft guidance describing criteria, processes, and other general considerations for demonstrating the safety and effectiveness of limited population antibacterial drugs and how the pathway can be expanded to other therapeutic areas in addition to antibacterial infections. The FDA shall conduct postapproval monitoring programs to study how antibacterial drugs approved through the pathway are used and to monitor changes in bacterial resistance to drugs, including drugs approved under this pathway. The FDA shall provide prompt advice to the sponsor of a drug for which the sponsor seeks approval through the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs to enable the sponsor to plan a development program to obtain the necessary data for approval of such drug through the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs and to conduct any additional studies that would be required to gain approval of such drug for use in a broader population. If, after approval of a drug through the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs, the FDA approves a broader indication for such drug for which the sponsor applies under the Public Health Service Act, the FDA may remove any postmarketing conditions, including requirements with respect to labeling and review of promotional materials and postapproval monitoring, applicable to the approval of the drug through the limited population pathway for antibacterial drugs. Beginning on October 1, 2016, the limited population pathway for antibiotic drugs may be expanded to apply to approval of other drugs intended to treat a serious or life-threatening illness.

Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) require a taxpayer to be at least age 18 in order to claim the first-time homebuyer tax credit; (2) require taxpayers to attach to their tax returns a properly executed copy of the settlement statement used to complete the purchase of a residence; and (3) treat certain errors with respect to such credit as mathematical or clerical errors.

Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to require any individual income tax return prepared by a tax return preparer to be filed on magnetic media if: (1) such return is filed by such tax return preparer, and (2) such tax return preparer is a specified tax return preparer for the calendar year during which such return is filed. Defines "specified tax return preparer" as any tax return preparer unless such preparer reasonably expects to file 100 or fewer individual income tax returns during such calendar year.

Directs the Attorney General to establish a process for: (1) recognizing nonprofit religious, charitable, social service, or similar organizations established in the United States; and (2) accrediting representatives of such organizations to provide immigration services on behalf of the organization.
Authorizes the Attorney General to provide grants to States to provide community outreach programs through State and local government agencies to educate individuals who use immigration consultants regarding the requirements of this Act.
Provides that the provisions of this Act supersede State laws only to the extent the State laws prevent the application of section 3. Authorizes States to impose requirements that are in addition to those established under this Act.
Prohibits the Attorney General, nor any other official or employee of the Department of Justice, or bureau or agency thereof, from using information furnished by any person specifically in relation to a violation of this Act for any purpose other than to carry out this Act.

Government Audit Reform Act of 2010 - Expresses the sense of Congress that the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) should follow the recommendations of the Government Accountability Office report entitled "Single Audit: Opportunities Exist to Improve the Single Audit Process and Oversight."

Amends the Single Audit Act to direct the Director, or the head of the office or entity designated by the Director, to monitor the risk, cost-benefit, efficiency, and effectiveness of the implementation by federal agencies of such Act.

Requires the Director to designate an office in OMB or another federal entity to act on behalf of the Director in monitoring such implementation.

Directs the Director, or the head of the office or entity designated by the Director, to evaluate the process for the single audit and the program-specific audit to identify simplified alternatives for achieving the purposes of the Single Audit Act of 1984 and the Single Audit Act Amendments of 1996 for the audits of small recipients that also achieve the proper balance between risk and cost-effective accountability for small and large recipients.

Requires the Director to evaluate the implementation of the recommendations made to OMB by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency in the report entitled "Report on National Single Audit Sampling Project."

Directs the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to establish a National Academy of Space for the instruction and preparation of selected individuals for service in a space-related capacity in the employ of the United States or a U.S. corporation. 
Requires the Board of the Academy to:  (1) develop an exam for secondary students testing knowledge in science, mathematics, and engineering; (2) establish uniform curriculum criteria for Member Institutes; (3) provide for the placement at one of the Member Institutes of students awarded scholarships under this Act at the Academy; (4) administer the awarding of such scholarships; and (5) establish a placement program to assist recipients of awards in obtaining positions as members of the Space Corps. 
Requires the Board to select between six and ten State universities that are regional in scope and that have outstanding degree programs in science, mathematics, and engineering to be designated as Member Institutes of the Academy. 
Requires the Board to annually certify the top ten scorers in each congressional district on the exam developed or selected under this Act and award to the top two scorers in each State, and to the top scorer in each district who is not one of the top two scorers in the State, a scholarship under this Act. 
Requires the Board to establish a scholarship program for students to attend the Academy who are willing to commit themselves to service as members of the Space Corps. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) eligibility; (2) waiver of full-time attendance requirements; (3) failure to meet eligibility requirements; (4) reinstatement or eligibility; (5) scholarship amount; and (6) service requirement. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Less Imprecision in Species Treatment Act of 2018 or the LIST Act of 2018 This bill amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require the Department of the Interior to initiate procedures to remove a species from the list of endangered and threatened species if: (1) the goals of a recovery plan for the species have been met, or (2) the goals for recovery of the species have not been developed and the Department determines that the species has recovered sufficiently to no longer require protection under the Act. The Department shall remove a species from any such list if it has produced or received substantial scientific or commercial information demonstrating that the species is recovered or that recovery goals set for the species have been met. The Department shall find within 90 days after receiving or producing information demonstrating that a species was erroneously or wrongfully listed whether the inclusion of such species in the list was less than likely to have occurred in the absence of the scientific or commercial information.
