If the Department finds that a person submitted a petition that is the subject of a positive finding knowing that it contained inaccurate, fraudulent, or misrepresentative scientific or commercial information, then during the 10-year period beginning on the date of the finding the person shall not be considered an interested person for purposes of the petition process with respect to any petition submitted by the person after the date the person submitted such information.

Rural Aviation Improvement Act - Amends federal aviation law to repeal the essential air service (EAS) local participation program.

Prohibits the Secretary of Transportation from providing compensation to an air carrier to provide EAS to an otherwise eligible place in the 48 contiguous states if the eligible place: (1) is located fewer than 70 highway miles from the nearest large or medium hub airport; or (2) is fewer than 210 miles from the nearest large or medium hub airport and requires a per passenger subsidy in excess of $200 for calendar year 2008, with annual increases based on the Consumer Price Index.

Allows a state or local government to submit a proposal to the Secretary for compensation for an air carrier to provide EAS to a place that is otherwise eligible but for which the per passenger subsidy exceeds the allowable dollar amount. Requires the Secretary to approve such a proposal if the state or local government or a person is willing and able to pay the difference between the per passenger subsidy and the allowable dollar amount.

Allows a state or local government to submit a proposal to the Secretary for compensation for a preferred air carrier to provide EAS to an eligible place. Defines "preferred air carrier" as an air carrier that: (1) submits an application to provide EAS to an eligible place; (2) is not the air carrier that submits the lowest cost bid to provide EAS to the eligible place; and (3) is an air carrier that the affected community prefers to provide EAS to the eligible place instead of the air carrier that submits the lowest cost bid.

Allows a state or local government to submit a proposal to the Secretary for restoring the eligibility of an otherwise eligible place to receive basic EAS by an air carrier for compensation if the per passenger subsidy required by the proposal does not exceed the per passenger subsidy cap.

Requires the Secretary, in any determination of compensation or eligibility for compensation for EAS based on the highway mileage of an eligible place from the nearest medium hub airport or large hub airport, to use the highway mileage of the most commonly used route.

Establishes within the Office of the Secretary the Office of Rural Aviation to: (1) develop a uniform four-year contract for air carriers providing EAS to communities; (2) develop a mechanism for comparing applications submitted by air carriers to provide EAS to communities; and (3) select an air carrier from among air carriers applying to provide EAS, based on specified criteria.

Extends through FY2011 the authority of the Secretary to make agreements under the EAS program.

Requires the Secretary to treat passenger boardings on aircraft operated by charter air carriers at airports receiving EAS as passenger boardings for purposes of determining whether an airport is eligible for airport development assistance.

Reduces the authorization of appropriations for EAS.

Spending Reduction Act This bill requires the head of each executive agency to submit to Congress and the President a report on the implementation of recommendations made by specified Government Accountability Office (GAO) reports. The reports must include:   an opinion by the Comptroller General on whether each recommendation is consistent with the intent of the GAO reports;  a proposal for legislative changes, if any, necessary to implement the recommendations; and  a statement of the annual impact on costs to the federal government, including cost savings, expected to occur as a result of the implementation of such recommendations.   Each agency must begin to implement the recommendations submitted in the report to eliminate, consolidate, streamline, or better coordinate government programs and agencies with duplicative, overlapping, or fragmented missions identified in the GAO reports. An agency may not carry out any recommendations contained in the report if a joint resolution disapproving such recommendations is enacted before the earlier of: (1) the end of the 45-day period beginning on the date on which the agency submits the report, or (2) the adjournment of Congress sine die for the session during which the report is submitted.

Veterinary Workforce Expansion Act of 2005 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award competitive grants to eligible entities for the purpose of improving public health preparedness through increasing the number of veterinarians in the workforce.

Requires the Secretary to give preference to applicants that demonstrate a comprehensive approach by involving more than one school of veterinary medicine, department of comparative medicine, department of veterinary science, school of public health, or school of medicine that offers postgraduate training for veterinarians in a public health practice area.

Technological Resource to Assist Criminal Enforcement (TRACE) Act - Amends the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act to require a licensed manufacturer or importer of firearms to: (1) test fire firearms manufactured or imported by such licensees; (2) prepare ballistics images of the fired bullet and cartridge casings from the test fire; (3) make the records available to the Attorney General for entry in a computerized database; and (4) store the fired bullet and cartridge casings in such a manner and for such a period as specified by the Attorney General.

Directs the Attorney General to: (1) assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with such requirements; (2) establish a computer system through which State and local law enforcement agencies can promptly access the ballistics records stored under this Act; (3) require training for all ballistics examiners; and (4) conduct mandatory ballistics testing of all firearms obtained or in the possession of their respective agencies.

Prohibits the use of ballistics information of individual guns in any form or database established by this Act for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement officials have a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and that ballistics information would assist in the investigation of that crime.

Sound Science Saves Species Act of 2002 - Amends the Endangered Species Act of 1973 to require that a petition to add or remove a species from either the endangered or threatened list contain: (1) clear and convincing evidence of the known and historic ranges of the species, the most recent population estimates and trends, the reason that the petitioned action is warranted, including known or perceived threats to the species, and the population of the species is declining or has declined from historic population levels and beyond normal population fluctuations for the species; (2) a bibliography of scientific literature on the species in support of the petition; and (3) a description of all available data on the historical and current range, population, and distribution of the species, an explanation of the methodology used to collect the data, and an identification of the location where the data can be reviewed.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to publish in the Federal Register a notice indicating receipt of such a petition and inviting interested persons to submit any relevant scientific information regarding the status of the species concerned. Requires the Secretary to: (1) promptly publish the petition on the Internet website of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; (2) provide notice of such receipt to each private owner of land or water on or in which the species may exist by publication of such notice in an appropriate newspaper of general circulation, except that such notice shall be provided directly to each such owner if the number of such owners is 100 or less; and (3) notify the Governor of each State that could be affected by the petition.Directs the Secretary to appoint and convene an independent review board to conduct an independent scientific review of the data included in the petition. Requires the board to provide to the Secretary its findings regarding: (1) the sufficiency of all relevant scientific information and assumptions in the petition relating to the taxonomy, population models, and supportive biological and ecological information regarding the species that is the subject of the petition; (2) whether the methodology and analysis supporting the petition meet the standards of the academic and scientific community; (3) whether the petition is supported by clear and convincing evidence/provides clear and convincing evidence that the petitioned action may be warranted; and (4) whether the review board concurs in the finding of the Secretary. Requires the Secretary to: (1) publish in the Federal Register each finding by an independent review board; (2) post each such finding on the Internet website of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; and (3) otherwise make each such finding available to the public. Directs the Secretary to: (1) revoke the finding of the Secretary if the review board does not concur; or (2) publish in the Federal Register an explanation of why the finding of the review board is incorrect, with clear and convincing evidence supporting such explanation.Requires the Secretary to maintain a list of individuals who are available to participate on independent review boards under this Act. Requires the Secretary to seek nominations of individuals to participate on such boards through the Federal Register, scientific and commercial journals, and the National Academy of Sciences and other such institutions. Requires the Secretary to update such list every two years.Requires the Secretary to appoint and convene an independent review board to conduct an independent scientific review of the scientific information used in making a statement that a proposed action is likely to jeopardize the continued existence of a species included in a list. Requires the board to provide to the Secretary its findings regarding: (1) the sufficiency of all relevant scientific information and assumptions in such statement relating to the taxonomy, population models, and supportive biological and ecological information regarding the species that is the subject of the statement; (2) whether the methodology and analysis supporting the statement meet the standards of the academic and scientific community; (3) whether the statement is supported by clear and convincing evidence; and (4) whether the review board concurs in the statement. Requires the Secretary to: (1) publish in the Federal Register each finding by an independent review board; (2) post each such finding on the Internet website of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; and (3) otherwise make each such finding available to the public. Directs the Secretary to: (1) revoke the statement if the review board does not concur; or (2) publish in the Federal Register an explanation of why the finding of the review board is incorrect, with clear and convincing evidence supporting such explanation.Prohibits another petition regarding that species from being considered by the Secretary for one year if the Secretary determines pursuant to a petition that addition of a species to either of the lists is not warranted.

Helping Empower Low-income Parents (HELP) Scholarships Amendments of 1997 - Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to revise provisions regarding the distribution of funds for voluntary public and private parental choice programs. 
Directs the Comptroller General to contract with an evaluating agency to conduct an ongoing rigorous evaluation of such programs.

Gun Show Background Check Act of 2008 - Amends the federal criminal code to prohibit any person from organizing, planning, promoting, or operating a gun show unless that person: (1) registers with the Attorney General and pays a registration fee; and (2) verifies the identity of each vendor participating in the gun show by examining a valid identification document containing a photograph of the vendor.

Prohibits any person who is not licensed under the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act from transferring a firearm to another unlicensed person, unless the firearm is transferred through a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer. Prohibits such transfer until the licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer makes specified notifications to the transferee.

Requires a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer who agrees to assist an unlicensed person in carrying out the responsibilities of that person with respect to the transfer of a firearm to: (1) enter such information about the firearm as the Attorney General may require into a separate bound record; (2) record the transfer on a form specified by the Attorney General; (3) comply with certain requirements as if transferring the firearm from the inventory of the licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer to the designated transferee; and (4) submit to the Attorney General a report of the transfer within ten days after the date on which the transfer occurs.

Sets forth penalties for violations of this Act.

Authorizes the Attorney General to enter during business hours the place of business of any gun show promoter and any place where a gun show is held for the purposes of examining the records required by this Act and the inventory of licensees conducting business at the gun show.

Increases penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees and for violations of criminal background check requirements.

Federal Physicians Comparability Allowance Amendments of 2000 - Makes permanent the authority for Federal physicians comparability allowances. 
Treats such allowances as part of basic pay for retirement purposes under the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and the Federal Employees' Retirement System (FERS).

Technology for the Classroom Act of 1993 - Directs the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to eligible consortia to develop instructional programs or technology-based systems for complete courses or units of study for a specific subject and grade level, if such programs or systems are commercially unavailable in the local area served by such consortia. 
Gives grant priority to applications describing programs or systems that:  (1) may be adapted and applied nationally; and (2) are designed to raise the achievement levels of students, particularly disadvantaged students who are not realizing their potential. 
Authorizes the Secretary to award grants to States to identify schools or school districts which have a large number of educationally disadvantaged students and limited access to technology-based learning resources and to develop strategies to improve the accessibility and use of such resources. 
Directs the Secretary to coordinate and share information regarding curriculum-based educational technology programs assisted under this Act with other Federal agencies which administer programs that support the development of such programs. 
Requires any royalties paid to any State or local educational agency as a result of assistance provided under this Act to be used by such agency for further development of curriculum-based learning resources authorized by this Act. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Drive America on Natural Gas Act of 2008 - Amends the Clean Air Act to include renewable and nonrenewable natural gas, including compressed natural and liquefied natural gas when used as transportation fuel, as renewable fuel for purposes of the renewable fuel standard.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a tax credit for new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles capable of operating on an alternative fuel and gasoline or diesel fuel.

Directs the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to conduct a program of natural gas vehicle research, development, and demonstration. Requires the Secretary to coordinate with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on issues related to streamlining the certification of natural gas conversion systems to appropriate federal certification requirements and in-use emission standards.

Requires the Administrator to establish and carry out a demonstration program to assist states in facilitating the development of alternative-fueled vehicles. Requires the Administrator to waive all fees applicable to small volume manufacturers for the certification and conversion of alternative-fueled vehicles, and other specified benefits for participating small volume manufacturers.

Requires the Administrator to: (1) waive requirements for recertification of kits for the conversion of vehicles into vehicles that are powered by natural gas in any case in which the kit has been previously certified for the model of vehicle to be converted and neither the kit nor the design and specifications of the model have substantially changed; and (2) waive emission certification system requirements for a vehicle that is over 10 years old or has over 120,000 miles that is powered by natural gas.

Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit knowingly transporting a minor across a State line with the intent that the minor obtain an abortion, and thereby in fact abridges the right of a parent of the minor under a law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision, in force in the State in which the minor resides.  Provides exceptions for life-endangering conditions and for minors and parents. 
Provides that it is an affirmative defense to a prosecution or civil action based on a violation of this Act that the defendant:  (1) reasonably believed, based on information obtained directly from a parent of the minor, that before the minor obtained the abortion, the parental consent or notification took place that would have been required under the law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision had the abortion been performed in the State in which the minor resides; or (2) was presented with documentation showing with a reasonable degree of certainty that a court in the minor's State of residence waived any parental notification required by the laws of that State, or otherwise authorized that the minor be allowed to procure an abortion. 
Prohibits knowingly transporting a minor across a State line with the intent that the minor obtain an abortion if the person has committed an act of incest with the minor. 
Requires a physician who performs or induces an abortion on a minor who is a resident of a State other than the State in which the abortion is performed or induced to provide, or cause his or her agent to provide, not less than 24 hours actual notice to a parent of the minor before performing or inducing the abortion.  Requires at least 24 hours constructive notice if actual notice is not accomplished after a reasonable effort has been made.  Provides exceptions for:  (1) the abortion being performed or induced in a State that has in force a law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision and the physician complies with the requirements of that law; (2) the physician being presented with documentation showing with a reasonable degree of certainty that a court in the minor's State of residence has waived any parental notification required by the laws of that State, or has otherwise authorized that the minor be allowed to procure an abortion; (3) the minor declaring in a signed written statement that she is the victim of sexual abuse, neglect, or physical abuse by a parent, and, before an abortion is performed on the minor, the physician notifies the authorities specified to receive reports of child abuse or neglect by the law of the State in which the minor resides of the known or suspected abuse or neglect; (4) the abortion being necessary to save the life of the minor because her life was endangered by a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness, including a life endangering physical condition caused by or arising from the pregnancy itself, except that an exception shall not apply unless the attending physician or an agent of such physician, not later than 24 hours after completion of the abortion, notifies a parent of the minor in writing that an abortion was performed on the minor and of the circumstances that warranted invocation of this paragraph; or (5) the minor being physically accompanied by a person who presents the physician or his or her agent with documentation showing with a reasonable degree of certainty that he or she is in fact the parent of that minor.

Preserving Patient Access to Inpatient Rehabilitation Hospitals Act of 2005 - Prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from: (1) requiring a compliance rate, pursuant to the criterion (commonly known as the "75 percent rule") that is used to determine whether a hospital or unit of a hospital is an inpatient rehabilitation facility, that is greater than the 50 percent compliance threshold that became effective on July 1, 2004; (2) changing the designation of an inpatient rehabilitation facility that is in compliance with the 50 percent threshold; or (3) conducting medical necessity review of inpatient rehabilitation facilities using any guidelines, such as fiscal intermediary Local Coverage Determinations, other than the national criteria established in the Medicare Benefits Policy Manual.

Directs the Secretary to establish procedures for: (1) making any necessary retroactive adjustment to restore the status of a facility as an inpatient rehabilitation facility as a result of this Act; (2) making any necessary payments to inpatient rehabilitation facilities based on such adjustment for discharges occurring on or after July 1, 2005, and before the date of enactment of this Act; and (3) developing and implementing an appeals process that provides for expedited review of any adjustment to the status of a facility as an inpatient rehabilitation facility made during the period beginning on July 1, 2005, and ending two years after the date of enactment of this Act.

Establishes the National Advisory Council on Medical Rehabilitation.

One Strike You're Out, Part II Act - Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to authorize a public housing agency (PHA) to deny assistance under the Section 8 program for assisted families in the same manner, for the same period, and subject to the same conditions that an owner of federally assisted housing may deny occupancy in such housing under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992. 
Amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 to:  (1) authorize an owner of federally assisted housing to deny occupancy to an applicant or any member of the applicant's household who is or was engaged in specified criminal activity during the preceding three years; (2) require such owner to consider such applicant as not having applied for such occupancy; and (3) allow such owner, after the expiration of the three-year period, to require the applicant to submit evidence sufficient to ensure that the individual or individuals in the applicant's household who engaged in criminal activity have not engaged in any criminal activity during such three-year period. 
Authorizes an owner of federally assisted housing to require, as a condition of providing occupancy in a dwelling unit to an applicant and the members of the applicant's household, that each adult member of the household provide the owner with a signed, written authorization for the owner to obtain records regarding such member from the National Crime Information Center, police departments, and other law enforcement agencies. 
Amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to revise provisions concerning termination of tenancy in public housing to:  (1) provide for an expedited grievance procedure for any grievance concerning an eviction or termination of tenancy that involves any activity described in this Act; (2) prohibit a PHA from terminating a tenancy except for violation of the terms and conditions of the lease, violation of applicable Federal, State, or local law, or other good cause; and (3) provide that any activity, engaged in by the tenant, any member of the tenant's household, or any guest or other person under the tenant's control, that threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of the premises by, other tenants or employees of the PHA or other manager of the housing, threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of their residences by, persons residing in the immediate vicinity of the premises, or is criminal activity (including drug-related criminal activity) on or off the premises, shall be cause for termination of tenancy. 
Amends the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 to require each lease for a dwelling unit in federally assisted housing to provide that:  (1) the owner may not terminate the tenancy except for violation of the terms and conditions of the lease, violation of applicable Federal, State, or local law, or other good cause; and (2) any activity, engaged in by the tenant, any member of the tenant's household, or any guest or other person under the tenant's control, that threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of the premises by, other tenants or employees of the owner or other manager of the housing, threatens the health or safety of, or right to peaceful enjoyment of their residences by, persons residing in the immediate vicinity of the premises, or is criminal activity (including drug-related criminal activity) on or off the premises, shall be cause for termination of tenancy. 
Requires the National Crime Information Center, a police department, and any other law enforcement agency, upon request of an owner of federally assisted housing, to provide to the owner information regarding the criminal conviction records of an adult applicant for, or tenants of, the federally assisted housing for purposes of applicant screening, lease enforcement, and eviction, but only if such Center, department, or agency is presented with a written authorization, signed by such applicant, for the release of such information to such owner.  Requires a law enforcement agency to provide information relating to any criminal conviction of a juvenile only to the extent that the release of such information is authorized under the law of the applicable State, tribe, or locality. 
Requires the public housing agency or owner, before an adverse action is taken with regard to assistance for federally assisted housing on the basis of a criminal record, to provide the tenant or applicant with a copy of the criminal record and an opportunity to dispute the accuracy and relevance of that record. 
Allows a public housing agency or owner of federally assisted housing to be charged a reasonable fee for information provided under this Act. 
Requires each public housing agency and owner of federally assisted housing that receives criminal record information under this Act to establish and implement a system of records management that ensures that any criminal record received by the agency or owner is:  (1) maintained confidentially; (2) not misused or improperly disseminated; and (3) destroyed, once the purpose for which the record was requested has been accomplished.

Renewable Energy Investment Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend through 2014 the renewable electricity production tax credit; (2) increase and extend through 2014 the authority for new clean renewable energy bonds; (3) extend through 2018 the investment tax credit for solar energy property, fuel cell property, qualified small wind energy property, and geothermal heat pump systems; and (4) increase the credit for investment in advanced energy facilities.

Extends through 2011 the tax credits for alcohol fuels and biodiesel and renewable diesel.

Authorizes appropriations for advanced biofuels research, development, and demonstration that will create fuels that are fungible in existing infrastructure.

National MS and Parkinson's Disease Registries Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR), to: (1) develop a system to collect data on multiple sclerosis (MS) and Parkinson's disease; (2) establish a national surveillance system for the collection and storage of such data to include a population-based registry of cases of MS and Parkinson's disease in the United States; (3) assist in application of MS national surveillance system methodologies for the development, piloting, and implementation of a national Parkinson's disease national surveillance system; and (4) provide analysis regarding expansion of national disease surveillance systems for other neurological diseases and disorders utilizing the MS and Parkinson's disease national surveillance systems' process and structure.

Directs the Secretary to establish the Advisory Committee on Neurological Disease Registries to review information and make recommendations to the Secretary concerning: (1) the development and maintenance of the MS and Parkinson's disease national surveillance systems; (2) the use and coordination of existing databases that collect or maintain information on neurological diseases and disorders; (3) the type of information to be collected and stored in the systems; (4) the manner in which such data is to be collected; (5) the use and availability of such data including guidelines for such use; and (6) the application of MS and Parkinson's disease registry methodologies to benefit other neurological diseases and disorders, including analysis of how other neurological disease surveillance systems or registries can be developed, piloted, and implemented nationally utilizing the MS and Parkinson's disease national surveillance systems' process and structure.

Authorizes the Secretary to award grants to, and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with, public or private nonprofit entities for the collection, analysis, and reporting of data on MS and Parkinson's disease.

Requires the Secretary, in establishing the MS and Parkinson's disease national surveillance systems, to: (1) identify, build upon, expand, and coordinate existing data and surveillance systems, surveys, registries, and other federal public health and environmental infrastructure wherever possible; and (2) provide for and conduct outreach in support of research access to Parkinson's disease and MS data as recommended by the Advisory Committee.

Veterans Programs Improvement Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to increase disability compensation and dependency and indemnity compensation (DIC) rates, effective December 1, 2003, by the same percentage as Social Security Act (SSA) benefit amounts are increased on that date. Repeals the 45-day rule for the effective date of a death pension award.Amends Federal veterans' benefits law to exclude lump-sum life insurance proceeds from determinations of annual income for pension purposes.Prohibits payment of compensation for alcohol or drug-related disability even if the abuse is secondary to a service-connected disability.Amends Federal law regarding National Service Life Insurance and U.S. Government Life Insurance to provide alternative beneficiaries in the event the first beneficiary does not make a claim within two years after the insured's death. Provides a time limitation on receipt of claim information pursuant to request by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).Revises burial plot allowance provisions to include a veteran who was discharged from active military service for a disability incurred or aggravated in line of duty. Expands burial eligibility for remarried spouses.Provides permanent authority for State cemetery grants program.Expands the list of subversive activities for which benefits shall be forfeited.Amends the Veterans' Advisory Committee on Education Act to extend the term of the Veterans' Advisory Committee on Education through FY 2013.Repeals the VA education loan program.Restores education benefits for certain individuals involuntarily ordered to full-time National Guard duty.Expands Montgomery GI Bill education benefits for certain self-employment training.

Ending Maternal Mortality Act of 2018 This bill amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop and submit to Congress a national plan to reduce the rate of preventable maternal mortality, with the goals of: (1) cutting the rate in half over the 10 years following enactment of this bill; and (2) eliminating preventable maternal deaths by the date that is 20 years after enactment of this bill. HHS must include in each biennial plan: (1) a list of objectives for meeting such goals; and (2) a strategy for implementing the plan across HHS agencies and offices. HHS must address specified issues in each biennial plan, including increasing public understanding of maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity, improving data collection, identifying at-risk populations and eliminating disparities, supporting and expanding maternal mortality review committees, assessing hospital culture of safety in maternity care, improving health and treatment services for expectant mothers struggling with substance use and mental health disorders, studying and supporting local and targeted responses to maternal death, and identifying federal programs and activities to reduce maternal mortality.

Preventive Medicine and Public Health Training Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to award grants to, or enter into contracts with, eligible entities to provide training to graduate medical residents in preventive medicine specialties.

Authorizes appropriations.

United States Employee Ownership Bank Act - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish the United States Employee Ownership Bank to foster increased employee ownership and greater employee participation in company decision-making throughout the United States. Requires the Bank to provide: (1) loans, loan guarantees, and technical assistance to employees to purchase a business through an employee stock ownership plan or eligible worker-owned cooperative that are at least 51 percent employee owned; and (2) grants to States and nonprofit and cooperative organizations with experience in developing employee-owned businesses and worker-owned cooperatives to provide education and outreach, technical assistance, participation training, and feasibility studies.Amends the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 to authorize the appropriate Federal financial supervisory agency, in assessing and taking into account the record of a financial institution, to consider as a factor capital investments, loans, loan participation, technical assistance, financial advice, grants, and other ventures undertaken by the institution to support or enable manufacturing employees to establish employee stock ownership plans or eligible worker owned cooperatives that are at least 51 percent employee-owned plans or cooperatives.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to:  (1) limit the tax deduction for interest paid by corporations; (2) allow a tax deduction for dividends paid by corporations; and (3) impose an additional tax on dividends received from sources within the United States by nonresident aliens or foreign corporations.
Alternative Minimum Tax Repeal Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the alternative minimum tax on individuals in 2011.

On-the-Job Training Tax Credit Act of 2015 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow employers with an average of not more than 500 full-time employees during a taxable year a tax credit for up to $5,000 for job training program expenses incurred by or on behalf of an employee who is employed at least 40 hours per week while participating in the job skills training program. The bill terminates such credit after 2017.

Reducing Barriers to Veterans' Benefits Act - Provides a presumption of service connection for hearing loss, tinnitus, or both of a veteran who: (1) was assigned to a military occupational specialty or equivalent in which individuals are or were likely to be exposed to a sufficiently high level of acoustic trauma as to result in permanent hearing loss, tinnitus, or both; or (2) served in combat against a hostile force during a period of hostilities.

Requires the Secretary of a military department to ensure that a member of the armed forces under the jurisdiction of the Secretary receives an audiometric test at the 8000 Hz frequency (or other test that the Secretary of Defense determines has the ability to discover potential future hearing loss) to evaluate the hearing of the member during the 90-day period before the date on which the member is discharged, separated, or retired.

Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011 - Amends the Securities Act of 1933 to direct the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to add a class of securities to the exempted small issues in accordance with specified terms and conditions, including: (1) an aggregate offering amount of all securities offered and sold within the prior 12-month period not exceeding $50 million; (2) that the securities may be offered and sold publicly; (3) that the securities shall not be restricted securities; (4) that civil liability provisions apply to any person offering or selling such securities; (5) that the issuer may solicit interest in the offering prior to filing any offering statement; and (6) that the SEC shall require the issuer to file audited financial statements annually.

Requires the SEC to review and increase the offering amount limitation every two years.

Treats as covered securities for purposes of the National Securities Markets Improvement Act of 1996 a rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this Act and such security is: (1) offered or sold on a national securities exchange; or (2) offered or sold to a qualified purchaser as defined by the SEC.

Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on the impact of state laws regulating securities offerings (commonly referred to as "Blue Sky laws") on offerings made under Regulation A.

Role Models Academy Demonstration Act - Directs the Secretary of Education to carry out a demonstration program under which the Secretary establishes a four-year, residential, military style academy that: (1) offers at-risk youth secondary school coursework and vocational training; (2) focuses on the education and vocational training of youth at risk of delinquency or dropping out of secondary school; (3) whose teachers are primarily composed of former members of the Armed Forces or participants in the Troops to Teachers Program; (4) operates a mentoring program that utilizes mentors from all sectors of society to serve as role models for Academy students; (5) may contain a Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps unit; (6) is housed on the site of any military installation closed pursuant to a base closure law; and (7) if the Secretary determines that the Academy is effective, serves as a model for similar military style academies throughout the United States.

Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) or any State from regulating the rates, charges, terms, or conditions for, or entry into the provision of, any high speed data service or Internet access service, or to regulate the facilities used in the provision of either such service. Provides that nothing in this Act shall be construed to limit or affect the authority of any State to regulate voice telephone exchange services, nor affect the rights of cable franchise authorities to establish requirements that are otherwise consistent with this Act.
Prohibits the FCC from requiring an incumbent local exchange carrier to: (1) provide unbundled access to any network elements used in the provision of any high speed data service; or (2) offer for resale at wholesale rates any high speed data service. Allows the FCC to modify the regulation referred to in this paragraph to reduce the number of network elements subject to the unbundling requirement, or to forbear from enforcing any portion of that regulation in accordance with the FCC's authority under the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
Requires each incumbent local exchange carrier to provide: (1) Internet users with the ability to subscribe to and have access to any Internet service provider that interconnects with such carrier's high speed data service; (2) any Internet service provider with the right to acquire the facilities and services necessary to interconnect with such carrier's high speed data service for the provision of Internet access service; and (3) any Internet service provider with the ability to collocate equipment in accordance with certain provisions to achieve the objectives of this Act.
Permits incidental interLATA service of high speed data service or Internet access service. Prohibits a Bell operating company offering any high speed data service or Internet access service pursuant to this Act until it is authorized to offer interLATA services originating in an in-region State from billing or collecting for interLATA voice telecommunications service obtained by means of the high speed data service or Internet access service provided by such company in such in-region State market.

Oklahoma City Victims Compensation Act - Directs the Attorney General, acting through the Special Master appointed under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001, to administer a compensation program for individuals who were physically injured or killed as a result of the bombing of the Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, on April 19, 1995. 
Authorizes appropriations. 
Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) filing and review of claims; (2) eligibility for compensation; (3) waiver of the right to file a civil action; (4) payments to eligible individuals; and (5) regulations. 
Grants the United States the right of subrogation with respect to any claim paid by the United States under this Act.

Satisfying Energy Needs and Saving the Environment Act or the SENSE Act (Sec. 2) This bill authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to require an operator of a coal refuse electric utility steam generating unit to comply with one of five specified emission standards for hydrogen chloride or sulfur dioxide. The EPA may not require that such unit comply with both an emission standard for hydrogen chloride and an emission standard for sulfur dioxide.

Directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the posthumous award of a gold medal to Lyndon Baines Johnson in recognition of his contributions to the nation, including passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the Social Security Amendments Act (Medicare) of 1965, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Higher Education Act of 1965, and the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1965. Requires the gold medal to be given to the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum, where it will be available for display and research. Expresses the sense of Congress that the Library and Museum should make the gold medal available for display elsewhere, particularly at appropriate locations associated with Johnson.

District of Columbia Full Self-Government Act - Continues to designate the territory constituting the permanent seat of the U.S. Government as the District of Columbia, which shall remain a body corporate. 
Establishes:  (1) a Council of the District of Columbia; and (2) the Office of the Mayor of the District of Columbia. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) treatment of employees formerly covered by the Federal Civil Service System; (2) restrictions on certain municipal planning activities; (3) emergency control of the Metropolitan Police Department; (4) judicial powers of the District of Columbia; (5) budget and financial management; (6) retention of Federal authorities; and (7) termination of existing charter.

Stop Assistance to Counterfeiters Act - Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to prohibit assistance from being provided to a person seeking U.S. assistance for a fiscal year until such person submits to the President a certification that: (1) such assistance will not be used to intentionally traffic in goods or services that contain counterfeit marks; (2) such assistance will not be used by any person that has had an administrative or judicial determination issued against the person for infringement, counterfeiting, or piracy of intellectual property in the United States or a foreign country; (3) any material or product developed using such assistance will not be imported into the United States in violation of specified provisions of the federal criminal code and the Tariff Act of 1930; and (4) if such assistance will be used for a contract, grant, cooperative agreement, or other agreement that includes use of any intellectual property, provides evidence of the right to use the intellectual property, including a written license agreement for the use, the date of the first commercial use of the intellectual property, and any registration for the use with an appropriate government.

Exempts foreign governments, international organizations, and entities of such governments from such certification requirement.

Directs the President to suspend or terminate the provision of assistance to a person seeking U.S. assistance if the President determines that such person has used the assistance to carry out an activity in violation of a certification made under this Act.

Authorizes the President to waive such prohibition if the President determines that such a waiver is necessary to the national security interests of the United States and promptly submits to Congress a notification of the waiver and of the reasons for the waiver.

Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2006 or the Credit CARD Act of 2006 - Amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit an increase in any annual percentage rate of interest (other than an increase due to the expiration of any introductory percentage rate of interest, or due solely to a change in another rate of interest to which such rate is indexed) from taking effect before the beginning of the billing cycle which begins not less than 15 days after the obligor receives notice of such increase.

Requires that such notice be made in a clear and conspicuous manner and contain a brief statement of the right of the obligor to cancel the account before the effective date of the increase.

Prohibits: (1) an annual percentage rate of interest applicable after the cancellation with respect to the outstanding balance on the account as of the date of cancellation from exceeding any annual percentage rate of interest applicable with respect to such balance under the terms and conditions in effect before the date of the notice of any increase; and (2) the repayment of the outstanding balance after the cancellation from being subject to all other terms and conditions applicable with respect to such account before the date of the notice of the increase.

Prohibits: (1) finance or interest charges for on-time payments; (2) fees or other penalties for on-time payments or payment in full; and (3) over-the-limit fees for creditor-approved transactions.

Requires creditors to disclose specified repayment information, including the outstanding balance in the account at the beginning of the statement period, the required minimum monthly payment on that balance, the grace period within which payment must be made to avoid additional charges, and the monthly payments amount that would be required for the consumer to eliminate the outstanding balance in 36 months if no further advances are made.

Requires a creditor to have a liability only for failing to comply with certain disclosure requirements.

Requires a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan under which a late fee or charge may be imposed due to the failure of the obligor to make payment on or before the due date for such payment to include: (1) the date by which the payment must be postmarked, if paid by mail, in order to avoid the imposition of a late payment fee; and (2) a statement that no late fee may be imposed in connection with a payment made by mail which was postmarked on or before the postmark date.

Requires a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan to include conspicuous notice of any increase in the annual percentage rate the account if one or more late payments may result in such an increase.

Prohibits issuance of a credit card to, or establishment of an open end credit plan on behalf of, a consumer who has not attained the age of 21 unless the consumer has submitted a written application that meets specified requirements, including the signature of the parent, legal guardian, or spouse of the consumer, or any other individual having a means to repay debts incurred by the consumer in connection with the account, indicating joint liability for debts incurred by the consumer in connection with the account before the consumer has attained the age of 18.

Requires enhanced penalties for violations of this Act.

Prohibits establishment of a credit card account under an open end credit plan by an individual who has not attained the age of 18 pursuant to any agreement relating to affinity cards between the creditor and an institution of higher education unless the requirements of this Act are met with respect to the obligor.

Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to revise requirements for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies. 
Prohibits payment under Medicare part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance) after July 1, 1994, for items furnished by a supplier of medical equipment and supplies unless such supplier meets national standards specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services and possesses a valid supplier number. 
Directs the Secretary to:  (1) revise the national standards for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies to include specified requirements; and (2) develop one or more standardized certificates of medical necessity for medical equipment and supplies other than durable medical equipment, prosthetic devices, orthotics and prosthetics, home dialysis supplies and equipment, and immunosuppressive drugs. 
Requires the Secretary to develop and establish uniform national coverage and utilization review criteria for 200 items of medical equipment and supplies selected in accordance with specified standards. 
Prohibits the Secretary from issuing more than one supplier number to any supplier of medical equipment and supplies unless the issuance of more than one number is appropriate to identify subsidiary or regional entities under the supplier's ownership or control. 
Revises provisions regarding inducements as kickbacks to exclude from such definition employment in a contract supply arrangement between a skilled nursing facility and a supplier of medical supplies and equipment that includes tasks of a clerical and cataloging nature in transmitting to suppliers assignment rights of individuals eligible for benefits under Medicare part B, or performance of warehousing or stock inventory functions. 
Provides that if a supplier of medical equipment and supplies furnishes an item or service to a beneficiary for which no payment may be made, payment is denied in advance, the supplier is excluded from participation under Medicare, or payment is denied under Medicare part A (Hospital Insurance), any expenses incurred for items and services furnished to an individual by such a supplier on an unassigned basis shall be the responsibility of such supplier.  Provides that the individual shall have no financial responsibility for such expenses and the supplier shall refund on a timely basis to the individual (and shall be liable to the individual for) any amounts collected from the individual for such items or services, unless the supplier informs the individual in advance that payment under Medicare will not be made for the item or services and the individual agrees to pay for the item or service. 
Treats nebulizers and aspirators as miscellaneous items of durable medical equipment. 
Provides for payment for ostomy supplies, tracheostomy supplies, urologicals, surgical dressings, and other medical supplies. 
Prohibits reasonable charges for parenteral and enteral nutrients, supplies, and equipment during 1994 from exceeding the charges determined to be reasonable with respect to such nutrients, supplies, and equipment during 1993. 
Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to the Congress on:  (1) the types, volume, and utilization of services and supplies furnished under contract or under arrangement with suppliers to individuals eligible for Medicare benefits residing in skilled nursing facilities and nursing facilities; and (2) whether changes made by the Department of Health and Human Services to the descriptions relating to the codes for medical equipment and supplies accurately reflect the items being furnished under such codes and are sufficiently explicit to distinguish between items of varying quality and price, and recommendations for additional changes that would improve the descriptions relating to the codes for such items.

Every Child Deserves a Family Act - Prohibits an entity that receives federal assistance and is involved in adoption or foster care placements from: (1) categorically denying to any person the opportunity to become an adoptive or a foster parent solely on the basis of the person's sexual orientation, gender identification, or marital status; (2) delaying or denying the placement of a child for adoption or into foster care, or otherwise discriminating in making a placement decision, solely on the basis of the sexual orientation, gender identification, or marital status of any prospective adoptive or foster parent; or (3) denying or limiting the parental rights of an adoptive parent based on the adoptive parent's sexual orientation, gender identification, or marital status.

Requires any individual who is aggrieved by an action in violation of this Act to bring an action seeking relief in a U.S. district court of appropriate jurisdiction.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to publish guidance to concerned entities with respect to compliance with this Act.

Sets a deadline for compliance with this Act, which may be extended if a state demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Secretary that it is necessary to amend state statutory law in order to change a particular practice that is inconsistent with this Act.

Authorizes the Secretary to withhold payment to a state of amounts otherwise payable to the state under part B or E of title IV of the Social Security Act, to the extent the Secretary deems the withholding necessary to induce the state into compliance with this Act.

Directs the Comptroller General to study and report to Congress on whether states have substantially complied with this Act.

Humanitarian Assistance to Combat HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean and National Security Act of 2003 - Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) effectively addressing the HIV/AIDS problem in countries in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean is a moral issue of the greatest magnitude and is in the national security interest of the United States; and (2) the President should enter into direct talks with the governments of other member countries of the G-8 and member countries of the European Union to increase the amount of financial support to combat the HIV/AIDS pandemic in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean.

Authorizes the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development to award grants to nongovernmental organizations for the prevention, treatment, and control of HIV/AIDS in countries in sub-Saharan Africa and Caribbean countries, including by expanding activities to prevent the mother-to-child transmission of HIV by providing treatment, medical care, and support services to HIV-infected parents and their children. Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, should provide appropriate medical and technical expertise to the Administrator and recipient governments.

Authorizes the Secretary of State, in conjunction with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to appoint to the country team in each U.S. embassy in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean a health officer to advise the U.S. Ambassador and assist in coordination of the effort to combat HIV/AIDS with local governments.

Authorizes appropriations.

Global Investments in America's Cities Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to reserve at least 3,000 EB-5 (employment creation) visas per fiscal year for qualified immigrants seeking to invest in a new commercial enterprise that will create employment in an economically distressed urban area. Defines "economically distressed urban area" as a city that has an average unemployment rate of not less than 150% of the national average rate for the preceding year or any principal city for a Metropolitan Statistical Area.

Guarantees a decision on an EB-5 visa petition within 60 days.

Directs the Comptroller General to report to Congress on the EB-5 Visa Program.

Reclamation Rural and Small Community Water Enhancement Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior, acting pursuant to the Reclamation Act and related laws, to undertake a program to investigate and identify opportunities to ensure safe and adequate regional rural water supply systems for municipal and industrial use in small communities and rural areas through the construction of new regional rural water supply systems and the enhancement of existing rural water supply systems.  Authorizes the Secretary to include a town or community with a population in excess of 40,000 persons if such town or community is considered to be a critical partner in the proposed regional rural water supply system. 
Requires the Secretary to: (1) consult and coordinate with the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Director of the Indian Health Service, in order to develop criteria to ensure that the program does not duplicate, but complements, activities undertaken pursuant to the authorities administered by such agency heads; and (2) report to specified congressional committees on the results of such consultation and criteria developed. 
Directs the Secretary to submit to such committees a report setting forth: (1) the status of all rural water projects within the jurisdiction of the Secretary authorized prior to enactment of this Act; and (2) the Secretary's plan, including projected financial and workforce requirements, for the completion of the rural water projects within the time frames set forth in the public laws authorizing the projects or the final engineering reports submitted pursuant thereto.  Requires the Secretary to take all necessary steps to complete the projects within the time frames identified. 
Authorizes the Secretary to undertake appraisal investigations to identify opportunities for the construction of regional rural water supply systems and the enhancement of existing rural water supply systems for small communities and rural areas.  Requires each such investigation to include recommendations as to the preparation of a feasibility study of the potential system or system enhancement. 
Authorizes the Secretary to participate with appropriate Federal, state, tribal, regional, and local authorities in studies to determine the feasibility of regional rural water supply systems and rural water supply system enhancements where an appraisal investigation so warrants.  Limits the Federal share of the costs of such feasibility studies to 50 percent of the total, except that the Secretary may increase the Federal share of the costs of such feasibility study if the Secretary determines, based upon a demonstration of financial hardship, that the non-Federal participant is unable to contribute at least 0.5 percent of the costs of such study.  Authorizes the Secretary to accept as part of the non-Federal cost share the contribution of such in-kind services by the non-Federal participant that the Secretary determines will contribute substantially toward the conduct and completion of the study.

Compassionate Pain Relief Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a program under which parenteral diacetylmorphine may be dispensed from pharmacies for the relief of intractable pain due to terminal cancer. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) the availability of such drug to pharmacies; (2) illicit diversion; and (3) prescription by physicians. 
Provides that the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and titles II and III of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 shall not apply with respect to the importing of opium, the manufacture of parenteral diacetylmorphine, and the distribution and dispensing of parenteral diacetylmorphine, in accordance with the program. 
Directs the Secretary to report to specified congressional committees on:  (1) implementation and activities undertaken to implement the program; (2) research activities on the management of pain that have received funds through the National Institutes of Health; and (3) ways in which the Federal Government supports the training of health personnel in pain management. 
Authorizes the Secretary to modify or terminate the program if it is no longer needed or if modifications or termination are needed to prevent substantial diversion of the diacetylmorphine.  Terminates the program 60 months after its establishment.

Secondary Payer Advancement, Rationalization, and Clarification Act or the SPARC Act - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to revise secondary payor and recovery rights for Medicare prescription drug plans.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require domestic service employment taxes to be filed on a calendar year basis.  Provides for the treatment of such taxes as a tax imposed by chapter 2 (Employment Taxes) of the Code for purposes of estimated tax provisions. 
Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to enter into an agreement with any State to collect, as the agent of such State, such State's unemployment taxes imposed on remuneration paid for domestic service in a private home of the employer. 
Requires the Secretary to prepare and make available information on the Federal tax obligations of employers with respect to employees performing domestic service in a private home of the employer. 
Revises the definition of "wages" for purposes of Social Security coverage to exclude cash remuneration paid by an employer in any calendar year to an employee for domestic service in a private home of the employer if the cash remuneration paid is less than $800.  Requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to adjust such amount at the same time and in the same manner as under the Social Security Act with respect to certain amounts, except that 1992 shall be substituted for the calendar year referred to in such Act.  Excludes from coverage domestic service in a private home of the employer performed in any year by an individual 16 and under during any portion of such year.

Outer Continental Shelf Permit Processing Coordination Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish: (1) a regional joint outer Continental Shelf lease and permit processing coordination office for the Alaska region; and (2) a regional joint outer Continental Shelf lease and permit processing coordination office for the Atlantic and Pacific regions, respectively.

Requires the Secretary to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Secretary of Commerce, the Chief of Engineers, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the head of any other federal agency that may have a role in permitting activities, and the head of each borough government located adjacent to any active lease area in Alaska. Requires the Secretary to request that the governor of a state adjacent to the applicable outer Continental Shelf region be a signatory to such memorandum.

Prohibits establishment of a coordination office for the Gulf of Mexico region until a proposed lease sale is conducted for the Atlantic or Pacific region.

Authorizes the Secretary to transfer funds to: (1) the Secretary of Commerce, the Chief of Engineers, the Administrator of EPA, the head of any other federal agency having a role in permitting activities, any state adjacent to the applicable outer Continental Shelf region, and the head of each borough government located adjacent to any active lease area in Alaska; and (2) the applicable coordination office for the Atlantic or Pacific region.

Grants the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit original and exclusive jurisdiction to review any claim relating to an action by the Administrator of EPA or the Secretary with respect to the review, approval, denial, or issuance of an oil or natural gas lease or permit in the area of the outer Continental Shelf described in this Act.

Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017 This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose an excise tax on employers who employ a low-wage employee during the calendar year. The tax is equal to the applicable percentage of the aggregate amount of wages paid by the employer with respect to employment of all employees of the employer during the calendar year. The applicable percentage is determined based on the ratio of the number of low-wage employees employed by the employer during the calendar year to the total number of individuals employed by the employer during such calendar year. The applicable percentage shall be reduced by 25 percentage points if the employer: (1) offers to all full-time low-wage employees the opportunity to enroll in minimum essential coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan for which the plan's share of the allowed costs of benefits provided under the plan is not less than 60% of such costs and the required contribution of the employee does not exceed the applicable percentage of the annual wages paid to the employee by the employer, and (2) meets the retirement plan requirements for all employees who are low-wage employees.

Victims of Abuse Access to Health Insurance Act - Prohibits an insurer from denying, canceling, or limiting health insurance coverage or benefits, or establishing, increasing, or varying the premium charged for such coverage or benefits: (1) to or for an individual on the basis that the individual is, has been, or may be the victim of domestic violence; or (2) to or for a group or employer on the basis that the group includes or the employer employs, or provides or subsidizes insurance for, an individual described in this Act.

Prohibits a health benefit plan from considering a condition or injury that occurred as a result of domestic violence as a pre-existing condition.

Subjects violators of this Act to: (1) a fine for a class A misdemeanor not resulting in death; (2) a civil monetary penalty; and (3) commencement by the aggrieved party of a civil action.

Higher Education Affordability and Availability Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to revise provisions relating to qualified tuition programs (QTPs) to:  (1) exclude from gross income distributions from QTPs for qualified higher education expenses; (2) impose an additional tax on amounts not used for such expenses; (3) permit eligible educational institutions to maintain QTPs; (4) limit contributions to QTPs not maintained by a State or agency or instrumentality thereof; (5) impose a tax on excess contributions to private QTPs and education individual retirement accounts; (6) allow a change of QTP or of designated beneficiary; and (7) include siblings as members of a family.
Urban Recovery and Growth Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend through 2014 the tax-exempt status of recovery zone economic development bonds for certain cities.

Preserving Medicare Advantage for all Medicare Beneficiaries Act of 2015 This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to prohibit the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services from terminating a contract with a Medicare Advantage organization solely because its plan has failed to achieve a minimum quality rating under the five-star rating system during the period beginning on the date of enactment of this bill and through the end of plan year 2018. The Department of Health and Human Services shall establish a demonstration project to provide funds to Medicare Advantage organizations offering one or more qualified Medicare Advantage plans for use in developing or expanding programs or services that seek to improve health care delivery and outcomes of care for enrollees with low socioeconomic status.

Immigrant Children's Educational Advancement and Dropout Prevention Act of 2001 - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Attorney General to cancel the removal of, and adjust to the status of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence, an alien who is inadmissible or deportable from the United States if the alien demonstrates that: (1) he or she has been physically present in the United States for a continuous period of not less than five years immediately preceding the date of such application; (2) he or she has been a person of good moral character during the five-year period preceding the application and admission; and (3) he or she is either a secondary school student in the United States, is attending an accredited two-year or four-year post-secondary educational institution in the United States, or has submitted an application for admission to an accredited two-year or four-year post-secondary educational institution in the United States. Provides for the adjustment of the status of an alien to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if the alien is the child of an alien described above. Directs the Attorney General to provide a procedure by regulation allowing eligible individuals to apply affirmatively for the relief available under this paragraph without being placed in removal proceedings. Exempts such aliens from numerical limitations.Directs that a child who has applied for relief under this Act but whose application has not been finally adjudicated be deemed to be a "qualified alien" under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 for the purpose of receiving any post-secondary education benefit, including any grants, loans, or scholarships.Repeals provisions of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 prohibiting State control over higher education admissions in State systems.

Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1998 - Amends the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 to prohibit the sale, importation, or exportation of products intended for human consumption or application containing, or labeled or advertised as containing, any substance derived from any species of rhinoceros or tiger. 
Directs the Secretary of the Interior to develop and implement an educational outreach program in the United States for the conservation of rhinoceros and tiger species.

Infant and Toddler Care Improvement Act - Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to make grants to states to improve the quality of care for infants and toddlers. Requires a state that receives such a grant to use the funds to carry out one or more of the following activities: (1) make grants to eligible entities to be resources for eligible infant and toddler care providers, to improve the quality of early care and development services provided to infants and toddlers in the community from low-income families and to help such providers serving low-income families improve their capacity to offer high-quality care to such families; (2) make grants to organizations with expertise in providing child care and related technical assistance, to establish and operate staffed family child care networks or systems that offer, to family child care providers who are eligible infant and toddler care providers, technical assistance, training, administrative support, or direct services including monitoring visits to providers; (3) support, or make a grant to an organization with expertise in providing child care technical assistance to support, a statewide network of specialists who are eligible infant and toddler care providers, that shall provide individual or group training and intensive consultation services to eligible infant and toddler care providers on strategies to improve the quality of care for infants and toddlers and assist eligible infant and toddler care providers in coordinating activities with other offices responsible for child care; (4) support initiatives to improve the quality of the workforce of eligible infant and toddler care providers; (5) develop infant and toddler components for the state's Quality Rating and Improvement System or similar rating system, child care licensing regulations, or voluntary early learning guidelines; (6) improve the ability of parents to obtain information about high-quality infant and toddler care; or (7) assist eligible infant and toddler care providers seeking to improve the quality of their infant and toddler care by increasing their ranking on the state's Quality Rating and Improvement System or similar rating system, meeting performance standards applicable to an Early Head Start agency under the Head Start Act, or becoming accredited by a national accrediting body.
Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase from 20 to 40 percent the credit for increasing research activities for qualified medical research expenses.

Recall Unsafe Drugs Act of 2017 This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require a person required to register under such Act to notify the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as soon as practicable if there is reason to believe that a drug is adulterated or misbranded and that there is a reasonable probability that the use or consumption of, or exposure to, the drug will cause a threat of serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals. The FDA may request that any person who distributes a drug that the FDA has reason to believe is adulterated, misbranded, or otherwise in violation of such Act voluntarily recall the drug and provide for notice to persons who may be affected by the recall. If the FDA has reason to believe that the use or consumption of, or exposure to, a drug may cause serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals, the FDA shall have the authority to issue an order requiring any person who distributes such drug to: (1) immediately cease distribution of such drug; and (2) provide for notice to persons who may be affected by such cessation of distribution. Any person subject to such an order shall immediately cease distribution of such drug and provide notification as required by such order. Any person subject to such an order may appeal within 24 hours of issuance such order to the FDA. If the FDA has credible evidence or information that a drug presents an imminent threat of serious adverse health consequences or death to humans or animals, the FDA may issue an order requiring any person who distributes such drug to: (1) immediately recall such drug; and (2) provide for notice to persons who may be affected by the recall. Any person subject to an emergency recall order shall immediately recall such drug and provide notification as required by such order. Any person subject to an emergency recall order may appeal within 24 hours after issuance such order to the FDA. The person subject to an emergency recall order shall conduct the recall notwithstanding the pendency of any appeal of such order. The FDA shall provide notice of a recall order to consumers to whom the drug was, or may have been, distributed and to appropriate state and local health officials.

Credible Military Option to Counter Iran Act - Declares that it shall be U.S. policy to take all necessary measures, including military action if required, to prevent Iran from threatening the United States, its allies, or Iran's neighbors with a nuclear weapon.

Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) military exercises conducted in the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman emphasize U.S. resolve and the policy described above by enhancing the readiness of U.S. military and allied forces, as well as signaling to the government of Iran the commitment of the United States to defend its vital national security interests; and (2) the President, as Commander in Chief, should require the U.S. military to develop a comprehensive plan to augment the presence of the U.S. Fifth Fleet in the Middle East and to conduct military deployments, exercises, or other visible, concrete military readiness activities to underscore such policy.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to prepare a plan to augment the presence of the U.S. Fifth Fleet in the Middle East and to conduct military deployments, exercises, or other visible, concrete military readiness activities to underscore such policy.

Authorizes appropriations for FY2012-FY2013 to enhance U.S. military capabilities in the Central Command Area of Responsibility.

Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should take specified actions to assist in the defense of Israel.

Directs the President to report to Congress on: (1) the status of Israel's qualitative military edge in light of current trends and instability in the region; and (2) taking into account Israel's urgent requirement for F-35 aircraft, actions to improve the process relating to Israel's purchase of F-35 aircraft to improve cost efficiency and timely delivery; (3) efforts to expand cooperation between the United States and Israel in homeland defense, counter-terrorism, maritime security, cybersecurity, and other appropriate areas; and (4) actions to integrate Israel into the defense of the Eastern Mediterranean.

Directs the Secretary of Defense to develop plans to: (1) enhance the military capabilities of Persian Gulf allies to bolster their posture in relation to Iran; and (2) increase the strategic partnership with regional allies to provide U.S. Armed Forces with the broadest set of geographic approaches to militarily access Iran.
