Algae-based Renewable Fuel Promotion Act of 2010 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat algae as a qualified feedstock for purposes of: (1) the cellulosic biofuel producer tax credit; and (2) bonus depreciation for biofuel plant property.

Stop Tampering of Prescription Pills Act of 2015 This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to consider whether an application for approval of a new brand name drug or a generic drug is subject to refusal because the drug is not an abuse-deterrent drug. An abuse-deterrent drug is one that: (1) contains as an active moiety a controlled substance classified as opium, an opiate, or a derivative thereof; (2) has been formulated for oral administration; and (3) exhibits physicochemical properties that make product manipulation significantly more difficult or ineffective in altering the characteristics of the drug for purposes of misuse or abuse when compared to drugs without such properties, or contains one or more additional active or inactive ingredients that are intended to deter abuse through potential pharmacological effects. The FDA may issue an order approving an application, even if the drug is not an abuse-deterrent drug, upon a finding that the drug is not a controlled substance, does not have a high potential for abuse, and is necessary either to prevent or alleviate a drug shortage or to otherwise address a significant unmet public health need. The FDA must include in the list of drugs under the generic drug provisions of the Act a list of each drug or category of drugs which it has found to be abuse-deterrent drugs.

Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate specified segments of the Taunton River in Massachusetts as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

Requires each such segment to be managed in accordance with the Taunton River Stewardship Plan, dated July 2005.

Authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into cooperative agreements with: (1) the Commonwealth of Massachusetts; (2) the Taunton River Stewardship Council; and (3) any appropriate nonprofit organization.

Prohibits each such segment from being: (1) administered as a unit of the National Park System; or (2) subject to the laws that govern the administration of the National Park System.

Requires the zoning ordinances adopted by the Towns of Bridgewater, Halifax, Middleborough, Raynham, Berkley, Dighton, Freetown, and Somerset, and the Cities of Taunton and Fall River, Massachusetts, to satisfy certain standards and requirements relating to land management.

Limits the authority of the Secretary to acquire parcels of land for each such segment to: (1) donation; or (2) with the consent of the owner of the parcel of land. Prohibits the Secretary from acquiring any parcel of land by condemnation.

Directs the Secretary to report to Congress on the energy resources available on the lands and waters included in the segments of the Taunton River designated under this Act.

Declares that nothing in this Act shall: (1) affect the authority, jurisdiction, or responsibility of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to manage, control, or regulate fish and resident wildlife under state law or regulations, including the regulation of hunting, fishing, trapping, and recreational shooting; or (2) impact the supply of domestically-produced energy resources.

Reducing Special Education Through Prevention Act - Amends the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act to authorize the Secretary of Education to make three-year grants to State and local educational agencies (SEAs and LEAs) to develop and implement effective strategies to reduce the number of children who have, or are at risk of developing, emotional disturbances that require the provision of special education and related services under such Act.

Iran Refined Petroleum Sanctions Act - Amends the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996 to revise sanctions against persons who have made an investment of $20 million or more (or any combination of investments of at least $5 million each, which in the aggregate equals or exceeds $20 million in any 12-month period) that directly and significantly contributed to the enhancement of Iran's ability to develop petroleum resources of Iran.

Requires the President to impose specified additional sanctions on a sanctioned person, including: (1) prohibiting transactions in foreign exchange; (2) prohibiting transfers of credit or payments between, by, through, or to any financial institution; and (3) prohibiting any acquisition, holding, withholding, use, transfer, withdrawal, transportation, importation, or exportation of, dealing in, or exercising any right, power, or privilege with respect to, or transactions involving, any property in which the sanctioned person has any interest by any person, or with respect to any property, subject to U.S. jurisdiction.

Directs the President to report to Congress every six months regarding any person who has: (1) provided Iran with refined petroleum resources; (2) engaged in any activity that could contribute to the enhancement of Iran's ability to import refined petroleum resources; or (3) sold, leased, or provided to Iran any goods, services, or technology that would allow Iran to maintain or expand its domestic production of refined petroleum resources.

Lamprey Wild and Scenic River Act - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate a specified segment of the Lamprey River in New Hampshire as a recreational river. 
Directs the Secretary of the Interior to coordinate management responsibilities with respect to such segment with the Lamprey River Advisory Committee.  Deems zoning ordinances adopted by the towns of Durham, Lee, and Newmarket, New Hampshire, including provisions for conservation of shorelands, floodplains, and wetlands associated with the segment, to satisfy standards and requirements of the Act.  Prohibits Federal acquisition of lands by condemnation for purposes of the segment.  Limits the authority of the Secretary to acquire lands for the segment to acquisition by donation or acquisition with the owner's consent. 
Requires the Secretary, upon request by the town of Epping, New Hampshire, which abuts an additional 12 miles of river found eligible for designation as a recreational river under the study described in this Act, to offer assistance concerning continued involvement of the town of Epping in the implementation of the Lamprey River Management Plan and in consideration of potential future addition of the portion of the river within Epping as a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Liquefied Natural Gas Act of 2005 - Amends the Natural Gas Act to prohibit any person from exporting or importing natural gas without first having secured an order of the Secretary of Energy authorizing such person to do so. Requires the Secretary to issue such order upon application, unless, after opportunity for hearing, the Secretary finds that the proposed exportation or importation will not be consistent with the public interest.

Requires the Secretary to treat as a "first sale" within the meaning of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 the importation of natural gas which is imported into the United States from a nation with which there is in effect a free trade agreement requiring national treatment for trade in natural gas. Prohibits the Secretary from treating any such imported natural gas on an unjust, unreasonable, unduly discriminatory, or preferential basis.

Deems the importation of such natural gas, or the exportation of natural gas to a nation with which there is in effect a free trade agreement requiring national treatment for trade in natural gas, to be consistent with the public interest, and requires applications for such importation or exportation to be granted without modification or delay.

Prohibits any person from siting, constructing, expanding, or operating a liquefied natural gas (LNG) import terminal without first having secured an order of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) authorizing such person to do so. Requires FERC to issue such order upon application, unless, after opportunity for hearing, it finds that the proposed siting, construction, expansion, or operation will not be consistent with the public interest. Allows FERC to grant such application, in whole or in part, with such modification and upon such terms and conditions as FERC may find necessary or appropriate.

Prohibits: (1) an order issued pursuant to this Act from being conditioned on a requirement that the LNG import terminal offer service to persons other than the person securing the order; (2) any regulation of the LNG import terminal's rates, charges, terms, or conditions of service; or (3) a requirement to file with FERC schedules or contracts related to the LNG import terminal's rates, charges, terms, or conditions of service.

Prohibits a state or local government from requiring a permit, license, concurrence, approval, certificate, or other form of authorization with respect to the siting, construction, expansion, or operation of an LNG import terminal.

Requires any decision made or action taken by a federal or state administrative agency or officer with respect to the siting, construction, expansion, or operation of an LNG import terminal to be consistent with any authorization provided by FERC under this Act, and prohibits or unreasonably delaying the siting, construction, expansion, or operation.

Requires FERC to approve or deny any application to site, construct, expand, or operate an LNG import terminal within one year after the application is complete.

Requires FERC to establish a schedule for all federal and state administrative proceedings commenced under authority of federal law, the completion of which is required before a person may site, construct, expand, or operate the LNG import terminal, in order to ensure expeditious progress toward such siting, construction, expansion, or operation. Requires the schedule also to include all federal and state administrative proceedings authorized by federal law for the siting, construction, expansion, and operation of natural gas pipelines and facilities related to the transportation of LNG or natural gas from the LNG import terminal.

Requires FERC to compile a single administrative record which shall consolidate the records of the proceedings referred to above.

Requires any federal administrative proceeding that is an appeal or review of a decision made or action taken by a federal or state administrative agency or officer with respect to the siting, construction, expansion, or operation of an LNG import terminal to use as its exclusive record for all purposes the administrative record compiled by FERC.

Grants the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit original and exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine any civil action for review of a decision made or action taken by a federal or state administrative agency or officer with respect to the siting, construction, expansion, or operation of an LNG import terminal.

Requires FERC to be the lead federal agency for purposes of complying with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 with respect to the siting, construction, expansion, or operation of an LNG import terminal.

Consumer Data Protection Act - Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to require a consumer reporting agency (CRA) to notify: (1) the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), and appropriate law enforcement and intelligence agencies within two days after discovering a data breach; and (2) each affected individual within three days after discovery of such breach. Allows an extension of such deadlines if the FTC and the intelligence agencies determine that there is a national security concern.

Requires a CRA, upon request by any affected individual, to provide: (1) a credit freeze with respect to the consumer report of the affected individual at any CRA; and (2) credit monitoring services for the affected individual at any CRA.

Requires a CRA to establish a consumer assistance unit to assist any affected individual who wants to dispute an item in the file of the affected individual that was entered into that file after the date on which the data breach occurred.

Authorizes the FTC or CFPB to bring a civil action to recover a civil penalty against any person that negligently, knowingly, or willingly causes a data breach at a CRA. Sets forth penalties for successful actions.

Allows an affected individual to bring an action in U.S. district court against any person that negligently, knowingly, or willingly caused a data breach at a CRA in which the sensitive personal information of the affected individual was lost, stolen, or accessed without authorization. Allows an affected individual to recover: (1) the greater of the actual loss to the affected individual with respect to the data breach or $1,000 in liquidated damages; (2) punitive damages; and (3) the costs of the action, together with reasonable attorney's fees.

Authorizes the CFPB to examine any CRA subject to supervision under the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 for compliance with standards established by the FTC under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act.

Prohibits a CRA from taking a covered action as a condition of providing any service or product to, or on behalf of, a consumer and that relates to the rights of a consumer after a data breach at the CRA in which the sensitive personal information of the consumer is lost, stolen, or accessed without authorization.

Directs the CFPB and the FTC to study and report annually to Congress regarding the costs to affected individuals from data breaches at CRAs.

Employers Financial Literacy Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a small business employer (an employer of between two and 50 employees) a tax credit for 35% of the continuing financial education expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the taxable year. Defines "continuing financial education expenses" as expenses for any educational program or services: (1) provided by a community-based budget and counseling agency; (2) which promotes consumer understanding of consumer, economic, and personal finance issues and concepts; (3) offered to all employees who have at least two weeks of service with the employer; and (4) offered during at least 24 hours of each month if the taxpayer is a corporation, or at least 16 hours of each month in any other case.

Requires an eligible small business or an eligible corporation (a corporation that employs 50 or more employees) to be given a preference when submitting a bid or proposal for a federal contract or applying for federal financial or nonfinancial assistance.

Hardship Outlays to protect Mortgagee Equity (HOME) Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt from the 10% additional tax on early distributions from certain retirement plans any distribution used to pay principal or interest on acquisition indebtedness for a principal residence.

Veterans' Burial Benefits Enhancement Act of 2003 - Modifies the eligibility for a burial plot allowance to include any veteran who is eligible for such an allowance or who was discharged from active military service for a disability incurred or aggravated in line of duty. (Current law provides for such an allowance only for veterans who were discharged from active military service for a disability incurred or aggravated in line of duty, or who are veterans of any war.)

Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to lease unutilized or underutilized land or facilities of the United States that are part of the National Cemetery Administration.

Directs the Secretary to establish a national cemetery in each geographic area in which: (1) the number of veterans who reside more than 50 miles from an open national cemetery or State cemetery for veterans exceeds 170,000; or (2) the number of veterans who reside more than 50 miles from an open national cemetery or State cemetery for veterans, when combined with the number of veterans who reside within 50 miles of a State cemetery for veterans but are ineligible for burial in such State cemetery due to residency requirements, exceeds 170,000.

Migratory Bird Treaty Reform Act of 2004 - Amends the Migratory Bird Treaty Act to exclude from its prohibitions against taking, possessing, importing, exporting, transporting, selling, purchasing, or bartering migratory birds and their parts, nests, and eggs any non-native species that occurs in the United States solely as a result of intentional or unintentional human-assisted introduction.

Requires the Secretary of the Interior to publish in the Federal Register a list of all non-native, human introduced bird species to which the Act does not apply that belong to biological families of migratory birds covered under any of the migratory bird conventions with Great Britain (for Canada), Mexico, Russia, or Japan.

Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Improvement Act of 2004 - Amends the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act to: (1) include Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands within the definition of "Caribbean"; (2) increase from 25 to 50 percent the non-Federal share required to be paid for projects carried out in Latin America or the Caribbean; (3) require the Secretary of the Treasury to deposit into the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Fund all amounts received by the Secretary in the form of donations; (4) authorize appropriations to the Fund; and (5) limit expenditures for projects in Canada.

National Hate Crimes Hotline Act of 2016 This bill authorizes the Department of Justice (DOJ) to award grants to private, nonprofit entities for: (1) establishing and operating a national, toll-free telephone hotline to provide information and assistance to victims of hate crimes; and (2) establishing and operating a highly secure website to provide that information and assistance. DOJ may award grants to state and local law enforcement entities for educational and training programs on solving hate crimes and establishing community dialogues with groups whose members are at-risk of being victims of such hate crimes. DOJ shall establish a grant program within the Office for Victims of Crime in the Office of Justice Programs under which DOJ may award grants to local community-based organizations, nonprofit organizations, and faith-based organizations to establish or expand local programs and activities that serve targeted areas and that provide legal, health, and other support services to victims of hate crimes.

Terrorism Elimination Act of 2001 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish in the Treasury the Counter-Terrorism Trust Fund. Makes amounts in such Fund available for expenditures for counter-terrorism efforts by the United States and for administrative expenses of the Department of the Treasury directly allocable to: (1) modifying income tax return forms to carry out this Act; (2) carrying out this Act with respect to such Fund; and (3) processing amounts received under this Act and transferring them to such Fund.Authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue Freedom Bonds in response to acts of terrorism perpetrated against the United States on September 11, 2001. Requires proceeds from the issuance of such bonds to be used to raise funds to assist in recovery operations following such terrorist acts and for efforts to combat terrorism.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a taxpayer to designate that a specified portion (but not less than $1) of any overpayment of tax for a taxable year and any cash contribution included with such return shall be deposited into the Counter-Terrorism Trust Fund.

Electronic Books Opening Opportunity for Knowledge Act of 2014 or the E-BOOK Act of 2014 - Amends title VIII (Innovation and Improvement) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education to award competitive grants to up to 10 public institutions of higher education to reduce the cost of attendance for undergraduate students by providing them with expanded access to digital course materials. Requires each grant to provide funds to support a pilot program for the institution to make digital course materials available to undergraduate students in at least two different academic departments. Gives preference to applications that demonstrate a commitment to serving disadvantaged students.

Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993 - Amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to authorize the President, on the same calendar day the President approves any appropriation bill, to transmit to both Houses of the Congress one or more special messages proposing to rescind all or part of any item of budget authority provided in the appropriation bill. 
Sets forth procedures for consideration of such a message. 
Requires that any item of budget authority proposed to be rescinded in a special message transmitted to the Congress be made available for obligation unless, not more than 60 days after the transmittal of the special message, both Houses have agreed to the bill or joint resolution accompanying such special message.

Amends title XIX (Medicaid) of the Social Security Act to require State Medicaid plans to provide that any congregate care provider that provides services to an individual for which medical assistance is available shall: (1) protect and promote the right of each individual to be free from physical or mental abuse, corporal punishment, involuntary seclusion, and any physical or chemical restraints imposed for purposes of discipline or convenience; (2) impose restraints only to ensure the physical safety of the individual or other individuals in the care or custody of the provider and only upon the written order of a physician that specifies the duration and circumstances under which the restraints are to be used (except in emergency circumstances specified by the Secretary until such an order could reasonably be obtained); and (3) submit reports required under this Act relating to sentinel events in the same manner as a provider of services under Medicare is required to submit such reports.

Community Access to Emergency Defibrillation Act of 2001 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to award grants to States, political subdivisions of States, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations to develop and implement public access defibrillation programs. Gives a preference to applicants that: (1) have a particularly low local survival rate for cardiac arrests or a particularly low local response rate for cardiac arrest victims; or (2) demonstrate in their applications the greatest commitment to establishing and maintaining a public access defibrillation program.Authorizes appropriations.Directs the Secretary to award grants to political subdivisions of States, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations to develop and implement innovative, comprehensive, community-based public access defibrillation demonstration projects that: (1) provide cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation to cardiac arrest victims in unique settings; (2) provide training to community members in cardiopulmonary resuscitation and automated external defibrillation; and (3) maximize community access to automated external defibrillators.Authorizes appropriations.Directs the Secretary to award a grant to a health care organization to establish a national information clearinghouse that provides information to increase public access to defibrillation in schools.

21st Century Federal Pell Grant Plus Act - Amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to provide that, for students pursuing a degree with a major in, or a certificate or program of study relating to, engineering, mathematics, science, or a foreign language, the amount of the Federal Pell Grant shall be the amount calculated for the student for the academic year involved, multiplied by two.

Oversight Workforce Improvement Act of 2014 - Exempts from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) information relating to the information security program or practices of a federal agency if disclosure could reasonably be expected to lead to or result in unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of such information system or the information it controls, processes, stores, or transmits. Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 and the Inspector General Reform Act of 2008 to: (1) require the Inspector General of each designated federal entity to be classified at a grade, level, or rank designation at or above those of a majority of the senior level executives of the designated federal entity; (2) prohibit a reduction in pay for career federal employees serving on an appointment made pursuant to statutory authority other than under provisions governing the Senior Executive Service who are appointed to the position of Inspector General; (3) allow allegations of wrongdoing against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel to be received, reviewed, and referred for investigation by the Integrity Committee to the same extent and in the same manner as in the case of an allegation against an Inspector General or a member of the staff of an Office of Inspector General; (4) apply the Inspector General Act of 1978 to designated federal entities; and (5) repeal a provision of the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2009 that prohibits the Inspector General of the Department of Justice from disclosing any information obtained from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

Colorectal Cancer Detection Act of 2018 This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide Medicare coverage for qualifying colorectal cancer screening blood-based tests. A "qualifying colorectal cancer screening blood-based test" is a screening blood-based test for the early detection of colorectal cancer that was marketed or used more than six months before the beginning of the year. The bill revises the frequency limits for colorectal cancer screening tests and payment amounts for qualifying colorectal cancer screening blood-based tests.

Survivor Benefits Improvement Act of 2013 - Extends the initial period for increased dependency and indemnity compensation (DIC) for surviving spouses with children from two to five years.  Provides that the remarriage after age 55 of a surviving spouse of a veteran shall not bar the furnishing of DIC, health care, and housing loans to such person as the surviving spouse of the veteran. Authorizes the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide to any child of a veteran who served in the active military, naval, or air service in Thailand during the period beginning on January 9, 1962, and ending on May 7, 1975, and who is determined by the Secretary to have been exposed to a herbicide agent during such service in Thailand, the health care, vocational training and rehabilitation, and monetary allowance required to be paid to a child of a Vietnam veteran who is suffering from spina bifida under provisions relating to children of veterans born with spina bifida. Directs the Secretary to carry out, through the Readjustment Counseling Service of the Veterans Health Administration, a pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of providing grief counseling services in group retreat settings to surviving spouses of veterans who die while serving on active duty in the Armed Forces.

Quit Smoking Incentive and Opportunity Act of 2003 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a refundable tax credit for qualified tobacco use cessation expenses paid by an individual, the individual's spouse, or any dependent of the individual. Limits such credit to $300 for products determined by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to be safe and effective in promoting a reduction in the use of tobacco products by individuals, and $100 for counseling for cessation of tobacco use. Defines "qualified tobacco use cessation expenses" as expenses for: (1) products determined by the FDA to be safe and effective in promoting a reduction in the use of tobacco products by individuals; and (2) counseling for cessation of tobacco use.

Energy and Water Integration Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of Energy (DOE) to enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Sciences to conduct an in-depth analysis of the impact of energy development and production on U.S. water resources.

Directs the Secretary to study and report to Congress on: (1) the best available technologies and related strategies to maximize water and energy efficiency in the production of electricity by each type of generation; and (2) the quantities of energy used in water storage and delivery operations in major Reclamation projects.

Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation, to evaluate the quantities of energy used in water storage and delivery operations in major Reclamation projects.

Directs the Secretary of the Interior to operate, manage, and maintain the Brackish Groundwater National Desalination Research Facility in Otero County, New Mexico, to carry out research, development, and demonstration activities to develop technologies and methods that promote brackish groundwater desalination as a viable method to increase water supply in a cost-effective manner.

Amends the Department of Energy Organization Act to require the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to collect information on energy consumption in various sectors of the economy that are associated with the acquisition, treatment, or delivery of water.

Directs the Secretary of Energy to develop the Energy-Water Research and Development Roadmap to define the future research, development, demonstration, and commercialization efforts that are required to address emerging water-related challenges to future, cost-effective, reliable, and sustainable energy generation and production.

American Eagle Palladium Bullion Coin Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue one-ounce palladium bullion coins in such quantities as appropriate to meet demand.

Requires the Secretary to acquire bullion for such coins by purchase of palladium mined from natural deposits in the United States, or in a U.S. territory or possession, within one year after the month in which the ore from which it is derived was mined. Authorizes the Secretary to obtain palladium from other available sources if no such palladium is available or if it is not economically feasible to obtain such palladium.

Directs the Secretary to pay no more than the average world price for the palladium.

Requires each coin issued under this Act to be sold for an amount the Secretary determines to be appropriate, but not less than the sum of: (1) the market value of the bullion at the time of sale; and (2) the cost of designing and issuing the coins, including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, distribution, and shipping.

Requires all coins minted under this Act to be considered to be numismatic items.

Authorizes the Secretary to issue such coins in both proof and uncirculated versions, except that, should the Secretary determine that it is appropriate to issue proof or uncirculated versions of such coin, the Secretary shall, to the greatest extent possible, ensure that the surface treatment of each year's proof or uncirculated version differs in some material way from that of the preceding year.

Requires such coins to bear designs on the obverse and reverse that are close likenesses of the work of famed American coin designer and medallic artist Adolph Alexander Weinman.

Permits any U.S. mint, other than the U.S. Mint at West Point, New York, to be used to strike coins minted under this Act other than any proof version of any such coin. Requires that if the Secretary determines that it is appropriate to issue any proof version of such coin, coins of such version shall be struck only at the U.S. Mint at West Point, New York.

Defines "market study" as an analysis of the market for palladium bullion investments conducted by a reputable, independent third party that demonstrates that there would be adequate demand for palladium bullion coins produced by the U.S. Mint to ensure that such coins could be minted and issued at no net cost to taxpayers.

Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) assess the U.S. economy to determine what goods the United States currently produces, where such goods are produced, in which manufacturing sector the United States is most competitive in the global economy, and what policies are necessary to maintain or increase the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing in the global economy; (2) develop a comprehensive national manufacturing strategy with specified goals; (3) establish targets for the growth of U.S. manufacturing, including targets for job creation, for each of FY2012-FY2016; (4) conduct a survey of all federal agencies that provide support to U.S. manufacturers; (5) report on progress and trends in U.S. manufacturing since the Secretary's 2004 report, "Manufacturing in America: A Comprehensive Strategy to Address the Challenges to U.S. Manufacturers," and 2009 report, "A Framework for Revitalizing American Manufacturing"; and (6) conduct a biennial survey of all persons with headquarters in the United States that maintain manufacturing facilities outside of the United States to identify the categories of products manufactured at such facilities and the number of manufacturing jobs located at such facilities.

Fan Freedom and Community Protection Act of 1995 - Provides that, in a case in which a professional sports league approves the relocation of a professional sports team from a community in which it has been located for at least ten years:  (1) the registered mark used to identify the team becomes the property of the league; (2) the league shall reserve such mark and any portion of it for use only by the community from which the team is relocating until the earlier of its expiration or the date on which the community informs the league that a team will not be using it; and (3) such mark may not be used by another team in the same league. 
Requires a team owner seeking to relocate the team from one community to another to provide notice of the proposed relocation to the local government for the community in which the team's stadium or arena is located, the owner or operator of such stadium or arena, and each team that is a member of the league for the professional sport concerned. 
Requires a league, within twelve months after submission of an investor's name to it, to grant to the investor a new expansion professional sports team franchise from the league at a fee no greater than 85 percent of the last expansion franchise fee charged by the league.  Applies this requirement to a league in any case in which:  (1) the league approves, on or after January 1, 1993, the relocation of a team from one community to another; (2) within three years after such relocation, the community in which the team was previously located submits to the league the name of an investor to be granted a new team franchise in such community; and (3) the investor demonstrates that he is financially able to purchase and support a team by placing the amount described above, in addition to an amount equal to the sale price of the last team sale approved by the league, in an escrow account.  Authorizes the league, in the case of a grant of a team franchise, to approve a resale of the team, but prohibits approval of a relocation of the team during the ten-year period beginning on the date of the grant of the expansion team franchise.  Makes this section inapplicable in the case of a community with a team if the team relocates within 60 miles of the community. 
Provides that it is not unlawful by reason of the antitrust laws for a professional sports league to enforce rules or agreements authorizing the membership of such league to decide whether a team that is a member of the league may relocate from one community to another.  Sets forth criteria for determining whether to approve or disapprove the relocation of a team from one community to another. 
Makes a league liable to the community in which the team was previously located for damages equal to three times the purchase price of the team if it violates the requirement of this Act by failing to grant a new team franchise.  Subjects such a league to suspension for one season of its antitrust exemption for pooling the broadcasting rights to games under specified Federal law. 
Provides that nothing in this Act shall:  (1) alter, determine, or otherwise affect the applicability or inapplicability of the antitrust laws, the labor laws, or any other provision of law to the wages, hours, or other terms and conditions of employment of players in any professional sports league, to any employment matter regarding players in any such league, or to any collective bargaining rights and privilege of any player union in any such league; (2) alter or affect the applicability or inapplicability of the antitrust laws or any applicable Federal or State law regarding broadcasting or telecasting to any agreement between any professional sports league or a team that is a member of the league and any person not affiliated with such a league for the broadcasting or telecasting of the games of such league or members of the league on any form of television; (3) affect any contract relating to the use of a stadium or arena between a team and the owner or operator of any stadium or arena or any other person; (4) exempt from the antitrust laws any agreement to fix the prices of admission to sports contests; (5) exempt from the antitrust laws any predatory practice or other conduct with respect to competing sports leagues which would otherwise be unlawful under the antitrust laws; or (6) alter, determine, or otherwise affect the applicability or inapplicability of the antitrust laws to any act, contract, agreement, rule, course of conduct, or other activity by, between, or among persons engaging in, conducting, or participating in professional football, basketball, hockey, or baseball.

MMA Territorial Equity for Low-Income Individuals Act of 2004 - Amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to provide for equitable treatment of residents of U.S. territories under the Medicare prescription drug transitional assistance program and the Medicare prescription drug program.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to request the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences to undertake a study that examines the access of Medicare beneficiaries residing in U.S. territories to prescription drugs during each of three periods: (1) before enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003; (2) during implementation of the discount card and transitional assistance program; and (3) beginning on January 1, 2006.

Accountability in Foster Care Act - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish an Advisory Panel on the Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System (AFCARS) to revise and monitor the data collection, analysis, and reporting system designed to be used to assess and improve state performance in operating child protection and child welfare programs pursuant to parts B and E of title IV of the Social Security Act.

Requires the Panel to: (1) make recommendations for changes in law or data collection procedures necessary to revise AFCARS; (2) monitor the implementation of these AFCARS improvements and propose improvements to other state performance measures related to provision of services to children and families; and (3) examine the feasibility of linking AFCARS and the National Child Abuse and Neglect Data Systems to understand longitudinal outcomes of children who may be in both systems.

Directs the Secretary to assess the extent to which a state is in compliance with a corrective action plan through use of alternative longitudinal measures as the state may select.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to require that certain programs under such Act include training of teachers, librarians, counselors, and other instructional and pupil services personnel in gender-equitable education methods, techniques, and practices. 
Requires innovative projects to include training of parents, teachers, and other instructional pupil services personnel regarding the impact of gender-role socialization on the educational needs of eligible children and the use of gender-equitable educational practices. 
Requires schoolwide projects to describe the methods used to ensure gender-equitable instruction in programs supported under such part. 
Requires parental involvement programs to include training in the impact of gender-role socialization on learning and on gender-equitable teaching practices. 
Requires local educational agencies (LEAs) that demonstrate a substantial difference in the participation or achievement of students by sex to include a description of planned efforts to implement gender equity training for chapter 1 personnel. 
Requires even start programs to include training on the impact of gender-role socialization on learning and gender-equitable education practices. 
Requires secondary school applications to describe the methods used to ensure gender-equitable instruction in the programs supported under such part. 
Requires grant awards to be made to LEAs that demonstrate the greatest degree of effort to promote gender equity and to incorporate gender-equitable instruction into the program. 
Requires local targeted assistance programs to include programs designed to promote gender equity in education by eliminating gender bias in instruction and educational materials, identifying and analyzing gender inequities in education, and implementing and evaluating educational policies and practices designed to achieve gender equity, including training in gender-equitable instruction for teachers and other educational personnel and community education programs to enhance the leadership and academic skills of girls and young women. 
Requires elementary and secondary education programs to include preservice, inservice, and retraining of teachers and other school personnel in gender-equitable instruction in mathematics and science. 
Requires national programs to demonstrate a commitment to achieving gender equity both in access to the computer-use program and in the teaching practices used in the program. 
Requires women's educational equity programs to include the development and implementation of model programs to provide career education programs and guidance to women. 
Requires gifted and talented programs to include training of personnel involved in such programs with respect to the impact of gender-role socialization on the educational needs of gifted and talented children and in gender-equitable education methods, techniques, and practices. 
Requires the Secretary's Fund for Innovation in Education to include training programs for teachers and instructional personnel on the impact of gender-role socialization on computer learning styles and gender-equitable methods, techniques, and practices for computer-based instruction.

Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 - Amends Federal law to provide that provisions terminating survivor annuities for Federal public safety officers who are killed in the line of duty shall not apply if: (1) the widow, widower, or former spouse was married for at least 30 years to the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based; or (2) the individual on whose service the survivor annuity is based was a Federal public safety officer who was killed in the line of duty.

Children First Act of 2010 - Amends part A (Temporary Assistance for Needy Families) (TANF) of title IV of the Social Security Act to exclude from the definition of "assistance" under TANF any funds provided under the TANF program that are used to provide child care for a family during a month under the state program.

Increases funding for child care for FY2011-FY2015.

Requires states to certify that procedures are in effect to ensure that any child care provider in the state that provides services funded through expenditures under TANF or with qualified state expenditures complies with all applicable state or local health and safety requirements as described in the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990.

Makes child care available to parents required to work, including other individuals with custody of children.

Subjects any funds provided under TANF that are expended for child care, whether or not transferred to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990, to the individual and case data reporting requirements imposed under that Act and need not be included in the report required by TANF for a fiscal quarter.

Cancer Survivorship Research and Quality of Life Act of 2002 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to require the Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to expand and coordinate NIH activities with respect to cancer survivorship research. Requires the Director to establish an Office on Survivorship within the National Cancer Institute through which such activities shall be implemented and directed. Requires the Director to appoint an Associate Director for Survivorship to coordinate and promote the programs in the Institute concerning cancer survivorship research.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services, acting through the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), to study the unique health challenges associated with cancer survivorship and carry out projects and interventions to improve the long-term health status of cancer survivors. Authorizes appropriations.Requires the Secretary, acting through the Director of CDC, and in consultation with the National Cancer Institute, to make grants to eligible entities for the purpose of enabling such entities to monitor and evaluate quality cancer care, develop information concerning quality cancer care, and monitor cancer survivorship.

Griffith Project Prepayment and Conveyance Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to convey to the Southern Nevada Water Authority all of the right, title, and interest of the United States in: (1) improvements and facilities of the Robert B. Griffith Water Project; (2) Acquired Lands that were acquired for the Project; and (3) interests reserved and developed as of the date of this Act for the Project in lands patented by the United States. 
Requires the Authority, from the effective date of conveyance of the Project, to have a right-of-way at no cost across all Public Land and Withdrawn Land on which the Project is situated and across any Federal lands as reasonably necessary for the operation, maintenance, replacement, and repair of the Project, including existing access routes.  Makes such rights-of-way valid for as long as they are needed for municipal water supply purposes and shall not require payment of rental or other fee. 
Directs the Secretary and the Authority to agree upon a description of the land subject to the rights-of-way established by this Act within twelve months after its effective date. 
Authorizes the Secretary and the Authority to modify Contract No. 7-07-30-W0004 and other contracts and land permits as necessary to conform to the provisions of this Act. 
Provides that if the Authority changes the use or operation of the Project, it shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations governing the changes at that time. 
Declares that, on conveyance of the Project under this Act, the Act of June 17, 1902, and all Acts amendatory or supplemental thereto shall not apply to the Project.  Provides that, effective upon transfer, the lands and facilities transferred pursuant to this Act shall not be entitled to receive any further Reclamation benefits pursuant to the Act of June 17, 1902, and all Acts amendatory or supplemental thereto attributable to their status as a Federal Reclamation Project, and the Project shall no longer be a Federal Reclamation Project. 
Provides that nothing in this Act shall: (1) transfer or affect Federal ownership, rights, or interests in Lake Mead National Recreation Area associated lands; (2) affect the authorities of the National Park Service to manage Lake Mead National Recreation Area including lands on which the Project is located consistent with specified legislation, regulation, or policy; or (3) affect the application of Federal reclamation law to water delivered to the Authority pursuant to any contract with the Secretary under section 5 of the Boulder Canyon Project Act. 
Provides that, effective upon conveyance of the Project and acquired interests in land under this Act, the United States shall not be liable for damages of any kind arising out of any act, omission, or occurrence based on its prior ownership of the conveyed property.

Trucking Industry Regulatory Reform Act of 1994 - Amends Federal transportation law to revise the national transportation policy to include:  (1) encouraging fair competition and reasonable rates for transportation by motor carriers of property; and (2) promoting Federal regulatory efficiency in the motor carrier transportation system and requiring fair and expeditious regulatory decisions when regulation is required. 
Authorizes the Secretary of Transportation to exempt from certain Federal transportation law provisions a motor carrier providing transportation of property other than household goods. 
Revises provisions regarding tariff filing to provide that:  (1) a motor contract carrier of property is not required to publish or file actual or minimum rates under such provisions; and (2) nothing in such provisions shall affect the application of the Negotiated Rates Act of 1993 to undercharge claims for transportation provided prior to the date of enactment of this Act. 
Revises provisions regarding motor common carrier licensing to require the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC), in making a finding on an applicant's ability to comply with specified requirements, to consider any evidence demonstrating that the applicant is unable to comply with such requirements.  Requires the ICC to find any applicant for authority to operate as a motor carrier unfit if the applicant does not meet the safety fitness requirements and to deny the application.  Authorizes a person to protest an application to provide transportation only on the ground that the applicant fails or will fail to comply with such requirements. 
Revises provisions regarding motor contract carrier licensing to require the ICC, in deciding whether to approve the application of a person for a permit as a motor contract carrier of property other than household goods, to consider any evidence demonstrating that the applicant is unable to comply with such requirements.  Requires the ICC to find any applicant for authority to operate as a motor carrier of property other than household goods unfit if the applicant does not meet the safety fitness requirements and to deny the application.  Authorizes a person to protest an application to provide transportation only on the ground that the applicant fails or will fail to comply with such requirements. 
Directs the Secretary of Transportation to study the feasibility of a merger of the operations and responsibilities of the Federal Maritime Commission and the ICC with respect to the cost savings that might be achieved by such a merger, the efficient allocation of resources, the elimination of unnecessary functions, and responsibility for regulatory functions. 
Requires the ICC to report to the Congress on all its regulatory responsibilities and make recommendations to the Congress concerning specific statutory functions that could be changed to enhance competition, safety, and efficiency in the motor carrier industry and to enhance efficiency in Government.

Directs the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission to investigate and make reasonable profit determinations for purposes of applying this Act.
Establishes in the Treasury the Windfall Oil Profits Trust Fund, consisting of amounts equivalent to the taxes received under this Act. Makes such amounts available for heating assistance for consumers and small businesses.

Return of Talent Act - Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish the Return of Talent Program to permit eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship in order to make a material contribution to that country if the country is engaged in post-conflict reconstruction activities, for a period not exceeding 24 months, unless an exception is granted. Makes eligible for such program an immigrant who: (1) has been lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence; (2) demonstrates an ability and willingness to make a material contribution to the post-conflict reconstruction in the alien's country of citizenship; and (3) is a citizen of a country in which U.S. Armed Forces are engaged, or have engaged in the ten years preceding such determination, in combat or peacekeeping operations, or is a citizen of a country where authorization for United Nations peacekeeping operations was initiated by the United Nations Security Council during the ten years preceding such determination.

Country of Origin Labeling Amendment Act of 2003 - Amends the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to require a retailer of certain meat and fish products, as well as perishable agricultural commodities and peanuts, to inform consumers at the final point of sale of the country of origin of such products. Exempts food service establishments from such requirement.

Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to carry out a program that provides for the self-certification by producers of the country of origin of covered commodities. Prohibits any third party audit or verification of producer compliance with country of origin labeling.

Older and Disabled Americans Criminal Protection Act of 1998 - Authorizes a shared housing referral service to request the Attorney General to conduct a search and exchange of records regarding any applicant for participation in a shared housing arrangement as a service provider resident by:  (1) submitting fingerprints and a written statement authorizing such search and exchange; and (2) making the submission within seven days after acquiring the information. 
Directs the Attorney General, pursuant to any such submission, to search the records of the Criminal Justice Information Services Division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for any criminal history records corresponding to the fingerprints or other positive identification submitted.  Directs the Attorney General to provide any corresponding information identified by the search to the appropriate State or local governmental agency authorized to receive such information. 
Permits the use of such information only by the shared housing referral service requesting it and only for determining the suitability of the applicant for participation in a shared housing arrangement as a service provider resident. 
Authorizes the Attorney General to charge a reasonable fee, not to exceed $50, to any shared housing referral service requesting a search and exchange of records to cover the costs of conducting the search and providing the records. 
Sets forth provisions regarding:  (1) organizational liability; and (2) criminal penalties.

Secure Federal File Sharing Act - Directs the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance on the use of peer-to-peer file sharing software to: (1) prohibit the download, installation, or use by government employees and contractors of open-network peer-to-peer file sharing software on all federal computers, computer systems, and networks, including those operated by contractors on behalf of the government, unless such software is approved in accordance with a specified procedure; and (2) address the download, installation, or use by government employees and contractors of such software on home or personal computers as it relates to telework and remotely accessing federal computers, computer systems, and networks, including those operated by contractors on the government's behalf.

Requires the Director to develop a procedure for receiving requests from agency heads or chief information officers for approval for use by government employees and contractors of specific open-network peer-to-peer file sharing software programs that are: (1) necessary for the day-to-day business operations of the agency; (2) instrumental in completing a particular task or project that directly supports the agency's overall mission; (3) necessary for use between, among, or within federal, state, or local government agencies in order to perform official agency business; or (4) necessary for use during the course of a law enforcement investigation.

Directs the Director to: (1) direct agencies to establish or update personal use policies consistent with the guidance issued under this Act; (2) direct agencies to require any contract awarded by the agency to include a requirement that the contractor comply with such guidance in the performance of the contract; (3) direct agencies to update their information technology security or ethics training policies to ensure that all employees, including those working for contractors on the government's behalf, are aware of the requirements of the guidance required by this Act and the consequences of engaging in prohibited conduct; and (4) direct agencies to ensure that proper security controls are in place to prevent, detect, and remove file sharing software that is prohibited by the guidance issued under this Act from all federal computers, computer systems, and networks, including those operated by contractors on the government's behalf.

Lorton Correctional Complex Closure Act - Directs the Administrator of General Services to transfer all real property and improvements comprising the Lorton Correctional Complex in Virginia (other than any such property retained by the District of Columbia under the Implementation Plan described in this Act) to the Administrator for disposal within six years after enactment of this Act. 
Prohibits establishment of a prison, penitentiary, jail, correctional institution, or related facility of the District of Columbia in Virginia without the approval of the Governor of Virginia. 
Requires any District of Columbia felon who is committed to the custody of the Attorney General for a term of imprisonment on or after enactment of this Act to be incarcerated in a facility designated by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons.  Requires any individual convicted of a felony in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia who is under the custody and control of the Director of the District of Columbia Department of Corrections as of enactment of this Act to be transferred to the control of the Director of the Bureau of Prisons not later than five years after enactment of this Act. 
Directs the Administrator to submit to Congress an Implementation Plan for the closure of the Lorton Correctional Complex which shall identify actions with respect to:  (1) the future use of the land on which the Complex is located; (2) the need to address the impact of such future uses on local and regional transportation resources; (3) the transfer of real property and improvements thereon to Federal agencies (including the Bureau of Prisons), the Government of the District of Columbia, or any other governmental entity; (4) the disposal of real property or improvements thereon; and (5) changes in law or regulation necessary to effect the purposes of this Act and the closure of the Lorton Correctional Complex. 
Establishes the Commission on Closure of the Lorton Correctional Complex.

Title II: Delivery of Services Regarding Lupus
 - Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to provide for projects for the establishment, operation, and coordination of effective and cost-efficient systems for the delivery of essential services to individuals with lupus and their families. Authorizes appropriations.

Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to direct the Secretary of Education to award grants to State educational agencies (SEAs) to assist local educational agencies (LEAs) in providing signing bonuses to middle or secondary school math or science teachers who agree to teach in a high-need area during the four-year period that begins on the date on which the teacher is hired. Requires such bonus recipients to have obtained licensing or certification to teach other than temporary or emergency licensing or certification, and to have an academic major or minor or a work-related concentration in the academic subject in which they intend to teach.Requires SEAs to establish peer review boards to review criteria for providing such bonuses.Directs the Secretary to award grants to SEAs to assist LEAs in providing mastery bonuses to supplement the salaries of middle or secondary school math or science teachers who pass an advanced competency exam in math and science that is approved by the National Academy of Sciences and agree to teach during the five-year period that begins during or after the date on which the SEA determines that the teacher has passed the advanced competency exam. Requires such bonus recipients to have obtained licensing or certification to teach other than temporary or emergency licensing or certification, and to have an academic or work-related concentration in the academic subject in which they intend to teach.Authorizes the Secretary to award competitive matching grants to eligible LEAs to develop and implement mentor teacher programs to enable experienced teachers to train, support, and mentor novice teachers.

Security Enhancement and Jobs Act of 2011 - Amends federal transportation law to revise the process for approving or denying an airport operator's application to participate in the Airport Security Screening Opt-Out Program.

Requires the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to approve or deny such applications within 120 days after receipt. Requires the Secretary to provide a written report to an airport operator that denies an application, including: (1) the findings that served as the basis for the denial; (2) the results of any cost or security analysis conducted in considering the application; and (3) recommendations on how the airport operator can address the reasons for the denial.

Requires the Secretary to provide a list of qualified private screening companies to an airport operator within 60 days after approval of an application, except in cases where the airport operator is competing to provide screening services at the airport.

Directs the Secretary to reconsider any application for the screening of passengers and property that was submitted by the operator of an airport pursuant to the opt-out program and was pending for final decision by the Secretary as of January 1, 2011, and has not been approved by the Secretary on or before enactment of this Act.

Drive Away From Ethanol Welfare Act of 1996 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to deny a tax credit for alcohol used to produce ether. 
Limits the alcohol eligible for such credit to alcohol produced by a still or other distilling apparatus placed in service before December 31, 1996.  Limits future credit to average historical production. 
Reduces the credit for ethanol by reason of carbon dioxide byproduct benefit. 
Repeals the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced other than from petroleum or natural gas and on ethanol fuel produced from natural gas. 
Treats fuel alcohol as taxable fuel. 
Increases the small ethanol producer credit. 
Imposes a floor stocks tax on fuel alcohol held on January 1, 1997.

Unemployment Assistance Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude from gross income any qualified unemployment distribution from a tax-favored account. Defines "qualified unemployment distribution" as any distribution from an eligible retirement plan, health savings account, Roth IRA, or qualified tuition program made during a period of unemployment which does not exceed two years and used to pay qualified living expenses, qualified health care expenses, or qualified education or job training expenses.

Allows any individual who receives a qualified unemployment distribution to make one or more contributions in an aggregate amount not to exceed the amount of such distribution to a tax-favored account of which such individual is a beneficiary and to which a rollover contribution could be made under specified provisions.

Telephone Call Privacy Act of 1999 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to modify requirements relating to use and disclosure of customer proprietary network information. 
Authorizes a telecommunications carrier that receives or obtains such information by virtue of its provision of a telecommunications service to use, disclose, or permit access to such information that identifies a customer: (1) in the provision of the telecommunications service from which such information is derived and services necessary to, or used in, the provision of such service; and (2) in the case of the use of such information by the carrier for the provision of another of its products or services to the customer, only if the carrier provides the customer with a clear and conspicuous notice meeting specified requirements, permits the customer to review such information for accuracy, and does not receive from the customer within 15 days after the date of the notice disapproving the use of such information for the provision of such product or service. 
Authorizes the use, disclosure, or access of or to such information by another party only if the telecommunications carrier that originally receives or obtains such information meets the requirements set forth above with respect to such information and receives from the customer written notice approving the use, disclosure, or access of or to such information for the provision of the product or service to the customer. 
Requires a telecommunications carrier, notwithstanding previous approval of the use, disclosure, or access of or to information for a purpose under this Act, upon receipt from a customer of written notice of the customer's disapproval of the use, disclosure, or access of or to information for such purpose, to terminate the use, disclosure, or access of or to such information for such purpose. 
Sets forth notice elements. 
Authorizes a person that receives or obtains consumer proprietary network information to disclose such information: (1) pursuant to the standards and procedures established in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure or comparable rules of other courts or administrative agencies, in connection with litigation or proceedings to which an individual who is the subject of the information is a party and in which the individual has placed the use, disclosure, or access to such information at issue; (2) to a court, and to others ordered by the court, if in response to a court order issued in accordance with this Act; or (3) to an investigative or law enforcement officer pursuant to a warrant issued under the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, an equivalent State warrant, or a grand jury subpoena, or a court order issued in accordance with this Act. 
Sets forth requirements for court orders.

Cyber Scholarship Opportunities Act of 2017 This bill amends the Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 to expand the federal CyberCorps: Scholarship-for-Service program. The program provides scholarships to students pursuing a degree in cybersecurity who agree to work for a period of time in a critical infrastructure sector or at an institution of higher education (IHE) or local educational agency (LEA) teaching cybersecurity skills. The bill expands the program to include students pursuing an associate's degree in a cybersecurity field without the intent of transferring to a bachelor's degree program and either have a bachelor's degree already or are veterans of the Armed Forces. The bill also allows scholarship recipients who are pursuing a doctoral or master's degree to work at an IHE or LEA teaching cybersecurity skills for a period equal to the length of the scholarship following receipt of such degree. The National Science Foundation (NSF) must evaluate and make public information on the success of recruiting individuals for scholarships under this bill and on hiring and retaining those individuals in the public sector workforce, including on placement rates, where students are placed, student salary ranges for students not released from obligations under this bill, how long after graduation they are placed, how long they stay in the positions they enter upon graduation, how many students are released from obligations, what (if any) remedial training needs are required, and the number of determinations permitting scholarship recipients to fulfill their obligations at an IHE or LEA or in a critical infrastructure position and the reason for each such determination. The NSF must: (1) work with the Office of Personnel Management to establish an online resource center for the CyberCorps community that consolidates or eliminates other relevant websites; (2) carry out a program to grow and improve cybersecurity education at the kindergarten through grade 12 level; and (3) assess the potential benefits and feasibility of granting scholarship awards to students who do not possess a bachelor's degree to pursue an associate's degree or an industry-recognized credential in a cybersecurity field and how scholarship recipients with an agreement to work at an IHE or LEA are supporting the cyber workforce pipeline. The NSF may grant exceptions to students for fulfilling post-award employment obligations under this bill who agree to work in a critical infrastructure mission at a federal government corporation or a state, local, or tribal government-affiliated asset, system, or network that is considered to be part of a critical infrastructure sector as described in Presidential Policy Directive-21, issued February 12, 2013, or any successor. The NSF may also develop a pilot program to enhance critical infrastructure protection training for students pursuing careers in cybersecurity.

Securities and Exchange Commission Reserve Fund This bill prohibits the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) from exceeding $48 million in deposits in the SEC Reserve Fund for FY2018.  Title I: TRID Improvement  This bill amends the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act of 1974 to revise mortgage disclosure requirements.  Title II: Protection of Source Code  The bill amends the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the Investment Company Act of 1940, and the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 to prohibit the SEC from compelling a person to produce or furnish algorithmic trading source code or similar intellectual property that forms the basis for design of the algorithmic trading source code, unless the SEC first issues a subpoena.  Title III: Fostering Innovation  The bill amends the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to exempt from certain internal control reporting requirements an issuer that:   ceased to be an emerging growth company on the last day of the fiscal year following the fifth anniversary of its first sale of common equity securities pursuant to an effective registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933;  had average annual gross revenues of less than $50 million as of its most recently completed fiscal year; and  is not a large accelerated filer.   An issuer ceases to be eligible for such exemption at the earliest of:   the last day of the fiscal year following the tenth anniversary of its first sale of common equity securities pursuant to an effective registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933;  the last day of the fiscal year during which its average annual gross revenues exceed $50 million; or  the date on which it becomes a large accelerated filer.   Title IV: National Securities Exchange Regulatory Parity  The bill amends the Securities Act of 1933 to repeal the requirement that a security designated as qualified for trading in the national market system must have listing standards that are substantially similar to the listing standards applicable to securities listed on a national securities exchange.  Title V: Eliminating Barriers to Jobs for Loan Originators  The bill amends the S.A.F.E. Mortgage Licensing Act of 2008 to grant temporary authority to loan originators who are registered in the Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry to act as loan originators in an application state if they meet specified requirements.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to terminate after 1997 the tax credit for alcohol used as a fuel. 
Denies such credit for alcohol used to produce ether. 
Repeals the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced other than from petroleum or natural gas and on ethanol fuel produced from natural gas. 
Treats fuel alcohol as taxable fuel. 
Imposes a floor stocks tax on fuel alcohol held on January 1, 1998.

Health Insurance Rate Review Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act, as amended by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), to authorize states to impose requirements on health insurance issuers that are more protective of consumers than those required under PPACA.

Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to determine which states will undertake corrective actions to ensure that any excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates are corrected prior to implementation, or as soon as possible thereafter. Requires such corrective actions to include mechanisms such as: (1) denying rates; (2) modifying rates; or (3) requiring rebates to consumers.

Applies this Act to grandfathered plans.

Land Management Agency Housing Improvement Act of 1994 - Authorizes the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to:  (1) make employee housing available on or off public lands; and (2) rent or lease such housing to employees at a reasonable value. 
Requires the Secretaries to provide such housing in accordance with specified Federal law, except that for purposes of this Act:  (1) "availability of quarters" means the existence within 30 miles of the employee's duty station of well-constructed and maintained housing suitable to the individual and family needs of the employee, for which the rental rate as a percentage of the employee's annual gross income does not exceed the most recent Census Bureau American Housing Survey median monthly housing cost for renters inclusive of utilities, as a percentage of current income, whether paid as part of rent or paid directly to a third party; (2) "contract" includes Build-to-Lease, Rental Guarantee, Joint Development, or other lease agreements entered into by the Secretary on or off public lands for sub-leasing to Departmental employees; and (3) "reasonable value" means the base rental rate comparable to private rental rates for comparable housing facilities and associated amenities, provided that the base rental rate as a percentage of the employee's annual gross income shall not exceed the most recent American Housing Survey median monthly housing cost for renters inclusive of utilities, as a percentage of current income, whether paid as part of rent or paid directly to a third party. 
Authorizes the Secretaries to enter into contracts and agreements with public and private entities to provide employee housing on or off public lands. 
Authorizes the Secretaries to enter into cooperative agreements or joint ventures with local governmental and private entities, either on or off public lands, to provide appropriate and necessary utility and other infrastructure facilities in support of employee housing facilities provided under this Act. 
Directs the Secretaries to conduct a survey of the availability of quarters at field units under each Secretary's jurisdiction at least every five years.  Authorizes the Secretaries to provide suitable quarters if such survey indicates that government owned or suitable privately owned quarters are not available for the personnel assigned to a specific duty station. 
Authorizes the Secretaries to determine that secondary quarters for employees who are permanently duty stationed at remote locations and are regularly required to relocate for temporary periods are necessary for the effective administration of an area under the jurisdiction of the respective agency.  Authorizes such secondary quarters to be made available to employees, either on or off public lands, in accordance with the provisions of this Act.  Requires rental rates for such secondary facilities to be established so that the aggregate rental rate paid by an employee for both primary and secondary quarters as a percentage of the employee's annual gross income shall not exceed the Census Bureau American Housing Survey median monthly housing cost for renters inclusive of utilities as a percentage of current income, whether paid as part of rent or paid directly to a third party. 
Directs the Secretaries to survey all existing Government-owned employee housing facilities under their jurisdictions to assess the physical condition of such housing and the suitability of such housing for the effective prosecution of the agency mission.  Directs the Secretaries to develop an agency-wide priority listing, by structure, identifying those units in greatest need of repair, rehabilitation, replacement, or initial construction, as appropriate.  Requires the survey and priority listing study to be transmitted to specified congressional committees. 
Authorizes appropriations.

Authorizes the Chief of the National Guard Bureau to establish and operate up to five National Guard counterdrug schools for the provision by the National Guard of training in drug interdiction and counter-drug activities, and drug demand reduction activities, to personnel of Federal agencies, State and local law enforcement agencies, community-based organizations engaged in such activities, and other non-Federal governmental and private entities and organizations engaged in such activities. Specifies such schools as: (1) the National Interagency Civil-Military Institute, San Luis Obispo, California; (2) the Multi-Jurisdictional Counterdrug Task Force Training, St. Petersburg, Florida; (3) the Midwest Counterdrug Training Center, to be established in Johnston, Iowa; (4) the Regional Counterdrug Training Academy, Meridian, Mississippi; and (5) the Northeast Regional Counterdrug Training Center, Fort Indiantown Gap, Pennsylvania. Authorizes the use of National Guard personnel ordered to perform full-time National Guard duty to provide such training at a school located in a State whose drug interdiction and counter-drug activities plan has been submitted to the Secretary of Defense. Directs the Secretary to report annually to Congress on the activities of the schools. Authorizes appropriations for FY 2002.
